entry.name: aaapolicy_kglobalconfig_help_1
entry.text: An AAA policy establishes the configuration to support the authentication and authorization of users requesting resources from the back-end servers. An AAA policy consists of the following components. Identity extraction One of many methods that discovers which identity is asserted in the service request. This processing phase answers the question, "What is your name?" Authentication One of many methods that authenticates the asserted identity. Methods include communication with external authorities, such as an LDAP server. The identity is accepted as authentic or rejected. When authenticated successfully, the identity is used as a credential. Resource extraction One of many methods that discovers which resource service is requested (such as query an account or perform an update) This processing phase answers the question, "What do you want to do?" Credential mapping While an identity can be authenticated by one authority as valid, this identity or credential might not be known to the authority that authorizes the requested resource. This processing phase allows the mapping of credentials from one form to another for interoperability between systems. Resource mapping While a resource can be identified from the service request, this resource name might not be known to the authority that authorizes use of the requested resource. This processing phase allows the mapping of resource names from one form to another for interoperability between systems. Authorization The combination of the authenticated and possibly remapped credential with the requested and possibly remapped resource are submitted to an authority for authorization. That authority could reside elsewhere on the network. The request for service is accepted or rejected. Postprocessing Additional processing to perform after authorization, such as the generation of a WS-Trust token or SAML assertion.

entry.name: aaapolicy_kglobalconfig_descr_1
entry.text: AAA Policy

entry.name: saml2_metadata_aaapolicy_help_31
entry.text: The file that contains metadata used in SAML 2.0 protocol message exchanges. This metadata is used to identify Identity Provider endpoints and certificates needed to secure SAML 2.0 message exchanges. This file must have a <md:EntitiesDescriptor> top-level element, with one or more <EntityDescriptor> child elements (one per Identity Provider).

entry.text: File that contains SAML 2.0 metadata.

entry.name: dos_valve_aaapolicy_help_32
entry.text: Set the maximum times of same XML processing that AAA policy allows for each user request. The AAA policy assumes that more than this value of the same processing is caused by potential DoS flooding attacks. The AAA policy limits the number of times to process the same request. These processes can include encryption, decryption, message signing, or signature verification. Currently, only identity extraction with subject DN from certificate in message signature and authorization with signer certificate for digitally signed messages support this setting. These methods designate the number of signatures or signing reference URIs. The default value is 3. This value means that the AAA policy processes only the first 3 signature and each signature can contain up to 3 reference URIs. Additional signatures or reference URIs are ignored.

entry.name: dos_valve_aaapolicy_descr_32
entry.text: Value to filter out denial-of-service (DoS) attacks.

entry.name: enforce_actor_role_aaapolicy_help_34
entry.text: Most of the times a WS-Security message has an S11:actor or S12:role attribute for its wsse:Security header, we can enforce those attributes when AAA tries to utilize wsse:Security header, for example, there should be only one wsse:Security element having same actor/role, and AAA should only process the wsse:Security header for the designated Actor/Role Identifier. This setting takes effect for all AAA steps except postprocessing, which generally generate new message for next SOAP node. The default value for this setting is 'on', enabling SOAP actor/role enforcement.

entry.name: enforce_actor_role_aaapolicy_descr_34
entry.text: Enforce the S11::actor or S12:role when the message is a WS-Security message.

entry.name: actor_role_id_aaapolicy_help_35
entry.text: If specified, the AAA policy acts as the assumed actor or role when it consumes the wsse:Security headers. This setting takes effect only when the AAA policy tries to process the incoming WS-Security message before making an authorization decision. Postprocessing does not use this setting. Postprocessing uses its own setting in generating WS-Security messages for the next SOAP node. Some well-known values are as follows: http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/actor/next Every one, including the intermediary and ultimate receiver, receives the message should be able to processing the Security header. http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope/role/none No one should process the Security Header. http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope/role/next Every one, including the intermediary and ultimate receiver, receives the message should be able to processing the Security header. http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope/role/ultimateReceiver The message ultimate receiver can process the Security header. This is the default value if such setting is not configured. <blank or empty string> The empty string "" (without quotes) indicates that no "actor/role" identifier is configured. if there is no actor/role setting configured, the ultimateReceiver is assumed when processing the message, and no actor/role attribute will be added when generating the WS-Security header. There should not be more than one Security headers omitting the actor/role identifier. USE_MESSAGE_BASE_URI The value "USE_MESSAGE_BASE_URI" without quotes indicates that the actor/role identifier will be the base URL of the message, if the SOAP message is transported using HTTP, the base URI is the Request-URI of the http request. any other customized string You can input any string to identify the actor or role of the Security header. The default value is a blank value.

entry.name: actor_role_id_aaapolicy_descr_35
entry.text: The assumed S11:actor or S12:role identifier that the AAA policy act as.

entry.name: dyn_config_aaapolicy_help_38
entry.text: Specifies how to obtain the AAA policy configuration dynamically. Dynamic configuration enables users to configure AAA policy at run time. When enabled, the configuration of AAA is determined dynamically based on the template AAA policy and the parameters that the dynamic configuration custom URL returns.

entry.name: dyn_config_aaapolicy_descr_38
entry.text: How to obtain the AAA policy configuration dynamically

entry.name: external_aaa_template_aaapolicy_help_39
entry.text: Specifies an external AAA policy to use as the template. When specified, it overwrites the configuration of the current AAA policy.

entry.name: external_aaa_template_aaapolicy_descr_39
entry.text: The external AAA policy to use as the template

entry.name: dyn_config_custom_url_aaapolicy_help_40
entry.text: Specifies the location of the custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file where to obtain the AAA policy configuration. The obtained configuration overwrites the configuration that is defined in the template AAA policy. In the custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file, it is recommended that you modify only those properties to be dynamically overwritten in the template AAA policy. See the ModifyAAAPolicy element in the store:///xml-mgmt.xsd schema to construct a schema-compliant AAA configuration. For the nodeset that the custom URL is expected to return and a sample stylesheet, see the topic in IBM Knowledge Center.

entry.name: dyn_config_custom_url_aaapolicy_descr_40
entry.text: The location of the custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file

entry.name: visible_domain_domain_help_45
entry.text: Which application domains have their local: directory visible to this application domain. References to visible application domains are explicit, not bidirectional. If application domain domainB is made visible to application domain domainA , the following conditions apply. Application domain domainA has read-only access to the local: directory of application domain domainB . Application domain domainB cannot see application domain domainA . In this case, you cannot make application domain domainA visible to application domain domainB . References to visible application domains cannot be circular.

entry.name: visible_domain_domain_descr_45
entry.text: Manage which application domains have their local: directory visible to this application domain.

entry.name: ssh_au_method_rbmsettings_help_66
entry.text: The method to authenticate SSH users. When no method, the user is prompted for both username and password. When password, the user is prompted for the password. For this method, the username must be part of the invocation. With the ssh command, the invocation is in the ssh username@host format. When user certificate, the user is not prompted for input. The connection is successful when the invocation provides a signed SSH user certificate that is verified by the CA public key file in the cert: directory. With the ssh command, the invocation must include the -i file parameter. When both certificate and password, processing attempts to first authenticate with the provided signed SSH user certificate. If unsuccessful, prompts for the password.

entry.name: ssh_au_method_rbmsettings_descr_66
entry.text: Set the method to authenticate SSH users.

entry.name: ssh_ca_pubkey_file_rbmsettings_help_67
entry.text: The certificate authority (CA) public key file in the cert: directory for SSH authentication with SSH user certificates. This public key file contains the public key for one or more certificate authorities.

entry.name: ssh_ca_pubkey_file_rbmsettings_descr_67
entry.text: Specify the CA public key file for SSH authentication.

entry.text: Set the local NSS client that defines how to connect to the NSS server for SAF communication.

entry.name: au_force_dn_ldap_order_rbmsettings_help_69
entry.text: Whether to convert the extracted DN to LDAP format. This property is essential when the extracted DN from a TLS certificate is in X.500 format. This format arranges the RDNs of the DNs from left to right with forward slashes as separators; for example, C=US/O=My Organization/CN=Fred . When you retrieve the group name with an LDAP search, the authenticated DN must be in LDAP format. This format arranges the RDNs of the DNs from right to left with commas as separators; for example, CN=Fred, O=My Organization, C=US .

entry.name: au_force_dn_ldap_order_rbmsettings_descr_69
entry.text: Indicate whether to convert the extracted DN to LDAP format.

entry.name: cli_timeout_rbmsettings_help_70
entry.text: The time after which to invalidate idle CLI sessions. When invalidated, requires re-authentication. Enter a value in the range 0 - 65535. A value of 0 disables the timer. The default value depends on common criteria mode. When common criteria is enabled, the default value is 900. When common criteria is disabled, the default value is 0.

entry.name: cli_timeout_rbmsettings_descr_70
entry.text: Enter the time after which to invalidate idle CLI sessions.

entry.name: max_login_failure_rbmsettings_help_71
entry.text: The number of failed login attempts to allow before account lockout. Enter a value in the range of 0 - 64, where 0 disables account lockout. The default value depends on common criteria mode. When common criteria is enabled, the default value is 3. When common criteria is disabled, the default value is 0.

entry.name: max_login_failure_rbmsettings_descr_71
entry.text: Enter the number of failed login attempts to allow before account lockout.

entry.name: lockout_duration_rbmsettings_help_72
entry.text: The duration to lock out local user accounts after the maximum number of failed login attempts is exceeded. Instead of locking out accounts for a specific duration, the account can be locked out until re-enabled by a privileged user. Enter a value in the range 0 - 1000, where 0 locks out accounts until reset. The default value depends on common criteria mode. When common criteria is enabled, the default value is 0. When common criteria is disabled, the default value is 1. #b#Note:#/b# The duration applies to all local accounts, including the admin user account. The only difference is that the admin user account cannot be locked out until reset. When the duration is 0, the admin user account is locked out for 120 minutes or until re-enabled by a privileged user.

entry.name: lockout_duration_rbmsettings_descr_72
entry.text: Enter the duration to lock out local user accounts after the maximum number of failed login attempts is exceeded.

entry.name: mc_force_dn_ldap_order_rbmsettings_help_73
entry.text: Whether to convert the extracted DN to LDAP format. This property is essential when the extracted DN from a TLS certificate is in X.500 format. This format arranges the RDNs of the DNs from left to right with forward slashes as separators; for example, C=US/O=My Organization/CN=Fred . When you retrieve the group name with an LDAP search, the authenticated DN must be in LDAP format. This format arranges the RDNs of the DNs from right to left with commas as separators; for example, CN=Fred, O=My Organization, C=US .

entry.name: mc_force_dn_ldap_order_rbmsettings_descr_73
entry.text: Indicate whether to convert the extracted DN to LDAP format.

entry.name: password_hash_algorithm_rbmsettings_help_74
entry.text: The hash algorithm to apply to passwords before they are stored. The hash algorithm affects firmware downgrade and cryptographic modes in the following ways. For firmware downgrade, sha256crypt is not supported in releases earlier than 6.0.1.0. For cryptographic modes, like FIPS 140-2 Level 1, md5crypt is not supported in FIPS mode.

entry.name: password_hash_algorithm_rbmsettings_descr_74
entry.text: Set the hash algorithm to apply to passwords.

entry.text: Whether to support basic users in the client

entry.text: Specify the attribute that identifies the basic user in the LDAP user entry. The default value is uid.

entry.text: The attribute that identifies the basic user in the LDAP user entry

entry.name: user_no_duplicates_tam_help_85
entry.text: Control whether to allow duplicate principals. When enabled, the search for basic users covers all suffixes to ensure that no users with the same name are found. If duplicate principals are found in this client, the system returns an error. When disabled, the search for basic users ignores possible duplicates. By default, duplicate principals are not allowed.

entry.name: user_no_duplicates_tam_descr_85
entry.text: Whether to allow duplicate principals

entry.name: user_search_suffixes_tam_help_86
entry.text: Specify the ordered list of LDAP suffixes to be searched for principals. When specified and suffix optimization is disabled, the suffixes are searched in entry order. If suffix optimization is enabled, this order is overridden by the suffix optimization order. If you do not specify any suffixes, the system searches all available suffixes.

entry.name: user_search_suffixes_tam_descr_86
entry.text: The LDAP suffixes to be searched for principals

entry.name: user_suffix_optimiser_tam_help_87
entry.text: Control whether to search the suffixes in an optimized order. When enabled and uplicate principals are allowed, the suffixes are searched in an optimized order based on hit count, with the most hit of the suffix at the head of the search suffix list. This can help reduce the number of suffixes searched. If duplicate principals are not allowed, the suffix optimization setting is disregarded and all suffixes are searched to check for duplicates. When disabled, the search order is provided by the order that is defined by the search suffixes property.

entry.name: user_suffix_optimiser_tam_descr_87
entry.text: Whether to search the suffixes in an optimized order

entry.name: federated_directory_tam_help_88
entry.text: Specify a list of federated directories. Each entry describes a unique set of LDAP suffixes and LDAP server. Federated directories define all the suffixes that can be searched for user identities.

entry.name: federated_directory_tam_descr_88
entry.text: List of LDAP federated directories

entry.name: auto_retry_tam_help_89
entry.text: Select whether to attempt starting the Access Manager client after an initial failure. The DataPower Gateway automatically attempts to start the client after a critical error. This property controls the behavior after the initial attempt to restart. When enabled, the DataPower Gateway attempts to start the client with the defined configuration. When disabled, the client is marked as down . The default behavior is to not attempt to start the client after an initial failure.

entry.name: auto_retry_tam_descr_89
entry.text: Whether to attempt starting the client after an initial failure

entry.name: retry_interval_tam_help_90
entry.text: Enter the number of seconds to wait between attempts to start the Access Manager client. Enter a value in the range 1 - 65535. The default value is 180.

entry.name: retry_interval_tam_descr_90
entry.text: Interval to wait between attempts to start the client.

entry.name: retry_attempts_tam_help_91
entry.text: Enter the number of attempts to perform for the Access Manager client. After performing these attempts and the client did not start, each additional attempt waits the number of seconds defined by the long interval. Enter a value in the range 0 - 65535. A value of 0 disables the long interval. The default value is 3.

entry.name: retry_attempts_tam_descr_91
entry.text: Number of attempts before using the long attempt interval.

entry.name: long_retry_interval_tam_help_92
entry.text: Specifies the number of seconds to wait after reaching the number of retry attempts. Enter a value in the range 1 - 65535. The default value is 900.

entry.name: long_retry_interval_tam_descr_92
entry.text: Long attempt interval before trying the failed connection again

entry.name: access_policy_accessprofile_help_103
entry.text: The set of access policies that define the access privileges for the profile. When more than one policy applies to a resource, the most specific policy is used. To create access policies, enter a correctly formatted policy statement. A policy statement takes the address / domain / resource ?Access= privileges & field = value general format. address The complete local IP address or host alias. Use an asterisk (*) to designate any address. domain The complete name of the application domain. Use an asterisk (*) to designate any application domain. resource The complete value for the resource type. Use an asterisk (*) to designate any resource type. privileges The privileges to apply. Separate permissions with the plus sign (+). For example, a+d+x+r+w defines add, delete, execute, read, and write privileges. field The complete name of a specific property in the configuration; for example, Name . value The PCRE match expression for the property value; For example, foo(.*)bar .

entry.name: access_policy_accessprofile_descr_103
entry.text: Manage the set of access policies that define the access privileges for the profile.

entry.name: amqp_broker_kglobalconfig_help_104
entry.text: In AMQP, distributed source and target termini are managed by a broker. The broker provides messaging services for communicating applications by periodically monitoring and polling termini. The broker ensures that sent messages are directed to the correct target terminus or are routed to another server. The AMQP broker configuration on the DataPower Gateway corresponds to an AMQP broker that is running on another host in the network. The configured properties enable communication between the DataPower Gateway and the remote AMQP broker.

entry.name: amqp_broker_kglobalconfig_descr_104
entry.text: AMQP Broker

entry.name: maximum_frame_size_amqpbroker_help_115
entry.text: Specify the maximum frame size in bytes to allow. Frames Frames that are larger are rejected. When rejected, the connection is closed. Enter a value in the range 512 - 104857600. The default value is 104857600.

entry.name: maximum_frame_size_amqpbroker_descr_115
entry.text: Maximum frame size to allow

entry.name: maximum_message_size_amqpbroker_help_116
entry.text: Specify the maximum message size in bytes to allow. Enter a value in the range 0 - 104857600. The default value is 0, which indicates unlimited.

entry.name: maximum_message_size_amqpbroker_descr_116
entry.text: Maximum message size to allow

entry.name: auto_retry_amqpbroker_help_117
entry.text: Indicates whether to enable the automatic retry procedure after an AMQP connection failure. By default, the automatic retry behavior is enabled. This setting does not affect attempts over an established connection.

entry.name: auto_retry_amqpbroker_descr_117
entry.text: Whether to enable the automatic retry procedure after an AMQP connection failure

entry.name: retry_interval_amqpbroker_help_118
entry.text: Specify the interval in seconds to wait before attempting to reestablish a failed connection. After the number of attempts is reached, attempts to reestablish a failed connection use the interval that is defined by the long retry interval. Enter a value in the range 1 - 65535. The default value is 10. This setting does not affect attempts over an established connection.

entry.name: retry_interval_amqpbroker_descr_118
entry.text: Interval to wait before attempting to reestablish a failed connection

entry.name: retry_attempts_amqpbroker_help_119
entry.text: Specify the number of attempts for a failed connection to the remote AMQP server. After the number of attempts is reached, the long retry interval is used. Enter a value in the range 0 - 65535. The default value is 6. The special value of 0 disables the long interval, where the retry interval is used forever.

entry.name: retry_attempts_amqpbroker_descr_119
entry.text: Number of attempts for a failed connection to the remote server

entry.name: long_retry_interval_amqpbroker_help_120
entry.text: Specify the interval in seconds to use after the number of attempts is reached to attempt to reestablish a failed connection. Enter a value in the range 1 - 65535. The default value is 600. This setting does not affect attempts over an established connection.

entry.name: long_retry_interval_amqpbroker_descr_120
entry.text: Interval to use after the number of attempts is reached to attempt to reestablish a failed connection

entry.name: reporting_interval_amqpbroker_help_121

entry.name: analytics_endpoint_kglobalconfig_help_123
entry.text: Configure an analytics endpoint to buffer API event data and offload the collected data as a bulk activity log to a remote server. When offloaded, you can use this data for display and analysis.

entry.name: analytics_endpoint_kglobalconfig_descr_123
entry.text: Analytics Endpoint

entry.name: admin_state_analyticsendpoint_help_124
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_analyticsendpoint_descr_124
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_analyticsendpoint_descr_125
entry.text: Descriptive summary for the Gateway Peering Manager

entry.name: analytics_server_url_analyticsendpoint_help_126
entry.text: Specifies the URL to offload the collected API event data. This URL can start with http or https for an Elasticsearch server or start with dpkafka for a Kafka server For an Elasticsearch server, specify the full URL to the endpoint starting with the http or https protocol identifier. With HTTPS, you must assign a TLS client profile. For a Kafka server, specify only the name of the existing Kafka cluster configuration after the dpkafka protocol identifier. To complete the complete the URL, you must specify which request topic to offload analytics data.

entry.name: analytics_server_url_analyticsendpoint_descr_126
entry.text: URL to offload the collected API event data

entry.name: ssl_client_analyticsendpoint_help_127
entry.text: Specifies the TLS client profile to secure connections with the analytics endpoint. With HTTPS, you must assign a TLS client profile. This property is meaningful only when HTTPS is used to connect to the analytics endpoint.

entry.name: ssl_client_analyticsendpoint_descr_127
entry.text: TLS client profile to secure connections

entry.name: request_topic_analyticsendpoint_help_128
entry.text: Specifies the name of the Kafka request topic to offload analytics data. This property is meaningful only when Kafka is the analytics endpoint.

entry.name: request_topic_analyticsendpoint_descr_128
entry.text: Name of the Kafka request topic to offload analytics data

entry.name: max_records_analyticsendpoint_help_129
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of records that can be buffered. The collected analytics data is offloaded when 10%% of this value set or the defined interval is reached. The value must be a power of 2. Enter a value in the range 256 - 65536. The default value is 1024.

entry.name: max_records_analyticsendpoint_descr_129
entry.text: Maximum number of records that can be buffered

entry.name: max_record_size_analyticsendpoint_help_130
entry.text: Specifies the maximum size of each record in kilobytes. Enter a value in the range 4 - 1024. The default value is 512.

entry.name: max_record_size_analyticsendpoint_descr_130
entry.text: Maximum size of each record

entry.name: max_delivery_size_analyticsendpoint_help_131
entry.text: Specifies the maximum memory for each delivery through the analytics endpoint in megabytes. Enter a value in the range 1 - 1024. The default value is 512.

entry.name: max_delivery_size_analyticsendpoint_descr_131
entry.text: Maximum size for each delivery

entry.name: index_root_analyticsendpoint_help_132
entry.text: Specifies the Static base name of the indexes to use to store the offloaded data. When the first event is offloaded to Elasticsearch, an index is created with a name that is constructed from the static index root and suffix.

entry.name: index_root_analyticsendpoint_descr_132
entry.text: Static base name of the indexes

entry.name: index_suffix_analyticsendpoint_help_133
entry.text: Specifies the syntax that represents a variable value that you want to append to the index root, to construct an index name. You can specify the following types of suffixes: Date pattern, which partitions your data by date. For example, when you specify a -%%{+YYYY.MM.dd} suffix, an Elasticsearch index is created daily. So for an index root value of apiconnectevents and a suffix of -%%{+YYYY.MM.dd} , an index is created daily using the naming convention apiconnectevents-YYYY.MM.dd . Dynamic value with any field name in an event record, which partitions your data by field. For example, -%%{org_id} creates an organization-specific Elasticsearch index.

entry.name: index_suffix_analyticsendpoint_descr_133
entry.text: Suffix to append to the index root

entry.name: primary_shards_analyticsendpoint_help_134
entry.text: Specifies the number of primary shards that are allocated to a new index created in the specified Elasticsearch server. The offloaded data are stored as Elasticsearch documents. Each document is stored in an index, and each index can have one or more primary shards. The specified value determines how many primary shards are used to store the data for a new index, which is created with the static index root value and variable suffix. Existing indexes are not affected. By default, an index has 5 primary shards. Note that you cannot change the number of primary shards in an index after the index is created.

entry.name: primary_shards_analyticsendpoint_descr_134
entry.text: Primary shards allocated for an index

entry.name: replica_shards_analyticsendpoint_help_135
entry.text: Specifies the number of replica shards that are defined for each primary shard, to hold copies of the offloaded data that is stored in each primary shard. One primary shard can have zero or more replicas. By default, a primary shard has 1 replica shard.

entry.name: replica_shards_analyticsendpoint_descr_135
entry.text: Replica shards allocated for each primary shard

entry.name: interval_analyticsendpoint_help_136
entry.text: Specifies the interval in seconds between offloads. Data is offloaded at this interval or when the 10%% of the value set for maximum records is reached. Enter a value in the range 1 - 3600. The default value is 600.

entry.name: interval_analyticsendpoint_descr_136
entry.text: Interval between offloads

entry.name: delivery_connections_analyticsendpoint_help_137
entry.text: Specifies the number of connection to establish per delivery to the remote server to offload analytics data. Each connection can carry a bulk activity log. Enter a value in the range 1 - 100. The default value is 1. This property is meaningful only when Kafka is the analytics endpoint.

entry.name: delivery_connections_analyticsendpoint_descr_137
entry.text: number of connection to establish per delivery to the remote server

entry.name: routing_prefix_apicollection_help_154
entry.text: The API Gateway uses the routing prefix to determine which API collection to route the request to. You can use routing prefixes to organize your APIs and plans into collections and subcollections. For example, if you have a collection of APIs serving for a certain purpose, and the APIs are to be used by two segments of your organization, you might create two API collections with the organization name, purpose name, and segment name in the routing prefix. If the organization name is myorg , the APIs serve for purpose purpose1 , and the two segments under the organization is section1 and section2 , the resulting URL routing prefixes are /myorg/purpose1/section1 and /myorg/purpose1/section2 . The resulting host name routing prefixes are section1.purpose1.myorg and section2.purpose1.myorg . The API Gateway uses the routing prefix to form the complete URI <routing prefix><base path><operation path> and accepts only the incoming requests with this URI. In the complete URI, <base path> is the base path on which the API is served, and <operation path> is the relative path to the base path where the operations are available. The default routing prefix is slash (/) when the type is URI and blank when the type is host name. An API collection becomes the default API collection in the API Gateway when the API collection has a default routing prefix. The API Gateway routes a request to the default API collection when other API collections do not match. An API Gateway can have only one default API collection; therefore, regardless of the prefix type, only one API collection can be configured with the default routing prefix.

entry.name: routing_prefix_apicollection_descr_154
entry.text: Prefixes of the routing path

entry.text: Defines the processing rule that matches the target API, enforces the rate limiting and security rules of using the API, executes the assembly of the API, and responds to the client. You should always use the default API processing rule. When your API collection requires custom processing, use API Connect global policies to define the custom rules.

entry.name: parse_settings_reference_apicollection_help_170
entry.text: A parse settings configuration defines the constraints on the documents to parse. You can configure the constraints by specifying a URL reference from which to retrieve the constraints definition. You can also specify a literal configuration string in XML management interface or REST management interface format that contains the constraints definition. You can also select a parse settings configuration object from the list in object reference to retrieve constraints definition. Precedence rules apply when the constraint for the same aspect of an input document is configured with more than one method.

entry.name: parse_settings_reference_apicollection_descr_170
entry.text: Use any or all of the following ways to define the parse settings configuration.

entry.name: apic_gw_service_kglobalconfig_help_171
entry.text: The API Connect Gateway Service defines the connection to API Connect and settings to use for creating the gateway for service. When an API Connect Gateway Service is configured and starts to work, DataPower starts a process that retrieves data from API Connect, transmits into DataPower Gateway, and stores the data as DataPower configurations that the API gateway can subsequently use to handle API calls.

entry.name: apic_gw_service_kglobalconfig_descr_171
entry.text: API Connect Gateway Service

entry.name: admin_state_apiconnectgatewayservice_help_172
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_apiconnectgatewayservice_descr_172
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_apiconnectgatewayservice_help_173
entry.text: A descriptive summary for the API Connect Gateway Service configuration.

entry.name: summary_apiconnectgatewayservice_descr_173
entry.text: Enter a brief descriptive summary for the API Connect Gateway Service configuration.

entry.name: local_address_apiconnectgatewayservice_help_174
entry.text: IP address or interface through which API Connect will connect to manage the gateway service. The default address is 0.0.0.0.

entry.name: local_address_apiconnectgatewayservice_descr_174
entry.text: IP address or interface to bind this service to

entry.name: local_port_apiconnectgatewayservice_help_175
entry.text: Specifies the TCP port through which API Connect will connect to orchestrate this service. The default port number is 3000. #b#Note:#/b# The gateway service uses two additional consecutive ports after the local port to bind to a loopback address. Therefore, you must clear the conflicts on all three consecutive ports starting from the local port and make sure these ports are available.

entry.name: local_port_apiconnectgatewayservice_descr_175
entry.text: TCP port of the API Connect Gateway service

entry.name: ssl_client_apiconnectgatewayservice_help_176
entry.text: The client profile to use to establish a secure connection to the API manager. The following restrictions apply to this profile. Keys and certificates are restricted to PEM and PKCS #12 formats. The validation credentials must use PEM formatted material.

entry.name: ssl_client_apiconnectgatewayservice_descr_176
entry.text: TLS client profile

entry.name: ssl_server_apiconnectgatewayservice_help_177
entry.text: The server profile to use to allow the secure connection attempts from API Connect to this service. The following restrictions apply to this profile. Keys and certificates are restricted to PEM and PKCS #12 formats. The validation credentials must use PEM formatted material.

entry.name: ssl_server_apiconnectgatewayservice_descr_177
entry.text: TLS server profile

entry.name: api_gw_address_apiconnectgatewayservice_help_178
entry.text: Specifies the IP address for the HTTPS handler of the API gateway that is managed by API Connect. The default address is 0.0.0.0.

entry.name: api_gw_address_apiconnectgatewayservice_descr_178
entry.text: IP address of the API gateway handler

entry.name: api_gw_port_apiconnectgatewayservice_help_179
entry.text: Specifies the port number for the HTTPS handler of the API gateway that is managed by API Connect. The default port number is 9443.

entry.name: api_gw_port_apiconnectgatewayservice_descr_179
entry.text: Port number of the API gateway handler

entry.name: startup_options_apiconnectgatewayservice_help_180
entry.text: This is an internal property.

entry.name: startup_options_apiconnectgatewayservice_descr_180
entry.text: Startup options

entry.name: gateway_peering_apiconnectgatewayservice_help_181
entry.text: Specifies a gateway peering configuration that defines peers for the current API gateway and the settings to use for synchronizing the distributed state among the peers. The following restrictions apply to this gateway peering configuration. When TLS and peer group mode are enabled, all peers must use the same cryptographic material. Keys and certificates are restricted to PEM and PKCS #12 formats.

entry.name: gateway_peering_apiconnectgatewayservice_descr_181
entry.text: Define peering for a cluster of API gateways

entry.name: gateway_peering_manager_apiconnectgatewayservice_help_182
entry.text: Define gateway peering manager for a cluster of API gateways

entry.name: gateway_peering_manager_apiconnectgatewayservice_descr_182
entry.text: Define gateway peering manager for a cluster of API gateways

entry.name: v5_compatibility_mode_apiconnectgatewayservice_help_183
entry.text: Controls the gateway to load for API Connect: When you enable V5 compatibility, DataPower loads a gateway framework that is compatible with V5. This is the default behavior. When you disable V5 compatibility, DataPower creates an API Gateway that is not compatible with V5. The API Gateway is currently provided as technical preview.

entry.name: v5_compatibility_mode_apiconnectgatewayservice_descr_183
entry.text: Whether to enable compatibility with API Connect V5

entry.name: user_defined_policies_apiconnectgatewayservice_help_184
entry.text: When V5 compatibility mode is disabled, you can use assembly functions to specify user-defined policies to advertise to API Connect for use in the API Connect Assembly Editor. For an assembly function that is a user-defined policy, configure the assembly function with a mechanism other than a watched file processed by a configuration sequence. Objects created through configuration sequence processing are not persisted to the startup configuration. The preferred method for DataPower configuration for user-defined policies is to define them explicitly so that they persist to the startup configuration.

entry.name: user_defined_policies_apiconnectgatewayservice_descr_184
entry.text: User-defined policies to advertise to API Connect.

entry.name: slm_mode_apiconnectgatewayservice_help_185

entry.name: slm_mode_apiconnectgatewayservice_descr_185
entry.text: Specifies the peer group type for the SLM policy in V5 compatibility mode.

entry.text: Multicast configuration

entry.text: Specifies the SLM policy's unicast peer group address.

entry.name: ip_unicast_apiconnectgatewayservice_descr_187
entry.text: Unicast peering address.

entry.text: Specifies the ID of the API.

entry.text: Specifies the name of the API.

entry.text: Specifies the version of the API.

entry.text: Version of the API

entry.name: base_path_apidefinition_help_202
entry.text: Specifies the base path on which the API is served, which is relative to the host. When the base path is not specified, the APIs are served directly under the host. The base path does not include the host name or any additional segments for paths or operations. The base path must start but not end with slash (/). All resources in a REST API are defined relative to its base path.

entry.name: base_path_apidefinition_descr_202
entry.text: The base path for the API

entry.name: html_page_apidefinition_help_203
entry.text: Specifies the name and location of a static HTML page that the API can return. Import the file to the local: directory, the store: directory, or the temporary: directory, or one their subdirectories in the DataPower file system.

entry.name: html_page_apidefinition_descr_203
entry.text: Location of a static HTML page

entry.name: type_apidefinition_help_204
entry.text: Specifies the API type.

entry.name: type_apidefinition_descr_204
entry.text: Type of the API

entry.name: assembly_apidefinition_help_205
entry.text: Specifies the assembly to apply to API calls. An assembly comprises a rule that defines the actions to run against the API call and how to handle the errors during assembly execution.

entry.name: assembly_apidefinition_descr_205
entry.text: The assembly for API invocation

entry.name: path_apidefinition_help_206
entry.text: Specifies a list of paths through which users access the API operations. A path consists of one or more HTTP operations.

entry.name: path_apidefinition_descr_206
entry.text: Routes to access REST APIs

entry.name: consume_apidefinition_help_207
entry.text: Specifies a list of MIME types that the API can consume. These MIME types apply to all API operations. You can override the setting for specific operations in the API operation.

entry.name: consume_apidefinition_descr_207
entry.text: MIME types that the API can consume

entry.name: produce_apidefinition_help_208
entry.text: Specifies a list of MIME types that the API can produce. These MIME types apply to all API operations. You can override the setting for specific operations in the API operation.

entry.name: produce_apidefinition_descr_208
entry.text: MIME types that the API can produce

entry.name: swagger_location_apidefinition_help_209
entry.text: When you create the API definition from a Swagger document, specify the name and location of the Swagger document. Prepare the document as follows before you specify the location. When the Swagger document is a YAML file, convert it to JSON format. Import the JSON file to the local: directory, the temporary: directory, or one their subdirectories in the DataPower file system. When you create the API definition by manually specifying the API properties, this field is not applicable.

entry.name: swagger_location_apidefinition_descr_209
entry.text: The name and location of the Swagger document

entry.name: graphql_schema_apidefinition_help_210
entry.text: GraphQL schema location.

entry.name: graphql_schema_apidefinition_descr_210
entry.text: GraphQL schema location.

entry.name: wsdl_advertised_schema_location_apidefinition_help_211
entry.text: When you create the API definition from a WSDL file, specify the name and location of the WSDL document or archive of the WSDL and its dependencies.

entry.name: wsdl_advertised_schema_location_apidefinition_descr_211
entry.text: The name and location of the WSDL file or archive file with a WSDL file, which should be used to advertise the contract for this API.

entry.name: wsdl_validation_schema_apidefinition_help_212
entry.text: When you create the API definition from a WSDL file, specify the name and location of the top-level WSDL document itself, which should be used to validate incoming SOAP payloads.

entry.name: wsdl_validation_schema_apidefinition_descr_212
entry.text: The name and location of the top-level WSDL file to use to validate SOAP payloads.

entry.name: security_req_apidefinition_help_213
entry.text: Specifies the alternative security requirements to enforce for the API as a whole. In other words, processing applies a logical OR between the security requirements. By default, the security requirement is applied to all operations in the API. However, for each API operation, you can override the API-level security by separately specifying security schemes to enforce at the operation level.

entry.name: security_req_apidefinition_descr_213
entry.text: Required security schemes to execute API operations

entry.name: require_api_mutual_tls_apidefinition_help_214
entry.text: Require mutual TLS protection for this API.

entry.name: require_api_mutual_tls_apidefinition_descr_214
entry.text: Require mutual TLS protection

entry.name: api_mutual_tls_source_apidefinition_help_215
entry.text: Indicates the sources to obtain the client certificate for mutual TLS. Because you can define multiple ways to obtain the source, ensure that you sequence the methods appropriately.

entry.name: api_mutual_tls_source_apidefinition_descr_215
entry.text: Sources to obtain the client certificate for mutual TLS

entry.name: api_mutual_tls_header_name_apidefinition_help_216
entry.text: The HTTP header that contains the client certificate for mutual TLS. The default value is X-Client-Certificate .

entry.name: api_mutual_tls_header_name_apidefinition_descr_216
entry.text: HTTP header that contains the client certificate for mutual TLS

entry.name: property_apidefinition_help_217
entry.text: Specifies a list of custom API property entries. An API property is a type of context variable whose value is dependent on the API collection that the API is provisioned in. Collection-specific API properties allow you to use the same API definition in different API collections when a property in a collection requires a unique or different value. A custom property entry specifies one property and the property value for one collection. To add another custom property, or to specify a different property value for another collection, add another entry.

entry.name: property_apidefinition_descr_217
entry.text: Custom API properties

entry.name: schema_apidefinition_help_218
entry.text: Specifies a list of API schema objects that define data types for request or message validation. An API data type consists of a name and the API schema object.

entry.name: schema_apidefinition_descr_218
entry.text: API schemas

entry.name: cors_apidefinition_help_219
entry.text: Indicates whether to enable the API Gateway to handle the the cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) requests. When enabled, the API Gateway runs the API CORS action to handle all CORS requests that are made to the API. The API routing action matches the API to invoke, determines that the request is a preflight CORS request, and sets the request.attributes.isCORSPreflight flag to true . When CORS is enabled and a preflight request is received, all assembly actions and many API actions are skipped. Only the following API actions are performed. The API CORS action configures the appropriate response headers. The API result action sets the response headers. For all preflight requests, the API security and API client identification actions are always skipped, whether CORS is enabled or not enabled.

entry.name: cors_apidefinition_descr_219
entry.text: Whether to enable the API Gateway to handle CORS requests

entry.name: cors_policy_apidefinition_help_220
entry.text: The CORS policy to apply to calls to this API.

entry.name: cors_policy_apidefinition_descr_220
entry.text: The name of a CORS policy

entry.name: activity_log_apidefinition_help_221
entry.text: Indicates whether to enable logging for API activities. The API Gateway runs the API activity log action to generate logs. To generate log data for calls that invoke this API, you must first enable this property and ensure that the following conditions are met. The logging type for successful and unsuccessful API invocations is not set to none. The activity log action is added in the API rule associated with the API definition. When disabled, the API Gateway does not generate any log data for calls that invoke this API.

entry.name: activity_log_apidefinition_descr_221
entry.text: Whether to enable logging for API activities

entry.name: success_content_apidefinition_help_222
entry.text: Defines the type of content to log when the API invocation is successful. When set to log payload data, you must enable message buffering if you want to ensure that all request and response data is captured.

entry.name: success_content_apidefinition_descr_222
entry.text: Type of content to be logged when the API invocation is successful

entry.name: error_content_apidefinition_help_223
entry.text: Defines the type of content to log when the API invocation completes with error. When set to log payload data, you must enable message buffering if you want to ensure that all request and response data is captured.

entry.name: error_content_apidefinition_descr_223
entry.text: Type of content to be logged when the API invocation completes with error

entry.name: preserved_request_header_apidefinition_help_224
entry.text: Specifies the list of request headers in the log to preserve at the end of the transaction.

entry.name: preserved_request_header_apidefinition_descr_224
entry.text: Request headers in the log to preserve at the end of the transaction

entry.name: preserved_response_header_apidefinition_help_225
entry.text: Specifies the list of response headers in the log to preserve at the end of the transaction.

entry.name: preserved_response_header_apidefinition_descr_225
entry.text: Response headers in the log to preserve at the end of the transaction

entry.name: message_buffering_apidefinition_help_226
entry.text: Indicates whether to buffer API requests and responses before processing. When enabled, the message payload and the output of the assembly invoke action are read as a binary large object (BLOB). When disabled, the message payload and the output of the assembly invoke action are only read by an asynchronous API call. If you enable API activity logging to capture payload data, you must also enable message buffering if you want to ensure that all request and response data is captured.

entry.name: message_buffering_apidefinition_descr_226
entry.text: Whether to enable message buffering for the API

entry.name: deployment_state_apidefinition_help_227
entry.text: Specifies the deployment state of the API. By default, the deployment state of an API is running.

entry.name: deployment_state_apidefinition_descr_227
entry.text: Deployment state of the API

entry.name: share_count_apidefinition_help_228
entry.text: Share rate limit count among all APIs under an application.

entry.name: share_count_apidefinition_descr_228
entry.text: Share rate limit count among all APIs under an application.

entry.name: return_v5_responses_apidefinition_help_229
entry.text: Indicates whether to return v5-compatible responses, such as OAuth and client security error responses.

entry.name: return_v5_responses_apidefinition_descr_229
entry.text: Return v5 responses.

entry.name: copy_id_headers_to_message_apidefinition_help_230
entry.text: Indicates whether to copy security headers to the message context for retrieval by the invoke backend service.

entry.name: copy_id_headers_to_message_apidefinition_descr_230
entry.text: Copy ID headers to message.

entry.name: enforce_required_params_apidefinition_help_231
entry.text: Indicates whether to check the request for required parameters during API routing.

entry.name: enforce_required_params_apidefinition_descr_231
entry.text: Enforce required parameter check.

entry.name: allow_chunked_uploads_apidefinition_help_232
entry.text: Indicates whether to allow the assembly invoke action to send documents to the server with Transfer-Encoding: chunked . This setting applies only to the invoke 1.5.0 wrapper policy deployed from API Connect using the migration utility. It does not apply to the native API Gateway assembly invoke action.

entry.name: allow_chunked_uploads_apidefinition_descr_232
entry.text: Allow chunked uploads.

entry.text: Indicates whether to populate v5-compatible headers, such as X-Client-IP and X-Global-Transaction-ID , in the request.headers context variable.

entry.name: set_v5_request_headers_apidefinition_descr_233
entry.text: Set v5 request headers.

entry.name: get_raw_body_value_apidefinition_help_234
entry.text: When using the GatewayScript apim.getvariable() API, indicates whether to get the raw body instead of parsing. The setting applies only when the context is other than message .

entry.name: get_raw_body_value_apidefinition_descr_234
entry.text: Get raw body value.

entry.text: Specifies allowed API protocol types in API gateway.

entry.name: allowed_api_protocols_apidefinition_descr_235
entry.text: Set allowed api protocols.

entry.text: An API Gateway matches the API to process the API request and routes the request to the matched API.

entry.name: apigw_kglobalconfig_descr_236
entry.text: API Gateway

entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_apigateway_descr_237
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.text: Enter a brief descriptive summary for the API gateway.

entry.name: front_protocol_apigateway_help_239
entry.text: Specifies the protocol handler to handle the traffic between the API requester and the DataPower Gateway. The API gateway can receive requests only through HTTP and HTTPS handlers.

entry.name: front_protocol_apigateway_descr_239
entry.text: Protocol handler (HTTP and HTTPS only)

entry.name: xslrefresh_apigateway_help_240
entry.text: Optionally, assigns a stylesheet refresh policy to the API gateway. Stylesheets cached by this gateway are refreshed in accordance with policy rules.

entry.name: xslrefresh_apigateway_descr_240
entry.text: Stylesheet refresh policy

entry.name: xsl_cache_memorysize_apigateway_help_241
entry.text: Enter the maximum size of the stylesheet cache. The default value is 2147483647. A value of 0 disables caching. Stylesheets are purged when either the cache size or the cache count is reached.

entry.name: xsl_cache_memorysize_apigateway_descr_241
entry.text: Maximum size of stylesheet cache

entry.name: xsl_cache_size_apigateway_help_242
entry.text: Enter the maximum number of stylesheets to cache. Enter a value in the range 5 - 250000. The default value is 256. Stylesheets are purged when either the cache size or the cache count is reached.

entry.name: xsl_cache_size_apigateway_descr_242
entry.text: Maximum number of stylesheets cached

entry.name: xsl_checksummed_cache_apigateway_help_243
entry.text: Enables or disables SHA1-assisted stylesheet caching. With SHA1 caching enabled, stylesheets are cached by both URL and SHA1 message digest value. With SHA1 caching disabled, stylesheets are cached only by URL.

entry.name: xsl_checksummed_cache_apigateway_descr_243
entry.text: Manages SHA1-assisted caching

entry.name: static_document_calls_apigateway_help_244
entry.text: The latest XSLT specifications require that multiple document calls in the same transformation return the same result. Disable to allow all document calls to operate independently.

entry.name: static_document_calls_apigateway_descr_244
entry.text: Manage static document calls

entry.name: loadbalancer_group_apigateway_help_245
entry.text: Select a load balancer group and assign that group to this API gateway. A load balancer group, or server pool, provides redundancy among back-end resources.

entry.name: loadbalancer_group_apigateway_descr_245
entry.text: Load balancer groups

entry.name: maxdocs_apigateway_help_246
entry.text: Enter the maximum number of documents to cache. Enter a value in the range 1 - 250000. The default value is 5000.

entry.name: maxdocs_apigateway_descr_246
entry.text: Maximum number of documents cached

entry.name: size_apigateway_help_247
entry.text: Enter the maximum size of the document cache. Regardless of the specified size, no document that is greater than 1073741824 bytes is cached. This restriction applies even if the cache has available space.

entry.name: size_apigateway_descr_247
entry.text: Maximum size of document cache

entry.name: max_writes_apigateway_help_248
entry.text: Enter the maximum number of concurrent write requests to create documents or refresh expired documents in the document cache. Enter a value in the range 1 - 32768. The default value is 32768. After the maximum number is reached, requests are forwarded to the target server and the response is not written to the cache.

entry.name: max_writes_apigateway_descr_248
entry.text: Maximum number of concurrent writes to create documents in the cache

entry.name: policy_apigateway_help_249
entry.text: A document cache policy allows the administrator to determine how documents are cached by the API gateway. The policy offers time-to-live, priority, and type configuration values. The document cache is distinct from the stylesheet cache.

entry.name: policy_apigateway_descr_249
entry.text: Document cache policy

entry.name: schedule_rule_apigateway_help_250
entry.text: Certain applications require the running of a scheduled processing rule. Integration with a CA Unicenter Manager is facilitated by a regularly scheduled processing rule that obtains relationship data from the Unicenter Manager.

entry.name: schedule_rule_apigateway_descr_250
entry.text: Run a processing rule periodically.

entry.name: collection_apigateway_descr_251

entry.name: ldap_pool_apigateway_help_256
entry.text: Identifies the LDAP connection pool to be used by the API gateway when contacting LDAP.

entry.name: ldap_pool_apigateway_descr_256
entry.text: Specify the LDAP connection pool to use

entry.name: proxy_apigateway_help_257
entry.text: Configure a proxy policy that associates a set of URLs with a specific HTTP proxy. When multiple proxy policies are defined, URLs are evaluated against each policy in order.

entry.name: proxy_apigateway_descr_257
entry.text: Proxy policy definition

entry.name: front_timeout_apigateway_help_258
entry.text: Set the intra-transaction timeout for API gateway to client connections. This value is the maximum idle time to allow in a transaction on the API gateway to client connection. This timer monitors idle time in the data transfer process. If the specified idle time is exceeded, the connection is torn down. Enter a value in the range 1 - 86400. The default value is 120.

entry.name: front_timeout_apigateway_descr_258
entry.text: Maximum intra-transaction timeout for API gateway to client connections

entry.name: front_persistent_timeout_apigateway_help_259
entry.text: Set the inter-transaction timeout for API gateway to client connections. This value is the maximum idle time to allow between the completion of a TCP transaction and the initiation of a new TCP transaction on the API gateway to client connection. If the specified idle time is exceeded, the connection is torn down. Enter a value in the range 0 - 86400. The default value is 180. A value of 0 disables persistent connections.

entry.name: front_persistent_timeout_apigateway_descr_259
entry.text: Maximum inter-transaction timeout for API gateway to client connections

entry.name: path_apipath_help_279
entry.text: Specifies the route to access the REST APIs. The path is appended to the base path to construct the full URI to access the APIs. The path must start but not end with the / character. When the path contains a parameter, make sure that you define the path parameter at either or both the path and operation levels. A parameter at the end of the path can contain a + qualifier to match one or more levels as in the following example. /petstore/{type}/{+category} The {type} parameter matches one path level. The {+category} parameter matches multiple levels. The following paths match this path template. /petstore/cats/supplies /petstore/cats/supplies/health /petstore/cats/supplies/health/medicines A parameter at the end of the path can contain a * qualifier to match zero or more levels as in the following example. /petstore/{type}/{*category} The {type} parameter matches one path level. The {*category} parameter matches multiple levels. The following paths match this path template. /petstore/cats/ /petstore/cats/supplies /petstore/cats/supplies/health /petstore/cats/supplies/health/medicines

entry.name: path_apipath_descr_279
entry.text: The relative path to access the REST APIs

entry.name: operation_apipath_help_280
entry.text: Describes the operations that can be executed under the path. When no operation is defined, all operations are accepted under this path.

entry.name: operation_apipath_descr_280
entry.text: Operations available on the path

entry.name: request_schema_apipath_help_281
entry.text: Specifies the request schema that describes the valid request messages for the API path.

entry.name: request_schema_apipath_descr_281
entry.text: The request schema for the API path

entry.name: parameter_apipath_help_282
entry.text: Specifies the parameters that are applicable for all operations under this path. The setting here can be overridden by the setting in the API Operation configuration for the same parameter.

entry.name: parameter_apipath_descr_282
entry.text: Parameters applicable for all operations under this path

entry.name: api_plan_kglobalconfig_help_283
entry.text: An API is exposed for access through an API plan. An API Plan packages a list of APIs and defines the rate limit schemes to enforce to access the APIs. By default, the rate limit scheme of the plan applies to all operations. However, you can exclude certain operations from the plan or override the plan-level rate limit schemes by specifying operation-specific rate limit schemes.

entry.name: api_plan_kglobalconfig_descr_283
entry.text: API Plan

entry.name: use_rate_limit_group_apiplan_help_291
entry.text: Indicates whether to use a rate limit definition group.

entry.name: use_rate_limit_group_apiplan_descr_291
entry.text: Indicates whether to use a rate limit definition group

entry.name: rate_limit_apiplan_help_292
entry.text: Specifies the rate limit scheme to enforce. A rate limit scheme defines the maximum rate that is allowed in a specified time interval and the actions to take when the limit is exceeded.

entry.name: rate_limit_apiplan_descr_292
entry.text: Rate limit scheme

entry.name: burst_limit_apiplan_help_293
entry.text: Specifies the burst limit scheme to enforce. A burst limit scheme defines the maximum burst rate that is allowed in a specified time interval. The burst limit scheme helps prevent usage spikes that may damage infrastructure. The burst limit takes higher priority than the rate limit, when a message arrives within an interval, the message is first checked against the burst limit scheme and then against the rate limit scheme.

entry.name: burst_limit_apiplan_descr_293
entry.text: Burst limit scheme

entry.name: rate_limit_group_apiplan_help_294
entry.text: The rate limit definition group to enforce preflow rate limits on all APIs that are packaged in the plan. When a rate limit definition group is specified, other preflow limits defined in the plan are ignored.

entry.name: rate_limit_group_apiplan_descr_294
entry.text: The rate limit definition group to enforce for the API plan

entry.name: assembly_burst_limit_apiplan_help_295
entry.text: Specifies the burst limit scheme to enforce. A burst limit scheme defines the maximum burst rate that is allowed in a specified time interval. The burst limit scheme helps prevent usage spikes that may damage infrastructure. The burst limit takes higher priority than the rate limit, when a message arrives within an interval, the message is first checked against the burst limit scheme and then against the rate limit scheme.

entry.name: assembly_burst_limit_apiplan_descr_295
entry.text: Burst limit scheme to be used by assembly rate limit action.

entry.name: assembly_rate_limit_apiplan_help_296
entry.text: Specifies the rate limit scheme to enforce. A rate limit scheme defines the maximum rate that is allowed in a specified time interval and the actions to take when the limit is exceeded.

entry.name: assembly_rate_limit_apiplan_descr_296
entry.text: Rate limit scheme to be used by assembly rate limit action.

entry.name: assembly_count_limit_apiplan_help_297
entry.text: Specifies the count limit scheme to enforce. A count limit scheme defines the maximum count that is allowed and the actions to take when the limit is exceeded.

entry.name: assembly_count_limit_apiplan_descr_297
entry.text: Count limit scheme to be used by assembly rate limit action.

entry.name: space_id_apiplan_help_298
entry.text: Specifies the space ID for the product. When space is enabled for a catalog, the catalog can be partitioned to spaces, where each space is used by a different API provider development team and has its own set of management capabilities that pertain specifically to the APIs in that space. Spaces enable each team to manage their APIs independently.

entry.name: space_id_apiplan_descr_298
entry.text: ID of the space that the product belongs to in the catalog

entry.name: space_name_apiplan_help_299
entry.text: Specifies the space name for the product. When space is enabled for a catalog, the catalog can be partitioned to spaces, where each space is used by a different API provider development team and has its own set of management capabilities that pertain specifically to the APIs in that space. Spaces enable each team to manage their APIs independently.

entry.name: space_name_apiplan_descr_299
entry.text: Name of the space that the product belongs to in the catalog

entry.text: Specifies a list of operations to exclude from the plan. When you exclude an operation from a plan, this operation is not available for access through this plan.

entry.name: json_schema_apischema_help_308
entry.text: Specifies the schema URL for JSON message validation. For example, local:///petstore.json#/definitions/Pet . To accept all input, use the string accept instead of entering a URL. To reject all input, use the string reject instead of entering a URL.

entry.name: graphql_schema_apischema_help_309
entry.text: Specifies the schema URL for GraphQL message validation. For example, local:///petstore-Pet.graphql . To accept all input, use the string accept instead of entering a URL. To reject all input, use the string reject instead of entering a URL.

entry.name: graphql_schema_apischema_descr_309
entry.text: GraphQL schema URL

entry.name: xml_type_apischema_help_310
entry.text: Specifies the type of XML validation to perform, either XML or WSDL.

entry.name: xml_type_apischema_descr_310
entry.text: XML type

entry.name: xml_validation_mode_apischema_help_311
entry.text: Specifies the mode to validate XML messages: validate the entire message or only the SOAP body of the message.

entry.name: xml_validation_mode_apischema_descr_311
entry.text: The mode for XML validation

entry.name: xml_schema_url_apischema_help_312
entry.text: Specifies the schema URL for XML message validation. For example, local:///petstore-Pet.xsd . To accept all input, use the string accept instead of entering a URL. To reject all input, use the string reject instead of entering a URL.

entry.name: xml_schema_url_apischema_descr_312
entry.text: XML schema URL

entry.name: wsdl_schema_url_apischema_help_313
entry.text: Specifies the schema URL for WSDL message validation. For example, local:///petstore-Pet.wsdl . To accept all input, use the string accept instead of entering a URL. To reject all input, use the string reject instead of entering a URL.

entry.name: wsdl_schema_url_apischema_descr_313
entry.text: WSDL schema URL

entry.name: wsdl_port_apischema_help_314
entry.text: The QName of the WSDL port that defines the service traffic to validate. The value should be a QName in the form "{namespace-uri}local-part" or "*" for all ports that are defined in the WSDL file. If specified and not "*", only messages that are defined for the named port are considered valid.

entry.name: wsdl_port_apischema_descr_314
entry.text: Validate messages from a specific wsdl:port

entry.name: wsdl_operation_apischema_help_315
entry.text: The name of the WSDL operation that defines the service traffic to validate. The value should be the unqualified name of the operation or "*" for all operations that are defined in the WSDL file. If specified and not "*", only messages that are defined for operations that match the specified name are considered valid.

entry.name: wsdl_operation_apischema_descr_315
entry.text: Validate messages that match the specified wsdl:operation

entry.name: wsdl_message_direction_or_name_apischema_help_316
entry.text: The name or direction of the WSDL input (wsdl:input), output (wsdl:output), or fault (wsdl:fault) that defines the service traffic to be validated. The value should be the name of one or more WSDL input, output, or fault components, or "#input" or "#output" for the request and response directions respectively, or "*" for all inputs, outputs, and faults that are defined in the WSDL file. If specified and not "*", only messages that are defined for inputs, outputs, and faults that match the specified name or direction are considered valid. Faults are considered valid for the response direction.

entry.name: wsdl_message_direction_or_name_apischema_descr_316
entry.text: Validate messages from wsdl:input, wsdl:output, or wsdl:faults that match the given name or direction

entry.name: wsdl_attachment_part_apischema_help_317
entry.text: The name of the WSDL message part that defines the content of a MIME attachment (mime:content/@part). The value should be the unqualified name of the message part. The name is the same as the part attribute on the corresponding mime:content component in the WSDL file. When this property is not defined or has the special value "*", the root MIME part is validated. The root MIME part is bound to a soap:body.

entry.name: wsdl_attachment_part_apischema_descr_317
entry.text: Validate messages defined by mime:content in the WSDL that match the specified message part name

entry.name: api_sec_apikey_kglobalconfig_help_318
entry.text: An API key security definition defines the credentials that an API client must provide to the API Gateway to identify itself when calling the API operations. You can require that the client must provide only the client ID, or both client ID and client secret, to call an API operation. When you require the client to provide both client ID and client secret, you must create two separate API Security API Key configurations, one of type ID and the other of type Secret.

entry.name: api_sec_apikey_kglobalconfig_descr_318
entry.text: API Security API Key

entry.text: A descriptive summary for the API Security API Key configuration.

entry.text: Enter a brief descriptive summary for the API Security API Key configuration.

entry.name: where_apisecurityapikey_help_321
entry.text: Specifies the location that the client credentials are expected to be found. An API call fails if the credentials are not included in the specified location. Note: Regardless of where the client credentials are sent, you must specify the same location for the client ID and client secret.

entry.name: where_apisecurityapikey_descr_321
entry.text: Location of client credentials

entry.name: type_apisecurityapikey_help_322
entry.text: Specifies the type of the client credential.

entry.name: type_apisecurityapikey_descr_322
entry.text: Type of client credentials

entry.name: key_name_apisecurityapikey_help_323
entry.text: Specifies the name of the request header, basic authentication header, query parameter, or form data, according to the credential type that you select.

entry.name: key_name_apisecurityapikey_descr_323
entry.text: The name of the API key

entry.name: api_sec_basic_auth_kglobalconfig_help_324
entry.text: A basic authentication security definition selects a user registry to authenticate accesses to the API operations. When you use basic authentication, API users must provide a valid user name and password in the requests to access operations that require basic authentication. #b#Note:#/b# You cannot apply more than one basic authentication security definition to an API.

entry.name: api_sec_basic_auth_kglobalconfig_descr_324
entry.text: API Security Basic Authentication

entry.text: Specifies the API user registry configuration to authenticate incoming API requests. The supported registries are API authentication URL and API LDAP.

entry.name: api_sec_http_scheme_kglobalconfig_help_328
entry.text: Configure and manage an HTTP bearer authentication security definition with the Bearer authentication security scheme in an API as defined in OpenAPI 3.0. Bearer authentication is an HTTP Authentication scheme and was originally part of RFC 6759: The OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework: Bearer Token Usage.

entry.text: API Security HTTP Scheme

entry.name: api_sec_oauth_req_kglobalconfig_help_336
entry.text: An OAuth security requirement defines the allowed scopes for controlling access to APIs or operations through the token-based OAuth protocol. By using an OAuth token, a user can grant websites or applications to access their data that are stored with another service provider, without sharing their personal credentials. #b#Note:#/b# You cannot apply more than one OAuth security requirement to an API or operation.

entry.name: api_sec_oauth_req_kglobalconfig_descr_336
entry.text: API Security OAuth Requirement

entry.name: oauth_definition_apisecurityoauthreq_help_339
entry.text: Specifies an OAuth security definition that defines the applicable OAuth provider settings.

entry.name: oauth_definition_apisecurityoauthreq_descr_339
entry.text: The OAuth security definition to use

entry.name: allowed_scopes_apisecurityoauthreq_help_340
entry.text: Specifies the scopes that the access token is valid to access. To specify multiple scopes, use a space between each scope. The order of scopes does not matter. The allowed scopes must be a subset of the allowed scopes set for the OAuth provider settings. Scopes ensure that the granted access token is valid to access only specific protected resources.

entry.name: allowed_scopes_apisecurityoauthreq_descr_340
entry.text: The scopes that the access token is valid to access

entry.name: oauth_provider_apisecurityoauth_help_344
entry.text: Specifies an OAuth provider settings configuration that defines the type of the provider and the authorization details about the provider.

entry.name: oauth_provider_apisecurityoauth_descr_344
entry.text: The OAuth provider to use

entry.name: oauth_flow_apisecurityoauth_help_345
entry.text: Specifies the OAuth flow to enforce to protect the target. The value should be among the supported grant types that are defined by the referenced OAuth provider.

entry.name: oauth_flow_apisecurityoauth_descr_345
entry.text: Which OAuth flow to enforce

entry.name: oauth_scope_apisecurityoauth_help_346
entry.text: Specifies the scopes that the access token is valid to access. To specify multiple scopes, use a space between each scope. The order of scopes does not matter. The allowed scopes for this configuration must be a subset of the allowed scopes set for the API OAuth security definition. The allowed scopes for the API OAuth security definition must be a subset of the allowed scopes set for the OAuth provider settings. Scopes ensure that the granted access token is valid to access only specific protected resources.

entry.name: oauth_scope_apisecurityoauth_descr_346
entry.text: The scopes that the access token is valid to access

entry.name: oauth_advanced_scope_url_apisecurityoauth_help_347
entry.text: When specified the URL that overrides the advanced scope URL in the OAuth provider settings. The value must be a properly formatted URL.

entry.name: oauth_advanced_scope_url_apisecurityoauth_descr_347
entry.text: The URL that overrides the advanced scope URL in the OAuth provider settings

entry.name: oauth_advanced_scope_tls_profile_apisecurityoauth_help_348
entry.text: When the OAuth advanced scope URL uses the HTTPS protocol, specifies the TLS client profile to secure the connection.

entry.name: oauth_advanced_scope_tls_profile_apisecurityoauth_descr_348
entry.text: TLS client profile to secure the HTTPS connection to the OAuth advanced scope URL

entry.name: api_sec_req_kglobalconfig_help_349
entry.text: An API Security Requirement configuration defines the required security schemes that an API request must pass to execute this operation. Specify the security requirement by selecting from the security schemes that are declared in the Security Definitions configuration. When multiple security schemes are selected, the API request must pass all security checks (that is, there is a logical AND between the schemes).

entry.name: api_sec_req_kglobalconfig_descr_349
entry.text: API Security Requirement

entry.name: admin_state_apisecurityrequirement_help_350
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_apisecurityrequirement_descr_350
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_apisecurityrequirement_help_351
entry.text: A descriptive summary for the API Security Requirement configuration.

entry.name: summary_apisecurityrequirement_descr_351
entry.text: Enter a brief descriptive summary for the API Security Requirement configuration.

entry.name: security_apisecurityrequirement_help_352
entry.text: Specifies the security scheme to enforce.

entry.name: security_apisecurityrequirement_descr_352
entry.text: Security scheme to use for the operation

entry.name: api_security_token_manager_kglobalconfig_help_353
entry.text: The security token manager provides storage configurations for security objects such as OAuth Providers and User Security.

entry.name: api_security_token_manager_kglobalconfig_descr_353
entry.text: API Security Token Manager

entry.text: A descriptive summary for the Security Token Manager.

entry.text: Enter a descriptive summary for the Security Token Manager.

entry.name: gateway_peering_apisecuritytokenmanager_help_356
entry.text: Specifies the gateway peering instance to store and manage internal OAuth token data in this domain. Native OAuth tokens that are managed by an external token management service are not stored in this gateway peering instance. This gateway peering instance must be configured to persist data across a restart.

entry.name: gateway_peering_apisecuritytokenmanager_descr_356
entry.text: Gateway peering instance to use as the store for internal token management

entry.name: gateway_peering_external_apisecuritytokenmanager_help_357
entry.text: Specifies the gateway peering instance to store and manage responses from external OAuth token management services in this domain. This gateway peering instance does not require that data persist across a restart.

entry.name: gateway_peering_external_apisecuritytokenmanager_descr_357
entry.text: Gateway peering instance to use as the store for responses from external token management services

entry.name: api_auth_url_reg_kglobalconfig_descr_358

entry.text: Enter a brief descriptive summary for the API authentication URL registry.

entry.name: auth_url_apiauthurlregistry_help_361
entry.text: The URL of the authentication endpoint to authenticate credentials. The user credentials in the authorization header are validated by the endpoint that is specified in the URL. When the user is authenticated, DataPower expects the authentication endpoint to return an HTTP 200 OK response status code. All other HTTP response status codes result in an authentication failure and access is denied.

entry.name: auth_url_apiauthurlregistry_descr_361
entry.text: Enter the URL of the authentication endpoint to authenticate credentials.

entry.name: tls_client_apiauthurlregistry_help_362
entry.text: Set the TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and the authentication URL.

entry.name: tls_client_apiauthurlregistry_descr_362
entry.text: Set the TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and the authentication URL.
