entry.name: xslt_version_compilesettings_help_663
entry.text: Specifies the XSLT processor version. The default value is XSLT10.

entry.name: strict_compilesettings_help_664
entry.text: Specifies whether to enable strict XSLT error checking. Non-strict operations attempt to recover from certain errors, such as use of undeclared variables, calling undeclared templates, and so forth. By default, strict XSLT error checking is enabled.

entry.name: profile_compilesettings_help_665
entry.text: Specifies whether to enable stylesheet profiling. This option should not be used in production environments. By default, stylesheet profiling is disabled.

entry.name: debug_compilesettings_help_666
entry.text: Specifies whether to run the stylesheet, XQuery script, and JSONiq script in debug mode. When a stylesheet, XQuery script, or JSONiq script is run in debug mode, it generates a custom web page instead of displaying its normal output. The web page details exactly what occurred during execution, including the values of variables and where particular pieces of the output came from. This option should not be used in production environments. By default, debug mode is disabled.

entry.name: stream_compilesettings_help_667
entry.text: Specifies whether the stylesheet must be run in streaming mode. Transformation of the document begins before the input is fully parsed. Not all stylesheets can be streamed. If the stylesheet cannot be streamed, an error is generated and the input is not processed. By default, streaming mode is disabled.

entry.name: try_stream_compilesettings_help_668
entry.text: Specifies whether to attempt to run the stylesheet in streaming mode. Transformation of the document begins before the input is fully parsed. Not all stylesheets can be streamed. If the stylesheet cannot be streamed, a warning is generated during compilation and the stylesheet is read in the entire input as normal at execution time. By default, attempting to run the stylesheet in streaming mode is disabled.

entry.name: minesc_compilesettings_help_669
entry.text: Specifies whether to escape output produced from the stylesheet during processing. Minimal escaping is particularly useful when handling non-English character sets. By default, minimum escaping is disabled.

entry.name: stack_size_compilesettings_help_670
entry.text: Indicates the maximum number of bytes that the stack is allowed to use while executing a stylesheet or other compiled content. This setting is used to block infinite recursion. The minimum value is 10 kilobytes, or 10,240 bytes. The maximum value is 100 megabytes, or 104,857,600 bytes. The default value is 1 megabyte, or 1,048,576 bytes.

entry.name: wsi_validate_compilesettings_help_671
entry.text: Specifies the validation behavior to apply to WSDL files that are checked for conformance to section 5 of WS-I Basic Profile (version 1.0, April 2004). The default setting is Warn.

entry.name: wsdl_validate_body_compilesettings_help_672
entry.text: Specifies the validation behavior for the soap:Body. The default setting is Strict.

entry.name: wsdl_validate_headers_compilesettings_help_673
entry.text: Specifies the validation behavior for the soap:Header. The default setting is Lax.

entry.name: wsdl_validate_faults_compilesettings_help_674
entry.text: Specifies the validation behavior for the fault detail. The default setting is Strict.

entry.name: wsdl_wrapped_faults_compilesettings_help_675
entry.text: Specifies whether to require compatibility with RPC-style wrappers. By default, RPC-style wrappers are not required.

entry.name: allow_soap_enc_array_compilesettings_help_676
entry.text: Specifies whether to allow the schema to accept most uses of elements with xsi:type='SOAP-ENC:Array' consistent with SOAP 1.1 Section 5, even when these attributes violate the XML Schema specification. Normally the xsi:type attribute must name a type equal to or derived from the actual type of the element. For schemas compiled with this option, xsi:type is accepted specifically for the SOAP 1.1 Encoding 'Array' complex type if the element type is derived from SOAP-ENC:Array. The opposite is the normal allowable case. By default, elements with xsi:type='SOAP-ENC:Array' are not accepted.

entry.name: validate_soap_enc_array_compilesettings_help_677
entry.text: Specifies whether to perform extra schema validation following the encoding rules in SOAP 1.1 Section 5. When enabled, members of SOAP arrays are validated, attributes such as @id and @href are allowed even if they are not allowed by the schema, and @href values are checked to ensure that they have a corresponding @id element. By default, the extra validation is not performed.

entry.name: wildcards_ignore_xsi_type_compilesettings_help_678
entry.text: Specifies whether xs:any elements in the schema validate only child elements by name. The XML Schema specification requires that, if a wildcard matches an element but that element does not have an element declaration, the element is instead validated according to an xsi:type attribute on it. This option ignores those xsi:type attributes. It should be used for cases such as SOAP envelope validation where a further validation step will validate the contents matching the wildcard, possibly using the SOAP 1.1 encoding rules. By default, xsi:type attributes are not ignored.

entry.name: wsdl_strict_soap_version_compilesettings_help_679
entry.text: Specifies whether to strictly follow the SOAP binding in the WSDL. When enabled, only messages bound to SOAP 1.2 appear in SOAP 1.2 envelopes and only messages bound to SOAP 1.1 appear in SOAP 1.1 envelopes. By default, strict SOAP binding is disabled.

entry.name: xacml_debug_compilesettings_help_680
entry.text: Specifies whether to compile XACML policies with debug information. Note that the XACML debugging messages are also controlled by the log event in the XACML category. Use the debug log level to view the full XACML debugging messages. By default, XACML policies are not compiled with debug information.

entry.name: allow_xop_include_compilesettings_help_681
entry.text: Specifies whether the schema or WSDL document accepts messages where base64-encoded binary content was optimized according to the MTOM/XOP specifications. XOP binary-optimization replaces base64-encoded binary data with an xop:Include reference element that references the unencoded binary data located in an attachment. By default, MTOM/XOP optimized messages are disabled. When disabled, such optimized messages are rejected by validation of the optimized form. Rejection occurs because the schema specifies a simple type that accepts base64-encoded data, such as xs:base64Binary or xs:string, but the message contains an xop:Include element instead. When enabled, an xop:Include element can optionally appear in place of content for any XML Schema simple type that validates base64-encoded binary data. The xop:Include element itself will be validated according to the built-in schema in store:///schemas/xop.xsd.

entry.name: deployment_policy_kglobalconfig_help_682
entry.text: A deployment policy contains a set of rules that are applied during a configuration import. A deployment policy can be used to accept, filter, or modify configuration during import.

entry.name: deployment_policy_kglobalconfig_descr_682
entry.text: Deployment Policy

entry.name: admin_state_configdeploymentpolicy_help_683
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_configdeploymentpolicy_descr_683
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_configdeploymentpolicy_descr_684
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: accept_configdeploymentpolicy_help_685
entry.text: Matching configuration is accepted during import. To create a match statement, type a correctly formatted resource match in the horizontal text box or select Build. Selecting Build displays the Configuration Match Builder in a popup window. A match statement takes the following general form: Addr / Domain / Resource [? Name=resource-name & Property=property-name & Value=property-value ] Addr Device Address. Specifies IP address or host alias. The value (*) matches all IP addresses. Domain Application Domain. The name of the application domain. The value (*) matches all domains. Resource Resource Type. The name of the resource type. The value (*) matches all resource types. Name=resource-name An additional specification field, such as "Name". Limits the match statement to resources of the specified name. Use a PCRE to select groups of resource instances. For example, "Name=foo.*" would match all resources with names that start with "foo". Property=property-name Property Name. The name of the configuration property. Limits the match statement to resources of the specified property. If change specified, set property-name to null string. Value=property-value Property Value. Specifies the value for the configuration property. This property limits the match statement to resources with the specified property value.

entry.name: accept_configdeploymentpolicy_descr_685
entry.text: Accepted Configuration

entry.name: filter_configdeploymentpolicy_help_686
entry.text: Matching configuration is filtered during import. Match statements do not control whether to import files that are part of the imported configuration package. Files are imported regardless of whether the filter disallows the resources with which the files are associated. To create a match statement, type a correctly formatted resource match in the horizontal text box or select Build. Selecting Build displays the Configuration Match Builder in a popup window. A match statement takes the following general form: Addr / Domain / Resource [? Name=resource-name & Property=property-name & Value=property-value ] Addr Device Address. Specifies IP address or host alias. The value (*) matches all IP addresses. Domain Application Domain. The name of the application domain. The value (*) matches all domains. Resource Resource Type. The name of the resource type. The value (*) matches all resource types. Name=resource-name An additional specification field, such as "Name". Limits the match statement to resources of the specified name. Use a PCRE to select groups of resource instances. For example, "Name=foo.*" would match all resources with names that start with "foo". Property=property-name Property Name. The name of the configuration property. Limits the match statement to resources of the specified property. If change specified, set property-name to null string. Value=property-value Property Value. Specifies the value for the configuration property. This property limits the match statement to resources with the specified property value.

entry.name: filter_configdeploymentpolicy_descr_686
entry.text: Filtered Configuration

entry.name: modify_configdeploymentpolicy_help_687
entry.text: Matching configuration is modified during import. The matching configuration may be changed, added, or deleted. To create a match statement, type a correctly formatted resource match in the horizontal text box or select Build. Selecting Build displays the Configuration Match Builder in a popup window. A match statement takes the following general form: Addr / Domain / Resource [? Name=resource-name & Property=property-name & Value=property-value ] Addr Device Address. Specifies IP address or host alias. The value (*) matches all IP addresses. Domain Application Domain. The name of the application domain. The value (*) matches all domains. Resource Resource Type. The name of the resource type. The value (*) matches all resource types. Name=resource-name An additional specification field, such as "Name". Limits the match statement to resources of the specified name. Use a PCRE to select groups of resource instances. For example, "Name=foo.*" would match all resources with names that start with "foo". Property=property-name Property Name. The name of the configuration property. Limits the match statement to resources of the specified property. If change specified, set property-name to null string. Value=property-value Property Value. Specifies the value for the configuration property. This property limits the match statement to resources with the specified property value.

entry.name: modify_configdeploymentpolicy_descr_687
entry.text: Modified Configuration

entry.name: shared_object_configdeploymentpolicy_help_688
entry.text: A list of class-name pairs. The 'class' specifies the class type of an object, while the 'name' references a particular object of the given class type. If an object is present within this list, it will not be overwritten during import.

entry.name: shared_object_configdeploymentpolicy_descr_688
entry.text: The list of all shared objects.

entry.name: config_sequence_kglobalconfig_help_689
entry.text: A sequence of configuration files to load after the start-up configuration. By default, changes on the configuration files are automatically detected and reloaded.

entry.name: config_sequence_kglobalconfig_descr_689
entry.text: Configuration Sequence

entry.name: admin_state_configsequence_help_690
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_configsequence_descr_690
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_configsequence_descr_691
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: location_configsequence_help_692
entry.text: Each entry specifies a directory in the file system where the configuration files to match are stored. The DataPower Gateway watches the specified location and reloads the configuration when a change is detected in configuration files that match the specified PCRE match pattern. The entries are processed in the order that they appear in the list. The assess profile, when specified, indicates the permissions for the file execution.

entry.name: location_configsequence_descr_692
entry.text: Ordered list of locations to watch for changes and load configuration, and associated permissions for each location

entry.name: match_pattern_configsequence_help_693
entry.text: Specifies the PCRE match pattern that determines whether a file should be considered part of the match location. For instance, when the configuration files to match are NNNNNN.input , then the PCRE pattern is "([0-9]{6})\.input$" .

entry.name: match_pattern_configsequence_descr_693
entry.text: PCRE pattern to match configuration files for the match location

entry.name: result_name_pattern_configsequence_help_694
entry.text: Enter the PCRE pattern to use to build the name of the result file. This PCRE pattern normally has a back-reference to the base input file name. For instance, when input files are NNNNNN.input and the desired result file name is NNNNNN.result , then the pattern is "$1.result" .

entry.name: result_name_pattern_configsequence_descr_694
entry.text: PCRE pattern to name the generated result files

entry.name: status_name_pattern_configsequence_help_695
entry.text: Enter the PCRE to use to build the name of the JSON-format object status file. This PCRE pattern normally has a back-reference for the base input file name. For instance, when the input files are NNNNNN.input and the desired object status file name is NNNNNN.json , then the pattern is "$1.json" .

entry.name: status_name_pattern_configsequence_descr_695
entry.text: PCRE pattern to name the generated status files

entry.name: watch_configsequence_help_696
entry.text: Specifies whether to watch the specified directory for configuration file changes and automatically reload the configuration when a change is detected. By default, the specified directory is watched.

entry.name: watch_configsequence_descr_696
entry.text: Whether to watch changes in the matching configuration files

entry.name: use_output_location_configsequence_help_697
entry.text: Specifies whether to place output log and status files in the configured output location after the files are processed. By default, output files are stored in the input file location.

entry.name: use_output_location_configsequence_descr_697
entry.text: Whether to place output log and status files in the configured output location

entry.name: output_location_configsequence_help_698
entry.text: Specifies the directory to store the output files that are generated for the execution of the loaded configuration files. When not specified, the input file location is used.

entry.name: output_location_configsequence_descr_698
entry.text: Directory to store the output log files and status files

entry.name: delete_unused_configsequence_help_699
entry.text: Specifies whether to enable cleaning up objects that are no longer needed. When enabled, the configuration sequence detects and attempts to delete the objects that are no longer modified by any configuration file. By default, the configuration sequence does not delete unneeded objects.

entry.name: delete_unused_configsequence_descr_699
entry.text: Whether to clean up objects no longer needed after configuration events

entry.name: run_sequence_interval_configsequence_help_700
entry.text: Specifies how long, after a file event occurs, to wait before running this sequence again to load file changes. This delay enables multiple file events to be aggregated and handled within the same sequence run. The unit of the value is milliseconds. Enter a value in the range 100 - 60000. By default, a sequence run will load changes caused by file events that occur during the last 100 milliseconds.

entry.name: run_sequence_interval_configsequence_descr_700
entry.text: Time delay between a file event occurrence and a new sequence running

entry.name: max_log_file_size_configsequence_help_701
entry.text: Specifies the maximum size of the output log file in kilobytes before archival or wrapping occurs. Enter a value in the range 1024 - 50000. The default value is 1024.

entry.name: max_log_file_size_configsequence_descr_701
entry.text: The maximum size of the output log file in kilobytes before archival occurs

entry.name: mark_objects_external_configsequence_help_702
entry.text: Specifies whether to mark objects created by the sequence as external objects. By default, objects created by the sequence are external.

entry.name: mark_objects_external_configsequence_descr_702
entry.text: Whether to mark objects created by the sequence as external

entry.name: delete_config_configsequence_help_703
entry.text: Specifies whether to delete the matched configuration files after the files are processed. By default, configuration files are not deleted after being processed.

entry.name: delete_config_configsequence_descr_703
entry.text: Whether to delete configuration files after processing

entry.name: output_cleanup_interval_configsequence_help_704
entry.text: Specifies how long, after the execution of the configuration file, to wait before automatically deleting the related output files, which includes the result logs and object status files. The unit of the value is seconds. Enter a value in the range 0 - 1800. The default of 0 indicates not to delete output files.

entry.name: output_cleanup_interval_configsequence_descr_704
entry.text: Time delay between configuration execution and output deletion

entry.name: serialize_deferred_processing_configsequence_help_705
entry.text: Specifies whether to run the sequence for deferred events after unused object deletion runs. By default, these processes are serialized. The risk of running them concurrently is if later events add an object or objects that were previously marked for deletion by a file event, then the object deletion might erroneously execute after the addition.

entry.name: serialize_deferred_processing_configsequence_descr_705
entry.text: Whether to run the sequence for deferred events after unused object deletion runs

entry.name: optimize_for_apic_configsequence_help_706
entry.text: Specifies whether the sequence is used by APIc for the configuration that it owns and manages. The processing is optimized for that environment if so.

entry.name: optimize_for_apic_configsequence_descr_706
entry.text: Whether this configuration sequence runs in an APIc context

entry.name: always_run_config_configsequence_help_707
entry.text: Specifies whether the sequence will always run configuration commands from the configuration files, even if the commands do not change the current configuration.

entry.name: always_run_config_configsequence_descr_707
entry.text: Whether this configuration sequence always runs configuration commands from the configuration files

entry.name: monitor_persistence_configsequence_help_708
entry.text: Specifies whether the sequence monitors for domain persistence and refrains from acting on related file events.

entry.name: monitor_persistence_configsequence_descr_708
entry.text: Whether this configuration sequence always runs configuration commands from the configuration files

entry.name: control_list_kglobalconfig_help_712
entry.text: A control list uses a value-matching pattern to determine whether values are on the allowlist or blocklist. The value-matching pattern is defined by a PCRE. When you define the control list, you can indicates whether evaluation is case-sensitive or case-insensitive.

entry.name: value_controllist_help_716
entry.text: Specifies the PCRE to evaluate values. An entry of ^foo indicates a match against only values that start with foo . An empty list indicates no match against any value. A list with only .* indicates a match against all values.

entry.name: allow_origin_corsrule_help_725
entry.text: The list of values for the Origin header that are accepted for cross-origin requests. This rule does not apply to a CORS request when the value for the Origin header does not match any value in the list.

entry.name: allow_origin_corsrule_descr_725
entry.text: Origin request header values that the rule allows.

entry.name: allow_credentials_corsrule_help_726
entry.text: By default, the Access-Control-Allow-Credentials header is not returned in response to a CORS request. To return this header with a value of true , enable this property.

entry.name: allow_credentials_corsrule_descr_726
entry.text: Whether the CORS Access-Control-Allow-Credentials response header has a value of true.

entry.name: expose_headers_corsrule_help_727

entry.name: jwt_generator_kconfigcrypto_help_728
entry.text: The JSON Web Token (JWT) Generator specifies the JWT content and the cryptographic methods, such as signing and encryption methods, used for generating a JWT during the AAA postprocessing phase.

entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: iss_aaajwtgenerator_help_731
entry.text: The issuer claim, "iss", identifies the principal that issues the JWT. The maximum length is 256 characters. The default value is idg .

entry.name: iss_aaajwtgenerator_descr_731
entry.text: Specify the value for the issuer claim.

entry.name: duration_aaajwtgenerator_help_732
entry.text: The validity period identifies the expiration time, "exp" claim. Enter a value in the range 1 - 31622400. The default value is 3600.

entry.name: duration_aaajwtgenerator_descr_732
entry.text: Specify the validity period for calculating the expiration time, "exp" claim, of the JWT processing.

entry.name: add_claims_aaajwtgenerator_help_733
entry.text: Additional JWT claims, such as audience "aud" claim, not before "nbf" claim, issued at "iat" claim, JWT ID "jit" claim, "nonce" claim, and custom claim, can be added for JWT. The subject, "sub" claim is added by default. You can override the subject claim value by specifying the "sub" claim in the Custom claims field.

entry.name: add_claims_aaajwtgenerator_descr_733
entry.text: Add additional JWT claims.

entry.name: aud_aaajwtgenerator_help_734

entry.name: aud_aaajwtgenerator_descr_734
entry.text: Specify the value for the audience claim.

entry.name: nbf_aaajwtgenerator_help_735
entry.text: The not before claim, "nbf", indicates the time before which the JWT must not be accepted for processing. Enter a value in the range 0 - 480. The default value is 0.

entry.name: nbf_aaajwtgenerator_descr_735
entry.text: Specify a delta used to calculate the not before claim.

entry.name: custom_claims_aaajwtgenerator_help_736
entry.text: The GatewayScript or XSLT file is processed to specify the custom claim. The GatewayScript or XSLT file must be stored in the local: or store: directory.

entry.name: custom_claims_aaajwtgenerator_descr_736

entry.text: The signing and encryption methods can be used to secure and generate a JWT.

entry.name: generate_method_aaajwtgenerator_descr_737
entry.text: Specify how to secure and generate a JWT, by using signing and encryption methods.

entry.name: sign_alg_aaajwtgenerator_help_738
entry.text: Various signing algorithms can be used to generate the JWT signature, such as HS256, HS384, HS512, RS256, RS384, and RS512. The default value is RS256.

entry.name: sign_alg_aaajwtgenerator_descr_738
entry.text: Specify a signing algorithm to generate the JWT signature.

entry.name: sign_key_aaajwtgenerator_help_739
entry.text: The key alias can be used to sign the JWT. You can get a key alias by configuring the Crypto Key.

entry.name: sign_key_aaajwtgenerator_descr_739

entry.name: sign_sskey_aaajwtgenerator_help_740

entry.name: enc_aaajwtgenerator_help_741

entry.name: file_name_cryptocertificate_help_775
entry.text: Specifies the file that contains the public key and certificate. This name might be the same as the file that contains the private key. You can specify a local certificate file, a remote z/OS certificate file, or a SafeNet certificate file. For a local certificate file, access a list of files that are contained in the cert: , pubcert: , or local: file repository, and select the file that contains the certificate that is referenced by this Certificate object. #b#Attention:#/b# Any file in the local: directory can be downloaded or included in an export. Therefore, consider carefully before you store cryptographic files in this directory. For a remote z/OS certificate file, specify the location and the file name. Select saf-cert:// from the list of directories. Enter the label name of an existing SAF certificate residing on the z/OS system using the nssclient/ZOSCERTLABEL format where nssclient is an existing NSS client. See the z/OS Communications Server: IP Configuration Guide for details on label names. For a certificate file that is stored on the SafeNet HSM, specify the location and the file name. Select luna-cert:// from the list of directories. Enter the file name in one of the following formats based on whether the certificate is part of a high availability (HA) group. When part of an HA group, use the group/label format. When not part of an HA group, use the partition/label format. where, group indicates the configuration name of the HA group that contains the certificate. partition indicates the configuration name of the partition that contains the certificate. label indicates the label name of the public key on the HSM. The label name of the public key is specified by the labelPublic parameter when you generate the key with the Luna cmu generatekeypair command on the Luna HSM. The DataPower Gateway communicates with the SafeNet HSM appliance through the SafeNet HSM configuration. To use a certificate on the SafeNet HSM, the SafeNet HSM configuration must be defined and in the up operational state. The certificate must be stored in a partition that the DataPower Gateway can access. Therefore, the SafeNet HSM partition configuration must be in the up operational state.

entry.name: file_name_cryptocertificate_descr_775
entry.text: Name of the file that contains the public key and certificate

entry.name: password_cryptocertificate_help_776
entry.text: A cleartext password required to access the file containing the public key and certificate.

entry.name: password_alias_cryptocertificate_help_777
entry.text: The password alias of a cleartext password required to access the file containing the public key and certificate.

entry.name: password_alias_cryptocertificate_descr_777
entry.text: The alias of the password required to access the file containing the public key and certificate.

entry.name: ignore_expiration_cryptocertificate_help_778
entry.text: Whether to allow the creation of a certificate prior to its activation date (the NotBefore value in the certificate) or after its expiration date (the NotAfter value in the certificate). When allowed, creates the certificate and places it in the up state. Although the certificate is in the up operational state, objects that reference the certificate use the internal expiration values. In other words, the certificate itself is in the up operational state, but validation credentials, firewall credentials, and identification credentials that references the certificate adhere to the internal expiration values. If the certificate is used for a certificate chain validation from the validation credentials and the certificate is not valid, validation fails. Similarly, if the certificate is used from the identification credentials, the DataPower Gateway sends the certificate to the TLS peer for a secure connection, but the peer can reject the certificate as invalid. When disallowed, prevents the creation of a certificate outside of its internal expiration values.

entry.name: ignore_expiration_cryptocertificate_descr_778
entry.text: Whether to allow certificate-creation outside of expiration values

entry.name: ca_cryptoidentcred_help_783
entry.text: A set of one or more intermediate Certification Authority certificates. These are passed to the client so it can establish a trust-chain starting with the certificate containing the public key. CA certificates might be necessary when the CA signing this certificate containing the public key is not a standard, well-known CA. If the intermediate CA certificate is also not signed by a standard, well-known CA, an additional intermediate CA certificate might be required for that CA. As many intermediate CA certs as necessary must be specified.

entry.name: file_name_cryptokey_help_789
entry.text: Specifies the file that contains the private key. This name might be the same as the file that contains the public key. You can specify a local private key file, a remote z/OS private key file, or a SafeNet Luna key file. For a local key file, access a list of files that are contained in the cert: or local: directory, and select the file that contains the private key aliased by this key object. #b#Attention:#/b# Any file in the local: directory can be downloaded or included in an export. Therefore, consider carefully before you store cryptographic files in this directory. For a remote z/OS key file, specify the location and the file name. Select saf-key:// or saf-remote-key:// from the list of directories. A saf-key:// must be a SAF key that is not stored in ICSF. A saf-remote-key:// must be a SAF key that is stored in ICSF. Enter the label name of an existing SAF key residing on the z/OS system using the form nssclient/ZOSKEYLABEL where nssclient is an existing NSS client. See the z/OS Communications Server: IP Configuration Guide for details on label names. For a remote key file on the SafeNet Luna Network HSM, specify the location and the file name. The DataPower Gateway supports keys that are generated on only the the Luna HSM. Select luna-remote-key:// from the list of directories. Enter the file name in one of the following formats based on whether the key is part of a high availability (HA) group. When part of an HA group, use the group/label format. When not part of an HA group, use the partition/label format. where, group indicates the configuration name of the HA group that contains the key. partition indicates the configuration name of the partition that contains the key. label indicates the label name of the private key on the HSM. The label name of the private key is specified by the labelPrivate parameter when you generate the key with the Luna cmu generatekeypair command on the Luna HSM. The DataPower Gateway communicates with the Luna HSM appliance through the SafeNet Luna HSM configuration. To use a private key on the HSM, the SafeNet Luna HSM configuration must be defined and in the up operational state. The key must be stored in a partition or an HA group that the DataPower Gateway can access. Therefore, the partition or HA group configuration must be in the up operational state.

entry.text: Name of the file that contains the private key

entry.name: ciphers_cryptoprofile_help_795
entry.text: The cipher list consists of one or more cipher strings separated by colons. Commas or spaces are also acceptable separators but colons are normally used. The actual cipher string can take several different forms. It can consist of a single cipher suite such as RC4-SHA. It can represent a list of cipher suites containing a certain algorithm, or cipher suites of a certain type. For example SHA1 represents all ciphers suites using the digest algorithm SHA1 and SSLv3 represents all TLS v3 algorithms. Lists of cipher suites can be combined in a single cipher string using the + character. This is used as a logical and operation. For example SHA1+DES represents all cipher suites containing the SHA1 and the DES algorithms. Each cipher string can be optionally preceded by the characters !, - or +. If the ! character is used, the ciphers are permanently deleted from the list. The deleted ciphers can never reappear in the list even if they are explicitly stated. If the - character is used, the ciphers are deleted from the list, but some or all of the ciphers can be added again by later options. If + is used then the ciphers are moved to the end of the list. This option doesn't add any new ciphers it just moves matching existing ones. If none of these characters is present then the string is just interpreted as a list of ciphers to be appended to the current preference list. If the list includes any ciphers already present they will be ignored: that is they will not moved to the end of the list. Additionally the cipher string @STRENGTH can be used at any point to sort the current cipher list in order of encryption algorithm key length. Note that as of firmware release 7.2.0.0 the default value of this property is now #b#HIGH:MEDIUM:!aNULL:!eNULL:!RC4:@STRENGTH#/b#. Before firmware release 7.2.0.0 the default value was #b#HIGH:MEDIUM:!aNULL:!eNULL:@STRENGTH#/b#. Here are all of the permitted cipher strings and their meanings. DEFAULT All cipher suites (including weak export ciphers) except the aNULL and eNULL ciphers. ALL All ciphers suites except the eNULL ciphers which must be explicitly enabled. HIGH "high" encryption cipher suites, currently AES or 3DES. MEDIUM "medium" encryption cipher suites, currently 128 bit RC2 and 128 bit RC4. LOW "low" encryption cipher suites, currently 64 bit RC4 and 56 bit DES non-export cipher suites. EXP, EXPORT Export (weak) encryption algorithms including 40 and 56 bits algorithms. EXPORT40 40 bit export (weak) encryption algorithms. EXPORT56 56 bit export (weak) encryption algorithms. eNULL, NULL Cipher suites offering no encryption. Because using no encryption is a security risk they are disabled unless explicitly included. aNULL Cipher suites offering no authentication. This is currently the anonymous DH algorithms. These cipher suites are vulnerable to a "man in the middle" attack so their use is normally discouraged. kRSA, RSA Cipher suites using RSA key exchange. kEDH Cipher suites using ephemeral DH key agreement. These cipher suites are only supported when acting as a client. aRSA Cipher suites using RSA authentication, that is, the certificates carry RSA keys. aDSS, DSS Cipher suites using DSS authentication, that is, the certificates carry DSS keys. TLSv1, SSLv3, SSLv2 TLS v1.0, TLS v3.0 or TLS v2.0 cipher suites respectively. DH Cipher suites using DH, including anonymous DH. ADH Anonymous DH cipher suites. 3DES Cipher suites using triple DES. DES Cipher suites using DES (not triple DES). RC4 Cipher suites using RC4. RC2 Cipher suites using RC2. MD5 Cipher suites using MD5. SHA1, SHA Cipher suites using SHA1. AES Cipher suites using AES.

entry.name: social_login_policy_kconfigcrypto_help_847

entry.name: client_scope_socialloginpolicy_help_853
entry.text: Specifies the scope value that defines what access privileges are requested for access tokens, ID tokens, or both. Use space separated strings. For example, openid email .

entry.name: client_scope_socialloginpolicy_descr_853
entry.text: What access privileges are requested

entry.name: client_redirect_uri_socialloginpolicy_help_854
entry.text: Specifies the URI that the social login policy redirects the client to after the client obtains a code or an access token. The URI must match with what is registered at the social login provider for DataPower as the OAuth/OIDC client. The URI is included in the OAuth/OIDC client request that DataPower generates. Note that the social login provider Google mandates that the redirect URI must be a fully qualified host name instead of an IP address. Note that the redirect URI should end with the suffix '/social-login-callback' in the pathname in order to differentiate between the callback requests and other types of requests coming into the service. You can specify the value of this redirect URI in the following forms. Static string. Enter a static string as the redirect URI. Must end with the suffix '/social-login-callback'. URL-in/suffix. In this case, it takes the value from the inbound URL service variable var://service/URL-in and then suffixes the value with whatever is specified after URL-in as the redirect URI. For example, the value of this property is 'URL-in/social-login-callback' and the incoming URL is 'https://datapower.ibm.com:10087/getresources', then the redirect URI is constructed as 'https://datapower.ibm.com:10087/getresources/social-login-callback'. Context variable. You can set a context variable before you invoke this AAA action and specify the context variable name for this value. For example, var://context/AAA/social-login-redirect-uri

entry.name: client_redirect_uri_socialloginpolicy_descr_854
entry.text: Where the user is redirected back to DataPower to process the code or access token from the social login provider

entry.name: client_opt_query_params_socialloginpolicy_help_855
entry.text: Specifies the optional query parameters to include in the initial OAuth/OIDC request that DataPower sends to the social login provider. Enter the optional query parameters as name=value pairs and separate each pair with an ampersand. For example, prompt=consent&login_hint=jsmith@example.com&openid.realm=example.comi&hd=example.com.

entry.name: client_opt_query_params_socialloginpolicy_descr_855
entry.text: The optional query parameters to include in the initial OAuth/OIDC request that DataPower sends to the social login provider

entry.text: Specifies the TLS client profile to secure connections when DataPower obtains an access token from the social login provider.

entry.name: client_ssl_socialloginpolicy_descr_856
entry.text: The TLS client profile to secure connections with the social login provider

entry.name: provider_socialloginpolicy_help_857
entry.text: Controls which social login provider to use.

entry.name: provider_socialloginpolicy_descr_857
entry.text: Which social login provider to use

entry.name: provider_az_endpoint_socialloginpolicy_help_858
entry.text: Specify the provider's endpoint URL that accepts an authorization request from a client to perform social login with the provider. When the provider is Google, you can retrieve the authorization endpoint URL from the Discovery document for Google's OpenID Connect service.

entry.name: provider_az_endpoint_socialloginpolicy_descr_858
entry.text: The provider's endpoint URL that accepts an authorization request from a client to perform social login with the provider

entry.name: provider_token_endpoint_socialloginpolicy_help_859
entry.text: Specify the provider's endpoint URL that accepts an authorization grant, or code, from a client in exchange for an access token from the social login provider. When the provider is Google, you can retrieve the token endpoint URL from the Discovery document for Google's OpenID Connect service.

entry.name: provider_token_endpoint_socialloginpolicy_descr_859
entry.text: The provider's endpoint URL that accepts an authorization grant, or code, from a client in exchange for an access token from the social login provider

entry.name: validate_jwt_token_socialloginpolicy_help_860
entry.text: Controls whether to validate the JWT token (ID token)from the provider. If yes, it is recommended that you validate the ID token that is obtained from Google by defining the following settings in the JWT Validator configuration. Verify the signature by fetching the certs from https://www.googleapis.com/oauth2/v3/certs Verify that the aud claim matches the client ID of DataPower. Verify that the iss claim matches accounts.google.com or https://accounts.google.com For other recommendations on validating the ID token from Google, see https://developers.google.com/identity/protocols/OpenIDConnect.

entry.name: validate_jwt_token_socialloginpolicy_descr_860
entry.text: Whether to validate the JWT token from the provider

entry.name: jwt_validator_socialloginpolicy_help_861
entry.text: Specify the JWT Validator configuration that defines how to validate and verify the ID token.

entry.name: jwt_validator_socialloginpolicy_descr_861
entry.text: The JWT Validator configuration

entry.name: sshclientprofile_kconfigcrypto_help_862
entry.text: An SSH Client Profile is associated with an SSH URLOpener or with a Secure Cloud Connector. Also, a Secure Cloud Connection requires an Application Optimization license. The remote server's public key must be contained in the SSH Client Profile known hosts list.

entry.name: profile_usage_sshclientprofile_help_866
entry.text: Specifies the usage of the profile. The usage can be either sftp or scc, but not both. scc is deprecated. If the profile is to be used with the SFTP protocol, the usage must be sftp. If the profile is to be used with a Secure Cloud Connector, the usage must be scc.

entry.text: Specifies the type(s) of SSH user authentication available for use by the client. Authentication can be either public key or password or both public key and password. If the configuration includes both authentication methods, public key authentication is attempted first.

entry.name: persistent_connections_sshclientprofile_help_871
entry.text: When on, persistent connections are enabled. Persistent connections allow new SSH requests to reuse the connection of a previous SSH session without having to reauthenticate. When off, persistent connections are disabled. The default is on.

entry.name: persistent_connections_sshclientprofile_descr_871
entry.text: Enable/Disable persistent connections for objects using this profile

entry.name: persistent_connection_timeout_sshclientprofile_help_872
entry.text: Specifies the number of seconds that a persistent connection can remain idle before closing the connection. Enter any value of 1 - 86000. The default is 120.

entry.name: persistent_connection_timeout_sshclientprofile_descr_872
entry.text: Timeout in seconds that a persistent connection can remain idle before closing the connection.

entry.name: strict_host_key_checking_sshclientprofile_help_873
entry.text: Specifies how host keys are checked during the connection and authentication phase. By default strict host key checking is disabled. The SSH client verifies the incoming host key against the keys in the known hosts list. If the host key does not match an existing known host entry for the remote server, the connection is rejected. If the known host list does not contain a host key for the remote server, the SSH client automatically accepts the host and adds its host key to the known host list. When strict host key checking is enabled, the SSH client connects only to known hosts with valid SSH host keys that are stored in the known hosts list. Host keys not listed in the known host list are rejected.

entry.name: client_auth_optional_sslproxyprofile_help_921
entry.text: When acting as a TLS server and performing client authentications, requests but does not require TLS client authentication. This property is meaningful when TLS client authentication is enabled in the server crypto profile. When both properties are enabled, TLS client authentication is optional. The request does not fail when there is no client certificate. When disabled (the default), TLS client authentication is required by the application server.

entry.name: client_auth_always_request_sslproxyprofile_help_922
entry.text: When acting as a TLS server, always request TLS client authentication even when there are no validation credentials present in the server crypto profile. When disabled (the default), the TLS server only requests TLS client authentication when validation credentials are present in the server crypto profile.

entry.name: permit_insecure_servers_sslproxyprofile_help_923
entry.text: When acting as a TLS client, specifies whether to permit connections to TLS servers that do not support RFC 5746. Such servers are vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks as documented in CVE-2009-3555. The default is off, which means reject insecure connections during the TLS handshake.

entry.name: require_client_auth_sslserverprofile_help_931
entry.text: Indicate whether to require client authentication during the TLS handshake. When enabled, the handshake is aborted if the client certificate is not provided. When disabled, the request does not fail when there is no client certificate.

entry.name: compression_sslserverprofile_help_942
entry.text: Indicate whether to enable TLS compression. Enabling TLS compression in HTTPS is dangerous because the connection becomes vulnerable to the CRIME attack.

entry.name: compression_sslserverprofile_descr_942

entry.name: allow_legacy_renegotiation_sslserverprofile_help_943
entry.text: Indicate whether to allow TLS renegotiation with TLS clients that do not support RFC 5746. By default, this support is disabled because renegotiation with such clients is vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks as documented in CVE-2009-3555. Renegotiation with TLS clients that support RFC 5746 is permitted regardless of the setting specified.

entry.name: allow_legacy_renegotiation_sslserverprofile_descr_943
entry.text: Whether to allow TLS renegotiation with TLS clients that do not support RFC 5746.

entry.name: prioritize_chacha_sslserverprofile_help_946
entry.text: When server cipher suite preferences is in effect, enabling this property will temporarily move ChaCha20-Poly1305 cipher to the top of preference list if clients that present ChaCha20-Poly1305 cipher also have it at the top of their preference list. This allows the client to negotiate ChaCha20-Poly1305 cipher while other clients can use other ciphers.

entry.name: prioritize_chacha_sslserverprofile_descr_946
entry.text: Whether to move ChaCha20-Poly1305 cipher to the top of preference list sent to the client if this cipher is also at the top of client's cipher list

entry.name: sni_server_default_sslsniserverprofile_help_957
entry.text: Select the TLS server profile to process the request when the ClientHello SNI extension is not provided. When the default server profile is defined, the following rules apply. When the client does not send a ClientHello SNI extension, the default server profile processes the request. When the client sends a ClientHello SNI extension but it does not match a configured host name mapping, the request is rejected. When not defined and the client does not send a ClientHello SNI extension, the request is rejected.

entry.text: DFDL Settings

entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: summary_dfdlsettings_descr_974
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation

entry.name: dfdl_validation_dfdlsettings_help_975
entry.text: Enable additional runtime checks to verify that binary data is fully valid according to the DFDL schema. These checks are in addition to the checks that are needed to parse or serialize the data.

entry.name: dfdl_validation_dfdlsettings_descr_975
entry.text: Enable additional runtime checks to verify that binary data is fully valid according to the DFDL schema.

entry.name: dfdl_strict_validation_dfdlsettings_help_976
entry.text: Additional DFDL runtime checks verify that binary data is fully valid according to the DFDL schema. These runtime checks are in addition to the checks that are needed to parse or serialize the data. Because these checks are not needed to complete processing, an error can be reported as a warning and ignored in Lax Mode, or can be treated as an error in Strict Mode. This property is only relevant if DFDL Validation is enabled.

entry.name: dfdl_strict_validation_dfdlsettings_descr_976
entry.text: Error if there is a runtime DFDL validation error, instead of warning.

entry.name: dfdl_ignore_trailing_data_dfdlsettings_help_977
entry.text: Enable DFDL processing to ignore any trailing data after completion of a good recognized message, for example during processing of a single message as part of batch processing. This setting is off by default, which is the stricter and more secure setting because it does not allow extraneous extra data after the message. You can enable this setting if you are expecting such data. One example use case scenario to enable this setting is batch processing. Another example use case scenario to enable this setting is to read only the front of a message to make a routing decision or some other decision. This settings only applies to DFDL parsing, and does not apply to DFDL serialization.

entry.name: dfdl_ignore_trailing_data_dfdlsettings_descr_977
entry.text: Instruct DFDL processing to ignore any trailing data after completion of a good recognized message, for example during processing of a single message as part of batch processing.

entry.name: dfdl_encoding_default_dfdlsettings_help_978
entry.text: Inside a DFDL Schema, the value of $dfdl:encoding carries the system assumption of encoding. You can use that variable within a DFDL schema to make it more resilient for systems that require different encodings, depending on transport header values, and so on. If the encoding value is not determined by the system based on the transport headers, then the system defaults to the value of this field. If the value is calculated from transport headers, then this field is not used.

entry.name: dfdl_encoding_default_dfdlsettings_descr_978
entry.text: DFDL Default Encoding

entry.name: dfdl_byte_order_default_dfdlsettings_help_979
entry.text: Inside a DFDL Schema, the value of $dfdl:byteOrder carries the system assumption of byte order. You can use that variable within a DFDL schema to make it more resilient for systems that require different byte orders, depending on transport header values, and so on. If the byte order value is not determined by the system based on the transport headers, then the system defaults to the value of this field. If the value is calculated from transport headers, then this field is not used.

entry.name: dfdl_byte_order_default_dfdlsettings_descr_979
entry.text: DFDL Default Byte Order

entry.name: dfdl_binary_float_rep_default_dfdlsettings_help_980
entry.text: Inside a DFDL Schema, the value of $dfdl:binaryFloatRep carries the system assumption of choice of binary float representation. You can use that variable within a DFDL schema to make it more resilient for systems which require different binary float representations, depending on transport header values, and so on. If the binary float representation value is not determined by the system based on the transport headers, then the system defaults to the value of this field. If the value is calculated from transport headers, then this field is not used.

entry.name: dfdl_binary_float_rep_default_dfdlsettings_descr_980
entry.text: DFDL Default Binary Float Representation

entry.name: dfdl_output_new_line_default_dfdlsettings_help_981
entry.text: Inside a DFDL Schema, the value of $dfdl:outputNewLine carries the value that is set here. You can use that variable within a DFDL schema to make it more resilient for systems which require carriage return and line feed at the end of a line, and other systems that require only a line feed. You can configure the system preference to control the DFDL Schema using this setting. The value specifies the character or characters that are used to replace the %%NL; character class entity during unparse.

entry.name: dfdl_output_new_line_default_dfdlsettings_descr_981
entry.text: DFDL Default New Line

entry.name: dfdl_user_trace_dfdlsettings_help_982
entry.text: Enable DFDL processing of user trace messages to be calculated and sent to the DataPower log at various log levels. CAUTION: Do not leave the DFDL user trace enabled in production conditions. Disable the DFDL user trace before you move the configuration into production.

entry.name: dfdl_user_trace_dfdlsettings_descr_982
entry.text: Enable DFDL processing user trace messages.

entry.text: Specify the protocol to upload log files.

entry.name: upload_method_tracetarget_descr_1021
entry.text: Protocol to upload log files

entry.name: rotate_tracetarget_help_1022
entry.text: Specify the maximum number of rotations. Enter a value in the range 1 - 100. The default value is 3.

entry.name: rotate_tracetarget_descr_1022
entry.text: Maximum number of rotations

entry.name: ansi_color_tracetarget_help_1023
entry.text: Enables the use of ANSI X3.64 escape sequences to color-code messages by log level.

entry.name: ansi_color_tracetarget_descr_1023
entry.text: Use ANSI color scheme

entry.name: remote_address_tracetarget_help_1024
entry.text: Specify the host name or IP address of the remote server. To establish a secure TLS connection to the server, set this value to the value of the remote host of a TLS proxy service. The local TLS proxy service then securely forwards the log entries to its configured remote server.

entry.name: remote_address_tracetarget_descr_1024
entry.text: Host name or IP address of remote server

entry.name: remote_port_tracetarget_help_1025
entry.text: Specify the listening port on the remote server. If using a local TLS proxy service to establish a secure TLS connection, set this value to the value of the remote port of the TLS proxy service.

entry.name: remote_port_tracetarget_descr_1025
entry.text: Listening port on remote server.

entry.name: remote_login_tracetarget_help_1026
entry.text: Specify the account or user name to access the remote server.

entry.name: remote_login_tracetarget_descr_1026
entry.text: Account or user name

entry.name: remote_directory_tracetarget_help_1027
entry.text: Specify an existing writable directory on the remote server to which to upload files. To denote an absolute directory from the root directory, specify a single forward slash character (/) or equivalent encoded character (%%2F) before the fully qualified path. For SCP or SFTP, enter / to resolve to //. For FTP, enter %%2F to resolve to /%%2F. To denote a directory that is relative to the user's home directory, do not specify a forward slash character or encoded character before the fully qualified file name.

entry.name: remote_directory_tracetarget_descr_1027
entry.text: Directory on the remote server

entry.name: local_address_tracetarget_help_1028
entry.text: Specify a host alias or IP address of a local interface.

entry.name: local_address_tracetarget_descr_1028
entry.text: Local address

entry.name: facility_tracetarget_help_1029
entry.text: Set the log facility (per RFC 3164) to include in messages sent to the syslog log target.

entry.name: facility_tracetarget_descr_1029
entry.text: syslog facility

entry.name: rate_limit_tracetarget_help_1030
entry.text: Set the maximum number of events to be logged per second. Enter a value in the range 1 - 1000. The default value is 100. Remote log targets might receive more than this number of events within a second, depending on network latency and buffering. syslog over TCP log targets are exclusive, because only a single TCP connection is made to the server. In the case of syslog over TCP log targets, the rate limit is the maximum number of events transmitted over the connection within one second. A value of 0 disables rate-limiting by the logging target.

entry.name: rate_limit_tracetarget_descr_1030
entry.text: The maximum number of events logged

entry.name: maximum_connections_tracetarget_help_1031
entry.text: Set the maximum number of concurrent connections that can be opened to the syslog-tcp server. Enter a value in the range 1 - 100. The default value is 1.

entry.name: maximum_connections_tracetarget_descr_1031
entry.text: Maximum number of concurrent connections to open

entry.name: connect_timeout_tracetarget_help_1032
entry.text: Set the number of seconds to wait for a connection to the server to be established before generating an error. A log message will be generated in the default log and connection retry attempts will be made. Enter a value in the range 1 - 90. The default value is 60.

entry.name: connect_timeout_tracetarget_descr_1032
entry.text: Number of seconds to wait for a connection to the server to be established before generating an error.

entry.name: idle_timeout_tracetarget_help_1033
entry.text: Set the number of seconds to wait before closing an established but inactive connection to the server. Enter a value in the range 1 - 600. The default value is 15. Attention: If multiple log targets have the following configuration, they might share connections. The same local address and port The same remote address and port Because of potential connection-sharing, set the same idle timeout value for these log targets.

entry.name: idle_timeout_tracetarget_descr_1033
entry.text: Number of seconds to wait before closing an established but inactive connection to the server.

entry.name: active_timeout_tracetarget_help_1034
entry.text: Set the number of seconds to wait before closing an established and active connection to the server. Enter a value in the range 0 - 60. A value of 0 allows the log target to most efficiently send messages to the server by maintaining a healthy connection indefinitely. The default value is 0. Attention: If multiple log targets have the following configuration, they might share connections. The same local address and port The same remote address and port Because of potential connection-sharing, set the same active timeout value for these log targets.

entry.name: active_timeout_tracetarget_descr_1034
entry.text: Number of seconds to wait before closing an established and active connection to the server.

entry.name: feedback_detection_tracetarget_help_1035
entry.text: Indicate whether to suppress events from the logging subsystem itself. A log target always suppresses its own events, but will record events from other log targets. Under certain circumstances with multiple log targets, these events could create a positive feedback loop that could cause resource contention. Enable to suppress all log events from the logging subsystem and prevent resource contention.

entry.name: feedback_detection_tracetarget_descr_1035
entry.text: Whether to suppress events from logging subsystem

entry.name: event_detection_tracetarget_help_1036
entry.text: Indicate whether to suppress identical events from the same object over a set time period. When enabled, the log target records only one instance of the event until the suppression period expires.

entry.name: event_detection_tracetarget_descr_1036
entry.text: Suppress identical events

entry.name: suppression_period_tracetarget_help_1037
entry.text: Set the duration of the suppression period. The default value is 10.

entry.name: suppression_period_tracetarget_descr_1037
entry.text: Duration to suppress identical events

entry.name: event_code_tracetarget_help_1038
entry.text: Subscription filters allow only those log messages that contain the configured event codes to be written to this log target. With this filter, it is possible to create a log target that collects only log messages for a specific set of event codes.

entry.name: event_code_tracetarget_descr_1038
entry.text: Filter to log specific event codes

entry.name: event_filter_tracetarget_help_1039
entry.text: Suppression filters suppress those log messages that contain the configured event codes to be written to this log target. With this filter, it is possible to create a log target that collects a wide range of log messages except for a specific set of event codes.

entry.name: event_filter_tracetarget_descr_1039
entry.text: Filter to suppress specific event codes

entry.name: object_tracetarget_help_1040
entry.text: Object filters allow only those log messages for specific objects to be written to this log target. Object filters are based on object classes. With this filter, you can create a log target that collects only log messages generated by particular instances of the specified object classes.

entry.name: object_tracetarget_descr_1040
entry.text: Filter to log events for specific objects

entry.name: ip_filter_tracetarget_help_1041
entry.text: IP address filters allow only those log messages from specific IP addresses to be written to this log target.

entry.name: ip_filter_tracetarget_descr_1041
entry.text: Filter to log events for specific IP addresses

entry.name: trigger_tracetarget_help_1042
entry.text: Event triggers perform actions only when triggered by a specified message ID or event code. With this filter, it is possible to create a log target that collects only the results of the specified trigger action. For example, to trigger the generation of an error report when a certain event occurs use the #b#save error-report#/b# command.

entry.name: trigger_tracetarget_descr_1042
entry.text: Event trigger points

entry.name: ssl_client_tracetarget_help_1043
entry.text: The TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

entry.name: ssl_client_tracetarget_descr_1043
entry.text: Set the TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets

entry.name: ssl_client_type_tracetarget_help_1044
entry.text: The TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_tracetarget_descr_1044
entry.text: Set the TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets

entry.name: retry_interval_tracetarget_help_1045
entry.text: Specify the number of seconds to wait before attempting to reestablish a failed connection to the syslog server. Enter a value in the range 1 - 600. The default value is 1.

entry.name: retry_interval_tracetarget_descr_1045
entry.text: Time to wait before attempting to reestablish a failed connection

entry.name: retry_attempts_tracetarget_help_1046
entry.text: Specify the number of attempts for a failed connection to the syslog server. After the number of attempts is reached, connection attempts use the value set by #b#Long Retry Interval#/b#. When the long interval is disabled, the log target repeatedly attempts to reconnect to the syslog server with the value set by #b#Retry Interval#/b#. #b#Note:#/b# 0 means the #b#Long Retry Interval#/b# will not be used and will retry forever using #b#Retry Interval#/b#.

entry.name: retry_attempts_tracetarget_descr_1046
entry.text: The number of attempts to retry the failed connections

entry.name: long_retry_interval_tracetarget_help_1047
entry.text: Specify the time to wait before attempting to reestablish a failed connection to the syslog server after the number of attempts is reached. Enter a value in the range 0 - 600. The default value is 20. #b#Note:#/b# The #b#Long Retry Interval#/b# must be greater than the #b#Retry Interval#/b# or it will take no effect.

entry.name: long_retry_interval_tracetarget_descr_1047
entry.text: Long retry interval before retrying the failed connections

entry.name: precision_tracetarget_help_1048
entry.text: Log timestamp precision configuration of the format of the timestamp of the log messages.

entry.name: precision_tracetarget_descr_1048
entry.text: Log timestamp precision

entry.name: buffer_size_tracetarget_help_1049
entry.text: Sets the buffer size in number of event entries to store log events before they are written to the target.The buffer of this size is allocated for each connection.

entry.name: buffer_size_tracetarget_descr_1049
entry.text: Buffer size

entry.name: backup_tracetarget_help_1050
entry.text: Allows setting of a backup trace target to redirect events to in case of an error on the current trace target

entry.name: backup_tracetarget_descr_1050
entry.text: Backup Trace Target

entry.name: event_tracetarget_help_1051
entry.text: Defines the log events the current trace target is subscribed to

entry.name: event_tracetarget_descr_1051
entry.text: Trace event subscription

entry.text: File system operations for Fibre Channel devices. When the volume's operational state changes from up to down, existing transactions using the volume will attempt to complete prior to the volume becoming inaccessible.

entry.name: read_only_fibrechannelvolume_help_1065
entry.text: Set the access permission to files on the storage volume. When set to "on", the access permission is read-only. When set to "off", the default value, the access permission is read-write.

entry.name: read_only_fibrechannelvolume_descr_1065
entry.text: Allow only file reads on this Fibre Channel Volume.

entry.name: directory_fibrechannelvolume_help_1066
entry.text: Specify the subdirectory in the local: directory where the files on the storage volume are available. Each application domain contains these subdirectories. These subdirectories are not shared across application domains. The name can be up to 64 characters long. The name cannot start with a period. The name can consist of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, numeric digits, dashes, underscores, and periods.

entry.name: directory_fibrechannelvolume_descr_1066
entry.text: Directory name

entry.name: lun_fibrechannelvolume_help_1067
entry.text: Specify the Logical Unit Number (LUN). Use an integer in the range of 0 through 255.

entry.name: lun_fibrechannelvolume_descr_1067

entry.name: lun_uid_fibrechannelvolume_help_1068
entry.text: Specify the globally unique type 3 (FC Name_Identifier) or type 2 (IEEE EUI-64) LUID which should be used to locate this device. Provide the 128 bit or 64 bit value as a hexadecimal string.

entry.name: lun_uid_fibrechannelvolume_descr_1068

entry.name: forms_login_policy_kglobalconfig_help_1073
entry.text: The HTML forms login policy defines the details for collecting user authentication information.

entry.name: forms_login_policy_kglobalconfig_descr_1073
entry.text: HTML Forms Login Policy

entry.name: admin_state_formsloginpolicy_help_1074
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_formsloginpolicy_descr_1074
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_formsloginpolicy_descr_1075
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: login_url_formsloginpolicy_help_1076
entry.text: The URL fragment of the login page on the application server. The login page collects user name and password information. The default is /LoginPage.htm.

entry.name: login_url_formsloginpolicy_descr_1076
entry.text: URL fragment of login form

entry.name: use_cookie_attribute_formsloginpolicy_help_1077
entry.text: Whether to attach a cookie attribute policy. If you do not use a cookie attribute policy, the configuration use the properties of the forms login policy. The default behavior is not to attach a cookie attribute policy.

entry.name: use_cookie_attribute_formsloginpolicy_descr_1077
entry.text: Indicate whether to attach a policy that describes cookie attributes.

entry.name: cookie_attributes_formsloginpolicy_help_1078
entry.text: Use a cookie attribute policy to allow predefined or custom attributes to be included in forms login cookie. Properties in the policy override common attributes of the forms login policy. Max-Age overrides inactivity timeout and session lifetime. Path replaces the form POST action URL. Secure replaces the use TLS for login.

entry.name: cookie_attributes_formsloginpolicy_descr_1078
entry.text: Set the policy that describes cookie attributes.

entry.name: use_ssl_formsloginpolicy_help_1079
entry.text: Whether to use a secure connection for the login exchange. If enabled, you must provide the TLS port. The default is enabled.

entry.name: use_ssl_formsloginpolicy_descr_1079
entry.text: Whether to use TLS for the login

entry.name: enable_migration_formsloginpolicy_help_1080
entry.text: Whether to permit session failover between cluster members. If enabled, you must specify a shared secret. The default is disabled.

entry.name: enable_migration_formsloginpolicy_descr_1080
entry.text: Whether to allow sessions to migrate between cluster members if a DataPower Gateway fails

entry.name: ssl_port_formsloginpolicy_help_1081
entry.text: The port the service uses for TLS redirection during the login transaction. Specify the port of the HTTPS handler that the Web application firewall uses for secure communication. The default is 8080.

entry.name: ssl_port_formsloginpolicy_descr_1081
entry.text: Port for TLS login redirection

entry.name: shared_secret_formsloginpolicy_help_1082
entry.text: Shared secret object that will be used to protect the migration cookie. All cluster members must specify the same shared secret.

entry.name: shared_secret_formsloginpolicy_descr_1082
entry.text: Shared secret, common to all DataPower Gateways to which a session may migrate

entry.name: error_url_formsloginpolicy_help_1083
entry.text: The URL fragment of the error page on the application server. The error page is displayed after a login failure. The default is /ErrorPage.htm.

entry.name: error_url_formsloginpolicy_descr_1083
entry.text: URL fragment of error page

entry.name: logout_url_formsloginpolicy_help_1084
entry.text: The URL fragment of the logout page on the application server. An empty string disables logout. The default is /LogoutPage.htm.

entry.name: logout_url_formsloginpolicy_descr_1084
entry.text: URL of logout page

entry.name: default_url_formsloginpolicy_help_1085
entry.text: The URL fragment to visit after a successful login when no other target is available. In most cases, login is triggered via an attempt to access a URL in the application, and the client is redirected to this URL after successfully logging in. However, if users explicitly visit the URL of the login form, they are redirected to this URL after logging in. This URL fragment is relative to the root directory. Although the default is /, you must specify the filename of the page to go after a successful login.

entry.name: default_url_formsloginpolicy_descr_1085
entry.text: URL fragment to go to after successful login

entry.name: forms_location_formsloginpolicy_help_1086

entry.text: Location of HTML pages

entry.text: The location of the login form on the DataPower Gateway. The default is store:///LoginPage.htm.

entry.name: local_login_page_formsloginpolicy_descr_1087
entry.text: Location of local login form

entry.text: The location of the error page on the DataPower Gateway. The default is store:///ErrorPage.htm.

entry.name: local_error_page_formsloginpolicy_descr_1088
entry.text: Location of local error page

entry.text: The location of the logout page on the DataPower Gateway. The default is store:///LogoutPage.htm.

entry.name: local_logout_page_formsloginpolicy_descr_1089
entry.text: Location of local logout page

entry.text: The value of the 'name' attribute for the user name field on the login form. The default is j_username.

entry.name: username_field_formsloginpolicy_descr_1090
entry.text: Attribute value of the user name field

entry.name: password_field_formsloginpolicy_help_1091
entry.text: The value of the 'name' attribute for the password field on the login form. The default is j_password.

entry.name: password_field_formsloginpolicy_descr_1091

entry.name: inactivity_timeout_formsloginpolicy_help_1094

entry.name: inactivity_timeout_formsloginpolicy_descr_1094

entry.name: session_lifetime_formsloginpolicy_help_1095
entry.text: The maximum time in seconds that a session can persist before that session becomes invalid and requires re-authentication. The minimum value is 1. The default is 10800.

entry.name: session_lifetime_formsloginpolicy_descr_1095
entry.text: Maximum time before requiring re-authentication

entry.name: redirect_url_type_formsloginpolicy_help_1096
entry.text: Control how the service retrieves host information for HTTP URL-redirects. The default behavior is to use the variable value.

entry.name: redirect_url_type_formsloginpolicy_descr_1096
entry.text: How to retrieve host information for HTTP URL-redirects

entry.name: support_type_formsloginpolicy_help_1098
entry.text: Manage the source for HTML pages. The default behavior is to use static HTML pages from an explicit location.

entry.name: support_type_formsloginpolicy_descr_1098
entry.text: Source for HTML pages

entry.name: script_location_formsloginpolicy_help_1099
entry.text: Specify the location of the custom XSLT stylesheet or GatewayScript file that generates the HTML pages. This stylesheet or GatewayScript file must generate the following HTML pages: A login form request allows processing to generate a login form with the login operation. A logout page request allows processing to generate a logout page with the logout operation. An error page request allows processing to generate an error page with the error operation.

entry.name: script_location_formsloginpolicy_descr_1099
entry.text: Location of the custom processing to generate HTML pages and form

entry.name: mpgw_kglobalconfig_help_1102
entry.text: A Multi-Protocol Gateway service can accept client-originated messages in a variety of protocols. The Gateway can subsequently pass messages to a back end server using a variety of protocols. The protocol used on the client side need not be the same as that on the back side. A Gateway can support more than one client, or Front Side, protocol. Similarly, the Gateway can support more than one back side, or server protocol. The messages may be processed and routed using any of the standard Document Processing Actions available to a firewall or a proxy.

entry.name: mpgw_kglobalconfig_descr_1102
entry.text: Multi-Protocol Gateway

entry.name: xml_manager_multiprotocolgateway_help_1107
entry.text: An XML Manager manages the compilation and caching of style sheets, the caching of documents, and provides configuration constraints on the size and parsing depth of documents. You can enable streaming operation by configuring an XML Manager to use a Streaming Compile Option Policy. Optionally, an XML Manager can employ a User Agent. The User Agent settings, in turn, can affect the behavior of the gateway when communicating with remote servers or with clients when sending back responses.

entry.name: xml_manager_multiprotocolgateway_descr_1107
entry.text: XML manager

entry.name: urlrewrite_policy_multiprotocolgateway_help_1108
entry.text: Define a URL Rewrite Policy that defines rules for the following rewrite and replacement operations: Rewrite the entire URL or a portion of the URL Replace a header value in a message Rewrite the HTTP POST body in a message The rewrite rules are applied before document processing. Therefore, the evaluation criteria in the Matching Rule is against the rewritten value.

entry.name: urlrewrite_policy_multiprotocolgateway_descr_1108
entry.text: URL rewrite policy

entry.text: Set the TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets

entry.text: The TLS proxy profile with the cryptographic profiles to secure connections.

entry.text: The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile.
