entry.name: summary_ethernetinterface_help_1454
entry.text: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

entry.name: summary_ethernetinterface_descr_1454
entry.text: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.

entry.name: ip_config_mode_ethernetinterface_help_1455
entry.text: The configuration mode of the interface. Although you can set multiple modes, only one mode is supported. With static configuration, you must define the configuration for the physical interface. Assign the primary network address. Manage secondary, or auxiliary, network addresses. Assign the default IPv4 gateway. Assign the default IPv6 gateway, if you define IPv6 IP addresses. Manage static routes in the routing table. With DHCP autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface. With SLAAC autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.

entry.name: ip_config_mode_ethernetinterface_descr_1455
entry.text: Set the configuration mode for the interface.

entry.name: ip_address_ethernetinterface_help_1456
entry.text: The IP address and netmask of the primary IP address. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation. For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32. For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.

entry.name: ip_address_ethernetinterface_descr_1456
entry.text: Set the primary IP address and netmask.

entry.name: ipv4_default_gateway_ethernetinterface_help_1457
entry.text: The IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway. All IPv4 network addresses use this gateway.

entry.name: ipv4_default_gateway_ethernetinterface_descr_1457
entry.text: Set the IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway.

entry.name: ipv6_default_gateway_ethernetinterface_help_1458
entry.text: The IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway. All IPv6 network addresses use this gateway. If you do not use IPv6 network addresses, do not define this property.

entry.name: ipv6_default_gateway_ethernetinterface_descr_1458
entry.text: Set the IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway.

entry.name: ip_secondary_address_ethernetinterface_help_1459
entry.text: The IP addresses and netmasks of secondary IP addresses. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation. For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32. For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.

entry.name: ip_secondary_address_ethernetinterface_descr_1459
entry.text: Set secondary IP addresses and netmasks.

entry.name: ip_route_ethernetinterface_help_1460
entry.text: The static routes in the routing table. Add a static route to a remote IP prefix through a router connected to this network. When the appliance connects to a remote address, the static route with the longest prefix match is used. If multiple routes have the same prefix match, the static route with the lowest metric is used. If the metric is the same, the static route is chosen randomly.

entry.name: ip_route_ethernetinterface_descr_1460
entry.text: Manage the static routes in the routing table.

entry.name: ipv6_dadtransmits_ethernetinterface_help_1461
entry.text: The number of IPv6 duplication address detection (DAD) attempts. The default value is 1.

entry.name: ipv6_dadtransmits_ethernetinterface_descr_1461
entry.text: Set the number of IPv6 duplication address detection attempts.

entry.name: ipv6_nd_retransmit_timer_ethernetinterface_help_1462
entry.text: The delay between IPv6 Neighbor Discovery (ND) attempts. The default value is 1000. This property affects duplication address detection (DAD) and other ND operations.

entry.name: ipv6_nd_retransmit_timer_ethernetinterface_descr_1462
entry.text: Set the delay between IPv6 neighbor discovery (ND) attempts.

entry.name: standby_enable_ethernetinterface_help_1463
entry.text: Whether to allow a standby configuration. The standby configuration defines the policies for the group that this interface is a member. A standby group is the collection of interfaces on different appliances in the multicast domain that share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. When at least one member of a standby group can reach the multicast domain, the virtual IP group receives the traffic. #b#Attention:#/b# Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.

entry.name: standby_enable_ethernetinterface_descr_1463
entry.text: Indicate whether to allow a standby configuration.

entry.name: standby_group_ethernetinterface_help_1464
entry.text: The number of the standby group in a multicast domain. The multicast domain is a group of interfaces that receive traffic from each other on the IP address 224.0.0.2 (the all-routers IP multicast group). If the multicast domain becomes partitioned, which is an unusual situation, a member in each partition becomes the active member to handle connections in its partition. #b#Attention:#/b# Do not use a group number that conflicts with the number of an existing standby group or any network group that uses Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP). The interfaces of a standby group are on the same network segment and share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. Interfaces in the standby group require the following configuration. Belong to the same group. Use the same primary virtual IP address. Use the same authentication, or security token.

entry.name: standby_group_ethernetinterface_descr_1464
entry.text: Set the number of the standby group in the multicast domain.

entry.name: standby_virtual_ip_ethernetinterface_help_1465
entry.text: The primary virtual IP address of the standby group. The active member of the standby group uses this IP address. All interfaces in the standby group must use the same virtual IP address. External clients that contact the active member of the standby group should use this IP address. #b#Attention:#/b# Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.

entry.name: standby_virtual_ip_ethernetinterface_descr_1465
entry.text: Set the primary virtual IP address of standby group.

entry.name: standby_secondary_virtual_ip_ethernetinterface_help_1466
entry.text: Auxiliary, or secondary, virtual IP addresses to the standby configuration. Secondary addresses follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface. Secondary addresses are on the same interface as the primary address and are enabled and disabled in coordination with the primary address. #b#Attention:#/b# Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.

entry.name: standby_secondary_virtual_ip_ethernetinterface_descr_1466
entry.text: Manage secondary virtual IP addresses that follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface.

entry.name: standby_preempt_ethernetinterface_help_1467
entry.text: Whether to support preemption in the standby configuration for the initially active interface. Depending on the preemption setting, the follow activity occurs when the initially active member returns to service after a failure. When preemption is enabled, the interface resumes its active role. The standby interface becomes a passive member. When preemption is disabled, the interface is a passive member. #b#Attention:#/b# Do not enable preemption.

entry.name: standby_preempt_ethernetinterface_descr_1467
entry.text: Indicates whether to support preemption in the standby group.

entry.name: standby_priority_ethernetinterface_help_1468
entry.text: The priority of the interface in the standby group. Enter a value in the range 0 - 255. The default value is 100. Use the default value unless one system or interface is in some way better than another one. For each standby group, there is one active member and one or more passive members. The interface with the highest priority seeks to be the active member. If multiple interfaces have the same priority, one becomes the active member.

entry.name: standby_priority_ethernetinterface_descr_1468
entry.text: Set the priority of the interface in the standby group.

entry.name: standby_self_balance_ethernetinterface_help_1469
entry.text: Whether to use self-balancing in the standby group. When enabled, the active member distributes connections to available members. When disabled, all connections go to the active member. The active member receives all TCP connections and processes all requests and responses. If the active member becomes unavailable, the standby member becomes the active members. The active member manages all TCP connections to virtual IP addresses. When a client initiates a new TCP connection, the active member selects a member to act as the connection endpoint. The active member tracks member capabilities to distribute traffic appropriately. The selected member completes the establishment of the connection. The active member forwards all segments of the TCP connection to the member that is acting as the connection endpoint. In a non-graceful transition, if the active member becomes unavailable, the passive member with the next highest priority becomes the active member. The active member might become unavailable because of network issues, an appliance crash, power outage, or similar cause. In a graceful transition, such as for scheduled maintenance, most connections can be preserved if the appliance that terminates the connection remains available. In practice, quiesce the active appliance to ensure that established connections complete before you start maintenance; for example, apply firmware. In some environments, the time for the takeover exceeds the client timeout value. Similarly, if the appliance timeout value is aggressive, connections can be lost because the appliance terminated the connection because of a timeout.

entry.name: standby_self_balance_ethernetinterface_descr_1469
entry.text: Indicates whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.

entry.name: standby_authentication_ethernetinterface_help_1470
entry.text: The authentication string, or security token in hex. The default value is 0x5841333500000000. Every member in the standby group must use the same security token.

entry.name: standby_authentication_ethernetinterface_descr_1470
entry.text: Set the authentication string for the interface in the standby group.

entry.name: standby_hello_timer_ethernetinterface_help_1471
entry.text: The frequency to broadcast hello messages. Set this value to at least one third the duration of the hold timer. Enter a value in the range 2 - 40. The default value is 3.

entry.name: standby_hello_timer_ethernetinterface_descr_1471
entry.text: Set the frequency to broadcast hello messages

entry.name: standby_hold_timer_ethernetinterface_help_1472
entry.text: The duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover. Set this value to at least three times the interval of hello messages. Enter a value in the range 6 - 120. The default value is 10.

entry.name: standby_hold_timer_ethernetinterface_descr_1472
entry.text: Set the duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover.

entry.name: standby_distribution_algorithm_ethernetinterface_help_1473
entry.text: The algorithm to distribute incoming connections to available members when self-balancing is enabled.

entry.name: standby_distribution_algorithm_ethernetinterface_descr_1473
entry.text: Set the distribution algorithm for incoming connections when self-balancing is enabled.

entry.name: link_aggregation_mode_ethernetinterface_help_1474
entry.text: Whether the interface is part of a link aggregation interface. When part of a link aggregation interface, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.

entry.name: link_aggregation_mode_ethernetinterface_descr_1474
entry.text: Indicate whether the interface is part of a link aggregation interface.

entry.name: mtu_ethernetinterface_help_1475
entry.text: The maximum transmission unit (MTU) for the Ethernet interface. The MTU is determined regardless of the length of the layer 2 encapsulation. Set the value greater than 1500 bytes only when you know that all other interfaces on this network are similarly configured. Enter a value in the range 576 - 16128. The default value is 1500. When the Ethernet interface is part of a VLAN interface, the MTU of the VLAN interface cannot be greater than the MTU for the Ethernet interface The appliance adds 4 bytes when a VLAN interface is enabled on this interface. When the Ethernet interface is part of a link aggregation interface, the MTU of the aggregate interface overrides the MTU of the Ethernet interface.

entry.name: mtu_ethernetinterface_descr_1475
entry.text: Set the maximum transmission unit for the Ethernet interface.

entry.name: mac_address_ethernetinterface_help_1476
entry.text: The MAC address of the Ethernet interface. By default, the appliance uses the burned-in MAC address from the network interface controller that was assigned when the system was manufactured. Enter a 48-bit hex MAC address in the 00:12:34:56:78:9c format. The value must be a unicast address, where the first byte must be even.

entry.name: mac_address_ethernetinterface_descr_1476
entry.text: Override the assigned 48-bit MAC address.

entry.name: mode_ethernetinterface_help_1477
entry.text: The physical mode is the interface speed and direction of the Ethernet unshielded twisted pair physical (PHY) layer. Use this property to set speed and direction explicitly when your networking equipment does not negotiate properly. If you manually configure one end of the link, you must manually configure the other end of the link to the same setting.

entry.name: mode_ethernetinterface_descr_1477
entry.text: Set the Ethernet physical mode.

entry.name: force_mode_ethernetinterface_help_1478
entry.text: Whether to force Ethernet physical mode instead of autonegotiation behavior. By default, this option is disabled, which means that autonegotiation is used. When this option is enabled, the physical mode is forced, and there is no autonegotiation performed at the Ethernet driver level. Enable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.

entry.name: force_mode_ethernetinterface_descr_1478
entry.text: Indicate whether to force Ethernet physical mode instead of autonegotiation behavior.

entry.name: hardware_offload_ethernetinterface_help_1479
entry.text: Whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing. By default, offloading is enabled. When enabled, offloads TCP/IP packet processing of Ethernet device drivers and chips. Hardware offload can improve performance. When disabled, does not offload TCP/IP packet processing. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem. If you disable the hardware offload and then re-enable offloading, you must restart the appliance for the change to take effect.

entry.name: hardware_offload_ethernetinterface_descr_1479
entry.text: Indicate whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing to hardware.

entry.name: flow_control_ethernetinterface_help_1480
entry.text: The flow control mode of the Ethernet interface. The default value is #b#Auto#/b#. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.

entry.name: flow_control_ethernetinterface_descr_1480
entry.text: Set the flow control mode.

entry.name: lldp_hardware_offload_ethernetinterface_help_1481
entry.text: Whether the NIC offloads responses to Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP) packets to the operating system. By default, the NIC offloads responses to the operating system. When set to #b#on#/b#, the NIC responds to LLDP packets. Having the hardware responding can improve performance. Use only when directed by IBM Support. When set to #b#off#/b#, the NIC offloads responses to LLDP packets to the operating system. If you set the NIC to respond to LLDP packets, you must restart the appliance for the change to take effect.

entry.name: lldp_hardware_offload_ethernetinterface_descr_1481
entry.text: Indicate whether the NIC offloads responses to LLDP packets to the operating system.

entry.name: link_aggregation_kglobalconfig_help_1482
entry.text: A link aggregation interface combines multiple Ethernet ports. When combined and used in parallel, the aggregate interface increases link speed beyond a single Ethernet port. Because the aggregate interface combines Ethernet ports, redundancy is increased to provider higher availability.

entry.name: link_aggregation_kglobalconfig_descr_1482
entry.text: Link Aggregation Interface

entry.name: admin_state_linkaggregation_help_1483
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_linkaggregation_descr_1483
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - A read-only property that indicates Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) support. Support is always enabled.

entry.name: arp_linkaggregation_descr_1484
entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - ARP support is always enabled

entry.name: ipv6_linkaggregation_help_1485
entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - A read-only property that indicates IPv6 address support. Support is always enabled.

entry.name: ipv6_linkaggregation_descr_1485
entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - IPv6 address support is always enabled

entry.name: dhcp_linkaggregation_help_1486
entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - A read-only property that indicates whether to support DCHP autoconfiguration for IPv4 IP addresses. IPv4 autoconfiguration with DHCP is control by the IP address configuration mode.

entry.name: dhcp_linkaggregation_descr_1486
entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - IPv4 autoconfiguration with DHCP is controlled by the IP address configuration mode

entry.name: slaac_linkaggregation_help_1487
entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - A read-only property that indicates whether to support SLAAC autoconfiguration for IPv6 IP addresses. IPv6 autoconfiguration with SLAAC is control by the IP address configuration mode.

entry.name: slaac_linkaggregation_descr_1487
entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - IPv6 autoconfiguration with SLAAC is controlled by the IP address configuration mode

entry.name: summary_linkaggregation_help_1488
entry.text: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

entry.name: summary_linkaggregation_descr_1488
entry.text: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.

entry.name: ip_config_mode_linkaggregation_help_1489
entry.text: The configuration mode of the interface. Although you can set multiple modes, only one mode is supported. With static configuration, you must define the configuration for the physical interface. Assign the primary network address. Manage secondary, or auxiliary, network addresses. Assign the default IPv4 gateway. Assign the default IPv6 gateway, if you define IPv6 IP addresses. Manage static routes in the routing table. With DHCP autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface. With SLAAC autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.

entry.name: ip_config_mode_linkaggregation_descr_1489
entry.text: Set the configuration mode for the interface.

entry.name: ip_address_linkaggregation_help_1490
entry.text: The IP address and netmask of the primary IP address. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation. For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32. For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.

entry.name: ip_address_linkaggregation_descr_1490
entry.text: Set the primary IP address and netmask.

entry.name: ipv4_default_gateway_linkaggregation_help_1491
entry.text: The IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway. All IPv4 network addresses use this gateway.

entry.name: ipv4_default_gateway_linkaggregation_descr_1491
entry.text: Set the IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway.

entry.name: ipv6_default_gateway_linkaggregation_help_1492
entry.text: The IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway. All IPv6 network addresses use this gateway. If you do not use IPv6 network addresses, do not define this property.

entry.name: ipv6_default_gateway_linkaggregation_descr_1492
entry.text: Set the IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway.

entry.name: ip_secondary_address_linkaggregation_help_1493
entry.text: The IP addresses and netmasks of secondary IP addresses. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation. For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32. For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.

entry.name: ip_secondary_address_linkaggregation_descr_1493
entry.text: Set secondary IP addresses and netmasks.

entry.name: ip_route_linkaggregation_help_1494
entry.text: The static routes in the routing table. Add a static route to a remote IP prefix through a router connected to this network. When the appliance connects to a remote address, the static route with the longest prefix match is used. If multiple routes have the same prefix match, the static route with the lowest metric is used. If the metric is the same, the static route is chosen randomly.

entry.name: ip_route_linkaggregation_descr_1494
entry.text: Manage the static routes in the routing table.

entry.name: ipv6_dadtransmits_linkaggregation_help_1495
entry.text: The number of IPv6 duplication address detection (DAD) attempts. The default value is 1.

entry.name: ipv6_dadtransmits_linkaggregation_descr_1495
entry.text: Set the number of IPv6 duplication address detection attempts.

entry.name: ipv6_nd_retransmit_timer_linkaggregation_help_1496
entry.text: The delay between IPv6 Neighbor Discovery (ND) attempts. The default value is 1000. This property affects duplication address detection (DAD) and other ND operations.

entry.name: ipv6_nd_retransmit_timer_linkaggregation_descr_1496
entry.text: Set the delay between IPv6 neighbor discovery (ND) attempts.

entry.name: standby_enable_linkaggregation_help_1497
entry.text: Whether to allow a standby configuration. The standby configuration defines the policies for the group that this interface is a member. A standby group is the collection of interfaces on different appliances in the multicast domain that share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. When at least one member of a standby group can reach the multicast domain, the virtual IP group receives the traffic. #b#Attention:#/b# Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.

entry.name: standby_enable_linkaggregation_descr_1497
entry.text: Indicate whether to allow a standby configuration.

entry.name: standby_group_linkaggregation_help_1498
entry.text: The number of the standby group in a multicast domain. The multicast domain is a group of interfaces that receive traffic from each other on the IP address 224.0.0.2 (the all-routers IP multicast group). If the multicast domain becomes partitioned, which is an unusual situation, a member in each partition becomes the active member to handle connections in its partition. #b#Attention:#/b# Do not use a group number that conflicts with the number of an existing standby group or any network group that uses Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP). The interfaces of a standby group are on the same network segment and share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. Interfaces in the standby group require the following configuration. Belong to the same group. Use the same primary virtual IP address. Use the same authentication, or security token.

entry.name: standby_group_linkaggregation_descr_1498
entry.text: Set the number of the standby group in the multicast domain.

entry.name: standby_virtual_ip_linkaggregation_help_1499
entry.text: The primary virtual IP address of the standby group. The active member of the standby group uses this IP address. All interfaces in the standby group must use the same virtual IP address. External clients that contact the active member of the standby group should use this IP address. #b#Attention:#/b# Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.

entry.name: standby_virtual_ip_linkaggregation_descr_1499
entry.text: Set the primary virtual IP address of standby group.

entry.name: standby_secondary_virtual_ip_linkaggregation_help_1500
entry.text: Auxiliary, or secondary, virtual IP addresses to the standby configuration. Secondary addresses follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface. Secondary addresses are on the same interface as the primary address and are enabled and disabled in coordination with the primary address. #b#Attention:#/b# Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.

entry.name: standby_secondary_virtual_ip_linkaggregation_descr_1500
entry.text: Manage secondary virtual IP addresses that follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface.

entry.name: standby_preempt_linkaggregation_help_1501
entry.text: Whether to support preemption in the standby configuration for the initially active interface. Depending on the preemption setting, the follow activity occurs when the initially active member returns to service after a failure. When preemption is enabled, the interface resumes its active role. The standby interface becomes a passive member. When preemption is disabled, the interface is a passive member. #b#Attention:#/b# Do not enable preemption.

entry.name: standby_preempt_linkaggregation_descr_1501
entry.text: Indicates whether to support preemption in the standby group.

entry.name: standby_priority_linkaggregation_help_1502
entry.text: The priority of the interface in the standby group. Enter a value in the range 0 - 255. The default value is 100. Use the default value unless one system or interface is in some way better than another one. For each standby group, there is one active member and one or more passive members. The interface with the highest priority seeks to be the active member. If multiple interfaces have the same priority, one becomes the active member.

entry.name: standby_priority_linkaggregation_descr_1502
entry.text: Set the priority of the interface in the standby group.

entry.name: standby_self_balance_linkaggregation_help_1503
entry.text: Whether to use self-balancing in the standby group. When enabled, the active member distributes connections to available members. When disabled, all connections go to the active member. The active member receives all TCP connections and processes all requests and responses. If the active member becomes unavailable, the standby member becomes the active members. The active member manages all TCP connections to virtual IP addresses. When a client initiates a new TCP connection, the active member selects a member to act as the connection endpoint. The active member tracks member capabilities to distribute traffic appropriately. The selected member completes the establishment of the connection. The active member forwards all segments of the TCP connection to the member that is acting as the connection endpoint. In a non-graceful transition, if the active member becomes unavailable, the passive member with the next highest priority becomes the active member. The active member might become unavailable because of network issues, an appliance crash, power outage, or similar cause. In a graceful transition, such as for scheduled maintenance, most connections can be preserved if the appliance that terminates the connection remains available. In practice, quiesce the active appliance to ensure that established connections complete before you start maintenance; for example, apply firmware. In some environments, the time for the takeover exceeds the client timeout value. Similarly, if the appliance timeout value is aggressive, connections can be lost because the appliance terminated the connection because of a timeout.

entry.name: standby_self_balance_linkaggregation_descr_1503
entry.text: Indicates whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.

entry.name: standby_authentication_linkaggregation_help_1504
entry.text: The authentication string, or security token in hex. The default value is 0x5841333500000000. Every member in the standby group must use the same security token.

entry.name: standby_authentication_linkaggregation_descr_1504
entry.text: Set the authentication string for the interface in the standby group.

entry.name: standby_hello_timer_linkaggregation_help_1505
entry.text: The frequency to broadcast hello messages. Set this value to at least one third the duration of the hold timer. Enter a value in the range 2 - 40. The default value is 3.

entry.name: standby_hello_timer_linkaggregation_descr_1505
entry.text: Set the frequency to broadcast hello messages

entry.name: standby_hold_timer_linkaggregation_help_1506
entry.text: The duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover. Set this value to at least three times the interval of hello messages. Enter a value in the range 6 - 120. The default value is 10.

entry.name: standby_hold_timer_linkaggregation_descr_1506
entry.text: Set the duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover.

entry.name: standby_distribution_algorithm_linkaggregation_help_1507
entry.text: The algorithm to distribute incoming connections to available members when self-balancing is enabled.

entry.name: standby_distribution_algorithm_linkaggregation_descr_1507
entry.text: Set the distribution algorithm for incoming connections when self-balancing is enabled.

entry.name: type_linkaggregation_help_1508
entry.text: The mode to use for link aggregation. When the link aggregation interface uses LACP, you can change the selection policy and the distribution algorithm for outbound packets.

entry.name: type_linkaggregation_descr_1508
entry.text: Set the mode for link aggregation.

entry.name: link_linkaggregation_help_1509
entry.text: The Ethernet interfaces in the link aggregation interface. Although you can add members in the following situations, the operational state of the link aggregation interface is down. The Ethernet interface is part of a VLAN interface. The Ethernet interface is part of another link aggregation interface. The Ethernet interface is not enabled for link aggregation.

entry.name: link_linkaggregation_descr_1509
entry.text: Manage Ethernet interfaces in the link aggregation interface.

entry.name: mtu_linkaggregation_help_1510
entry.text: The maximum transmission unit (MTU) for the link aggregation interface. The MTU of the link aggregation interface overrides the MTU of the Ethernet interface. Enter a value in the range 576 - 16128. The default value is 1500. The MTU is determined regardless of the length of the layer 2 encapsulation.

entry.name: mtu_linkaggregation_descr_1510
entry.text: Set the maximum transmission unit for the link aggregation interface.

entry.name: lacp_select_linkaggregation_help_1511
entry.text: The algorithm for the Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP) selection policy. When there is more than one LACP aggregator for the members of an LACP aggregation, the appliance uses the algorithm to determine which aggregator to use. In other words, the algorithm determines which group of link aggregation interfaces is active.

entry.name: lacp_select_linkaggregation_descr_1511
entry.text: Set the algorithm for the LACP selection policy.

entry.name: lacp_hash_linkaggregation_help_1512
entry.text: The distribution algorithm for outbound packets among the active physical interfaces in an Link Aggregation Control Protocol (LACP) aggregation. The default algorithm uses uses both MAC addresses and IP addresses.

entry.name: lacp_hash_linkaggregation_descr_1512
entry.text: Set the distribution algorithm for outbound packets among the active physical interfaces in an LACP aggregation.

entry.name: lacp_rate_linkaggregation_help_1513
entry.text: The rate of the LACP aggregation, which can be slow (every 30 seconds) or fast (every 1 second).

entry.name: lacp_rate_linkaggregation_descr_1513
entry.text: Set the rate in the LACP aggregation.

entry.name: hardware_offload_linkaggregation_help_1514
entry.text: Whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing. By default, offloading is enabled. When enabled, offloads TCP/IP packet processing of Ethernet device drivers and chips. Hardware offload can improve performance. When disabled, does not offload TCP/IP packet processing. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem. If you disable the hardware offload and then re-enable offloading, you must restart the appliance for the change to take effect.

entry.name: hardware_offload_linkaggregation_descr_1514
entry.text: Indicate whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing to hardware.

entry.name: vlan_kglobalconfig_help_1515
entry.text: A VLAN interface allows multiple logical LANs to coexist on the same Ethernet segment. VLAN packets are identified by the IEEE 802.1Q protocol. You can define multiple VLAN interfaces on a single parent interface. The parent interface can be an Ethernet interface or a link aggregation interface.

entry.name: vlan_kglobalconfig_descr_1515
entry.text: VLAN Interface

entry.name: admin_state_vlaninterface_help_1516
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_vlaninterface_descr_1516
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: arp_vlaninterface_help_1517
entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - A read-only property that indicates Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) support. Support is always enabled.

entry.name: arp_vlaninterface_descr_1517
entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - ARP support is always enabled

entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - A read-only property that indicates IPv6 address support. Support is always enabled.

entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - IPv6 address support is always enabled

entry.name: over_vlaninterface_help_1541
entry.text: The parent interface type for the VLAN interface.

entry.name: over_vlaninterface_descr_1541
entry.text: Set the parent interface type.

entry.name: ethernet_interface_vlaninterface_help_1542
entry.text: The parent Ethernet interface for the VLAN interface.

entry.name: ethernet_interface_vlaninterface_descr_1542
entry.text: Set the parent Ethernet interface.

entry.name: link_aggregation_interface_vlaninterface_help_1543
entry.text: The parent link aggregation interface for the VLAN interface.

entry.name: link_aggregation_interface_vlaninterface_descr_1543
entry.text: Set the parent link aggregation interface.

entry.name: identifier_vlaninterface_help_1544
entry.text: The unique VLAN identifier to send and receive traffic. The identifier must be unique among all VLAN interfaces on the same Ethernet interface. Enter a value in the range 1 - 4094. The default value is 2.

entry.name: identifier_vlaninterface_descr_1544
entry.text: Set the unique VLAN identifier.

entry.name: outbound_priority_vlaninterface_help_1545
entry.text: The priority value for outbound VLAN headers for packets. These packets are sent on this VLAN interface. This value is placed in the user_control field of the Tag Control Information (TCI). The exact interpretation of the value depends on the VLAN switch configuration. Enter a value in the range 0 - 7. The default value is 0.

entry.name: outbound_priority_vlaninterface_descr_1545
entry.text: Set the priority for outbound packets.

entry.name: mtu_vlaninterface_help_1546
entry.text: The maximum transmission unit (MTU) for the VLAN interface. The MTU for the VLAN interface cannot be greater than the MTU of the parent interface. The MTU is determined regardless of the length of the layer 2 encapsulation. Enter a value in the range 576 - 16128. The default value is 1500.

entry.name: mtu_vlaninterface_descr_1546
entry.text: Set the maximum transmission unit for the VLAN interface.

entry.name: hardware_offload_vlaninterface_help_1547
entry.text: Whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing. By default, offloading is enabled. When enabled, offloads TCP/IP packet processing of VLAN device drivers and chips. Hardware offload can improve performance. When disabled, does not offload TCP/IP packet processing. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem. If you disable the hardware offload and then re-enable offloading, you must restart the appliance for the change to take effect.

entry.name: hardware_offload_vlaninterface_descr_1547
entry.text: Indicate whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing to hardware.

entry.name: ipmi_lan_channel_kglobalconfig_help_1548
entry.text: An Intelligent Platform Management Interface (IPMI) LAN channel allows access to the Baseboard Management Controller (BMC) on the appliance over a LAN. IPMI allows remote management access and can provide serial over LAN to the console serial port. The LAN channel must use the 'mgt0' management Ethernet connector.

entry.name: ipmi_lan_channel_kglobalconfig_descr_1548
entry.text: IPMI LAN Channel

entry.name: admin_state_ipmilanchannel_help_1549
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_ipmilanchannel_descr_1549
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_ipmilanchannel_help_1550
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: summary_ipmilanchannel_descr_1550
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation

entry.name: maximum_channel_privilege_level_ipmilanchannel_help_1551
entry.text: The maximum privilege level for all users on the LAN channel. Each IPMI command has a minimum privilege level. This property sets the maximum privilege level that a user can attain on the LAN channel even when that user has a greater privilege level.

entry.name: maximum_channel_privilege_level_ipmilanchannel_descr_1551
entry.text: Maximum privilege level allowed on channel.

entry.name: sol_enabled_ipmilanchannel_help_1552
entry.text: Whether to support the serial over LAN protocol over Remote Control and Management Protocol Plus (RCMP+) on this channel.

entry.name: sol_enabled_ipmilanchannel_descr_1552
entry.text: LAN channel can support serial over LAN

entry.name: sol_required_user_privilege_level_ipmilanchannel_help_1553
entry.text: The required privilege level for users to use the serial over LAN protocol (payload) over RCMP+ on this LAN channel.

entry.name: sol_required_user_privilege_level_ipmilanchannel_descr_1553
entry.text: Privilege level for Serial-over-LAN

entry.name: allowed_user_ipmilanchannel_help_1554
entry.text: The users allowed to use this LAN channel. For each user, include the maximum privilege level, whether to allow serial over LAN, and the maximum number of simultaneous sessions.

entry.name: allowed_user_ipmilanchannel_descr_1554
entry.text: Users allowed to use this channel

entry.name: ip_address_ipmilanchannel_help_1555
entry.text: The IPv4 IP address and subnet mask to this interface. This IP address must be distinct from all IP addresses on the appliance and from all IP address on the connected subnet (broadcast domain).

entry.name: ip_address_ipmilanchannel_descr_1555
entry.text: IP Address and mask

entry.name: ip_default_gateway_ipmilanchannel_help_1556
entry.text: The IPv4 default gateway that communicate with systems not on the local subnet. Without a default gateway, the LAN channel cannot communicate with clients that are not on the same local subnet (broadcast domain).

entry.name: ip_default_gateway_ipmilanchannel_descr_1556
entry.text: Default IP Gateway

entry.name: ipmi_user_kglobalconfig_help_1557
entry.text: An Intelligent Platform Management Interface (IPMI) user can create, change, or destroy user authentication records in the Baseboard Management Controller (BMC). Authentication records allow users to communicate using IPMI protocols over external channels, such as an IPMI LAN channel. On an appliance, there can be eight IPMI users. #b#Note#/b#: If you apply the configuration but do not save it, the IPMI user data is written to the BMC but not saved to the startup configuration. In this situation, the IPMI user can connect to the serial port over the IPMI LAN channel.

entry.name: ipmi_user_kglobalconfig_descr_1557
entry.text: IPMI User

entry.name: admin_state_ipmiuser_help_1558
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_ipmiuser_descr_1558
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_ipmiuser_help_1559
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: summary_ipmiuser_descr_1559
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: user_id_ipmiuser_help_1560
entry.text: The IPMI identifier for the IPMI user. Each user must have a unique User ID. All configuration for the user in the BMC is indexed by this User ID. Use any value of 3 - 10. The default value is 3.

entry.name: user_id_ipmiuser_descr_1560
entry.text: IPMI identifier for the IPMI user

entry.name: password_ipmiuser_help_1561
entry.text: The password that the remote user must present for authentication. The password must be between 8 and 16 characters in length. Because the password is in only the BMC, it will not be included as part of an export or backup operation. Because the password is not part of an export, it will not be added during an import or restore operation.

entry.name: password_ipmiuser_descr_1561
entry.text: Password for remote authentication

entry.text: IP Multicast mode defines the properties for the multicast configuration used to transmit and receive peering update messages.

entry.text: IP Multicast

entry.name: multicast_group_ipmulticast_help_1565
entry.text: Specifies the multicast IP group address. For IPv4, enter an address in the range 224.0.0.0 - 239.255.255.255. For IPv6, enter an address beginning with FF.

entry.name: multicast_group_ipmulticast_descr_1565
entry.text: Specifies the multicast IP group address.

entry.name: interface_ipmulticast_help_1566
entry.text: The local IP interface address, host name, or host alias of the Ethernet interface or VLAN interface that is used to transmit and receive multicast messages. Specify an IP address, a host name, or an existing host alias that is mapped to an IP address.

entry.name: interface_ipmulticast_descr_1566
entry.text: Specifies the local IP address, host name, or host alias that is used to transmit and receive multicast messages.

entry.name: port_ipmulticast_help_1567
entry.text: The IP port used to transmit and receive multicast packets. Enter a value in the range 1 - 0xFFFF.

entry.name: port_ipmulticast_descr_1567
entry.text: Specifies the IP port used to transmit and receive multicast packets.

entry.name: key_ipmulticast_help_1568
entry.text: The key is optional. If a key is not specified, the packets are not signed and verified. All peers in the peer group must be configured with an identical key.

entry.name: key_ipmulticast_descr_1568
entry.text: The shared secret key to sign and verify packets.

entry.name: max_data_size_ipmulticast_help_1569
entry.text: The maximum size of a transmitted data block within a multicast packet. The sum of the maximum transmit data size and the IP header should not exceed the MTU of the network.

entry.name: max_data_size_ipmulticast_descr_1569
entry.text: Specifies the maximum allowable size of a transmitted data block.

entry.name: nak_time_ipmulticast_help_1570
entry.text: The length of time before the first NAK packet is transmitted or the length of time between subsequent NAK transmissions. Enter a value in the range 100 - 60000. The default value is 200.

entry.name: nak_time_ipmulticast_descr_1570
entry.text: Specifies the length of time to wait before an NAK is initially transmitted or is retransmitted.

entry.name: nak_retries_ipmulticast_help_1571
entry.text: The number of times that an NAK packet is retransmitted. Enter a value in the range 0 - 100. The default value is 5.

entry.name: nak_retries_ipmulticast_descr_1571
entry.text: Specifies the number of times a missing NAK packet is retransmitted.

entry.name: buffer_resend_time_ipmulticast_help_1572
entry.text: The number of seconds that a transmitted multicast packet remains buffered. Enter a value in the range 1 - 60. The default value is 2.

entry.name: buffer_resend_time_ipmulticast_descr_1572
entry.text: Specifies the number of seconds that a transmitted packet remains buffered.

entry.name: session_reauthen_for_inactive_isamreverseproxy_help_1624
entry.text: Prompt users to re-authenticate if their entry in the server credential cache times out because of inactivity. When disabled, entries in the cache are deleted when the inactivity timeout is reached. When enabled, entries in the cache are retained until the cache lifetime timeout is reached. If the inactivity timeout is reached and the client makes another request before the cache lifetime timeout is reached, users are prompted to re-authenticate.

entry.name: session_reauthen_for_inactive_isamreverseproxy_descr_1624
entry.text: Prompt users to re-authenticate if their entry in the server credential cache times out because of inactivity.

entry.name: isam_reverseproxy_junction_kglobalconfig_help_1663
entry.text: An Access Manager junction logically combines the Web space of the Web application server with the Web space of the Access Manager Reverse Proxy server, resulting in a unified view of the entire Web object space. A junction allows the Access Manager Reverse Proxy to provide protective services on behalf of the Web application server.

entry.name: policy_server_host_isamruntime_help_1716
entry.text: Specifies the host name or IP address of the IBM Security Access Manager policy server (pdmgrd). The policy server manages the policy database (sometimes referred to as master authorization database), updates the database replicas whenever a change is made to the master database, and replicates the policy information throughout the domains. The policy server also maintains location information about other resource managers that operate in the domain. You must define at least one policy server for each domain. You can specify the host name with or without the domain extension. You can specify the fully qualified host name with or without the domain extension. Examples: pdmgr or pdmgr.tivoli.com

entry.name: policy_server_host_isamruntime_descr_1716

entry.name: session_reestablish_timeout_iscsitargetconfig_help_1755
entry.text: The amount of time that the DataPower iSCSI initiator will attempt to reestablish a connection to this remote iSCSI target. Specify the number of seconds to wait for an operation on this iSCSI target to complete before considering the operation to have failed. The default is 120 seconds. Setting this value too low may cause operations that would have completed successfully to fail due to intermittent network issues. If the appliance fails to establish a connection to the iSCSI target within this timeout threshold, the default value of 120 seconds can lead to appliance-level hang-detection being triggered. If this occurs, set the iSCSI Target object's Session Reestablish Timeout to a lower value.

entry.name: session_reestablish_timeout_iscsitargetconfig_descr_1755
entry.text: Session reestablish timeout in seconds

entry.name: read_only_iscsivolumeconfig_help_1761
entry.text: Set the access permission to files on the storage volume. When set to "on", the access permission is read-only. When set to "off", the default value, the access permission is read-write.

entry.name: read_only_iscsivolumeconfig_descr_1761
entry.text: Allow only file reads on this iSCSI Volume.

entry.name: directory_iscsivolumeconfig_help_1762
entry.text: Specify the subdirectory in the local: and logstore: directories where the files on the storage volume are available. Each application domain contains these subdirectories. These subdirectories are not shared across application domains. The name can be up to 64 characters long. The name cannot start with a period. The name can consist of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, numeric digits, dashes, underscores, and periods.

entry.name: directory_iscsivolumeconfig_descr_1762
entry.text: Directory name

entry.name: lun_iscsivolumeconfig_help_1763
entry.text: Specify the Logical Unit Number (LUN). Use an integer in the range of 0 through 255.

entry.name: json_settings_kglobalconfig_help_1769
entry.text: The JSON settings specify constraints for parsing JSON messages. JSON settings work in conjunction with the parser limits specified in the XML Manager. The more restrictive limits apply.

entry.name: json_settings_kglobalconfig_descr_1769
entry.text: JSON Settings

entry.name: admin_state_jsonsettings_help_1770
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_jsonsettings_descr_1770
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_jsonsettings_help_1771
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: summary_jsonsettings_descr_1771
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation

entry.name: max_nesting_depth_jsonsettings_help_1772
entry.text: The maximum nesting depth provides threat protection by limiting the number of nested label-value pairs allowed in the JSON message. Enter a value in the range 64 - 256. The default value is 64.

entry.name: max_nesting_depth_jsonsettings_descr_1772
entry.text: Maximum number of levels to nest label-value pairs.

entry.name: max_label_string_length_jsonsettings_help_1773
entry.text: The maximum label length limits the number of bytes in the label portion of the JSON label-value pair. The length includes any white space that is contained between quotation marks. Enter a value in the range 256 - 8192. The default value is 256.

entry.name: max_label_string_length_jsonsettings_descr_1773
entry.text: Maximum length of the label portion of label-value pairs.

entry.name: max_value_string_length_jsonsettings_help_1774
entry.text: The maximum value length limits the number of bytes in the value portion of a label-value pair when the value is a string. The length includes any white space that is contained between quotation marks. Enter a value in the range 8192 - 5368709121. The default value is 8192.

entry.name: max_value_string_length_jsonsettings_descr_1774
entry.text: Maximum number of bytes for string values of label-value pairs.

entry.name: max_number_length_jsonsettings_help_1775
entry.text: The maximum number length limits the number of bytes in the value portion of a label-value pair when the value is a number. The number must be a contiguous string of bytes that contain no white space. The number can include a minus sign and a positive or negative exponent. Enter a value in the range 128 - 256. The default value is 128.

entry.name: max_number_length_jsonsettings_descr_1775
entry.text: Maximum number of bytes for number values of label-value pairs.

entry.name: max_document_size_jsonsettings_help_1776
entry.text: The maximum document size provides threat protection by limiting the number of bytes in the body of the JSON message. If the message is converted to JSONx, the maximum document size specifies the size before conversion to JSONx. Note that the document size of the JSON message and the size of the JSONx equivalent might differ. Enter a value in the range 4194304 - 5368709121. The default value is 4194304.

entry.name: max_document_size_jsonsettings_descr_1776
entry.text: Maximum size of the JSON message in bytes.

entry.name: kafka_cluster_kglobalconfig_help_1777
entry.text: A Kafka cluster is responsible for the messaging services. The Kafka cluster periodically monitors and polls topics. The Kafka cluster ensures that sent messages are directed to the correct response topic or are routed to another server.

entry.name: kafka_cluster_kglobalconfig_descr_1777
entry.text: Kafka Cluster

entry.name: admin_state_kafkacluster_help_1778
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_kafkacluster_descr_1778
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_kafkacluster_descr_1779
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: protocol_kafkacluster_help_1780
entry.text: Indicates the transport protocol for the Kafka bootstrap connection. The selected protocol is used for the exchange of information between the Kafka server and the bootstrap server.

entry.name: protocol_kafkacluster_descr_1780
entry.text: Transport protocol for the Kafka bootstrap connection

entry.name: endpoint_kafkacluster_help_1781
entry.text: Identifies the endpoint for the bootstrap process. A bootstrap server uses a host name or IP address and a port to define an endpoint address. You can add multiple nondefault bootstrap servers. For failover capability, the endpoints must be members of the same cluster.

entry.name: endpoint_kafkacluster_descr_1781
entry.text: Endpoint for the bootstrap process

entry.name: sasl_mechanism_kafkacluster_help_1782
entry.text: Sets the Simple Authentication and Security Layer (SASL) mechanism to communicate with the Kafka cluster. The default value is plaintext.

entry.name: sasl_mechanism_kafkacluster_descr_1782
entry.text: Simple Authentication and Security Layer mechanism to communicate with the Kafka cluster

entry.name: username_kafkacluster_help_1783
entry.text: Specifies the account name to access the Kafka cluster.

entry.name: username_kafkacluster_descr_1783
entry.text: Account name to access the Kafka cluster

entry.name: password_alias_kafkacluster_help_1784
entry.text: Specifies the password alias of the password to access the Kafka cluster.

entry.name: password_alias_kafkacluster_descr_1784
entry.text: Password alias of the password to access the Kafka cluster

entry.name: autocommit_kafkacluster_help_1785
entry.text: Indicates whether to commit offsets at the defined interval or at process-completion. When enabled, commits offsets at the defined interval. The default interval is 5 seconds. To change the interval, set the auto.commit.interval.ms property. When disabled, commits offsets at process-completion. You can use the batch size setting for the Kafka handle to define the number of messages to attempt to receive from the consumer.

entry.name: autocommit_kafkacluster_descr_1785
entry.text: Whether to commit offsets at the defined interval or at process-completion

entry.name: ssl_client_kafkacluster_help_1786
entry.text: The TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

entry.name: ssl_client_kafkacluster_descr_1786
entry.text: Set the TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets

entry.name: memory_threshold_kafkacluster_help_1787
entry.text: Specifies the maximum memory to allocate in bytes. Enter a value in the range 1048576 - 1073741824. The default value is 268435456.

entry.name: memory_threshold_kafkacluster_descr_1787
entry.text: maximum memory allocation for pending messages

entry.name: maximum_message_size_kafkacluster_help_1788
entry.text: Specifies the maximum message size in bytes Enter a value in the range 0 - 1073741824. The default value is 1048576. A value of 0 disables the enforcement of a maximum message size.

entry.name: maximum_message_size_kafkacluster_descr_1788
entry.text: maximum message size for the Kafka cluster

entry.name: total_connection_limit_kafkacluster_help_1789
entry.text: Total connection limit

entry.name: total_connection_limit_kafkacluster_descr_1789
entry.text: Total connection limit

entry.name: auto_retry_kafkacluster_help_1790
entry.text: Controls the automatic error-recovery procedure that attempts to re-establish a connection that was broken in response to an error condition.

entry.name: auto_retry_kafkacluster_descr_1790
entry.text: Automatic error-recovery procedure for the connection with the Kafka cluster

entry.name: retry_interval_kafkacluster_help_1791
entry.text: When automatic error-recovery is enabled, the interval in seconds between attempts to re-establish a downed connection. Enter a value in the range 1 - 65535. The default value is 10.

entry.name: retry_interval_kafkacluster_descr_1791
entry.text: Interval between attempts to re-establish a connection with the Kafka cluster

entry.name: property_kafkacluster_help_1792
entry.text: Defines the additional properties to configure the connection to the Kafka server. Use this property for each additional property that is required. Some properties are unsupported and will cause a configuration failure.

entry.name: property_kafkacluster_descr_1792
entry.text: Additional property for the connection to the Kafka server

entry.name: admin_state_language_descr_1793
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.text: The LDAP Connection Pool settings specify the LDAP connection pool to use.

entry.name: ldap_connection_pool_kglobalconfig_descr_1794
entry.text: LDAP Connection Pool

entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.
