entry.name: llm_instance_kglobalconfig_help_1797
entry.text: An LLM Instance object defines all port resources used by the LLM service. The instance aggregates a combination of objects required to transmit and receive the following types of data streams: Multicast Reliable Multicast Messaging (RMM) Unicast Reliable User Datagram Protocol (RUDP) or Reliable Unicast Messaging (RUM) Tier Fail over data streams The LLM Instance can contain the following objects: LLM Multicast Receive LLM Multicast Transmit LLM Unicast LLM Multicast Tier Group

entry.name: llm_instance_kglobalconfig_descr_1797
entry.text: LLM Instance

entry.name: admin_state_llminstance_help_1798
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_llminstance_descr_1798
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_llminstance_descr_1799
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: receive_llminstance_help_1800
entry.text: Use this panel to define the properties of a Low Latency Messaging Multicast Receiver object. A receiver is part of a message delivery system that accepts messages from one or more LLM multicast transmitters. The source of the data would be either another DataPower system, or more likely a user application using IBM MQ Low Latency Messaging (LLM).

entry.name: receive_llminstance_descr_1800
entry.text: LLM Multicast Receive

entry.name: transmit_llminstance_help_1801
entry.text: Use this panel to define the properties of a Low Latency Messaging Multicast Transmit object. A transmitter is part of a message delivery system that sends messages to one or more receivers. The transmitter supports the following types of data transmissions: one-to-one, one-to-many, and many-to-many.

entry.name: transmit_llminstance_descr_1801
entry.text: LLM Multicast Transmit

entry.name: unicast_llminstance_help_1802
entry.text: Use this panel to define the properties of a Low Latency Messaging Unicast object. The LLM Unicast object describes the options for a TCP based point-to-point receiver and transmitter.

entry.name: unicast_llminstance_descr_1802
entry.text: LLM Unicast

entry.name: tier_llminstance_help_1803
entry.text: The LLM Tier specifies the settings for running in a high-availability mode in which there are multiple LLM processors running in parallel to allow for failure of one of them. To make a tier, you must have a valid and enabled receive and transmit object. All members of a tier must have similar configuration.

entry.name: tier_llminstance_descr_1803
entry.text: LLM Tier Group

entry.name: debug_llminstance_help_1804
entry.text: This option specifies that non-production level debugging may be used. This enables several options which may harm performance in a production environment, but which can help resolve problems such as failure to connect to streams.

entry.name: debug_llminstance_descr_1804
entry.text: Debug mode

entry.name: config_llminstance_help_1805
entry.text: The advanced configuration file contains additional configuration for an LLM Instance. This file is not required in most cases but allows performance and functional tweaking. If the values that are specified in the advanced configuration file overlap with the values that are present in the existing configuration, the values in the advanced configuration file take precedence. Advanced configuration file values override the values specified in the current configuration. They do not overwrite the values displayed in the LLM Instance configuration. If the advanced configuration file is updated after it has already been added to the LLM Instance, the object must be disabled and re-enabled to reflect the updates.

entry.name: config_llminstance_descr_1805
entry.text: Advanced configuration file

entry.name: llm_receive_kglobalconfig_help_1808
entry.text: Use this panel to define the properties of a Low Latency Messaging Multicast Receiver object. A receiver is part of a message delivery system that accepts messages from one or more LLM multicast transmitters. The source of the data would be either another DataPower system, or more likely a user application using IBM MQ Low Latency Messaging (LLM).

entry.name: llm_receive_kglobalconfig_descr_1808
entry.text: LLM Multicast Receive

entry.name: admin_state_llmmulticastreceive_help_1809
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1809
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: interface_llmmulticastreceive_help_1810
entry.text: The name of network interface or IP address for which the LLM Multicast Receive object is expected to receive message packets. As a best practice, enter an IP address with a specific value. Do not specify 0.0.0.0 for IPv4 or :: for IPv6 to receive packets from any network interface.

entry.name: interface_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1810
entry.text: Multicast Interface

entry.name: port_llmmulticastreceive_help_1811
entry.text: The port number on which the LLM Multicast Receive object is expected to receive message packets. This port is reserved for RMM traffic.

entry.name: port_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1811
entry.text: Data Port

entry.name: additional_ports_llmmulticastreceive_help_1812
entry.text: A list of additional UDP ports for RUDP traffic. Each port is either just a port number, or ip:port. UDP ports can be used for RMM traffic.

entry.name: additional_ports_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1812
entry.text: Additional UDP Ports

entry.name: multicast_loop_llmmulticastreceive_help_1813
entry.text: Enable or disable Multicast Loop. Enable Multicast Loop when the transmitter and receiver are on the same machine or network interface. When enabled, a copy of the message received on the appliance is routed back to the sending process on the same network interface.

entry.name: multicast_loop_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1813
entry.text: Multicast Loop

entry.name: packet_size_llmmulticastreceive_help_1814
entry.text: Packet size in bytes

entry.name: packet_size_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1814
entry.text: Packet Size

entry.name: buffer_size_llmmulticastreceive_help_1815
entry.text: Enter a value in kilobytes that specifies the size for the receiver socket buffer. To support high data rates, set the receiver socket buffer size to a value of over 1024 kilobytes. A large value is essential to support high throughput.

entry.name: buffer_size_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1815
entry.text: Socket Buffer Size

entry.name: max_memory_llmmulticastreceive_help_1816
entry.text: Enter a value in kilobytes that specifies the maximum amount of memory that the receiver can consume.

entry.name: max_memory_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1816
entry.text: Max Memory Allowed

entry.name: peer_name_llmmulticastreceive_help_1817
entry.text: The name to use for point-to-point communications between the receiver and a transmitter. Use point-to-point communication for applications that must run over an infrastructure where IP multicast is not available.

entry.name: peer_name_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1817
entry.text: Point-to-Point Name

entry.name: multicast_nacks_llmmulticastreceive_help_1818
entry.text: Enable multicast NAK (negative acknowledgment) processing. When enabled, the receiver sends a NAK for the missing sequence number of a packet with a time to live value of 1 microsecond.

entry.name: multicast_nacks_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1818
entry.text: Multicast NAK

entry.name: max_nack_retries_llmmulticastreceive_help_1819
entry.text: Value that represents the number of times the receiver attempts to send a NAK for a missing repair data packet. Unless set to zero (no NAK retry limit), do not exceed the value specified in the Max Multicast NAK Rate field.

entry.name: max_nack_retries_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1819
entry.text: Max NAK Retries

entry.name: max_nack_retry_interval_llmmulticastreceive_help_1820
entry.text: Value in milliseconds for the amount of time the receiver waits before resending NAK packets. A zero value, the default, means the value is set automatically based on calculations of packet round trip latency.

entry.name: max_nack_retry_interval_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1820
entry.text: Max NAK Retry Interval

entry.name: nack_timeout_llmmulticastreceive_help_1821
entry.text: A value in milliseconds during which a NAK packet remains valid. If repair data is not received within the timeout period, the NAK is canceled and the repair data is considered lost.

entry.name: nack_timeout_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1821
entry.text: NAK Timeout

entry.name: max_nack_gap_llmmulticastreceive_help_1822
entry.text: Value for a missing packet sequence number that becomes the NAK gap. The receiver will not send a NAK for a repair data packet if the Maximum NAK sequence number is less than the currently known front sequence number of the data stream. Pending NAK elements are also deleted using this policy.

entry.name: max_nack_gap_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1822
entry.text: Maximum NAK

entry.name: max_repair_rate_llmmulticastreceive_help_1823
entry.text: The maximum number of repair data packets that the receiver can request using the NAK mechanism. The unit value is in repair packets per second. A value of 0, the default, means that there is no limit imposed on repair requests.

entry.name: max_repair_rate_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1823
entry.text: Maximum repair request rate

entry.name: nack_alert_rate_high_llmmulticastreceive_help_1824
entry.text: High watermark for NAK alerts. If the receiver detects that NAK alerts have exceeded the specified value, it sends a NAK alert ON event to the application. The watermark value is given in packets per second. The ON event could result in a log entry or some other application action. A value of 0, the default, indicates that NAK alert events should be disabled.

entry.name: nack_alert_rate_high_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1824
entry.text: NAK Alert Rate High

entry.name: nack_alert_rate_low_llmmulticastreceive_help_1825
entry.text: Low watermark for NAK alerts. If the receiver detects that NAK alerts have met the specified value, it sends a NAK alert OFF event to the application. The watermark value is given in packets per second. The OFF event could result in a log entry or some other application action. A value of 0, the default, indicates that NAK alert events should be disabled.

entry.name: nack_alert_rate_low_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1825
entry.text: NAK Alert Rate Low

entry.name: max_nack_rate_llmmulticastreceive_help_1826
entry.text: Value in NAK packets per second that represents the max rate of multicast NAK packets that a receiver can generate. A value greater than zero represents the ceiling for the number of multicast NAKs the receiver can generate per second. The default is 500. A value of 0 indicates that multicast NAK rate control is disabled. This parameter setting does not affect the sending of Unicast NAKs.

entry.name: max_nack_rate_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1826
entry.text: Max Multicast NAK Rate

entry.name: thread_priority_llmmulticastreceive_help_1827
entry.text: Priority value to assign Fireout (sending) threads for the receiver. Enter a value from 0 to 100. A value of 100, for example, means the highest possible priority. A value of 0 means thread priority is not changed by RMM. Thread priority is only honored in RMM.

entry.name: thread_priority_llmmulticastreceive_descr_1827
entry.text: Thread Priority

entry.name: llm_tier_group_kglobalconfig_help_1828
entry.text: The LLM Multicast Tier Group identifies a configuration that combines a group of two or more machines called tier members into a tier failover group for stream-based Reliable and Consistent Message Streaming (RCMS). A tier consists of a group of application components in a configuration where each component is an identical replica. Each replica executes the application logic as if it was the only component. RCMS, by synchronizing inbound and outbound traffic for each tier member, ensures that the application remains available in the case of a failure. As a result, any new tier component can start fully functioning in parallel with its existing running peers, and support them in case of failure. RCMS is a part of LLM that provides high availability and consistent, ordered message delivery. It supports the following features: Failure detection and failover Total ordering State synchronization Component group management RCMS is based on a component replication model where all members of a tier group perform the following actions: Receive the same input Perform same processing Produce the same output RCMS enhances the high availability capabilities of RMM by ensuring that all instances of the application get exactly the same input and can therefore maintain identical state. For receiver tier topics this means that in all tier members all the tier receiver topics deliver exactly the same set of messages to the application. If the tier enforces total order, then all the messages from all topics are delivered in exactly the same order. Multiple instances of the application run simultaneously. If one of the instances of the application fails, RCMS detects the failure and automatically takes corrective actions (for example, to replace an instance that failed). Stream failover allows receivers to switch from one transmitter stream to another with little or no message loss when a transmitter fails. Both RMM and RUM support stream failover. RCMS implements basic stream failover by coordinating transmitters and synchronizing application state and message sequence numbers.

entry.name: llm_tier_group_kglobalconfig_descr_1828
entry.text: LLM Multicast Tier Group

entry.name: admin_state_llmmulticasttiergroup_help_1829
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_llmmulticasttiergroup_descr_1829
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: topic_llmmulticasttiergroup_help_1830
entry.text: The topic name to use for tier control messages. LLM maintains the specified control topic identically in all tiermembers.

entry.name: topic_llmmulticasttiergroup_descr_1830
entry.text: The topic to use for tier control messages

entry.name: group_llmmulticasttiergroup_help_1831
entry.text: Multicast group IP address to use for tier control messages. The full range of IPv4 multicast addresses is from 224.0.0.0 to 239.255.255.255. IPv6 multicast addresses have the prefix ff00::/8

entry.name: group_llmmulticasttiergroup_descr_1831
entry.text: The multicast group to use for tier control messages

entry.name: port_llmmulticasttiergroup_help_1832
entry.text: The port to use for tier control messages.

entry.name: port_llmmulticasttiergroup_descr_1832
entry.text: The port to use for tier control messages

entry.name: total_order_llmmulticasttiergroup_help_1833
entry.text: Use the Total Order toggle to ensure that all members process messages in the same order from different sources. When enabled, total order enforces a consistent, ordered delivery of messages from a number of independent data transmitters to multiple receivers. If set to on, enforces total order message processing for all tier members. otal order is required in most cases where the application processes messages from more than one source. Each source sends a reliable ordered stream of messages, but the message ordering among different sources is not preserved, so each receiving component sees a different order of incoming data. If the application receives its data from a single source there is no need for total order (the order of the single source will be provided by RMM). If set to off, which is the default, it does not enforce total order processing.

entry.name: total_order_llmmulticasttiergroup_descr_1833
entry.text: Total Order

entry.name: real_synchrony_llmmulticasttiergroup_help_1834
entry.text: Use the Full Synchronization toggle to force the primary member of the tier to ensure that message ordering information has been received and acknowledged by all tier members before it is allowed to process messages. When on it enables full synchronization. Using synchronization can significantly slow down message processing.

entry.name: real_synchrony_llmmulticasttiergroup_descr_1834
entry.text: Full Synchronization

entry.name: member_name_llmmulticasttiergroup_help_1835
entry.text: Name for the primary member of the tier group which is an alphanumeric string that is unique to the Member List.

entry.name: member_name_llmmulticasttiergroup_descr_1835
entry.text: Member Name

entry.name: member_llmmulticasttiergroup_help_1836
entry.text: The name and IP address information for a tier group member. Use the up, down, and delete icons to maintain the member list. Enter values using the following syntax: <member name>@ip:port Specified port numbers are used for inter-tier communication between LLM Multicast Tier Group objects and are unique to the Member List. Any member of a Multicast Tier Group must specify its name and address information in its own Member List.

entry.name: member_llmmulticasttiergroup_descr_1836
entry.text: Member List

entry.name: sync_interval_llmmulticasttiergroup_help_1837
entry.text: Time value, in milliseconds, to establish the interval between synchronization control tier reports. By default, the tier group member will send synchronization tier reports using the control channel every 60000 milliseconds.

entry.name: sync_interval_llmmulticasttiergroup_descr_1837
entry.text: Synchronization Period

entry.name: max_order_memory_llmmulticasttiergroup_help_1838
entry.text: Value in kilobytes for the maximum amount of memory to allocate for total order information in the Max Order Buffer Size field. The default is 256 kilobytes.

entry.name: max_order_memory_llmmulticasttiergroup_descr_1838
entry.text: Max order buffer size

entry.name: max_tier_memory_llmmulticasttiergroup_help_1839
entry.text: Value in megabytes for the maximum amount of memory to allocate for tier data. The default is 150 megabytes.

entry.name: max_tier_memory_llmmulticasttiergroup_descr_1839
entry.text: Max tier memory use

entry.name: heartbeat_timeout_llmmulticasttiergroup_help_1840
entry.text: Timeout value for heartbeats. The default is 2000 milliseconds. Use heartbeats to detect when transmitters or receivers are no longer present. If a receiver does not get a transmitted heartbeat message within the configured time, it closes any data streams from that transmitter. Minimally configure the heartbeat timeout to be several times the size of the heartbeat interval. Setting the heartbeat timeout closer to the heartbeat interval will cause connection failures to be detected sooner, but can cause failures due to temporary network delays.

entry.name: heartbeat_timeout_llmmulticasttiergroup_descr_1840
entry.text: Heartbeat timeout

entry.name: heartbeat_interval_llmmulticasttiergroup_help_1841
entry.text: Time interval at which the transmitter sends heartbeat messages to its receivers. The default is 500 milliseconds. Enter a value of 0 to disable heartbeat transmissions. To avoid false heartbeat timeout events, set the heartbeat interval to a time value considerably smaller than the heartbeat timeout.

entry.name: heartbeat_interval_llmmulticasttiergroup_descr_1841
entry.text: Heartbeat interval

entry.name: startup_timeout_llmmulticasttiergroup_help_1842
entry.text: Value for the maximum amount of time to wait for other members of the tier group to start up. The default is 60000 milliseconds.

entry.name: startup_timeout_llmmulticasttiergroup_descr_1842
entry.text: Startup timout

entry.name: llm_transmit_kglobalconfig_help_1843
entry.text: Use this panel to define the properties of a Low Latency Messaging Multicast Transmit object. A transmitter is part of a message delivery system that sends messages to one or more receivers. The transmitter supports the following types of data transmissions: one-to-one, one-to-many, and many-to-many.

entry.name: llm_transmit_kglobalconfig_descr_1843
entry.text: LLM Multicast Transmit

entry.name: admin_state_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1844
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1844
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: interface_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1845
entry.text: Specifies the names of network interfaces or IP addresses for which the LLM Multicast Transmit object is expected to send message packets. The first network interface name or address in a list is primary. As a best practice, enter an IP address with a specific value. Do not specify 0.0.0.0 for IPv4 or :: for IPv6 to transmit packets on any network interface.

entry.name: interface_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1845
entry.text: Multicast Interfaces

entry.name: port_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1846
entry.text: The port number on which the LLM Multicast Transmit object is expected to transmit message packets.

entry.name: port_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1846
entry.text: Data Port

entry.name: multicast_loop_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1847
entry.text: Enable or disable Multicast Loop. Enable Multicast Loop when the transmitter and receiver are on the same machine or network interface. When enabled, a copy of the message received on the appliance is routed back to the sending process on the same network interface.

entry.name: multicast_loop_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1847
entry.text: Multicast Loopback

entry.name: rate_limit_mode_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1848
entry.text: Specify a mechanism to use for controlling the rate of message transmission. Choose one of the following:

entry.name: rate_limit_mode_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1848
entry.text: Sets rate limit mode for message transmission

entry.name: rate_limit_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1849
entry.text: Specifies a rate limit you can enter in kilobits per second (kbps). A value of 0 (the default) designates unlimited transmit rate; there is no transmission rate control. If Rate Limit Mode is set to: Static Transmit Rate Limit specifies the maximum rate at which the transmitter can transmit. Dynamic Transmit Rate Limit specifies the upper boundary rate at which transmitter can transmit. There is no lower limit.

entry.name: rate_limit_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1849
entry.text: Transmit Rate limit

entry.name: packet_size_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1850
entry.text: Specifies the size of packets the transmitter can send in bytes. The default and recommended size is 8000 bytes.

entry.name: packet_size_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1850
entry.text: Packet Size

entry.name: connection_ttl_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1851
entry.text: Specifies the Time To Live (TTL) value for multicast packets. The default is 1. This parameter controls the number of times a multicast packet can be propagated across routers. This field configures the number of hops.

entry.name: connection_ttl_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1851
entry.text: Multicast Connection TTL

entry.name: heartbeat_timeout_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1852
entry.text: Specifies the timeout value you can enter for a heartbeat message sent by the transmitter to its receivers. The default is 2000 milliseconds. The transmitter constantly sends heartbeat messages to its receivers. If a receiver does not get a heartbeat message within the specified period of time, it closes any stream that originated from the transmitter. The receiver assumes that the transmitter has failed. This should be several times the size of the heartbeat interval. Setting this smaller will cause failure to be detected sooner, but can cause failures to be detected due to network delay.

entry.name: heartbeat_timeout_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1852
entry.text: Heartbeat timeout

entry.name: heartbeat_interval_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1853
entry.text: Specifies the time interval at which the transmitter sends heartbeat messages to its receivers. The default is 500 milliseconds. Enter a value of 0 to disable heartbeat transmissions. To avoid false heartbeat timeout events, set the Heartbeat Interval to a value considerably smaller than the Heartbeat Timeout.

entry.name: heartbeat_interval_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1853
entry.text: Heartbeat interval

entry.name: max_memory_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1854
entry.text: Specifies a value you can enter for the maximum amount of memory that the transmitter can consume. The default is 200000 kilobytes.

entry.name: max_memory_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1854
entry.text: Maximum memory

entry.name: min_history_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1855
entry.text: Specifies a value you can enter for configuring the minimum amount of memory that the transmitter must reserve for storing history packets. The default is 120000 kilobytes. The transmitter stores sent packets in its history buffers. The buffers enable the transmitter to resend packets to receivers that experience packet loss.

entry.name: min_history_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1855
entry.text: Minimum history

entry.name: max_pending_q_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1856
entry.text: Specifies a value you can enter for the maximum total amount of memory that pending packets can consume. The default is 0 and will allow the LLM Unicast object to compute the size.

entry.name: max_pending_q_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1856
entry.text: Max pending queue size in KBytes

entry.name: adaptive_packet_rate_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1857
entry.text: Specifies a value you can configure for controlling the rate of partial packets sent by the transmitter. The default value is Disabled. When enabled, the value you select can be used to increase throughput or reduce transmitter latency by modifying the batching policy of the transmitter. Controlling the rate of partial packets is important when the transmitter sends many small packets. The optimal rate of partial packets depends on feedback from the transmitter and/or the receivers. The Minimum batching and Maximum batching parameters set the lower and upper limit for batching time. If the transmitter is not receiving NAKs, it will decrease the batching time to the value configured for Minimum batching. If NAKs are received, the transmitter will increase the batching time to the value configured for Maximum batching. Choose one of the following:

entry.name: adaptive_packet_rate_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1857
entry.text: Adaptive packet rate

entry.name: min_batching_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1858
entry.text: When Adaptive packet rate is enabled, specifies the lower limit on batching time for partial packets. The default is 20 microseconds. The transmitter will wait at least the specified amount of time before sending a partial packet on a stream. If you set Adaptive packet rate to Global, the global rate of partial packets is calculated as rate=1e6/ Minimum batching.

entry.name: min_batching_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1858
entry.text: Minimum batching

entry.name: max_batching_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1859
entry.text: When Adaptive packet rate is enabled, specifies the upper limit on batching time for partial packets. The default is 500 microseconds. The transmitter will wait at most the specified amount of time before sending a partial packet on a stream. If you set Adaptive packet rate to Global, this value is not used.

entry.name: max_batching_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1859
entry.text: Maximum batching

entry.name: repair_alert_rate_high_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1860
entry.text: Integer value of one or higher to define an upper threshold at which Repair alert ON event is raised to the application. The specified value represents repair packets requested per second. The default value of 0 or lower indicates that NAK alert events should be disabled.

entry.name: repair_alert_rate_high_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1860
entry.text: Repair alert rate high

entry.name: repair_alert_rate_low_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1861
entry.text: Integer value of one or higher to define a low threshold at which Repair alert ON event is raised to the application. The specified value represents repair packets requested per second. The default value of 0 or lower indicates that NAK alert events should be disabled.

entry.name: repair_alert_rate_low_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1861
entry.text: Repair alert rate low

entry.name: thread_priority_llmmulticasttransmit_help_1862
entry.text: Priority value to assign the transmitter Fireout thread that sends packets out to the network. Specify a value from 0 to 100. The default value is 0. A zero value means the thread priority is not changed by the RMM protocol. Specify a value of 100 to assign the highest priority to a transmitter thread. Setting a higher Thread priority to key RMM threads can reduce overall latency and latency spikes.

entry.name: thread_priority_llmmulticasttransmit_descr_1862
entry.text: Thread priority

entry.name: llm_policy_kglobalconfig_help_1863
entry.text: An LLM Policy provides the means for receiving LLM data streams. Receiving resources are defined in the LLM Multicast Receive object or LLM Unicast object associated with the LLM Instance assigned to a policy. A policy can contain one or more LLM routes that define outbound destinations for received messages. Rules for topic and message selection can be built using SQL-92 like expressions that use LLM properties, variables, and fields. You can receive messages over multiple topics and reject data streams from particular sources. A policy functions as a gateway for routing messages rapidly through the appliance or as a bridge to DataPower service policies.

entry.name: llm_policy_kglobalconfig_descr_1863
entry.text: LLM Policy

entry.name: admin_state_llmpolicy_help_1864
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_llmpolicy_descr_1864
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_llmpolicy_descr_1865
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: protocol_llmpolicy_help_1866
entry.text: To configure the receive protocol for this policy, choose one of the following:

entry.name: protocol_llmpolicy_descr_1866
entry.text: Receive protocol for policy

entry.name: instance_llmpolicy_help_1867
entry.text: Select the name of an existing Multicast or Unicast Instance object from the list or create a new one.

entry.name: instance_llmpolicy_descr_1867
entry.text: LLM Instance

entry.name: topic_llmpolicy_help_1868
entry.text: The name of the topic or queue. If Topic Selection is specified, this will not be used. Only one policy at a time can receive a particular stream. Policies which give the topic name are preferred to those with a Topic Selection if several policies attempt to receive the same stream.

entry.name: topic_llmpolicy_descr_1868
entry.text: Topic Name

entry.name: topic_selection_llmpolicy_help_1869
entry.text: Use a SQL-92 expression to define a set of topics. If specified, this field overrides Topic Name when deciding which topics to select for a policy. Using Topic Selection it is possible to have one policy receive from multiple topics. It is also possible to have several policies receive from a single topic, but from separate streams. The following example shows a SQL-92 expression that will select all of the incoming topics in set {topicIBM, topic3, topic_fred}: llm:Topic LIKE 'topic%%' Additionally, setting Topic Selection to: llm:Topic IN topicIBM generates the same result as entering topicIBM for Topic Name. You can specify the following strings: Topic The topic or queue name on which the data is transmitted LocalAddr The local address on which the stream is received LocalPort The local port on which the stream is received SourceAddr The source address from which the stream is received SourcePort The source port from which the stream is received Authorization A string send from the other side of the stream to identify the sender. This can be used to authenticate the stream.

entry.name: topic_selection_llmpolicy_descr_1869
entry.text: Topic Selection

entry.name: selection_llmpolicy_help_1870
entry.text: A SQL92 statement. If this evaluates TRUE the message is selected. If it evaluates FALSE or UNKNOWN it is not selected. An empty selection evaluates TRUE. The result of the expression is coerced to boolean if required. Fields and expression are evaluated as boolean, string, int (32 bit) long (64 bit), or double. The type is coerced as required by the operator. If both operands are of the same type, no conversion is done. The unary operators int, long, float, double, and string may be used to force conversion to the desired type. String constants are created by placing the string in single quotes. Unquoted values which can be evaluated to an integer or floating point value are numeric constant. The names true , false , and unknown are boolean constants. Operators and constants may be given in either lower or upper case, but mixed case is not allowed. Unquoted names are considered names if they start with an alphabetic character or one of the specials at-sign (@), percent (%%), or underscore (_). Names may continue with any alphanumeric character including the special characters colon(:), left-bracket([), right-bracket (]) at-sign (@), dot (.), percent(%%), ampersand(&), underscore (_), dollar ($), or bar (|). Any character may be used in a name by enclosing it in double quotes. The names between, boolean, double, escape, exists, false, float, in, is, int, like, long, not null, or, string, true, and unknown are reserved for operators. Expressions are evaluated based on the priority of the operators. Parenthesis can be used at any point to control the order of execution. Otherwise the priority order is: Unary operators (not, -, +, int, long, float, double, string) Binary multiply and divide Binary addition and subtraction String concatenation between, boolean, in, is, like, exists Logical AND and OR Expressions are evaluated in order, and if any AND or OR clause derives a result of TRUE or FALSE, which resolves the expression, the rest of the expression is not evaluated. Integers are coerced to boolean by the rule that 0 is false, and all other values are true. Strings are coerced to boolean by the rule that the values true , enabled , on , yes , and 1 are true, the values false , disabled , off , no , and 0 are false, and all other values are unknown. All other types are unknown. Field names may be the names of properties, special fields, or content parsing fields. Special fields and content parsing are indicated by the use of a namespace at the start of the field followed by a colon. The following namespaces are allowed: #b#llm#/b# When the name is a number from 0 to 32767 this is an llm field with a numeric name. The special names are: Byte[#] A numeric byte from the message, where 0 is the first byte From The source IP if known Label The numeric TurboFlow label Length The length of the message Sequence The sequence number of the message Text The text of the message Time The current timestamp Topic The topic name #b#fix#/b# The name is either a number in the range 0 to 32767 or the canonical name of a FIX field. For fields which exist multiple times in the file, a value in brackets starting with the value 0 can be used to indicate which instance. All FIX fields are of type string. #b#var#/b# The field is a global variable. #b#xml#/b# This returns a simple value (not a list) from the content parse of an XML document. The result is the value of an attribute, the name of an element, or the value of the first content of the element. The slash (/) or bar (|) can be used as the element separator. If there is no leading separator, or if there are two adjacent separators, and number of levels are matched. If the string ends with an at-sign (@) followed by an attribute name, the value of the attribute is returned. Examples field names: fix:8 Check if this is a FIX document fix:Symbol Fix Symbol (55) tag fix:213[3] The fourth instance of tag 213 llm:7 LLM numeric property 7 llm:Topic The topic xml:/ Check if this is an XML document xml:symbol The contents of the first symbol element xml:symbol@v The value of the v attribute of the first symbol element xml:/root/symbol The value of the symbol element within root

entry.name: selection_llmpolicy_descr_1870
entry.text: Message Selection

entry.name: interface_llmpolicy_help_1871
entry.text: The interface specified here will override the local receiving interface specified in the Unicast/RMM Receive object associated with this policy's instance.

entry.name: interface_llmpolicy_descr_1871
entry.text: The interface to use when using the RUDP or RUM protocols

entry.name: group_llmpolicy_help_1872
entry.text: The multicast group to use when using the RMM protocol. Ignored for other protocol options. The full range of IPv4 multicast addresses is from 224.0.0.0 to 239.255.255.255. IPv6 multicast addresses have the prefix ff00::/8

entry.name: group_llmpolicy_descr_1872
entry.text: The multicast group to use when using the RMM protocol

entry.name: route_llmpolicy_help_1873
entry.text: A list of LLM Route objects on which to send

entry.name: route_llmpolicy_descr_1873
entry.text: Route List

entry.name: reliability_llmpolicy_help_1874
entry.text: Sets the reliability level that ensures the delivery of data to intended recipients. Reliability protects the data stream by tolerating transient network disruption or application failure. Transmitters and recipients must have the same reliability level. The following reliability levels are available:

entry.name: reliability_llmpolicy_descr_1874
entry.text: Reliability level for data delivery

entry.name: goback_time_llmpolicy_help_1875
entry.text: Value in milliseconds that is the time allotted for a receiver to get previously sent data upon joining a stream. Entering a nonzero number is equivalent to late join.

entry.name: goback_time_llmpolicy_descr_1875
entry.text: Goback time

entry.name: stream_join_backtrack_llmpolicy_help_1876
entry.text: The number of packets the receiver will attempt to request from the transmitter history buffer when joining a new stream. The default value is null. The receiver joins on the first data packet and does not request any previously sent packets. Note: This feature is implemented on the RMM protocol only.

entry.name: stream_join_backtrack_llmpolicy_descr_1876
entry.text: Stream join backtrack

entry.name: app_level_ack_llmpolicy_help_1877
entry.text: The Application level ACK toggle configures the sending of ACKs at the application level. If on, it enables ACKs at the application level. The application does not send an ACK until it has completely processed a message. Off (default) does not enable the ACKs.

entry.name: app_level_ack_llmpolicy_descr_1877
entry.text: Application level ACK

entry.name: mandatory_acker_llmpolicy_help_1878
entry.text: Determines whether ther receiver will identify itself as a mandatory ACKer. As a prerequisite the application level ACK must also be enabled. Default value is off.

entry.name: mandatory_acker_llmpolicy_descr_1878
entry.text: Identity ACK as Mandatory

entry.name: trv_policy_kglobalconfig_help_1879
entry.text: A TIBCO RV Policy provides the means for receiving TIBCO RV data streams. Receiving resources are defined in the TIBCO RV Policy object. A policy can contain one or more TIBCO RV routes that define outbound destinations for received messages. Rules for subject and message selection can be built using SQL-92 like expressions that use TICBO RV properties, variables, and fields. You can receive messages over multiple subjects and reject data streams from particular sources. A policy functions as a gateway for routing messages rapidly through the appliance or as a bridge to DataPower service policies.

entry.name: trv_policy_kglobalconfig_descr_1879
entry.text: TIBCO RV Policy

entry.name: instance_trvpolicy_descr_1883

entry.name: subject_trvpolicy_help_1884
entry.text: A subject name is a string that defines a logical channel of communication between transmitters and receivers. Configure what subjects a policy can listen on by specifying a Subject. Receivers subscribe to messages on a subject. The structure of a subject name is a string of characters which are divided into elements by the dot character. A valid subject name may not be more than 196 characters minus the number of elements. A single element can not be longer than 127 characters. Wildcard characters are acceptable character. The asterisk is a wildcard character that matches any one element. The greater-than character is a wild card character that matches all the elements remaining to the right. Examples of valid subject names: finance.stock.yield finance.stock.* finance.>

entry.name: subject_trvpolicy_descr_1884
entry.text: Subject

entry.name: search_subject_trvpolicy_help_1885
entry.text: Specifies the prearranged subject name representing the logical channel to listen on for inbound point-to-point inbox request messages.

entry.name: search_subject_trvpolicy_descr_1885
entry.text: Search Subject

entry.name: selection_trvpolicy_help_1886
entry.text: A SQL92 statement. If this evaluates TRUE the message is selected. If it evaluates FALSE or UNKNOWN it is not selected. An empty selection evaluates TRUE. The result of the expression is coerced to boolean if required. Fields and expression are evaluated as boolean, string, int (32 bit) long (64 bit), or double. The type is coerced as required by the operator. If both operands are of the same type, no conversion is done. The unary operators int, long, float, double, and string may be used to force conversion to the desired type. String constants are created by placing the string in single quotes. Unquoted values which can be evaluated to an integer or floating point value are numeric constant. The names true , false , and unknown are boolean constants. Operators and constants may be given in either lower or upper case, but mixed case is not allowed. Unquoted names are considered names if they start with an alphabetic character or one of the specials at-sign (@), percent (%%), or underscore (_). Names may continue with any alphanumeric character including the special characters colon(:), left-bracket([), right-bracket (]) at-sign (@), dot (.), percent(%%), ampersand(&), underscore (_), dollar ($), or bar (|). Any character may be used in a name by enclosing it in double quotes. The names between, boolean, double, escape, exists, false, float, in, is, int, like, long, not null, or, string, true, and unknown are reserved for operators. Expressions are evaluated based on the priority of the operators. Parenthesis can be used at any point to control the order of execution. Otherwise the priority order is: Unary operators (not, -, +, int, long, float, double, string) Binary multiply and divide Binary addition and subtraction String concatenation between, boolean, in, is, like, exists Logical AND and OR Expressions are evaluated in order, and if any AND or OR clause derives a result of TRUE or FALSE, which resolves the expression, the rest of the expression is not evaluated. Integers are coerced to boolean by the rule that 0 is false, and all other values are true. Strings are coerced to boolean by the rule that the values true , enabled , on , yes , and 1 are true, the values false , disabled , off , no , and 0 are false, and all other values are unknown. All other types are unknown. Field names may be the names of properties, special fields, or content parsing fields. Special fields and content parsing are indicated by the use of a namespace at the start of the field followed by a colon. The following namespaces are allowed: #b#llm#/b# When the name is a number from 0 to 32767 this is an llm field with a numeric name. The special names are: Byte[#] A numeric byte from the message, where 0 is the first byte From The source IP if known Label The numeric TurboFlow label Length The length of the message Sequence The sequence number of the message Text The text of the message Time The current timestamp Topic The topic name #b#fix#/b# The name is either a number in the range 0 to 32767 or the canonical name of a FIX field. For fields which exist multiple times in the file, a value in brackets starting with the value 0 can be used to indicate which instance. All FIX fields are of type string. #b#var#/b# The field is a global variable. #b#xml#/b# This returns a simple value (not a list) from the content parse of an XML document. The result is the value of an attribute, the name of an element, or the value of the first content of the element. The slash (/) or bar (|) can be used as the element separator. If there is no leading separator, or if there are two adjacent separators, and number of levels are matched. If the string ends with an at-sign (@) followed by an attribute name, the value of the attribute is returned. Examples field names: fix:8 Check if this is a FIX document fix:Symbol Fix Symbol (55) tag fix:213[3] The fourth instance of tag 213 llm:7 LLM numeric property 7 llm:Topic The topic xml:/ Check if this is an XML document xml:symbol The contents of the first symbol element xml:symbol@v The value of the v attribute of the first symbol element xml:/root/symbol The value of the symbol element within root

entry.name: certified_message_delivery_trvpolicy_help_1889
entry.text: Specifies whether to provide delivery assurance. When certified message delivery is enabled the receiver will attempt to establish a certified delivery agreement with the sender. Once agreement is established, confirmation is provided to the message sender that its messages have been delivered to the recipient and that the messages are received in the order in which they were sent.

entry.name: use_ledger_file_trvpolicy_help_1896
entry.text: Enables use of a persistent file based ledger. The default is off, which means the ledger is stored in memory. Using a persistent file based ledger enables certified message delivery to be resumed in the case where the transport is destroyed and reestablished.

entry.name: use_ledger_file_trvpolicy_descr_1896
entry.text: Use Ledger File

entry.name: sync_ledger_trvpolicy_help_1898
entry.text: Specifies whether ledger file updates are synchronized to the disk before an operation can continue. Default is off.

entry.name: sync_ledger_trvpolicy_descr_1898
entry.text: Sync ledger file to disk

entry.name: cm_name_trvpolicy_help_1899
entry.text: The reusable name for the certified message delivery transport. If the transport also uses a file based ledger, then Certified Message Delivery can be resumed in the case where the transport is destroyed and reestablished. If Certified Message Delivery Name is not specified, a unique non-resuable name will be automatically generated. Reusable names must not contain the following: Reserved elements such as _INBOX, _RV, _LOCAL More than four elements More than fifty characters in length Leading character of an underscore ('_') Wildcard characters Null element The same name as an existing cm-name or relay agent on the network

entry.name: cm_name_trvpolicy_descr_1899
entry.text: Certified Message Delivery Name

entry.name: llm_route_kglobalconfig_help_1904
entry.text: The Route object configures the transmission characteristics for outbound messages. Each route object creates a logical outbound stream. An LLM policy can define multiple routes on which to send outbound messages. The routes also use Message Selection rules to filter outbound messages. Once a message is selected for routing, you configure a Topic Name that describes where to route the message. The route also provides a property mapping rule that controls the propagation of properties from inbound to outbound messages. The Copy Message Properties toggle, when enabled, automatically copies all inbound message properties to output properties. A property map allows you to change or suppress the propagation of properties. The TurboFlow label and/or bitmap are always copied from input to output independently of the copy properties setting.

entry.name: llm_route_kglobalconfig_descr_1904
entry.text: LLM Route

entry.name: admin_state_llmroute_help_1905
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: selection_llmroute_help_1909
entry.text: A SQL-92 expression. Use this field to filter outbound messages. If the SQL-92 expression evaluates to TRUE, the message is selected and routed. If it evaluates to FALSE or UNKNOWN, it is not routed. The default is TRUE. For example, use the following syntax to select all outbound messages whose prop1 property begins with the letter a: prop1 like 'a%%' You can build expressions using message properties or parsed fields that are part of the message content. For example, specifying: xml:Symbol@name will give you the name attribute on the first Symbol element in the message. If this element does not exist, the result is UNKNOWN and the message is not selected.

entry.name: selection_llmroute_descr_1909
entry.text: Message Selection

entry.text: The name of the topic on which to send the message

entry.text: Topic Name

entry.name: destination_llmroute_help_1911
entry.text: The remote host name or IP address when using the RUDP or RUM protocols. Ignored for other protocol options.

entry.name: destination_llmroute_descr_1911
entry.text: The remote host name or IP address when using the RUDP or RUM protocols

entry.name: group_llmroute_help_1912
entry.text: The multicast group to use when using the RMM protocol. Ignored for other protocol options. The full range of IPv4 multicast addresses is from 224.0.0.0 to 239.255.255.255. IPv6 multicast addresses have the prefix ff00::/8

entry.name: group_llmroute_descr_1912
entry.text: The multicast group to use when using the RMM protocol

entry.name: port_llmroute_help_1913
entry.text: The destination port. If port number is not specified in the route object, the service uses the port number defined in the LLM Instance associated with the protocol type. If the route uses the RUDP or RMM protocol, the service uses the default destination port on the LLM Transmit object associated with the LLM Instance. If the route uses RUM, the service uses the default destination port defined on the LLM Unicast Instance object.

entry.name: port_llmroute_descr_1913
entry.text: Data Port

entry.name: reliability_llmroute_help_1914
entry.text: Sets the reliability level that ensures the delivery of data to intended recipients. Reliability protects the data stream by tolerating transient network disruption or application failure. Transmitters and recipients must have the same reliability level. The following reliability levels are available:

entry.name: reliability_llmroute_descr_1914
entry.text: Reliability level for data delivery

entry.name: turboflow_llmroute_help_1915
entry.text: The TurboFlow label and/or bitmap is propagated from input to output or suppressed based on the Use TurboFlow setting on the route. The Use TurboFlow setting is independent of the Copy Message Properties setting. Applications outside of DataPower may use the TurboFlow property for high performance message selection. External applications must use the same TurboFlow method between transmitter and receiver to enable the message filtering process. The DataPower appliance, however, will receive all messages regardless of the enabled TurboFlow method and may perform message filtering based on llm:Label or llm:Bitmap properties. Select one of the following:

entry.name: turboflow_llmroute_descr_1915
entry.text: Use TurboFlow

entry.name: properties_llmroute_help_1916
entry.text: Use this toggle to enable property mapping rules that transform input properties to output properties for transmitted messages.

entry.name: properties_llmroute_descr_1916
entry.text: Use Properties

entry.name: copy_properties_llmroute_help_1917
entry.text: Use this toggle to copy input properties to output properties for transmitted messages before property mapping.

entry.name: copy_properties_llmroute_descr_1917
entry.text: Copy Message Properties

entry.name: map_properties_llmroute_help_1918
entry.text: Specifies a set of rules to add properties to outbound messages that are transmitted through this route. Before creating mapping rules, enable the Use Properties toggle. Enable the Copy Message Properties toggle to ensure that properties are copied from the input message and are available for use with a map. Copying properties is not required if only using the map to create new properties. Mapping rules provide a set of actions for modifying certain properties. Each rule consists of a property name or field that you can specify, such as llm:Length, followed by a new value, which can be a SQL92 expression to be evaluated. If the SQL92 expression is blank or resolves to unknown, no assignment is done, and the specified property is removed from the output. Otherwise, expressions used in mapping rules resolve to integers, strings, or floating points. Mapping rules for a message execute in sequential order. Output properties can reside in the unspecified or llm namespaces. Variables defined in the var namespace are never part of the output message. Properties in the fix and xml namespaces cannot be mapped, although fields in these namespaces can be used in creating a property value. You can modify or suppress TurboFlow values using a map properties rule. After configuring a field, such as llm:Length, all future references to that field will use its modified value. Create property mappings using the following fields or properties: llm:Label Sets the TurboFlow numeric label. llm:Length Sets the length of the message in bytes. llm:Text Replaces the text of the message with the expression value. llm:Bitmap Sets the TurboFlow bitmap. llm:Byte[#] Modifies the specified byte, where # is a number from 0 to the length of the message. The expression value is interpreted as an integer. var:integer Sets a local variable, a number between 0 and 9. Use to save a result in a temporary location. The saved value can be accessed in subsequent mappings within the same map. Local variables are never part of the message. var:name Sets a string used to create a variable that is global to the domain. Use to save a result in a temporary location. The saved value can be accessed in subsequent mappings across all maps in the domain. Global variables are never part of the message. property The name of a property in the unspecified property namespace (not llm or var) of an input message. Examples (if fred=3): fred fred+3 result: 6 fred fred#3 result: 33 fred 'fred'#3 result: fred3 fred fred+4.0 result: 7 fred "'fred' # fred" result: fred3

entry.name: map_properties_llmroute_descr_1918
entry.text: Map Properties

entry.name: interface_llmroute_help_1919
entry.text: This can be an IP address and will override the interface specified in the LLM instance associated with this route. Note: Currently supported for only RMM and RUDP.

entry.name: interface_llmroute_descr_1919
entry.text: Network Interface the LLM Route should use

entry.name: repair_port_llmroute_help_1920
entry.text: The UDP Repair Port to use for repair packets. These are packets that were missed by a receiver in the initial transmission. The receiver requests the retransmission of the missed packets. You can configure different destination ports for data and repair. Enter a value of 0 to send repair packets through the data port. If a receiver requests a message dropped from the history buffer, LLM generates an unrecoverable packet loss event.

entry.name: repair_port_llmroute_descr_1920
entry.text: Repair Port

entry.name: heartbeat_timeout_llmroute_help_1921
entry.text: Heartbeat Timeout value (in milliseconds) for a heartbeat message sent by the transmitter to its receivers. This value overrides the timeout value entered in the transmit object. Used by the receiver to decide if the transmitter is still alive.

entry.name: heartbeat_timeout_llmroute_descr_1921
entry.text: Heartbeat timeout

entry.name: heartbeat_interval_llmroute_help_1922
entry.text: Interval value in milliseconds for the amount of time between periodic heartbeats sent by the transmitter to its receivers in the Heartbeat Interval field. This value overrides the heartbeat interval entered in the transmit object. Heartbeats are sent to inform the receiver that the transmitter is alive.

entry.name: heartbeat_interval_llmroute_descr_1922
entry.text: Heartbeat interval

entry.name: history_size_llmroute_help_1923
entry.text: The number of packets for the minimum amount of memory that the transmitter must reserve for storing history packets. The transmitter stores sent packets in its history buffers. The buffers enable the transmitter to resend packets to receivers that experience packet loss.

entry.name: history_size_llmroute_descr_1923
entry.text: History size

entry.name: history_timeout_llmroute_help_1924
entry.text: Value in milliseconds for the time interval between periodic history cleaning for topics created with a history size greater than zero packets.

entry.name: history_timeout_llmroute_descr_1924
entry.text: History timeout

entry.name: ack_llmroute_help_1925
entry.text: Use Acknowledgment toggle to enable the transmission of positive acknowledgments (Acks) from receiver to transmitter acknowledging the receipt of a sent packet.

entry.name: ack_llmroute_descr_1925
entry.text: Use Acknowledgment

entry.name: ack_timeout_llmroute_help_1926
entry.text: Value in milliseconds for the amount of time a transmitter waits for an ACK before raising an alert event.

entry.name: ack_timeout_llmroute_descr_1926
entry.text: Ack Timeout

entry.name: ack_interval_llmroute_help_1927
entry.text: Value in milliseconds for how often the receiver should send ACKs back to the transmitter. Set this value lower than ACK timeout to avoid false ACK timeout events.

entry.name: ack_interval_llmroute_descr_1927
entry.text: Ack Interval

entry.name: ack_probe_llmroute_help_1928
entry.text: Value in milliseconds for the amount of time between receiver aliveness probes. The probes are used to ensure that the receiver is still alive and functioning. If the value is -1, no probes will be sent (in which case the transmitter may not detect that the receiver is no longer available).

entry.name: ack_probe_llmroute_descr_1928
entry.text: Ack Probe

entry.name: ack_max_retries_llmroute_help_1929
entry.text: Integer value that limits the number of times that the transmitter will attempt to request an ACK for a data packet with a specific sequence number. If an ACK for a sequence number is not received after the specified retry limit, then the transmitter stops sending requests to the receiver. The packet will be removed from the history buffer and a retry exceeded event will be raised to the application.

entry.name: ack_max_retries_llmroute_descr_1929
entry.text: Ack Max Retries

entry.name: num_ackers_llmroute_help_1930
entry.text: The number of receivers that need to send a positive acknowledgment for a packet before the transmitter will remove the packet from the history queue. Default value is 1.

entry.name: num_ackers_llmroute_descr_1930
entry.text: Number of Acknowledges required

entry.name: num_mandatory_ackers_llmroute_help_1931
entry.text: Specifies the number of mandatory receiver that need to send a positive acknowledgement for a packet before the transmitter will remover the packet from the history queue. The value must be less than or equal to the number of ACKers. Default value is 0.

entry.name: num_mandatory_ackers_llmroute_descr_1931
entry.text: Mandatory ACKers required

entry.name: late_join_llmroute_help_1932
entry.text: Allow late join when the topic is transmitted.

entry.name: late_join_llmroute_descr_1932
entry.text: Allow late join

entry.name: oneway_heartbeat_llmroute_help_1933
entry.text: One way heartbeat. If on, no response will be expected by the sender of the heartbeat.

entry.name: oneway_heartbeat_llmroute_descr_1933
entry.text: One way Heartbeat

entry.name: cron_llmroute_help_1934
entry.text: When the current time matches the entered time specification, a time based event is sent over this route. The event can be further processed using the property map of this route. The time specification is a string containing any number of the following (where # represents a number): D# Specify a day in the month (1-31) Enter: D1 Result: Run on the first day of the month W# Specify a day in the week (0=Sunday, 6=Saturday) Enter: W0 Result: Run on Sunday H# Specify an hour (0 - 23) Enter: H13 Result: Run at 13:00UTC H%%# Match an hour where the modulo # is zero Enter: H%%2 Result: Run every two hours M# Specify a minute (0 - 59) Enter: M10 Result: Run in ten minutes M%%# Match a minute where the modulo # is zero Enter: M%%5 Result: Run every five minutes S# Specify a second (0 - 59) Enter: S30 Result: Run at 30 seconds into the minute S%%# Match a second where the modulo # is zero Enter: S%%30 Result: Run every 30 seconds

entry.name: cron_llmroute_descr_1934
entry.text: Time based event

entry.name: send_events_llmroute_help_1935
entry.text: Specify a condition to meet for sending events on this route. Specify one of the following:

entry.name: send_events_llmroute_descr_1935
entry.text: Filter for sending events

entry.name: global_event_llmroute_help_1936
entry.text: Use the Events for All Instances toggle to configure the sending of RMM or RUM events. Use this option to create an event monitor for the system. If set to on, send events that occur on any LLM Instance. If set to off, which is the default, only send events that occur on the LLM Instance associated with this route.

entry.name: global_event_llmroute_descr_1936
entry.text: Enable events for all instances

entry.name: connection_timeout_llmunicast_help_1951
entry.text: The value for the amount of time a receiver waits for a connection to be established in the Connection Timeout field. Time is measured from the moment the connection is accepted at the TCP level until the LLM connection establishment process is completed. The default is 60000 milliseconds.

entry.name: connection_timeout_llmunicast_descr_1951
entry.text: Establish connection timeout

entry.name: rx_thread_priority_llmunicast_help_1952
entry.text: Priority value to assign threads for the receiver. Enter a value from 0 to 100. A value of 100, for example, means the highest possible priority. A value of 0 means thread priority is not changed by the unicast object.

entry.name: rx_thread_priority_llmunicast_descr_1952

entry.name: tx_thread_priority_llmunicast_help_1953
entry.text: Priority value to assign the transmitter Fireout thread that sends packets out to the network. Specify a value from 0 to 100. The default value is 0. A zero value means the thread priority is not changed by the unicast object. Specify a value of 100 to assign the highest priority to a transmitter thread. Setting a higher Thread priority to key unicast transmit threads can reduce overall latency and latency spikes.

entry.name: mpgw_error_handling_kglobalconfig_help_2019
entry.text: A Multi-Protocol gateway error policy consists of one or more error actions. A service runs an error action depending on whether or not a corresponding matching rule selects the action for processing. A service can have one policy active at a time. When an error occurs in the Multi-Protocol Gateway from an HTTP or HTTPS request flow and no precedent error handler handles the error, the service calls the error policy.

entry.name: match_mpgwerrorhandlingpolicy_help_2022

entry.name: idg_mq_qm_kglobalconfig_help_2023
entry.text: In IBM MQ, distributed send and receive queues are managed by a component called a queue manager. The queue manager provides messaging services for communicating applications by periodically monitoring/polling queues, by ensuring that sent messages are directed to the correct receive queue, or that messages are routed to another queue manager. This queue manager object corresponds to a queue manager that is running on an IBM MQ server in your network. These properties enable communication between the DataPower Gateway and the queue manager on the remote IBM MQ server.

entry.name: idg_mq_qm_kglobalconfig_descr_2023
entry.text: IBM MQ v9+ Queue Manager

entry.name: admin_state_mqmanager_help_2024
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: hostname_mqmanager_help_2026
entry.text: Specify the host name or IP address with the listening port of the IBM MQ server where the queue manager is running. If you do not specify the port, the default is 1414. The value depends on IP family. For IPv4 hostname:port -- For example, server1:1414 hostname(port) -- For example, server1(1414) hostname -- For example, server1 address:port -- For example, 10.10.1.2:1414 address(port) -- For example, 10.10.1.2(1414) address -- For example, 10.10.1.2 For IPv6 hostname:port -- For example, server1:1414 hostname(port) -- For example, server1(1414) hostname -- For example, server1 [address]:port -- For example, [2202::148:248]:1414 address(port) -- For example, 2202::148:248(1414) address -- For example, 2202::148:248

entry.name: hostname_mqmanager_descr_2026
entry.text: Host name or IP address with port
