entry.name: queue_manager_mqmanager_descr_2027
entry.text: Name of queue manager

entry.name: ccsid_mqmanager_help_2028
entry.text: Specify the CCSID to present to the queue manager when the DataPower Gateway connects to it. This setting has the same effect as setting the MQCCSID environment variable for an IBM MQ client. Refer to the IBM MQ Knowledge Center for more information and a list of specific CCSID values. Unless necessary, use the default value.

entry.name: ccsid_mqmanager_descr_2028
entry.text: Coded character set identifier (CCSID)

entry.name: channel_name_mqmanager_help_2029
entry.text: Specify the name of the channel to use as an alternative to the default SYSTEM.DEF.SVRCONN.

entry.name: channel_name_mqmanager_descr_2029
entry.text: Name of channel connection

entry.name: mqcsp_userid_mqmanager_help_2030
entry.text: Specify the user ID value of the MQCSP connection security parameter when the MQCSP structure is used for authorization service. The MQCSP support enables the authorization service to authenticate a user ID and password. You can specify the MQCSP connection security parameters structure on an MQCONNX call. Before using the MQCSP support, you need to define a security exit in the queue manager on the IBM MQ server. Ensure that your MQCSP user ID and password in the security exit are consistent with what you input in the local queue manager. Either an inconsistent MQCSP user ID or an inconsistent password causes a failure of connection between the DataPower Gateway and the IBM MQ server. #b#Notes:#/b# If neither of the MQCSP user ID or the password is defined, the DataPower Gateway connects to the IBM MQ server without MQCSP settings. If only one of them is defined, a warning occurs and the IBM MQ Queue Manager is not up. If both of them are defined but one is not consistent with that defined on the IBM MQ server, the connection fails and the queue manager is not up.

entry.name: mqcsp_userid_mqmanager_descr_2030
entry.text: User ID value of the MQCSP connection security parameter

entry.name: mqcsp_password_mqmanager_help_2031
entry.text: Specify the password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter when the MQCSP structure is used for authorization service. The MQCSP support enables the authorization service to authenticate a user ID and password. You can specify the MQCSP connection security parameters structure on an MQCONNX call. Before using the MQCSP support, you need to define a security exit in the queue manager on the IBM MQ server. Ensure that your MQCSP user ID and password in the security exit are consistent with what you input in the IBM MQ Queue Manager configuration. Either an inconsistent MQCSP user ID or an inconsistent password causes a failure of connection between the DataPower Gateway and the IBM MQ server. #b#Notes:#/b# If neither of the MQCSP user ID or the password is defined, DataPower connects to the IBM MQ server without MQCSP settings. If only one of them is defined, a warning occurs and the IBM MQ Queue Manager is not up. If both of them are defined but one is not consistent with that defined on the IBM MQ server, the connection fails and the local queue manager is not up.

entry.name: mqcsp_password_mqmanager_descr_2031
entry.text: Password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter

entry.name: mqcsp_password_alias_mqmanager_help_2032
entry.text: Specify the password alias of the password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter when the MQCSP structure is used for authorization service. The MQCSP support enables the authorization service to authenticate a user ID and password. You can specify the MQCSP connection security parameters structure on an MQCONNX call. Before using the MQCSP support, you need to define a security exit in the queue manager on the IBM MQ server. Ensure that your MQCSP user ID and password in the security exit are consistent with what you input in the IBM MQ Queue Manager configuration. Either an inconsistent MQCSP user ID or an inconsistent password causes a failure of connection between the DataPower Gateway and the IBM MQ server. #b#Notes:#/b# If neither of the MQCSP user ID or the password is defined, DataPower connects to the IBM MQ server without MQCSP settings. If only one of them is defined, a warning occurs and the IBM MQ Queue Manager is not up. If both of them are defined but one is not consistent with that defined on the IBM MQ server, the connection fails and the queue manager is not up.

entry.name: mqcsp_password_alias_mqmanager_descr_2032
entry.text: Password alias of the password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter

entry.name: heartbeat_mqmanager_help_2033
entry.text: Specify the approximate time in seconds between heartbeat flows on a channel when waiting for a message on a queue. Enter a value in the range 0 - 999999. If 0, there will not be heartbeat flows exchanged when waiting for a message on the channel. This property does not set the heartbeat on the channel. Instead, it is used to negotiate the heartbeat value with the channel. The greater of the two values is used.

entry.name: heartbeat_mqmanager_descr_2033
entry.text: Time between heartbeat flows

entry.name: maximum_message_size_mqmanager_help_2034
entry.text: Specify the maximum size in bytes of allowed messages. Use a value that is equal to or greater than the MaxMsgLength attribute of the channel and of the queue on the IBM MQ server. Messages that are bigger than this size are rejected. Enter a value in the range 1024 - 104857600.

entry.name: maximum_message_size_mqmanager_descr_2034
entry.text: Maximum size of messages to accept

entry.name: cache_timeout_mqmanager_help_2035
entry.text: Specify the number of seconds that the DataPower Gateway retains (keeps alive) a dynamic connection in the connection cache. Enter a value in the range 0 - 65535. The default value is 60. Enter 0 to disable the timer. Use a value that is greater than the negotiated heartbeat interval but less than the keep alive interval. The negotiated heartbeat interval is between the DataPower Gateway and the IBM MQ server. The channel heartbeat defines the starting value for the negotiation. The keep alive (timeout) interval is on the IBM MQ server. The KAINT attribute on the IBM MQ server defines the timeout value for a channel. Not all channels have a defined, explicit keep alive interval on the IBM MQ server. Some queue managers use an automatic timeout setting when the KAINT attribute set to AUTO . In these cases, the keep alive interval is the negotiated heartbeat interval plus 60 seconds. When an inactive connection reaches this threshold, the DataPower Gateway removes that dynamic connection from the cache. When the cache no longer contains dynamic connections, the DataPower Gateway deletes the dynamic queue manager. Without a dynamic queue manager, there is no connection with the IBM MQ server. The cache timeout value is the only way to configure a timeout value from the DataPower Gateway to the IBM MQ server. No other configuration setting on the DataPower Gateway can time out an IBM MQ connection.

entry.name: cache_timeout_mqmanager_descr_2035
entry.text: Maximum period to retain a dynamic connection in the connection cache

entry.name: units_of_work_mqmanager_help_2036
entry.text: When set to 0, the default value, the DataPower Gateway gets and puts messages with no provision for rollback. Either the operation succeeds or not. Undeliverable messages are silently discarded, which leaves higher level protocols with the responsibility to detect and retransmit lost packets When set to 1, the DataPower Gateway uses syncpoints. A syncpoint commits and rolls back each IBM MQ message, not the entire transaction. When specified, the DataPower Gateway does not remove the message that it gets from a queue until it completes its transaction using that message (such as placing the message on a server queue for processing). If the transaction fails and the message is left available on the queue, the DataPower Gateway can attempt to get the message and process it again.

entry.name: units_of_work_mqmanager_descr_2036
entry.text: Whether to use units-of-work

entry.name: automatic_backout_mqmanager_help_2037
entry.text: Use the radio buttons to enable (on) or disable (off) the automatic backout of poison messages. A poison message is any message that the receiving application does not know how to process. Usually an application rolls back the get of this message, which leaves the message on the input queue. However, the backout count ( MQMD.Backoutcount ) is incremented. As the queue manager continues to re-get the message, the backout count continues to increase. When the backout count exceeds the backout threshold, the queue manager moves the message to the backout queue. If disabled, the poison message remains on the get queue and continues to be reprocessed by the DataPower Gateway until the queue manager that manages the get queue removes it or the DataPower Gateway reroutes the offending message. The message could be rerouted by a custom stylesheet in the request rule.

entry.name: automatic_backout_mqmanager_descr_2037
entry.text: Enables automatic routing of undeliverable messages

entry.name: backout_threshold_mqmanager_help_2038
entry.text: Specify the total number of processing attempts. After this number of processing attempts fails, the following actions occur. The poison message is moved to the backout queue. The unit of work that contains this message is committed. Enter a value that is equal to or greater than 1.

entry.name: backout_threshold_mqmanager_descr_2038
entry.text: Number of processing attempts

entry.name: backout_queue_mqmanager_help_2039
entry.text: Specify the queue to contains messages that exceeded the backout threshold. This queue must be managed by the same IBM MQ Queue Manager as the defined GET queue. The backout queue, typically SYSTEM.DEAD.LETTER.QUEUE contains messages that cannot be processed or delivered.

entry.name: backout_queue_mqmanager_descr_2039
entry.text: Queue for undeliverable messages

entry.name: total_connection_limit_mqmanager_help_2040
entry.text: Specify the total number of open TCP connections to allow. Enter a value in the range 1 - 10000. The default value is 250.

entry.name: total_connection_limit_mqmanager_descr_2040
entry.text: Total number of TCP connections

entry.name: initial_connections_mqmanager_help_2041
entry.text: Specify the number of TCP connections to open immediately with the IBM MQ server. Enter a value in the range 0 - 10000. The default value is 1.

entry.name: initial_connections_mqmanager_descr_2041
entry.text: Number of preallocated TCP connections

entry.name: sharing_conversations_mqmanager_help_2042
entry.text: Specify the maximum number of conversations to share a single TCP/IP connection. Enter a value in the range 1 - 5000. The default value is 1.

entry.name: sharing_conversations_mqmanager_descr_2042
entry.text: Maximum number of conversations to share in a TCP connection

entry.name: ssl_key_mqmanager_help_2043
entry.text: Specify the location of the key database file in which keys and certificates are stored. Use this property with the TLS Cipher property to enable TLS communication when the TLS artifacts were created with IBM Global Security Kit (GSKit). #b#Note:#/b# To integrate with IBM MQ for z/OS, do not use these properties. Use the TLS Client Profile property. Each key database file has an associated stash file. The stash file holds encrypted passwords that allow programmatic access to the key database. The stash file must reside in the same directory as the key database file, have the same file name as the key database file, and have the .sth file extension. For example, if the key database file is MQkeys.pem or MQkeys.kidb , the stash file must be MQkeys.sth . If these file are not on the DataPower Gateway, upload or fetch them.

entry.name: ssl_key_mqmanager_descr_2043
entry.text: File name of the key database

entry.name: permit_insecure_servers_mqmanager_help_2044
entry.text: When using the TLS key repository, specifies whether to permit connections to IBM MQ servers that do not support RFC 5746. Such servers are vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks as documented in CVE-2009-3555. The default is off which means reject insecure connections during the TLS handshake.

entry.name: permit_insecure_servers_mqmanager_descr_2044
entry.text: Permit connections to insecure TLS servers when TLS key repository is used

entry.name: ssl_cipher_mqmanager_help_2045
entry.text: Select the cipher suite for TLS communication when using a TLS key repository. The cipher suite must match the ciphers in use by the remote queue manager. Use this property with the TLS key repository property to enable TLS communication when the TLS artifacts were created with IBM Global Security Kit (GSKit). #b#Note:#/b# To integrate with IBM MQ for z/OS, do not use these properties. Use the TLS client profile.

entry.name: ssl_cipher_mqmanager_descr_2045
entry.text: Cipher suite

entry.name: ssl_cert_label_mqmanager_help_2046
entry.text: Specify the unique identifier of the certificate in the key database file.

entry.name: ssl_cert_label_mqmanager_descr_2046
entry.text: Unique identifier of the certificate in the key database file

entry.name: auto_recovery_mqmanager_descr_2047
entry.text: Advanced recovery after critical error.

entry.name: convert_mqmanager_help_2048
entry.text: Indicates whether the queue manager can convert input messages to a different CCSI (Coded Character Set Identifier) than the one in the incoming message. This conversion is done by the remote queue manager, not the DataPower Gateway. Click #b#off#/b# to disable automatic conversion of incoming messages to the CCSI established for this queue manager.

entry.name: convert_mqmanager_descr_2048
entry.text: Enable conversion of the incoming message to the default CCSI

entry.name: auto_retry_mqmanager_help_2049
entry.text: Define whether to attempt to reconnect to remote server after a connection failure. When enabled, the DataPower Gateway automatically attempt to reconnect to the remote host. This is on by default. This setting does not affect attempts to put or get messages over an established connection.

entry.name: auto_retry_mqmanager_descr_2049
entry.text: Advanced recovery after critical error

entry.name: retry_interval_mqmanager_help_2050
entry.text: Specify the time interval in seconds between attempts to retry the failed connections to a remote host. The default value is 10. This setting does not affect attempts to put or get messages over an established connection.

entry.name: retry_interval_mqmanager_descr_2050
entry.text: Specify the time interval in seconds between attempts to retry the failed connections to a remote host.

entry.name: retry_attempts_mqmanager_help_2051
entry.text: Specify the number of attempts to retry the failed connections. After the number of attempts is reached, the long interval is used. The default value is 6. When 0, the long retry interval is not used. The retry interval is used forever.

entry.name: retry_attempts_mqmanager_descr_2051
entry.text: The number of attempts to retry the failed connections

entry.name: long_retry_interval_mqmanager_help_2052
entry.text: Specify the retry interval to use after the number of retry attempts is reached. The default value is 600. The long retry interval must be greater than the retry interval, or it will take no effect.

entry.name: long_retry_interval_mqmanager_descr_2052
entry.text: Long retry interval before retrying the failed connections

entry.name: reporting_interval_mqmanager_help_2053
entry.text: Specify the number of seconds between the creations of log messages at the error level when failed connections are retried. This setting filters the generation of identical error messages to IBM MQ logging targets. The default value is 10.

entry.name: reporting_interval_mqmanager_descr_2053
entry.text: Log a connection failure as an error at this interval

entry.name: alternate_user_mqmanager_help_2054
entry.text: Determines whether to use the MQOD.AlternateUserId as the value of the #b#User name#/b# property. When enabled (on), uses MQOD.AlternateUserId . When disabled, uses MQMD.UserIdentifier .

entry.name: alternate_user_mqmanager_descr_2054
entry.text: Enables ALTERNATE_USER_AUTHORITY flag

entry.name: local_address_mqmanager_help_2055
entry.text: Specify the local address for outbound connections to a specific local interface and port. Supported formats are 1.1.1.1 or 1.1.1.1(1) or just (1) to tell TCP to bind to port 1 and for a range of ports use (1,10) or 1.1.1.1(1,10). #b#Note:#/b# If the port is set, the range must be greater than the total number of allowed connections.

entry.name: local_address_mqmanager_descr_2055
entry.text: Local address for channel

entry.name: polling_tolerance_mqmanager_help_2056
entry.text: Adds the extra network tolerance time to the polling interval of IBM MQ MQGET call #b#Note:#/b# Big tolerance value might impact performance if the transaction is hold to wait MQGET reply from IBM MQ server.

entry.name: polling_tolerance_mqmanager_descr_2056
entry.text: The extra network tolerance time that is added to the polling interval of MQGET call

entry.name: xml_manager_mqmanager_help_2057
entry.text: Select an XML Manager.

entry.name: xml_manager_mqmanager_descr_2057
entry.text: XML manager

entry.name: ssl_client_mqmanager_descr_2058
entry.text: Set the TLS client profile to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets

entry.name: idg_mq_qm_group_kglobalconfig_help_2059
entry.text: An IBM MQ queue manager group enables automatic failover between queue managers when a queue manager becomes unavailable. When you define multiple backup queue managers, the first active queue manager in the group replaces the primary queue manager. You can configure the queue manager to work with the multi-instance feature in the IBM MQ server. Connect the primary queue manager to one of the instances of a queue manager in the IBM MQ server, and the backup queue manager to the other instance. All connections for the queue manager group go to the queue manager connected to the active instance. If the active instance in the IBM MQ server fails, the queue manager connected to the standby instance automatically takes over all the data and logs from the queue manager connected to the original active instance.

entry.name: idg_mq_qm_group_kglobalconfig_descr_2059
entry.text: IBM MQ v9+ Queue Manager Group

entry.name: block_traffic_networksettings_help_2081
entry.text: When at least one network interface has an invalid configuration, whether to block nonmanagement traffic or allow all network traffic. When enabled, nonmanagement traffic is blocked. When disabled, all network traffic is allowed. In a production environment, always enable this property to support only management traffic over Telnet, SSH, web management interfaces (GUIs), and the XML management interface. Until you correct the problem, client requests cannot be accepted and processed.

entry.name: block_traffic_networksettings_descr_2081
entry.text: Indicate whether to block nonmanagement traffic for invalid interface configuration.

entry.name: icmp_disable_networksettings_help_2082
entry.text: Which Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) requests to disable the generation of ICMP reply messages.

entry.name: icmp_disable_networksettings_descr_2082
entry.text: Indicate which ICMP replies to disable.

entry.name: ecn_disable_networksettings_help_2083
entry.text: Whether to disable the generation of ECN-capable TCP sessions. By default, TCP sessions are ECN enabled.

entry.name: ecn_disable_networksettings_descr_2083
entry.text: Indicate whether to disable ECN TCP indication.

entry.name: destination_routing_networksettings_help_2084
entry.text: How the route is determined to return the response to the originating client. The route to return the response is the outbound packet. The originating client is the destination of the outbound packet. When enabled, interface selection is based on the best path to the client, irrespective of the service or receiving interface. The best path is determined by static routes that are bound to the available interfaces. #b#Note:#/b# Destination-based routing is for compatibility with an earlier version only. Enable destination-based routing only if an upgrade disables existing connectivity. When disabled, the default, interface selection is based on the interface that is bound to the address of the service that generated the response. If the service is bound to a single address, responses are routed through the interface that is assigned to that address. If the service is bound to multiple addresses, responses are routed through the receiving interface instead of the interface for the service that generated the response.

entry.name: destination_routing_networksettings_descr_2084
entry.text: Indicate how the route is determined to return the response to the originating client.

entry.name: relax_interface_isolation_networksettings_help_2085
entry.text: Whether to relax the restriction on interface isolation. As a security policy, the interface that receives a packet must be configured with the IP address that is the destination address of the packet. Enabling this option relaxes that restriction. The packet is allowed if the interface it arrives on contains an IP address in the same subnet as the destination address of the packet. Relax interface isolation when destination-routing is enabled.

entry.name: relax_interface_isolation_networksettings_descr_2085
entry.text: Indicate whether to allow packets from a wrong interface when both interfaces are on the same subnet.

entry.name: disable_interface_isolation_networksettings_help_2086
entry.text: Whether to allow interface isolation. By default, an interface refuses to accept a packet other than the one bound to the destination address of the packet. As a security policy, the interface that receives a packet must be configured with the IP address that is the destination address of the packet. Enabling interface isolation relaxes the restriction.

entry.name: disable_interface_isolation_networksettings_descr_2086
entry.text: Indicate whether to allow packets from one interface that are destined for a service on another interface.

entry.name: tcp_retries_networksettings_help_2087
entry.text: The number of times the local system attempts to send a TCP SYN that receives no response. Enter a value in the range 1 - 32. The default value is 5.

entry.name: tcp_retries_networksettings_descr_2087
entry.text: Set the number of times to send a failed TCP SYN request.

entry.name: arp_retries_networksettings_help_2088
entry.text: The number of times to attempt a failed ARP request. Enter a value in the range 1 - 64. The default value is 8.

entry.name: arp_retries_networksettings_descr_2088
entry.text: Set the number of times to attempt a failed ARP request.

entry.name: arp_interval_networksettings_help_2089
entry.text: The interval to wait before the next attempt for a failed ARP request. Enter a value in the range 500 - 5000. The default value is 500.

entry.name: arp_interval_networksettings_descr_2089
entry.text: Set the interval between ARP attempts.

entry.name: tcp_segmentation_offload_networksettings_help_2090
entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - Control whether Ethernet devices perform TCP segmentation offload (TSO). By default, all of the Ethernet device drivers and chips are allowed to perform TSO. This Ethernet chip feature improves performance on large TCP writes to the network. On rare occasions, this feature might interact poorly on a deployed network by causing link layer resets. This option allows disabling TSO on all Ethernet interfaces. Disable this only if customer support has diagnosed that you are encountering this problem. After re-enabling TSO, a restart is required for the change to take effect.

entry.name: tcp_segmentation_offload_networksettings_descr_2090
entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - Whether Ethernet devices perform TCP segmentation offload

entry.name: reverse_path_filtering_networksettings_help_2091
entry.text: Whether incoming packets with a source address that cannot be routed by that interface are accepted and processed. When enabled, the interface ignores incoming packets with a source address that it cannot route. When disabled, the interface accepts and processes incoming packets with a source address that it cannot route.

entry.name: reverse_path_filtering_networksettings_descr_2091
entry.text: Indicate whether to ignore incoming packets with a source address that the interface cannot route.

entry.name: tcp_window_scale_networksettings_help_2092
entry.text: Whether to enable TCP window scaling. Window scaling allows the negotiation of window sizes greater than 64 KB. Disabling this option might help to work around TCP systems that do not understand or misinterpret window scaling.

entry.name: tcp_window_scale_networksettings_descr_2092
entry.text: Indicate whether to enable TCP window scaling.

entry.name: mac_takeover_networksettings_help_2093
entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - Control, in the event of a standby control group takeover, whether to use virtual MAC address takeover. This option is relevant for appliances that are members of a standby control group. When enabled, a standby control takeover moves the group-defined virtual MAC address to the newly active appliance. When disabled, all standby control groups use ARP takeover. #b#Attention:#/b# Do not use this option for any appliance that is active in a standby group. Before DataPower version 4.0.2, only virtual MAC address takeover is available. Therefore, MAC address takeover must be enabled for compatibility with earlier versions. For new deployments, the default is preferred because it does not require that the network support rapid spanning tree, and takeovers can occur more quickly. However, when MAC address takeover is disabled, stations on the local network must permit and honor gratuitous ARP for a standby control takeover to be effective.

entry.name: mac_takeover_networksettings_descr_2093
entry.text: NONTRANSLATABLE - Whether to use virtual MAC address takeover

entry.name: ephemeral_port_range_networksettings_help_2094
entry.text: The starting port of the ephemeral port range. The system can use ephemeral ports in the range 10000 - 61000 to send data over TCP and UDP. You can define a subset of ephemeral ports to not be ephemeral ports. These ports are ephemeral ports in the range 10000 - 32768. The system always has control of the ephemeral ports in the range 32769 - 61000.

entry.name: ephemeral_port_range_networksettings_descr_2094
entry.text: Set the starting port for the ephemeral port range.

entry.name: oauth_provider_settings_kglobalconfig_help_2103
entry.text: An OAuth provider settings configuration defines how a client application is authorized to access resources on behalf of the resource owner.

entry.name: oauth_provider_settings_kglobalconfig_descr_2103
entry.text: OAuth Provider Settings

entry.name: enable_debug_mode_oauthprovidersettings_help_2106
entry.text: When you use a validation endpoint, specifies whether to enable debug mode. In debug mode, security error details are sent in the x-apic-debug-oauth-error and x-apic-debug-oauth-error-desc response headers.

entry.name: enable_debug_mode_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2106
entry.text: Whether to enable debug mode to put security error details in response headers

entry.name: provider_type_oauthprovidersettings_help_2107
entry.text: Specifies the type of the OAuth provider.

entry.name: provider_type_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2107
entry.text: The type of the provider

entry.name: scopes_allowed_oauthprovidersettings_help_2108
entry.text: Specifies the scopes that the access token is valid to access. To specify multiple scopes, use a space between each scope. The order of scopes does not matter. Scopes ensure that the granted access token is valid to access only specific protected resources.

entry.name: scopes_allowed_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2108
entry.text: The scopes that the access token is valid to access

entry.name: default_scopes_oauthprovidersettings_help_2109
entry.text: Specifies the default scopes to apply when the request does not contain a scope. To specify multiple scopes, use a space between each scope. The order of scopes does not matter. The default scopes must be a subset of the allowed scopes that are defined by the API security OAuth requirement configuration. When no default scope is defined and the request does not contain a scope, an invalid scope error is returned for the request. Scopes ensure that the granted access token is valid to access only specific protected resources.

entry.name: default_scopes_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2109
entry.text: The default scopes to apply when the request does not contain a scope

entry.name: supported_grant_types_oauthprovidersettings_help_2110
entry.text: Specifies the supported grant types where each grant type defines a method to grant authorization to client applications.

entry.name: supported_grant_types_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2110
entry.text: Supported methods to grant authorization

entry.name: supported_client_types_oauthprovidersettings_help_2111
entry.text: Specifies the supported client types that are authorized to obtain an access token.

entry.name: supported_client_types_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2111
entry.text: Types of client who can obtain access tokens

entry.name: apic_provider_base_path_oauthprovidersettings_help_2112
entry.text: When the provider type is API Connect, specifies the base path on which the OAuth provider API is served. The default base path is / .

entry.name: apic_provider_base_path_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2112
entry.text: Base path URL for the OAuth provider API

entry.name: apic_authorize_endpoint_oauthprovidersettings_help_2113
entry.text: When the provider is API Connect, specifies the endpoint where the client application obtains authorization grant. The default authorization endpoint is /oauth2/authorize .

entry.name: apic_authorize_endpoint_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2113
entry.text: URL to the authorization endpoint

entry.name: apic_token_endpoint_oauthprovidersettings_help_2114
entry.text: When the provider is API Connect, specifies the endpoint where the client application exchanges an authorization grant for an access token. The default token endpoint is /oauth2/token .

entry.name: apic_token_endpoint_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2114
entry.text: URL to the token endpoint

entry.name: apic_enable_introspection_oauthprovidersettings_help_2115
entry.text: When the OAuth provider is API Connect, specifies whether to enable the introspection of access tokens. When enabled, authorized protected resources can introspect the access token to determine the metadata for making appropriate authorization decisions. By default, token introspection is disabled.

entry.name: apic_enable_introspection_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2115
entry.text: Whether to enable introspection of access tokens

entry.name: apic_introspect_endpoint_oauthprovidersettings_help_2116
entry.text: When the provider is API Connect, specifies the endpoint through which the token introspection operation is accomplished. The default introspection endpoint is /oauth2/introspect .

entry.name: apic_introspect_endpoint_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2116
entry.text: URL to the introspection endpoint

entry.name: apic_enable_revocation_oauthprovidersettings_help_2117
entry.text: When the OAuth provider is API Connect, specifies whether to enable the revocation of access tokens. When enabled, users can revoke the access token when they change their mind and decide that they do not want the client application to continue to have access to their resources. By default, token revocation is disabled.

entry.name: apic_enable_revocation_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2117
entry.text: When to enable token revocation

entry.name: apic_revocation_endpoint_oauthprovidersettings_help_2118
entry.text: When the provider is API Connect, specifies the endpoint through which the token revocation is accomplished. The default revocation endpoint is /oauth2/revocation .

entry.name: apic_revocation_endpoint_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2118
entry.text: URL to the revocation endpoint

entry.name: apic_token_secret_oauthprovidersettings_help_2119
entry.text: When the provider is API Connect, specifies the secret of the generated token.

entry.name: apic_token_secret_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2119
entry.text: The secret of the token

entry.name: apic_enable_one_time_use_access_token_oauthprovidersettings_help_2120
entry.text: When the OAuth provider is API Connect, controls whether to set access tokens to one-time use.

entry.name: apic_enable_one_time_use_access_token_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2120
entry.text: Whether to enable the one-time use of an access token

entry.name: apic_access_token_ttl_oauthprovidersettings_help_2121
entry.text: When the provider is API Connect, specifies the time that an access token remains valid in seconds. The default value is 3600.

entry.text: The lifetime for the access token

entry.name: apic_auth_code_ttl_oauthprovidersettings_help_2122

entry.name: apic_enable_refresh_token_oauthprovidersettings_help_2123
entry.text: When the OAuth provider is API Connect, controls whether to enable issuing refresh tokens. Refresh tokens are issued to the client. Refresh tokens are used to obtain a new access token when the current access token becomes invalid or expires or are used to obtain additional access tokens with identical or narrower scope. By default, this setting is disabled.

entry.name: apic_enable_refresh_token_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2123
entry.text: Whether to enable the use of refresh tokens

entry.name: apic_enable_one_time_use_refresh_token_oauthprovidersettings_help_2124
entry.text: When the OAuth provider is API Connect, controls whether a refresh tokens is one-time use. When enabled, the refresh token is one-time use. This setting is the default value. When disabled, the refresh token can be reused until it expires or is revoked.

entry.name: apic_enable_one_time_use_refresh_token_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2124
entry.text: Whether to disable the one-time use of a refresh token

entry.name: apic_refresh_token_limit_oauthprovidersettings_help_2125
entry.text: Specifies the number of refresh tokens allowed to be generated. The default value is 10.

entry.name: apic_refresh_token_limit_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2125
entry.text: The maximum number of refresh tokens allowed

entry.name: apic_refresh_token_ttl_oauthprovidersettings_help_2126
entry.text: When the provider is API Connect and the refresh token is enabled, specifies the time that a refresh token remains valid in seconds. The default value is 5400.

entry.name: apic_refresh_token_ttl_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2126
entry.text: The lifetime for the refresh token

entry.name: apic_maximum_consent_ttl_oauthprovidersettings_help_2127

entry.name: apic_maximum_consent_ttl_oauthprovidersettings_descr_2127

entry.name: apic_enable_oidc_oauthprovidersettings_help_2140
entry.text: When the OAuth provider is API Connect, specifies whether to enable OIDC to verify the identity of the user. When enabled, the client application verifies the identity of the user based on the requirement of an OIDC provider before requesting access to client resources. By default, OIDC token generation is enabled. OIDC is only available for Implicit and Authorization Code grant types.

entry.name: odr_kglobalconfig_help_2184
entry.text: Specifies an on demand router (ODR). The ODR feature acts as a collection of load balancer groups that distribute traffic to various clusters within a WebSphere cell or Liberty Collective. If multiple ODR connector groups are defined, the ODR distributes traffic to any of the clusters. The ODR feature on the DataPower Gateway supports a subset of On Demand Router in Intelligent Management.

entry.name: odr_kglobalconfig_descr_2184
entry.text: On Demand Router

entry.name: admin_state_odr_help_2185
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_odr_descr_2185
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_odr_help_2186
entry.text: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.

entry.name: summary_odr_descr_2186
entry.text: Descriptive summary for the configuration

entry.name: odr_server_name_odr_help_2187
entry.text: Enter the name of the ODR routing rules server that is used to determine whether routing rules are delivered to the DataPower Gateway. If the DataPower Gateway is not using routing rules, you can use any server name. You must define the RoutingRulesConnectorClusterName custom property to set the name of the ODR connector group from which routing rules are accepted. The web server name is configured in on one of the following ways. In a Liberty Collective, defined as an attribute of the routingRules element. In a WebSphere cell as the value of the serverName parameter of WebServerRoutingRule command.

entry.name: odr_server_name_odr_descr_2187
entry.text: Name of the ODR routing rules server

entry.name: odr_connector_groups_odr_help_2188
entry.text: Define one ODR connector group for each WebSphere cell or Liberty Collective. Each connector group establishes the communications with an Intelligent management service. The DataPower Gateway retrieves topology information, application information, routing rules, and other information over the connectors in the connector group.

entry.name: odr_connector_groups_odr_descr_2188
entry.text: Connector groups

entry.name: odr_custom_properties_odr_help_2189
entry.text: Defines custom property name-value strings to connect to Liberty Collective or WebSphere cell to define which ODR connection group accepts routing rules. The scheme that the DataPower ODR feature uses to connect to WebSphere Application Server does not apply to Liberty Collective. For any HTTP or HTTPS request to connect to Liberty Collective, you must define the profileType property. Set the #b#Name#/b# to profileType . Set the #b#Value#/b# to Liberty . To set the name of the ODR connector group from which routing rules are accepted, you must define the RoutingRulesConnectorClusterName property. The following example shows setting the liberty-collective-node03 connector group as the group that accepts routing rules. Set the #b#Name#/b# to RoutingRulesConnectorClusterName . Set the #b#Value#/b# to liberty-collective-node03 . Beyond these situations, use custom properties only when directed by IBM Support.

entry.name: odr_custom_properties_odr_descr_2189
entry.text: Custom property name-value strings to connect to Liberty Collective or WebSphere cell

entry.name: odr_connector_group_kglobalconfig_help_2190
entry.text: A collection of on demand router (ODR) connectors used to communicate with the Intelligent Management service.

entry.name: odr_connector_group_kglobalconfig_descr_2190
entry.text: ODR Connector Group

entry.name: admin_state_odrconnectorgroup_help_2191
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_odrconnectorgroup_descr_2191
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_odrconnectorgroup_descr_2192
entry.text: Contains a brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: odr_connector_odrconnectorgroup_help_2193
entry.text: The ODR connectors that are used to retrieve ODR information. An ODR connector defines a connection to the Intelligent Management service. The DataPower Gateway retrieves topology, weights, session affinity, and other information from the WebSphere cell over the connection. If multiple connectors are configured, the top most connection is tried first, followed by the second, and so on. After a connection is established, other endpoints might be retrieved and used if the configured connector endpoint is down. You must define at least one connector in an ODR connector group but cannot define more than 16 connectors.

entry.name: odr_connector_odrconnectorgroup_descr_2193
entry.text: Define the ODR connectors that are used to retrieve ODR information

entry.name: api_operation_rate_limit_kglobalconfig_help_2200
entry.text: An API Operation Rate Limit configuration defines the operation-specific rate limit scheme. By default, the rate limit scheme setting for the plan applies to all operations in the associated APIs. However, you can define a different rate limit scheme for an operation.

entry.name: document_type_parsesettings_help_2210
entry.text: Specifies the type of document to parse. By default, the document type is automatically detected.

entry.name: document_type_parsesettings_descr_2210
entry.text: Type of document to parse

entry.name: document_size_parsesettings_help_2211
entry.text: Specifies the maximum document size in bytes that the parse action accepts. This setting provides threat protection by enforcing the maximum document size. Enter a value in the range 0 - 5368709121. The default value is 4194304. A document is rejected when its size exceeds the maximum size. A value of 0 indicates an unlimited document size. When you set the value to 0, the action result does not return the document size. This setting is applicable to binary, JSON, XML, or GraphQL input documents.

entry.name: document_size_parsesettings_descr_2211
entry.text: Maximum document size that the parse action accepts

entry.name: nesting_depth_parsesettings_help_2212
entry.text: Specifies the maximum level of nested element depth in an XML, JSON, or GraphQL message that the parse action accepts. This setting provides threat protection by enforcing limits in the message. For XML, it is the maximum level of element depth. For JSON, it is the maximum number of nested label-value pairs, the maximum number of nested arrays, or the maximum number of combination of label-value pairs and arrays. For GraphQL, the nesting depth specifies the maximum level of nested selection sets. Enter a value in the range 0 - 4096. The default value is 512. A document is rejected when its nesting depth exceeds the maximum depth. A value of 0 indicates unlimited nesting depth. When you set the value to 0, the action result does not return the nesting depth of a document.

entry.name: nesting_depth_parsesettings_descr_2212
entry.text: Maximum nesting depth of the XML, JSON, or GraphQL message that the parse action accepts

entry.name: width_parsesettings_help_2213
entry.text: Specifies the maximum width of a payload that the parse action accepts. This constraint is relevant only when the input document is XML, JSON, or GraphQL. When the input document is XML, this property specifies: The maximum number of attributes on an element The maximum number of child elements for an element When the input document is JSON, this property specifies: The maximum number of properties on a JSON object The maximum number of JSON items in a JSON array When the input document is GraphQL, this property specifies the maximum number of selections in a selection set. Enter a value in the range 0 - 65535. The default value is 4096. The document is rejected when its width exceeds the maximum width. A value of 0 indicates unlimited width. When you set the value to 0, the action result does not return the width of the document.

entry.name: width_parsesettings_descr_2213
entry.text: Maximum width of a payload that the parse action accepts

entry.name: name_length_parsesettings_help_2214
entry.text: Specifies the maximum name length in bytes that the parse action accepts. This constraint is relevant only when the input document is XML, JSON, or GraphQL. For XML, it is the length of the name portion of a tag. For JSON, it is the length of the label portion of the JSON label-value pair. For GraphQL, it is the length of the identifiers, including field names and directive names. The length includes any white space that is contained between tags in XML or quotation marks in JSON. Enter a value in the range 0 - 8192. The default value is 256. A document is rejected when its name length exceeds the maximum length. A value of 0 indicates unlimited name length. When you set the value to 0, the action result does not return the name length of a document.

entry.name: name_length_parsesettings_descr_2214
entry.text: Maximum name length that the parse action accepts

entry.name: value_length_parsesettings_help_2215
entry.text: Specify the maximum value length in bytes that the parse action accepts. This constraint is relevant only when the input document is XML, JSON, or GraphQL. For XML, it is the length of an attribute or the length of a text value. For JSON, it is the length of a string value. For GraphQL, it is the number of bytes in any string from which GraphQL is composed. The length includes any white space that is contained between tags in XML or quotation marks in JSON. Enter a value in the range 0 - 5368709121. The default value is 8192. A document is rejected when its value length exceeds the maximum length. A value of 0 indicates unlimited value length. When you set the value to 0, the action result does not return the value length of a document.

entry.name: value_length_parsesettings_descr_2215
entry.text: Maximum value length that the parse action accepts

entry.name: unique_prefixes_parsesettings_help_2216
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of unique XML namespace prefixes in a document that the parse action accepts. This limit counts multiple prefixes defined for the same namespace, but does not count multiple namespaces defined in different parts of the input document under a single prefix. Enter a value in the range 0 - 262143. The default value is 1024. A document is rejected when the number of unique prefixes in the document exceeds the maximum number. A value of 0 indicates an unlimited number of unique prefixes. When you set the value to 0, the action result does not return the number of unique prefixes in a document.

entry.name: unique_prefixes_parsesettings_descr_2216
entry.text: Maximum number of unique prefixes that the parse action accepts

entry.name: unique_namespaces_parsesettings_help_2217
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of unique XML namespace URIs that the parse action accepts. This limit counts all XML namespaces, regardless of how many prefixes are used to declare them. Enter a value in the range 0 - 65535. The default value is 1024. A document is rejected when the number of unique namespaces in the document exceeds the maximum number. A value of 0 indicates an unlimited number of unique namespaces. When you set the value to 0, the action result does not return the number of unique namespaces in a document.

entry.name: unique_namespaces_parsesettings_descr_2217
entry.text: Maximum number of unique namespaces that the parse action accepts

entry.name: unique_names_parsesettings_help_2218
entry.text: Specify the maximum number of unique names that the parse action accepts. For XML, it is the number of unique XML local names. For JSON, it is the number of unique JSON labels. Enter a value in the range 0 - 1048575. The default value is 1024. A document is rejected when the number of unique names in the document exceeds the maximum number. A value of 0 indicates an unlimited number of unique names. When you set the value to 0, the action result does not return the number of unique names in a document.

entry.name: unique_names_parsesettings_descr_2218
entry.text: Maximum number of unique names that the parse action accepts

entry.name: number_length_parsesettings_help_2219
entry.text: The maximum number length limits the number of bytes in the value portion of a label-value pair when the value is a number. The number must be a contiguous string of bytes that contain no white space. The number can include a minus sign and a positive or negative exponent. Enter a value in the range 0 - 256. The default value is 128. A document is rejected when the number length in the document exceeds the maximum length. A value of 0 indicates unlimited number length. When you set the value to 0, the action result does not return the number length in a document.

entry.name: number_length_parsesettings_descr_2219
entry.text: Maximum number length that the parse action accepts

entry.name: quota_enforcement_server_kglobalconfig_help_2251
entry.text: On each DataPower Gateway, you configure the quota enforcement server to store the thresholds and associated metadata in memory or persist them on the RAID volume. The quota enforcement server can work in standalone mode or peer group mode. A peer group is collection of at least three nodes across which quota enforcement is implemented. In each peer group, one DataPower Gateway is the primary node and others are replicas. Failover might occur when the primary node becomes unavailable. When you enable the peer group mode, the appropriate configuration properties are displayed. You must configure the connection among peers. Based on your requirements for quota enforcement, you can enable or disable strict mode. Strict mode affects data-consistency across the peer group. When strict mode is enabled, the following effects are caused: When the primary node is operational and when strict mode of all nodes in a peer group is enabled, threshold synchronization is more frequent to ensure data-consistency across the peer group. However, more network bandwidth is used. Therefore, strict mode is suitable for peers in the same data center. When the primary node becomes unavailable, before failover occurs, the replica with enabled strict mode cannot process the request. If service performance and availability are more important than data-consistency, you can disable strict mode for the replica so that this replica can process the request. The replica with disabled strict mode writes the threshold and associated metadata to the local data storage. After failover occurs, the connection is resumed between the replica and the new primary node. The threshold and associated metadata stored by the replica might be overwritten by the new primary node when the new primay node synchronizes the data to all replicas. Data-consistency might be affected across the peer group. By default, data is stored in memory and quota enforcement server works in standalone mode.

entry.name: quota_enforcement_server_kglobalconfig_descr_2251
entry.text: Quota Enforcement Server

entry.text: Whether to enable the peer group mode

entry.name: enable_ssl_quotaenforcementserver_help_2259

entry.name: enable_ssl_quotaenforcementserver_descr_2259

entry.name: ssl_key_quotaenforcementserver_help_2260
entry.text: Indicates the key alias for the DataPower Gateway to authenticate a peer of the DataPower Gateway during the TLS handshake.

entry.name: ssl_key_quotaenforcementserver_descr_2260
entry.text: Private key alias

entry.name: ssl_cert_quotaenforcementserver_help_2261
entry.text: Indicates the certificate alias that is sent to a peer when the DataPower Gateway negotiates a TLS connection with the peer.

entry.name: ssl_cert_quotaenforcementserver_descr_2261
entry.text: Certificate alias

entry.name: ip_address_quotaenforcementserver_help_2262
entry.text: Indicates the IP address of the DataPower Gateway for other peers to connect to. The IP address can be the IP address on any interface of the DataPower Gateway and must be accessible by other peers in the peer group. The IP address cannot be 127.0.0.1, 0.0.0.0 or ::. This IP address uniquely identifies the DataPower Gateway. You can use a local host alias instead of a static IP address. A host alias resolves a locally configured alias to a static IP address.

entry.name: ip_address_quotaenforcementserver_descr_2262
entry.text: IP address of the DataPower Gateway

entry.name: peer_quotaenforcementserver_help_2263
entry.text: Specifies peers of the DataPower Gateway in the peer group. The DataPower Gateway connects to each peer in the order in which peers are added in the list. It is not necessary to specify all peers in the Peers list. When the DataPower Gateway connects to no peer in the list, this DataPower Gateway is the first active server and joins the peer group as the primary node. When the DataPower Gateway connects to any peer in the list, it joins the peer group as a replica. You can use a local host alias instead of a static IP address. A host alias resolves a locally configured alias to a static IP address. Aliasing can help when you move configurations among appliances. Note: Do not specify the IP address or hostname of this DataPower Gateway.

entry.name: peer_quotaenforcementserver_descr_2263
entry.text: The IP address or hostname of peers of the DataPower Gateway

entry.name: priority_quotaenforcementserver_help_2264
entry.text: Indicates the priority that is used to decide which replica is promoted to the primary node when failover occurs. Enter a value in range 0 - 255. The default value is 100. The replica with the lowest priority number is promoted. A replica with the value of 0 can never be promoted.

entry.name: priority_quotaenforcementserver_descr_2264
entry.text: The priority of the DataPower Gateway

entry.name: strict_mode_quotaenforcementserver_help_2265
entry.text: Based on your requirements for quota enforcement, enable or disable strict mode. By default, the strict mode is enabled.

entry.name: strict_mode_quotaenforcementserver_descr_2265
entry.text: Whether to enable or disable the strict mode

entry.text: Maximum number of requests to handle

entry.name: unit_ratelimitdefinition_help_2278

entry.name: unit_ratelimitdefinition_descr_2278

entry.name: hard_limit_ratelimitdefinition_help_2279
entry.text: Indicates whether to reject requests when the specified rate limit is exceeded. When enabled, the API Gateway rejects requests when the limit is exceeded. When disabled, the API Gateway still handles requests when the limit is exceeded but produces a warning message. By default, the API Gateway rejects requests when the limit is exceeded.

entry.name: hard_limit_ratelimitdefinition_descr_2279
entry.text: Whether to enable hard limit

entry.name: is_client_ratelimitdefinition_help_2280
entry.text: Indicates whether to apply the rate limit to the client or to an internal component. Client rate limits return a 429 error when exceeded. Non-client rate limits return a 503 error when exceeded. When set to off, rate limit information is not included in the response header.

entry.name: is_client_ratelimitdefinition_descr_2280
entry.text: Whether to apply the rate limit to the client

entry.name: use_api_name_ratelimitdefinition_help_2281
entry.text: Indicates whether to use the API name as part of the rate limit key.

entry.name: use_api_name_ratelimitdefinition_descr_2281
entry.text: Whether to use the API name as part of the rate limit key

entry.name: use_app_id_ratelimitdefinition_help_2282
entry.text: Indicates whether to use the application ID as part of the rate limit key.

entry.name: use_app_id_ratelimitdefinition_descr_2282
entry.text: Whether to use the application ID as part of the rate limit key

entry.name: use_client_id_ratelimitdefinition_help_2283
entry.text: Indicates whether to use the client ID as part of the rate limit key.

entry.name: use_client_id_ratelimitdefinition_descr_2283
entry.text: Whether to use the client ID as part of the rate limit key

entry.name: dynamic_value_ratelimitdefinition_help_2284
entry.text: Indicates the dynamic value string for the rate limit, which should contain one or more context variables. The dynamic value makes it possible to use a context variable to enforce the rate limit based on parameters other than those defined in the rate limit scheme, such as a user name, incoming IP address, or server name. The context variable can be set in a GatewayScript action and then included in the dynamic value. The following example uses the context object in a GatewayScript action to add the my.server variable to the API context. context.set("my.server", "server34") The dynamic value can then include the variable my.server , which resolves to the server name server34 . The default value is an empty string.

entry.name: dynamic_value_ratelimitdefinition_descr_2284
entry.text: The dynamic value for the rate limit

entry.name: weight_ratelimitdefinition_help_2285
entry.text: Specifies a JSONata expression that assigns a weight value to the transaction. For each API call, the value computed by the weight expression is applied to the rate limit. The default value is 1. If the weight expression evaluates to a value that is less than or equal to 0, it is set to 1. An empty string results in an error.

entry.name: weight_ratelimitdefinition_descr_2285
entry.text: Expression determining how much weight to apply to the limit.

entry.name: response_headers_ratelimitdefinition_help_2286
entry.text: Indicates whether to enable HTTP response headers that include rate limit information.

entry.name: response_headers_ratelimitdefinition_descr_2286
entry.text: Enable rate limit response headers

entry.name: use_interval_offset_ratelimitdefinition_help_2287
entry.text: Indicates whether to allow limit intervals to start at differing offsets.

entry.name: use_interval_offset_ratelimitdefinition_descr_2287
entry.text: Use interval offset

entry.name: allow_cache_fallback_ratelimitdefinition_help_2288
entry.text: Indicates whether to allow a cache to enforce the rate limit when gateway peering instances cannot be contacted, even when use of a cache is disabled for this limit.

entry.name: allow_cache_fallback_ratelimitdefinition_descr_2288
entry.text: Use cache as a fallback

entry.name: use_cache_ratelimitdefinition_help_2289
entry.text: Indicates whether to allow a cache to be used to store rate limit information. Using a cache may be faster when the number of API calls is low, but a cache can cause degraded performance when the number of API calls is exceptionally high.

entry.name: use_cache_ratelimitdefinition_descr_2289
entry.text: Use cache

entry.text: Defines tuning parameters for the rate limit.

entry.name: parameter_ratelimitdefinition_descr_2290
entry.text: Defines tuning parameters for the rate limit

entry.name: chunked_uploads_xmlfirewallservice_help_2384
entry.text: Use the radio buttons to enable (on) or disable (off) the ability to send Content-Type Chunked Encoded documents to the back end server. When the device employs the HTTP/1.1 protocol, the body of the document can be delimited by either Content-Length or chunked encodings. While all servers will understand how to interpret Content-Length, many applications will fail to understand Chunked encoding. For this reason, Content-Length is the standard method used. However doing so interferes with the ability of the device to fully stream. To stream full documents towards the back end server, this property should be turned on. However, the back end server must be RFC 2616 compatible, because this feature cannot be renegotiated at run time, unlike all other HTTP/1.1 features which can be negotiated down at runtime if necessary. This property can also be enabled by configuring a User Agent to enable it on a per-URL basis.

entry.name: chunked_uploads_xmlfirewallservice_descr_2384
entry.text: Enabled/Disable HTTP/1.1 Chunked Request Bodies

entry.name: suppress_xmlfirewallservice_help_2386
entry.text: HTTP Headers can be suppressed (removed) from the message flow using this property. For example, the Via: header, which contains the name of the DataPower service handling the message, may be suppressed from messages sent by the DataPower device back to the client.

entry.name: webgui_mode_xmlfirewallservice_help_2387
entry.text: When enabled, WebGUI extension functions are supported.

entry.name: webgui_mode_xmlfirewallservice_descr_2387
entry.text: Enable/Disable WebGUI Extensions

entry.name: rewrite_errors_xmlfirewallservice_help_2388
entry.text: Error messages after a decryption action can provide an attacker who is using the padding oracle attack method with enough information to determine the contents of the plaintext data. When enabled, the default, the client receives error messages without the internal information that could lead to a discovery. When disabled, the client receives the original message with this information.

entry.name: rewrite_errors_xmlfirewallservice_descr_2388
entry.text: Whether to rewrite error messages to avoid providing a padding oracle.

entry.name: delay_errors_xmlfirewallservice_help_2389
entry.text: The timing difference of the error messages returned after a decryption action can provide an attacker with enough information to determine the contents of the plain-text data. When enabled, the default, the DataPower Gateway delays error messages for the defined duration. When disabled, the DataPower Gateway does not delay error messages.

entry.name: delay_errors_xmlfirewallservice_descr_2389
entry.text: Whether to delay error messages to avoid providing a padding oracle.

entry.name: delay_errors_duration_xmlfirewallservice_help_2390
entry.text: When enabling the delay of error messages, specify the delay duration in milliseconds. If delaying messages for 3000 ms, the DataPower Gateway will not send error messages to the client until 3 seconds have elapsed since the DataPower Gateway performed decryption on the requests. Use any value of 250 - 300000. The default value is 1000.

entry.name: delay_errors_duration_xmlfirewallservice_descr_2390
entry.text: How long to delay error messages from the start of the transaction.

entry.name: forbid_external_references_xmlfirewallservice_help_2391
entry.text: Defines if the XML parser will abort when an input document specifies to resolve an external reference such as an external entity or external DTD definition.

entry.name: forbid_external_references_xmlfirewallservice_descr_2391
entry.text: XML parser forbid external references toggle

entry.name: xslproxy_kglobalconfig_help_2392
entry.text: The XSL Proxy is obsolete.

entry.name: xslproxy_kglobalconfig_descr_2392
entry.text: XSL Proxy

entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: ip_address_xslproxyservice_help_2394
entry.text: Enter a host alias or the IP address that the service listens on. Host aliases can ease migration tasks among appliances. 0 or 0.0.0.0 indicates all configured IPv4 addresses. :: indicates all configured IPv4 and IPv6 addresses. #b#Attention:#/b# For management services, the value of 0.0.0.0 or :: is a security risk. Use an explicit IP address to isolate management traffic from application data traffic.

entry.text: Enter the local IP address or host alias.

entry.name: summary_xslproxyservice_descr_2395

entry.name: priority_xslproxyservice_help_2396
entry.text: Control the service scheduling priority. When system resources are in high demand, "high" priority services will be favored over lower priority services.

entry.name: priority_xslproxyservice_descr_2396
entry.text: Service scheduling priority

entry.name: port_xslproxyservice_help_2397
entry.text: Specify the local port to monitor for incoming client requests.

entry.name: port_xslproxyservice_descr_2397
entry.text: Port number

entry.name: remote_ip_address_xslproxyservice_help_2398
entry.text: Specify the host name or IP address of the specific server supported by this DataPower service. If using load balancers, specify the name of the Load Balancer Group. If using the On Demand Router, specify the keyword ODR-LBG. Load balancer groups and the On Demand Router can be used only when Type is static-backend.

entry.name: remote_ip_address_xslproxyservice_descr_2398
entry.text: Host name, IP address, or Load Balancer Group

entry.name: remote_port_xslproxyservice_help_2399
entry.text: Specify the port number to monitor. Used only when Type is static-backend.

entry.name: remote_port_xslproxyservice_descr_2399
entry.text: Port number

entry.name: acl_xslproxyservice_help_2400
entry.text: This Access Control List will be used to allow or deny access to this service based on the IP address of the client. When attached to a service, an Access Control List (ACL) denies all access by default. To deny access to only selected addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0) and then create deny entries for the desired hosts.

entry.name: http_timeout_xslproxyservice_help_2401
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of seconds (within the range 1 through 86400, with a default of 120) that a firewall or proxy maintains an idle HTTP connection.

entry.name: http_timeout_xslproxyservice_descr_2401
entry.text: HTTP idle timer

entry.name: persistent_timeout_xslproxyservice_help_2402
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of seconds (within the range 0 through 7200, with a default of 180) that a firewall or proxy maintains an idle TCP connection.

entry.name: persistent_timeout_xslproxyservice_descr_2402
entry.text: TCP idle timer

entry.name: host_rewriting_xslproxyservice_help_2403
entry.text: When enabled, the device will rewrite the Host: header to be the address of the back-end server. This is not what a strict proxy would do, and may not be appropriate for all topologies.

entry.name: host_rewriting_xslproxyservice_descr_2403
entry.text: Enable/Disable host rewrite

entry.name: silence_warning_xslproxyservice_help_2404
entry.text: Toggle to enable or disable the generation of Transformation Applied (Warning Code: 214) messages by the HTTP service.

entry.name: silence_warning_xslproxyservice_descr_2404
entry.text: Enable/Disable 214 warnings

entry.name: compression_xslproxyservice_help_2405
entry.text: Toggle to enable or disable the GZIP compression function.

entry.name: compression_xslproxyservice_descr_2405
entry.text: Enable/Disable GZIP compression

entry.name: include_response_type_encoding_xslproxyservice_help_2406
entry.text: Toggle to enable or disable including the character set encoding in the HTTP content-type header produced. For example, when sending a UTF-8 encoded XML document: If this property is disabled, 'content-type=text/xml' will be sent. If this property is enabled, 'content-type=text/xml; charset=UTF-8' will be sent.

entry.name: include_response_type_encoding_xslproxyservice_descr_2406
entry.text: Include the character set encoding in the HTTP content-type header

entry.name: always_show_errors_xslproxyservice_help_2407
entry.text: If set, HTTP responses may be generated with errors appended to partially generated documents. If not set error responses will only be sent to the browser if no other output has been created.

entry.name: always_show_errors_xslproxyservice_descr_2407
entry.text: Provide full error reports even when inline with other documents.

entry.name: disallow_get_xslproxyservice_help_2408
entry.text: If set, only methods with incoming data (such as POST) are allowed.

entry.name: disallow_get_xslproxyservice_descr_2408
entry.text: Do not allow clients to do GET and HEAD

entry.name: disallow_empty_reply_xslproxyservice_help_2409
entry.text: If set, only responses with message bodies are allowed (that is, not 304 and so forth).

entry.name: disallow_empty_reply_xslproxyservice_descr_2409
entry.text: Require all responses to have bodies

entry.name: persistent_connections_xslproxyservice_help_2410
entry.text: Toggle to enable or disable HTTP persistent connections.

entry.name: persistent_connections_xslproxyservice_descr_2410
entry.text: Enable/Disable HTTP persistent connections

entry.name: client_address_xslproxyservice_help_2411
entry.text: Retain the default value (X-Client-IP) or provide an other value (for example, X-Forwarded-For).

entry.name: client_address_xslproxyservice_descr_2411
entry.text: HTTP header label containing client IP address

entry.name: http_global_tranid_label_xslproxyservice_help_2412
entry.text: Enter the name of an HTTP Header to read to determine the global transaction ID for chained services. This value defaults to X-Global-Transaction-ID.

entry.name: http_global_tranid_label_xslproxyservice_descr_2412
entry.text: HTTP header label containing global transaction ID

entry.text: Specify the host name or IP address of the HTTP proxy to use when the remote server can be accessed only through another HTTP proxy.

entry.name: httpproxy_address_xslproxyservice_descr_2413
entry.text: Host name or IP address

entry.text: Specify the port number on the HTTP proxy server.

entry.name: httpproxy_port_xslproxyservice_descr_2414
entry.text: Port number

entry.name: version_xslproxyservice_descr_2415
entry.text: HTTP version

entry.name: chunked_uploads_xslproxyservice_help_2416
entry.text: Use the radio buttons to enable (on) or disable (off) the ability to send Content-Type Chunked Encoded documents to the back end server. When the device employs the HTTP/1.1 protocol, the body of the document can be delimited by either Content-Length or chunked encodings. While all servers will understand how to interpret Content-Length, many applications will fail to understand Chunked encoding. For this reason, Content-Length is the standard method used. However doing so interferes with the ability of the device to fully stream. To stream full documents towards the back end server, this property should be turned on. However, the back end server must be RFC 2616 compatible, because this feature cannot be renegotiated at run time, unlike all other HTTP/1.1 features which can be negotiated down at runtime if necessary. This property can also be enabled by configuring a User Agent to enable it on a per-URL basis.

entry.name: chunked_uploads_xslproxyservice_descr_2416
entry.text: Enabled/Disable HTTP/1.1 Chunked Request Bodies

entry.name: suppress_xslproxyservice_help_2418
entry.text: HTTP Headers can be suppressed (removed) from the message flow using this property. For example, the Via: header, which contains the name of the DataPower service handling the message, may be suppressed from messages sent by the DataPower device back to the client.

entry.name: parameter_xslproxyservice_help_2419
entry.text: Stylesheets used in Processing Policies can take stylesheet parameters. These parameters can be passed in by this object. More than one parameter can be defined.

entry.name: default_param_namespace_xslproxyservice_help_2420
entry.text: If a stylesheet parameter is defined without a namespace (or without explicitly specifying the null namespace), then this is the namespace into which the parameter will be assigned.

entry.name: query_param_namespace_xslproxyservice_help_2421
entry.text: The namespace in which to put all parameters that are specified in the URL query string.

entry.name: force_policy_exec_xslproxyservice_help_2422
entry.text: Some message patterns may include bodyless request and response messages. This is common with RESTful web services where messages may or may not include a body but still requires the processing policy to run. To enable this capability for services whose request and response type is XML (or marked as non-XML i.e. JSON), set this option to 'on'. By doing so, the processing policy rules will always be executed.

entry.name: force_policy_exec_xslproxyservice_descr_2422
entry.text: Bypasses the one way exchange pattern

entry.name: monitor_count_xslproxyservice_help_2423
entry.text: Count Monitors watch for defined messaging events and increment counters each time the event occurs. When a certain threshold is reached, the monitor can either post a notification to a log or block service for a configured amount of time. Select a Count Monitor from the list to activate that monitor for this firewall. Click the + button to create a new Count Monitor.

entry.name: monitor_duration_xslproxyservice_help_2424
entry.text: Duration Monitors watch for events meeting or exceeding a configured duration. When a duration is met or exceeded, the monitor can either post a notification to a log or block service for a configured amount of time. Select a Duration Monitor from the list to activate that monitor for this firewall. Click the + button to create a new Duration Monitor.

entry.name: monitor_processing_policy_xslproxyservice_help_2425
entry.text: Select the way that the system behaves when more than one monitor is attached to a service.

entry.name: monitor_processing_policy_xslproxyservice_descr_2425
entry.text: Monitors evaluation method

entry.name: debug_mode_xslproxyservice_help_2426
entry.text: Select the diagnostic mode for processing policies. When enabled, you can view details about the state of variables and contexts for a captured transaction in the probe. The default value is off . Transaction diagnostic mode is not intended for use in a production environment. Transaction diagnostic mode consumes significant resources that can slow down transaction processing.

entry.name: debug_mode_xslproxyservice_descr_2426
entry.text: Controls transaction diagnostic mode

entry.name: debugger_type_xslproxyservice_help_2427
entry.text: Select the probe mode.

entry.name: debugger_type_xslproxyservice_descr_2427
entry.text: Probe Mode

entry.name: debugger_url_xslproxyservice_help_2428
entry.text: Configures the URL for external probe mode

entry.name: debugger_url_xslproxyservice_descr_2428
entry.text: External Server URL

entry.name: debug_history_xslproxyservice_help_2429
entry.text: Set the number of records for transaction diagnostic mode in the probe. Enter a value in the range 10 - 250. The default value is 25.

entry.name: debug_history_xslproxyservice_descr_2429
entry.text: Set the number of records for transaction diagnostic mode in the probe

entry.name: debug_trigger_xslproxyservice_help_2430
entry.text: The probe captures transactions that meet one or more of the conditions defined by the triggers. These triggers examine the direction or type of the message flow and examine the message for an XPath expression match. When a message meets one of these conditions, the transaction is captured in diagnostics mode and becomes part of the list of transactions that can be viewed.

entry.name: debug_trigger_xslproxyservice_descr_2430
entry.text: Probe Triggers

entry.text: The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile and a TLS server profile or TLS SNI server profile.

entry.name: front_timeout_sslproxyservice_help_2453
entry.text: Specify the maximum idle time for client connections in a transaction. This timer monitors the idle time in the data transfer process. If the specified idle time is exceeded, the connection is torn down. Enter a value in the range 0 - 86400. The value of 0 indicates that the timer is disabled. The default value is 0.

entry.name: front_timeout_sslproxyservice_descr_2453
entry.text: Maximum idle time for client connections in a transaction

entry.name: back_timeout_sslproxyservice_help_2454
entry.text: Specify the maximum idle time for server connections in a transaction. This timer monitors the idle time in the data transfer process. If the specified idle time is exceeded, the connection is torn down. Enter a value in the range 0 - 86400. The value of 0 indicates that the timer is disabled. The default value is 0.

entry.name: back_timeout_sslproxyservice_descr_2454
entry.text: Maximum idle time for a server connection in a transaction

entry.name: connection_timeout_sslproxyservice_help_2455
entry.text: Specify the maximum duration for transactions. This timer monitors the duration of end-to-end transactions. If the specified connection time is exceeded, the client connection is torn down. Enter a value in the range of 0 - 86400. The value of 0 indicates that the timer is disabled. The default value is 0.

entry.name: connection_timeout_sslproxyservice_descr_2455
entry.text: Maximum duration for transactions

entry.name: maximum_connections_sslproxyservice_help_2456
entry.text: Specify the maximum number of concurrent client connections to the service. Enter a value in the range of 0 - 65535. The value of 0 indicates an unlimited number of connections. The default value is 100.

entry.name: smtp_server_connection_kglobalconfig_help_2505
entry.text: The SMTP server connection defines the connection details for a Simple Mail Transport Protocol (SMTP) server. The DataPower Gateway uses the SMTP server connection for the following purposes B2B partners use this configuration to send an e-mail message to an AS1 or ESMTP destination. B2B gateways use this configuration to request an AS1 MDN. For ease of configuration, the DataPower Gateway provides the default SMTP server connection configuration in each domain. By default, this configuration is empty and disabled.

entry.name: smtp_server_connection_kglobalconfig_descr_2505
entry.text: SMTP Server Connection

entry.name: server_port_smtpserverconnection_help_2509

entry.name: ssl_smtpserverconnection_help_2510
entry.text: The TLS proxy profile to use to establish a secured connection with the mail server. If blank, the configuration uses the setting from the TLS proxy profile policy in the associated user agent.

entry.name: options_smtpserverconnection_help_2511
entry.text: The SMTP options to enable for the SMTP client. If blank, the configuration uses the setting from the SMTP client policy in the associated user agent.

entry.name: options_smtpserverconnection_descr_2511
entry.text: SMTP options to enable

entry.name: auth_smtpserverconnection_help_2512
entry.text: With the client authentication option, the method to authenticate the SMTP client. If blank, the configuration uses the setting from the SMTP client policy in the associated user agent.

entry.name: auth_smtpserverconnection_descr_2512
entry.text: Method to authenticate SMTP client

entry.name: username_smtpserverconnection_help_2513
entry.text: The account or user name of the SMTP client to authenticate on the SMTP server. The account generally takes the name@domain.com form. If blank, the configuration uses the setting from the basic authentication policy in the associated user agent.

entry.name: username_smtpserverconnection_descr_2513
entry.text: Account or user name to authenticate

entry.name: password_smtpserverconnection_help_2514
entry.text: The password for the SMTP client account or user name that is authenticated to the SMTP server. If either password or alias are blank, the configuration uses the setting from the basic authentication policy in the associated user agent.

entry.name: password_smtpserverconnection_descr_2514
entry.text: Password for account

entry.name: password_alias_smtpserverconnection_help_2515
entry.text: The password alias of the password for the SMTP client account or the user name that is authenticated to the SMTP server. If password or alias are blank, the configuration uses the setting from the basic authentication policy in the associated user agent.

entry.name: password_alias_smtpserverconnection_descr_2515
entry.text: Password alias for account

entry.name: trap_priority_snmpsettings_help_2521
entry.text: Select a minimum trap event priority. The priorities are hierarchical. The lowest is listed last. Set to the minimum that is required for your trap events.
