entry.name: summary_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2678
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: source_sftp_poller_kglobalconfig_help_2679
entry.text: Use an SFTP poller handler to have file based input from a configured SFTP directory. The directory must exist and have the appropriate permission to perform the designated operations. For these configured directories, ensure that the read, write, and delete permissions are available, as required.

entry.name: source_sftp_poller_kglobalconfig_descr_2679
entry.text: SFTP Poller Handler

entry.name: admin_state_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2680
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2680
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2681
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: target_dir_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2682
entry.text: Specify the directory to poll. The path must end in a slash. The path denotes a directory. FTP examples: Absolute to the root directory: "ftp://user:password@host:port/%%2Fpath/" If the user name or password contains the characters colon (:), at symbol (@), or slash (/), use their URL-encoded values in accordance with the specification. Relative to the home directory of the user: "ftp://user:password@host:port/path/" Include a password in the URL with caution. The use of user:/password@host results in a server connection. However, with this configuration, the connection could be unable to send multiple commands to the FTP server. For a stable connection, define a basic authentication policy in the user agent. The user agent is in the XML manager associated with the DataPower service. NFS example: "dpnfs://static-mount-name/path/" SFTP examples: Absolute to the root directory: "sftp://host:port/path/" Relative to the home directory of the user: "sftp://host:port/~/path/" Do not configure one poller to point at a host name that is a virtual name of a load balancer group. This configuration is not the correct way to poll multiple hosts. To poll multiple hosts, use the same DataPower service and configure one poller object for each real host.

entry.name: target_dir_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2682
entry.text: The directory to poll.

entry.name: delay_time_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2683
entry.text: Enter the number of milliseconds to wait after the completion of one poll sequence before starting the next one. A polling sequence is the actual polling action plus the time to complete all transactions that were started by the poll action. The next polling action will start the specified number of milliseconds after the last transaction completes. Enter a value in the range 25 - 100000000. The default value is 60000.

entry.name: delay_time_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2683
entry.text: Interval between polling sequences

entry.name: match_pattern_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2684
entry.text: Enter the PCRE to use to match the contents of the directory being polled. If there is file-renaming or there is a response, this PCRE must create PCRE back references using () pairs. For example, if the input files are NNNNNN.input , the match pattern would be "([0-9]{6})\.input$" .

entry.name: match_pattern_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2684
entry.text: File name pattern to base poll search criteria.

entry.name: processing_rename_pattern_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2685
entry.text: Enter the PCRE to use to rename a file that is being processed. This functionality allows multiple pollers to poll the same directory with the same match pattern. There is no lack of atomicity if the rename operation on the server is atomic. The poller that succeeds in renaming the input file will proceed to process the file. Any other poller that tries to rename the file at the same time will fail to rename the file and will proceed to try the next file that matches the specified match pattern. To ensure uniqueness, the resulting file name will be in the following format: filename . hostname . serial . domain . poller . timestamp filename The file name for the renamed input file. hostname The hostname (system identifier) of the configured DataPower device. serial The serial number of the configured DataPower device. domain The domain of the polling object. poller The name of the polling object. timestamp The timestamp #b#Note:#/b# File renaming cannot be used with an FTP server that supports only 8.3 file names. For example if the input files are NNNNNN.input and you want to rename them to NNNNNN.processing , then the match pattern would be "([0-9]{6})\.input$" and the processing pattern would be "$1.processing" . The resultant file name on the server would be: NNNNNN.processing. hostname . serial . domain . poller . timestamp #b#Note:#/b# If no processing rename pattern is configured, the file will still be renamed. The only difference is that the filename portion of the resulting file is the name of the original input file, not the renamed input file.

entry.name: processing_rename_pattern_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2685
entry.text: File name pattern used to rename a file that is being processed.

entry.name: success_delete_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2686
entry.text: Select whether to delete the input file after successful processing. When enabled, deletes the input file. When not enabled, renames the input file using the renaming pattern specified by Success File Renaming Pattern.

entry.name: success_delete_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2686
entry.text: Delete an input file after successful processing.

entry.name: success_rename_pattern_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2687
entry.text: When Delete File on Success is off, enter the PCRE to use to rename the input file on success. This PCRE will normally have a back reference for the base input file name. For instance, if input files are NNNNNN.input and you want to rename them to NNNNNN.processed , the match pattern would be "([0-9]{6})\.input$" and the rename pattern would be "$1.processed" . Some servers might allow this pattern to indicate a path that puts the file in a different directory, if it allows cross-directory renames. For instance, the match pattern would be "(.*)" and the rename pattern would be "../processed/$1" .

entry.name: success_rename_pattern_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2687
entry.text: File name pattern used to rename a file that has been processed successfully.

entry.name: error_delete_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2688
entry.text: Select whether to delete the input or processing rename file when it could not be processed. When enabled, deletes the file. When not enabled, renames the input or processing rename file using the renaming pattern specified by Error File Renaming Pattern.

entry.name: error_delete_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2688
entry.text: Delete a file after failure to process.

entry.name: error_rename_pattern_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2689
entry.text: When Delete File on Processing Error is not enabled, enter the PCRE to use to rename a file when it could not be processed.

entry.name: error_rename_pattern_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2689
entry.text: File name pattern used to rename a file that could not be processed.

entry.name: result_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2690
entry.text: Select whether to create a result file after processing an input file. When enabled, creates the result file using the naming pattern specified by Result File Name Pattern. When not enabled, does not create the result file.

entry.name: result_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2690
entry.text: Create a result file after processing an input file.

entry.name: result_name_pattern_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2691
entry.text: When Generate Result File is on, enter the PCRE to use as the match pattern to build the name of the result file. This PCRE will normally have a back reference for the base input file name. For instance, if input files are NNNNNN.input and the desired result file name is NNNNNN.result , then the match pattern would be "([0-9]{6})\.input$" and the result pattern would be "$1.result" . Some servers might allow this pattern to indicate a path that puts the file in a different directory, if it allows cross-directory renames. For instance, the match pattern would be "(.*)" and the result pattern would be "../result/$1" .

entry.name: result_name_pattern_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2691
entry.text: File name pattern used to build the name of a response file.

entry.name: processing_seize_timeout_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2692
entry.text: Enter the time to wait before processing a file that is already in the processing state. Enter a value in the range 0 - 1000. The default value is 0, which means disabled. Processing seizure allows failure handling of a poller when more than one poller polls the same target. If another poller renames a file and does not process and rename or delete it in the specified time, another poller can take over processing. A poller attempts to take over processing when the following conditions are met when compared to the processing seize pattern. The seize pattern includes the portion of the file name with the configured processing suffix to match. The time stamp is further in the past than the wait time specified by the timeout. When these conditions are met, another poller renames the file with a fresh time stamp and processes the file. The processing assumes that the rename operation succeeded.

entry.name: processing_seize_timeout_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2692
entry.text: Time to wait to process a file that is in the processing state.

entry.name: processing_seize_pattern_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2693
entry.text: Enter the PCRE to find files that were renamed to indicate that they are in the "being processed" state but the processing was never completed. The seize pattern contains two phrases. The first phrase is the portion of the file name with the configured processing suffix. The second phrase is the time stamp. For example: (.*.processing).*[.*]([0-9]*) . This assumes that $1.processing was supplied as the renaming pattern.

entry.name: processing_seize_pattern_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2693
entry.text: PCRE to find files that were renamed to indicate that they are in the "being processed" state but the processing never completed.

entry.name: xml_manager_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2694
entry.text: An XML Manager manages the compilation and caching of stylesheets and documents. The XML Manager can also control the size and depth of messages processed by this host. Specify an existing XML Manager. More than one service may use the same XML Manager.

entry.name: xml_manager_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2694
entry.text: An XML manager

entry.name: max_transfers_per_poll_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2695
entry.text: The number of allowed concurrent client connections in a polling sequence. Enter a value in the range 0 - 100. The value must be less than the number of simultaneous connections that the polled server accepts. The default value is 0 which means unlimited number of connections based on available system resources. To avoid the consumption of all the systems resources, enter a value other than 0.

entry.name: max_transfers_per_poll_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2695
entry.text: Maximum number of files to be transferred during each cycle of the poller connection

entry.name: ssh_client_connection_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2696
entry.text: Specifies the name of the SSH client profile which describes how SSH connections are made from the SSH client to an SSH server.

entry.name: ssh_client_connection_sftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2696
entry.text: SSH Client Connection profile

entry.name: source_ftp_server_kglobalconfig_help_2697
entry.text: The FTP server handler provides an FTP server that can be used to submit files for processing by the system. Each file that is written results in one transaction. There can be multiple FTP servers, but only one server can listen on the default port 21 on a given IP address. There can be multiple simultaneous connections from FTP clients to the same FTP server. #b#Notes:#/b# The 226 FTP response code at the end of an FTP STOR or STOU command is conditional on successful completion of the internal steps and backside operation of the transaction. Changes in the configuration affect only new connections to this FTP server. Existing connections continue to use their current configuration until they disconnect.

entry.name: source_ftp_server_kglobalconfig_descr_2697
entry.text: FTP Server Handler

entry.name: admin_state_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2698
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2698
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2699
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: address_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2700
entry.text: Enter the address on which the FTP server service listens. The default of 0.0.0.0 indicates that the service is active on all addresses. Click Select Alias to use an alias for this value. Local host aliases can help ease migration tasks among machines. If the FTP server service is listening on a virtual IP address managed by a standby control group with the self-balancing feature enabled, incoming control and data connections will always go to the active member of the standby control group.

entry.name: address_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2700
entry.text: Local IP address

entry.name: port_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2701
entry.text: Enter the port that is monitored by the FTP server service. This port is the port on which FTP control connections can be established. This port does not control the TCP port that is used for the data connections. If the FTP client uses the PASV command, data connections will use an arbitrary, unused TCP port. Defaults to 21. Valid range is 1 through 65535.

entry.name: port_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2701
entry.text: Local TCP port for the FTP server

entry.name: filesystem_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2702
entry.text: Select the file system type that is presented by the FTP server. If Virtual Ephemeral or Virtual Persistent is chosen, the client can write files to all directories. These files are shown in directory listings but cannot be retrieved. For file system responses, the responses are shown and can be retrieved, renamed, and deleted by the client. If Transparent is chosen, the file system shows the contents of the equivalent path of the remote server of the DataPower service with which this FTP server is associated. This configuration property is only supported by the FTP server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

entry.name: filesystem_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2702
entry.text: The type of file system the FTP server will present

entry.name: persistent_filesystem_timeout_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2703
entry.text: Enter the duration in seconds that a connection to a virtual file system is retained after all FTP control connections from user identities are disconnected. When the timeout expires, the virtual file system object is destroyed. All of the response files that were not deleted by the FTP client are deleted from their storage area. Default to 600 (10 minutes). Valid range is 1 to 43,200 seconds (12 hours).

entry.name: persistent_filesystem_timeout_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2703
entry.text: Controls how long a virtual persistent file system with no active connections is retained

entry.name: virtual_directory_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2704
entry.text: In virtual mode, create a directory in the virtual file system that is presented by this FTP server. The FTP client can use all of these directories to write file to be processed. The root directory (/) is always present and cannot be created. Its response directory is always the root directory.

entry.name: virtual_directory_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2704
entry.text: Create directory in virtual file system of FTP server

entry.name: default_directory_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2705
entry.text: Enter the initial working directory on the FTP server (after users connect and authenticate). When using a virtual file system and the working directory is not the root directory, the specified directory must be one of the configured virtual directories. The default value is the root directory (/).

entry.name: default_directory_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2705
entry.text: Default for current working directory

entry.name: max_filename_len_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2706
entry.text: Enter the maximum file name length on the FTP server. Defaults to 256 characters. Valid range is 1 through 4000.

entry.name: max_filename_len_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2706
entry.text: Maximum length of a file name on the server

entry.name: acl_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2707
entry.text: Select an access control list to apply. The ACL allows or denies access to the FTP server based on the IP address of the FTP client. When attached to a server, the default for an ACL is to deny all access. To deny access to only select IP addresses, first grant access to all addresses (allow 0.0.0.0). Then, create deny entries for the desired hosts.

entry.name: require_tls_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2708
entry.text: Specify whether FTP control connections require TLS encryption. For implicit or explicit FTP, you must complete the configuration by specifying the TLS profile to secure the connection.

entry.name: require_tls_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2708
entry.text: Control whether FTP control connections require TLS encryption

entry.name: ssl_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2709
entry.text: The TLS proxy profile references the required cryptographic configurations for the secure connection.

entry.name: ssl_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2709
entry.text: The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS server profile or TLS SNI server profile.

entry.name: password_aaa_policy_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2710
entry.text: Selects the AAA Policy to perform authentication of user names and passwords provided to the FTP server by the client with the USER and PASS commands. If the authentication succeeds, the FTP client may use all the features of the FTP server. If the authentication fails, a 530 error is returned, and the user can attempt to authenticate again. Without this AAA Policy configured, any user name and password will be accepted.

entry.name: password_aaa_policy_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2710
entry.text: AAA policy for validating user name and password

entry.name: certificate_aaa_policy_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2711
entry.text: Selects the AAA Policy to perform secondary authentication of the information provided in the TLS certificate provided during TLS negotiation after the AUTH TLS command to the FTP server. Primary authentication is done by the TLS Profile, it can completely reject a certificate. This authentication stage controls whether an FTP password will be demanded or not. If the result of this authentication succeeds, the FTP client will only have to use the USER command to login after the AUTH TLS . If this authentication fails, the FTP client will have to use both the USER and #b#PASS#/b# commands to complete the login process. If no Certificate AAA Policy is configured, USER and #b#PASS#/b# will always be required. If the AUTH TLS command is not used by the FTP client, USER and #b#PASS#/b# will always be required.

entry.name: certificate_aaa_policy_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2711
entry.text: AAA Policy for determining whether password is required

entry.name: allow_ccc_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2712
entry.text: Specify whether the FTP #b#CCC#/b# command can be used to turn off TLS encryption of the FTP control connection after user authentication. If allowed, the #b#CCC#/b# command can be used to turn off encryption after authentication. Turning off encryption is necessary when the FTP control connection crosses a firewall or NAT device that needs to sniff the control connection. Turning off encryption eliminates the secrecy of the files being transferred and allows TCP packets injection attacks.

entry.name: allow_ccc_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2712
entry.text: Control use of CCC command

entry.name: passive_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2713
entry.text: Control use of the FTP PASV and EPSV commands by the FTP client, as an alternative to the PORT and EPRT commands. The default behavior is to allow PORT, EPRT, PASV, and EPSV. Other settings either require PASV or EPSV, or require PORT or EPRT. If an acceptable PORT, EPRT, PASV, or EPSV command is not received, the STOR, STOU, RETR, LIST, and NLST data transfer commands will fail. (This FTP server will never attempt to connect to the deprecated default FTP data port at TCP port 20.)

entry.name: passive_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2713
entry.text: Control use of passive mode

entry.name: passive_port_range_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2714
entry.text: When enabled, when a PASV or EPSV command is received from the FTP client, instead of selecting any free listening TCP port in the range 1024 to 65534, allow configuration of a restricted port range. This may be used when a firewall wants to allow incoming FTP data connections only on a limited range of ports, particularly when it cannot "sniff" the FTP control connection. Note that the size of the range specified limits how many FTP clients can be in the state between receiving the 227 response code to the PASV or EPSV command, and establishing the FTP data TCP connection. Pressure on this limited resource can be controlled by adjusting the passive data connection idle timeout. While it is perfectly legal to configure multiple FTP servers on the same system to use the same (or overlapping) passive port ranges, realize that they are contending for a common resource in the TCP implementation. However, it is not wise to use a port range that overlaps with other services (HTTP servers, etc.) that are configured on the system. There is no configuration checking for such conflicts, and other configured services will allocate the ports first, and they will not be available for the FTP server. (The FTP server allocates these listing ports dynamically.)

entry.name: passive_port_range_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2714
entry.text: Enable using a limited range of TCP port numbers for Passive connections.

entry.name: passive_port_min_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2715
entry.text: Specify the lowest listening TCP port number to use for passive FTP data connections. Enter a value in the range 1024 - 65534 as long as this value is not greater than the value for the maximum passive port.

entry.name: passive_port_min_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2715
entry.text: Lowest port value for the passive port range

entry.name: passive_port_max_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2716
entry.text: Specify the highest listening TCP port number to use for passive FTP data connections. Enter a value in the range 1024 - 65534 as long as this value is not less than the value for the minimum passive port.

entry.name: passive_port_max_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2716
entry.text: Highest port value for the passive port range

entry.name: passive_idle_timeout_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2717
entry.text: Specifies the number of seconds that the server waits for a client to establish a passive connection. Enter a value in the range 5 - 300. The default value is 60. This setting controls the amount of time in seconds between when the FTP server issues code 227 (Entering Passive Mode) in response to the PASV or EPSV command from the FTP client and when the FTP client must establish a TCP data connection to the listening port and issue a data transfer command. If the data connection is not established within the timeout period, the listening port will be closed. If a data transfer command is issued after the port is closed, the command fails with code 425 and the Failed to open data connection message. If the data connection is established but no data transfer command is issued within the timeout period, the TCP data connection will be closed. Any data transfer command after the timeout will be treated as if the PASV or EPSV command was never issued. The command fails with code 425 and the Require PASV or PORT command first message.

entry.name: passive_idle_timeout_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2717
entry.text: Idle timeout for a passive data connection

entry.name: passive_promiscuous_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2718
entry.text: This option will disable the IP security check that is done when processing the FTP PASV command. The check verifies that the IP address of the client connecting to the data connection is the same as the one that established the control connection. The default value for this option is off, which is the expected behavior for an FTP server. Turn the option on if there is a specific reason the incoming connection will not be coming from the same client as the control connection (i.e. from a load balancer). This configuration property is only supported by the FTP server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

entry.name: passive_promiscuous_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2718
entry.text: Disable passive data connection (PASV) IP security check

entry.name: port_promiscuous_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2719
entry.text: This option will disable the IP security check that verifies that outgoing data connections can only connect to the client. The default value for this option is off, which is the expected behavior for an FTP server. This configuration property is only supported by the FTP server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

entry.name: port_promiscuous_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2719
entry.text: Disable active data connection (PORT) IP security check

entry.name: allow_passive_addr_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2720
entry.text: When on, this option will enable the ability to override the IP address that is presented to the FTP client when the server is in passive mode. This configuration property is only supported by the FTP server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

entry.name: allow_passive_addr_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2720
entry.text: Use alternate PASV IP address

entry.name: passive_addr_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2721
entry.text: The numeric IP address that will be returned to the FTP client in response to a PASV command. This does not change the IP address that the FTP server will listen on, which is always the IP address that the FTP data connection was made to. This is used in certain situations when the FTP server is behind a firewall that is not FTP-aware.

entry.name: passive_addr_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2721
entry.text: Alternate PASV IP address

entry.name: list_cmd_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2722
entry.text: When on, the server will make a distinction between the LIST and NLST commands. When off, the server will always respond with an NLST when requesting a file listing. The default value for this option is off This configuration property is only supported by the FTP server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

entry.name: list_cmd_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2722
entry.text: Enable LIST command support

entry.name: dele_cmd_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2723
entry.text: When on, allows the DELE (delete) command to be passed to the FTP server. This is only valid in transparent file system type. The default value for this option is off This configuration property is only supported by the FTP server handler and in conjunction with a Multi-Protocol Gateway or Web Service Proxy.

entry.name: dele_cmd_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2723
entry.text: Enable DELE (delete) support

entry.name: data_encryption_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2724
entry.text: Select the use of encryption for data connections (file transfers). Data encryption is controlled by the FTP PROT P command.

entry.name: data_encryption_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2724
entry.text: Control use of data encryption for file transfers

entry.name: allow_compression_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2725
entry.text: Specify whether the FTP client can use FTP MODE Z compression. After enabling FTP compression, the FTP client can use the zlib method to compress data transfers.

entry.name: allow_compression_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2725
entry.text: Control use of MODE Z command to compress data transfer

entry.name: allow_unique_filename_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2726
entry.text: Specify whether the FTP client can use the FTP STOU command. When enabled, the FTP server generates a unique file name for each transferred file.

entry.name: allow_unique_filename_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2726
entry.text: Control use of STOU command for unique file names

entry.name: unique_filename_prefix_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2727
entry.text: Enter the prefix (leading characters) for file names that are generated when using the FTP STOU command. When defining the prefix, the directory separator (/) is not allowed. The default behavior is to not add a prefix, which is an empty string. #b#Note:#/b# The software adds a numeric suffix.

entry.name: unique_filename_prefix_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2727
entry.text: Prefix of all unique filenames generated by STOU

entry.name: allow_restart_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2728
entry.text: Controls whether the FTP client can use the FTP REST command to continue the transfer of a file after an interruption in the data transfer. This is supported in the BSD stream style described in draft-ietf-ftpext-mlst-16.txt. (The MODE B style that is described in RFC 959 is not supported.) The FTP server must be configured with a virtual persistent file system. For written files, the server will delay the actual processing until a timeout expires or until the next FTP command other than a SIZE or REST command. This processing allows the FTP client can return and resume to the transfer using the SIZE , REST , and STOR commands. The argument to the REST command must be the same as the byte count returned by the SIZE command. #b#Note:#/b# The response code to all STOR commands on this server will always be 226. The response codes does not reflect the success of the transaction. This capability is also supported for reading the response files, if the server is configured for a response type of virtual file system. #b#Note:#/b# The generation of response files are delayed until the transaction is completed.

entry.name: allow_restart_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2728
entry.text: Control use of the REST command for interrupted file transfers

entry.name: restart_timeout_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2729
entry.text: When restart ( REST ) is enabled, the number of seconds that the FTP client has to reconnect to the server and use the SIZE , REST , and STOR commands to continue an interrupted file transfer. If this period of time elapses, the data that was received to this point on the TCP data connection will be passed to the DataPower service. This timeout is canceled if another command (other than SIZE or REST ) is received on the FTP control connection.

entry.name: restart_timeout_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2729
entry.text: Time that the STOR command waits for a restart

entry.name: idle_timeout_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2730
entry.text: Enter the number of seconds that the FTP control connection can be idle. After the specified duration elapses, the FTP server closes the control connection. Defaults to 0, which disables the timeout.

entry.name: idle_timeout_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2730
entry.text: Inactivity limit on FTP control connection

entry.name: response_type_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2731
entry.text: Select how to make response files available for gateway transactions started by an FTP STOR or SOUT operation.

entry.name: response_type_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2731
entry.text: How to make response available to FTP client

entry.name: response_storage_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2732
entry.text: Select where response files are stored.

entry.name: response_storage_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2732
entry.text: Where to store response files

entry.name: filesystem_size_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2733
entry.text: Enter in megabytes the maximum size for the temporary file system size. Defaults to 32 MB. Valid range is 1 MB through 2048 MB.

entry.name: filesystem_size_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2733
entry.text: Maximum size of temporary file system

entry.name: response_nfs_mount_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2734
entry.text: When Response Type is Virtual File System and Response Storage is NFS, select an NFS static mount to apply. Each response file will have a unique file name in the NFS directory. The name of the response file is not related to the file name that the virtual file system presents to the FTP client. Generally, this NFS directory is not made available through the FTP server. This directory should not be used for any other purpose.

entry.name: response_nfs_mount_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2734
entry.text: NFS mount to store response files in

entry.name: response_suffix_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2735
entry.text: When the response type is a virtual file system, enter the suffix to add when generating response files. The directory separator (/) is not allowed. If the response type is a virtual file system and the FTP client is writing in virtual directories that do not have a response directory or if the response directory is the same as the virtual directory, this value must have a non-empty value. If empty, the response would try to overwrite the request, which is not allowed. Defaults to an empty string.

entry.name: response_suffix_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2735
entry.text: URL file name suffix to response file

entry.name: ssl_config_type_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2736
entry.text: The TLS profile type to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway. If a TLS profile is assigned, the FTP AUTH TLS server command will be enabled, and the client will be able to start TLS encryption of the FTP control connection. The chosen TLS profile controls the TLS credentials that the FTP server will present to the client after the AUTH TLS command, and how the TLS credentials presented by the client will be evaluated.

entry.name: ssl_config_type_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2736
entry.text: Set the TLS profile type to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway

entry.name: ssl_server_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2737
entry.text: The TLS server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway.

entry.name: ssl_server_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2737
entry.text: Set the TLS server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_help_2738
entry.text: The TLS SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway.

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_ftpserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_2738
entry.text: Set the TLS SNI server profile to secure connections between clients and the DataPower Gateway

entry.name: source_http_kglobalconfig_help_2739
entry.text: An HTTP handler receives HTTP requests that are not over TLS and forwards them to the appropriate DataPower service. HTTP handlers conform to RFC 2616.

entry.name: source_http_kglobalconfig_descr_2739
entry.text: HTTP Handler

entry.name: admin_state_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2740
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2740
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2741
entry.text: A descriptive summary for the configuration.

entry.name: summary_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2741
entry.text: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.

entry.name: local_address_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2742
entry.text: The address on which the HTTP handler listens. The default value indicates that The handler listens on all IPv4 addresses.

entry.name: local_address_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2742
entry.text: Enter the IP address or host alias on which the HTTP handler listens.

entry.name: port_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2743
entry.text: The port on which the HTTP handler listens. The default value is 80.

entry.name: port_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2743
entry.text: Enter the port on which the HTTP handler listens.

entry.name: socket_path_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2744
entry.text: Unix domain socket path.

entry.name: socket_path_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2744
entry.text: Unix domain socket path.

entry.name: http_client_version_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2745
entry.text: The HTTP version for the client side connection. The default value is HTTP 1.1. For the HTTP/2 protocol, requests and responses are always HTTP/2. When HTTP/2, this setting is ignored.

entry.name: http_client_version_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2745
entry.text: Set the HTTP version for the client side connection.

entry.name: allowed_features_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2746
entry.text: The methods and versions to allow for incoming requests.

entry.name: allowed_features_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2746
entry.text: Set the methods and versions to allow for incoming requests.

entry.name: persistent_connections_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2747
entry.text: Whether to negotiate persistent client side connections. The HTTP/2 protocol controls persistent connections and reuse. Therefore, these settings are ignored.

entry.name: persistent_connections_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2747
entry.text: Indicate whether to negotiate persistent client side connections.

entry.name: max_persistent_reuse_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2748
entry.text: The maximum number of times a persistent client side connection is reused. When the maximum reuse count is reached, an explicit HTTP Connection: close header is sent in the response, and the TCP connection is closed. The default value is 0, which means unlimited reuse.

entry.name: max_persistent_reuse_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2748
entry.text: Enter the maximum number of times a persistent client side connection is reused.

entry.name: compression_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2749
entry.text: Whether to negotiate GZIP compression for client side connections. If enabled, the DataPower service uses GZIP to compress HTTP transmissions when the Accept-Encoding HTTP header indicates that compressed documents can be processed. The Transfer-Encoding HTTP header indicates compression.

entry.name: compression_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2749
entry.text: Indicate whether to negotiate GZIP compression for client side connections.

entry.name: websocket_upgrade_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2750
entry.text: Whether to allow WebSocket upgrade requests from clients. The default value is disabled. This request is to switch the existing connection to use the WebSocket protocol. WebSocket upgrade requests require that The handler allows GET methods.

entry.name: websocket_upgrade_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2750
entry.text: Indicate whether to allow WebSocket upgrade requests from clients.

entry.name: websocket_idle_timeout_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2751
entry.text: The maximum idle time for client connections. This timer monitors the idle time in the data transfer process. When the specified idle time is exceeded, the connection is torn down. Enter a value in the range 0 - 86400. The default value is 0, which indicates that the timer is disabled.

entry.name: websocket_idle_timeout_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2751
entry.text: Enter the maximum idle time for client connections.

entry.name: max_url_len_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2752
entry.text: The length of the longest incoming URL to accept. The length includes any query string or fragment identifier. Enter a value in the range 1 - 128000. The default value is 16384.

entry.name: max_url_len_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2752
entry.text: Enter the length of the longest incoming URL to accept.

entry.name: max_total_header_len_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2753
entry.text: The maximum aggregate length of HTTP headers to allow. Enter a value in the range 5 - 128000. The default value is 128000.

entry.name: max_total_header_len_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2753
entry.text: Enter the maximum aggregate length of HTTP headers to allow.

entry.name: max_header_count_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2754
entry.text: The maximum number of headers to allow in client requests. The default value is 0, which indicates no limit.

entry.name: max_header_count_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2754
entry.text: Enter the maximum number of headers to allow in client requests.

entry.name: max_header_name_len_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2755
entry.text: The maximum length of a header name to allow in client requests. Each HTTP header is expressed as a name-value pair. This setting sets the maximum length of the name portion of a header. The default value is 0, which indicates no limit.

entry.name: max_header_name_len_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2755
entry.text: Enter the maximum length of a header name to allow in client requests.

entry.name: max_header_value_len_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2756
entry.text: The maximum length of a header value to allow in client requests. Each HTTP header is expressed as a name-value pair. This setting sets the maximum length of the value portion of a header. The default value is 0, which indicates no limit.

entry.name: max_header_value_len_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2756
entry.text: Enter the maximum length of a header value to allow in client requests.

entry.name: max_querystring_len_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2757
entry.text: The maximum length of the query string to allow in client requests. The query string is the portion of the URL after the question mark (?) character. The default value is 0, which indicates no limit.

entry.name: max_querystring_len_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2757
entry.text: Enter the maximum length of the query string to allow in client requests.

entry.name: acl_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2758
entry.text: The access control list uses the defined client IP addresses to allow or deny access.

entry.name: acl_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2758
entry.text: Assign the access control list.

entry.name: credential_charset_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2759
entry.text: The character encoding of the original basic authentication values. Basic authentication credentials are combined and base64 encoded in the authorization header of the request. The DataPower Gateway transcodes the contents of the authorization header to UTF-8. The default value represents ISO-8859-1 Latin 1.

entry.name: credential_charset_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2759
entry.text: Set the character encoding of the original basic authentication values.

entry.name: http2_max_streams_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2760
entry.text: The maximum number of concurrent streams that the client can have outstanding at the same time with The handler. The limit applies to the number of streams that the client allows the target to create. The greater the number of streams in use, the more resources the client uses. Resources include memory and the network connections to the destination. Enter a value in the range 1 - 500. The default value is 100.

entry.name: http2_max_streams_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2760
entry.text: Enter the maximum number of current streams that a client can have

entry.name: http2_max_frame_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2761
entry.text: The largest payload frame size that the client can send. Enter a value in the range 16384 - 16777215. The default value is 16384.

entry.name: http2_max_frame_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2761
entry.text: Enter the largest payload frame size that clients can send

entry.name: http2_stream_header_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2762
entry.text: Indicates whether to enable the HTTP/2 stream identifier header in the request or response. When enabled, the HTTP/2 stream identifier is included in the X-DP-http2-stream header. With this header, you can correlate the HTTP/2 stream. The default behavior is disabled.

entry.name: http2_stream_header_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2762
entry.text: Whether to enable the HTTP/2 stream identifier header in the request or response

entry.name: chunked_encoding_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2763
entry.text: When enabled, the HTTP response will use Transfer-Encoding: chunked. The default behavior is enabled.

entry.name: chunked_encoding_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2763
entry.text: Whether to enable the responses to use Transfer-Encoding: chunked

entry.name: header_timeout_httpsourceprotocolhandler_help_2764
entry.text: The maximum duration in milliseconds to allow for request headers processing. When the value is greater than 0, request header processing must complete before the duration elapses. Enter a value in the range 0 - 3600000, where a value of 0 disables the timer. The default value is 30000.

entry.name: header_timeout_httpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2764
entry.text: Enter the maximum duration to allow for request headers processing

entry.name: http2_stream_header_httpssourceprotocolhandler_help_2791
entry.text: Indicates whether to enable the HTTP/2 stream identifier header in the request or response. When enabled, the HTTP/2 stream identifier is included in the X-DP-http2-stream header. With this header, you can correlate the HTTP/2 stream. The default behavior is disabled.

entry.name: http2_stream_header_httpssourceprotocolhandler_descr_2791
entry.text: Whether to enable the HTTP/2 stream identifier header in the request or response

entry.name: chunked_encoding_httpssourceprotocolhandler_help_2792
entry.text: When enabled, the HTTP response will use Transfer-Encoding: chunked. The default behavior is enabled.

entry.text: Whether to enable the responses to use Transfer-Encoding: chunked

entry.name: header_timeout_httpssourceprotocolhandler_help_2793
entry.text: The maximum duration in milliseconds to allow for request headers processing. When the value is greater than 0, request header processing must complete before the duration elapses. Enter a value in the range 0 - 3600000, where a value of 0 disables the timer. The default value is 30000.

entry.name: header_timeout_httpssourceprotocolhandler_descr_2793
entry.text: Enter the maximum duration to allow for request headers processing

entry.name: source_ims_callout_kglobalconfig_help_2794

entry.name: retry_attempts_imscalloutsourceprotocolhandler_help_2805
entry.text: Specifies the number of times to attempt to resume a transaction pipe (tpipe) after processing encounters an error. Enter a value in the range 1 - 256. The default value is 5.

entry.name: retry_attempts_imscalloutsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2805
entry.text: Number of times to attempt to resume a tpipe

entry.name: retry_interval_imscalloutsourceprotocolhandler_help_2806
entry.text: Specifies the number of seconds to wait before processing attempts to resume the transaction pipe (tpipe). The minimum value is 1. The default value is 3.

entry.name: retry_interval_imscalloutsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2806
entry.text: Interval to wait before processing attempts to resume the tpipe

entry.name: connect_timeout_imscalloutsourceprotocolhandler_help_2807
entry.text: Specifies the number of seconds that the DataPower Gateway waits to establish a connection to IMS Connect. A value of 0 disables the timeout. The default value is 10.

entry.name: connect_timeout_imscalloutsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2807
entry.text: Time to wait to establish a connection

entry.name: response_concurrency_imscalloutsourceprotocolhandler_help_2808
entry.text: Specifies the number of response processors to allocate for each tpipe for concurrent transaction processing. Enter a value in the range 1 - 32. The default value is 1. For example, when you set response concurrency to 2 and you have 5 tpipe definitions, the number of response processors is 10. The maximum number of response processors is 50.

entry.name: response_concurrency_imscalloutsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2808
entry.text: Number of response processors to allocate for concurrent transactions processing.

entry.name: trace_file_imscalloutsourceprotocolhandler_help_2809
entry.text: Enables IMS tracing and specifies the location of the trace file. You can use the following directories as the location when you enable tracing: logtemp logstore temporary #b#Note:#/b# Enable tracing when instructed by IBM Support to help in problem determination. If you enabled tracing and want to disable, remove the directory and apply the configuration.

entry.name: trace_file_imscalloutsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2809
entry.text: Location for the trace file

entry.name: source_internal_imscalloutsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2810
entry.text: HTTP dplane link

entry.name: input_message_timeout_imscalloutsourceprotocolhandler_help_2811
entry.text: Sets the value for the IRM_TIMER field in milliseconds to wait for the input message from the client. Enter a value in the range -1 to 3600000. The default value is 60000. The specified value is internally set to the following incremental duration. Entered value as the 1-millisecond boundary when the value is in the range 1 - 25. Increments to the nearest 5-millisecond boundary when the value is in the range 26 - 95. Increments to the nearest 100-millisecond (1-second) boundary when the value is in the range 96 - 60000. Increments to the nearest 60000-millisecond (1-minute) boundary when the value is in the range 60001 - 3600000. The following values have specific meaning. -1 (0x00) Use default values. The default for all RESUME_TPIPE is 2 seconds. The default for all RESUME_TPIPE non-single ACK is .25 seconds. The value of the TIMEOUT parameter in the IMS Connect TCPIP configuration statement for all others. 0 (0xFF) Wait indefinitely. This setting is intended to support the auto option of the asynchronous output function.

entry.name: input_message_timeout_imscalloutsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2811
entry.text: Value for IRM_TIMER to wait for the input message

entry.name: queue_manager_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_help_2841
entry.text: Select the queue manager that provides messaging services for communicating applications by periodically monitoring or polling queues, and by ensuring that messages are directed to the correct receive queue or routed to another queue manager. The local queue manager corresponds to a queue manager running on another host on the network.

entry.name: queue_manager_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_descr_2841
entry.text: The name of a local queue manager

entry.name: get_queue_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_help_2842
entry.text: Enter the name of the get queue associated with the identified queue manager. The handler will get messages from this queue.

entry.name: get_queue_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_descr_2842
entry.text: The get queue associated with the queue manager

entry.name: get_message_options_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_help_2843
entry.text: Specifies the cumulative value of the MQGET options that are applicable to an IBM MQ message in decimal or hex format. The value is passed directly to the IBM MQ API. The default value is 32769, which is the decimal value for the MQGMO_WAIT and MQGMO_LOGICAL_ORDER options.

entry.name: get_message_options_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_descr_2843
entry.text: Options flags for the MQGMO structure

entry.name: concurrent_connections_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_help_2844
entry.text: The number of concurrent IBM MQ conversations allocated for this handler. The default value is 1 but can be increased to improve performance.

entry.name: concurrent_connections_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_descr_2844
entry.text: The number of concurrent IBM MQ conversations allocated for this handler

entry.name: polling_interval_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_help_2845
entry.text: The number of seconds to wait after processing all messages before attempting to retrieve messages from the get queue.

entry.name: polling_interval_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_descr_2845
entry.text: The duration to wait after processing all messages before attempting to retrieve messages from the get queue.

entry.name: retrieve_backout_settings_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_help_2846
entry.text: Controls whether to retrieve backout setting from the IBM MQ server. When enabled, retrieves the #b#Backout threshold#/b# and #b#Backout requeue queue name#/b# settings from the IBM MQ server and checks these values. On a reattempt, the handler uses the higher priority backout settings from the server. If the server does not contain backout settings, the handler uses any existing backout values, either empty or populated, from the local queue manager. If there are no backout settings, the backout function is disabled. When an alias queue is used, its attributes are retrieved, not those of the base queue.

entry.name: retrieve_backout_settings_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_descr_2846
entry.text: Controls retrieval of backout settings from the IBM MQ server

entry.name: use_qm_in_url_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_help_2847
entry.text: Indicates whether the var://service/URL-in variable returns the name of the local queue manager or queue manager group when this configuration defines a queue manager group as the queue manager. When #b#on#/b#, the variable returns the name of the queue manager. When #b#off#/b#, the default, the variable returns the name of the queue manager group.

entry.name: use_qm_in_url_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_descr_2847
entry.text: Whether to use the queue manager or the queue manager group in the front-end URL

entry.name: retrieve_backout_settings_mqv9plusmftsourceprotocolhandler_help_2858
entry.text: Controls whether to retrieve backout setting from the IBM MQ server. When enabled, retrieves the #b#Backout threshold#/b# and #b#Backout requeue queue name#/b# settings from the IBM MQ server and checks these values. On a reattempt, the IBM MQ handler uses the higher priority backout settings from the server. If the server does not contain backout settings, the handler uses any existing backout values, either empty or populated, from the local IBM MQ queue manager. If there are no backout settings, the backout function is disabled. When an alias queue is used, its attributes are retrieved, not those of the base queue.

entry.text: Controls retrieval of backout settings from the IBM MQ server

entry.name: ignore_backout_errors_mqv9plusmftsourceprotocolhandler_help_2859
entry.text: Controls whether to ignore backout errors When disabled, the default, roll back and retry the transfer. When enabled, ignore the error in sending the transfer to the backout queue and commit the transfer from the get queue.

entry.name: ignore_backout_errors_mqv9plusmftsourceprotocolhandler_descr_2859
entry.text: Controls whether to ignore backout errors

entry.name: ccsi_mqv9plussourceprotocolhandler_help_2870
entry.text: Specifies the coded character set identifier to which the remote queue manager converts output data. This property is meaningful only when the queue manager has the convert property set to on. The CCSI will be put in the CodeCharSetId field of MQMD. The default CCSI is for ISO-8859-1 (latin-1). For MQCCSI_EMBEDDED enter 4294967295; for MQCCSI_INHERIT enter 4294967294. For the other CCSIDs, refer to the IBM Code Pages in the Information Center.

entry.name: ccsi_mqv9plussourceprotocolhandler_descr_2870
entry.text: Coded character set identifier

entry.name: get_message_options_mqv9plussourceprotocolhandler_help_2871
entry.text: Specifies the cumulative value of the MQGET options that are applicable to an IBM MQ message in decimal or hex format. The value is passed directly to the IBM MQ API. The default value is 1, which is the decimal value for the MQGMO_WAIT option.

entry.name: get_message_options_mqv9plussourceprotocolhandler_descr_2871
entry.text: Options flags for the MQGMO structure

entry.name: selector_mqv9plussourceprotocolhandler_help_2872
entry.text: A selector filters the messages delivered from a queue or a subscription by their properties. The selector uses the SQL92 conditional expression syntax. The selector enables the handler to filter messages delivered from a queue or a subscription.

entry.name: selector_mqv9plussourceprotocolhandler_descr_2872
entry.text: The selector that filters the messages delivered from a queue or a subscription

entry.name: parse_properties_mqv9plussourceprotocolhandler_help_2873
entry.text: Parse the properties of the incoming messages from a queue or a subscription. By default, the properties are not parsed.

entry.name: parse_properties_mqv9plussourceprotocolhandler_descr_2873
entry.text: Parse the message properties

entry.name: async_put_mqv9plussourceprotocolhandler_help_2874
entry.text: Asynchronously put a message to a queue without waiting for a response from the queue manager.

entry.name: retrieve_backout_settings_mqv9plussourceprotocolhandler_help_2881
entry.text: Controls whether to retrieve backout setting from the IBM MQ server. When enabled, retrieves the #b#Backout threshold#/b# and #b#Backout requeue queue name#/b# settings from the IBM MQ server and checks these values. On a reattempt, the IBM MQ handler uses the higher priority backout settings from the server. If the server does not contain backout settings, the handler uses any existing backout values, either empty or populated, from the local queue manager. If there are no backout settings, the backout function is disabled. When an alias queue is used, its attributes are retrieved, not those of the base queue.

entry.name: retrieve_backout_settings_mqv9plussourceprotocolhandler_descr_2881
entry.text: Controls retrieval of backout settings from the IBM MQ server

entry.name: use_qm_in_url_mqv9plussourceprotocolhandler_help_2882
entry.text: Indicates whether the var://service/URL-in variable returns the name of local queue manager or queue manager group when this configuration defines a queue manager group as the queue manager. When #b#on#/b#, the variable returns the name of the queue manager. When #b#off#/b#, the default, the variable returns the name of the queue manager group.

entry.name: use_qm_in_url_mqv9plussourceprotocolhandler_descr_2882
entry.text: Whether to use the queue manager or the queue manager group in the front-end URL

entry.name: source_as1_poller_kglobalconfig_help_2883
entry.text: The AS1 handler is a Post Office Protocol (POP) handler. The handler manages the polling of a mailbox on a mail server. The mailbox receives mail messages from external partners. The handler retrieves and deletes mail messages on each polling cycle. Each mail message that the handler retrieves results in one transaction.

entry.name: source_as1_poller_kglobalconfig_descr_2883
entry.text: AS1 Poller Handler

entry.name: delay_time_as1pollersourceprotocolhandler_help_2894
entry.text: The number of seconds to wait after the completion of one polling sequence before starting the next one. A polling sequence is the time to retrieve the messages plus the time to complete their processing. Enter a value in the range 1 - 65535. The default value is 300. #b#Note:#/b# Some mail servers restrict the number of times an account can establish a connection during a specific time period. Ensure that the configured interval complies with any restriction.

entry.name: delay_time_as1pollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_2894
entry.text: Interval between polling sequences

entry.name: ancillary_server_sqldatasource_help_2925
entry.text: Define ancillary servers for high availability or load balancing configurations. The effect of ancillary servers depends on the database vendor and other SQL data source configuration options. Ancillary servers are only supported for the following configurations: Oracle with Oracle object support enabled. Each ancillary server specifies a remote ONS daemon on Oracle RAC nodes. The host and port fields are the only required fields.

entry.name: ancillary_server_sqldatasource_descr_2925
entry.text: Ancillary servers for high availability or load balancing

entry.name: standalone_standby_control_kglobalconfig_help_2926
entry.text: The standby configuration defines the policies for the group that this interface is a member. A standby group is the collection of interfaces on different appliances in the multicast domain that share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. When at least one member of a standby group can reach the multicast domain, the virtual IP group receives the traffic. #b#Attention:#/b# Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.

entry.name: standalone_standby_control_kglobalconfig_descr_2926
entry.text: Standalone Standby Control

entry.name: admin_state_standalonestandbycontrol_help_2927
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_standalonestandbycontrol_descr_2927
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_standalonestandbycontrol_help_2928
entry.text: This property is read-only.

entry.name: summary_standalonestandbycontrol_descr_2928
entry.text: This property is read-only.

entry.name: interface_standalonestandbycontrol_help_2929
entry.text: The network interface that the standby group uses.

entry.name: interface_standalonestandbycontrol_descr_2929
entry.text: The network interface for the standby group.

entry.name: standby_group_standalonestandbycontrol_help_2930
entry.text: The number of the standby group in a multicast domain. The multicast domain is a group of interfaces that receive traffic from each other on the IP address 224.0.0.2 (the all-routers IP multicast group). If the multicast domain becomes partitioned, which is an unusual situation, a member in each partition becomes the active member to handle connections in its partition. #b#Attention:#/b# Do not use a group number that conflicts with the number of an existing standby group or any network group that uses Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP). The interfaces of a standby group are on the same network segment and share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. Interfaces in the standby group require the following configuration. Belong to the same group. Use the same primary virtual IP address. Use the same authentication, or security token.

entry.name: standby_group_standalonestandbycontrol_descr_2930
entry.text: Set the number of the standby group in the multicast domain.

entry.name: standby_virtual_ip_standalonestandbycontrol_help_2931
entry.text: The primary virtual IP address of the standby group. The active member of the standby group uses this IP address. All interfaces in the standby group must use the same virtual IP address. External clients that contact the active member of the standby group should use this IP address. #b#Attention:#/b# Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.

entry.name: standby_virtual_ip_standalonestandbycontrol_descr_2931
entry.text: Set the primary virtual IP address of standby group.

entry.name: standby_secondary_virtual_ip_standalonestandbycontrol_help_2932
entry.text: Auxiliary, or secondary, virtual IP addresses to the standby configuration. Secondary addresses follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface. Secondary addresses are on the same interface as the primary address and are enabled and disabled in coordination with the primary address. #b#Attention:#/b# Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.

entry.name: standby_secondary_virtual_ip_standalonestandbycontrol_descr_2932
entry.text: Manage secondary virtual IP addresses that follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface.

entry.name: standby_preempt_standalonestandbycontrol_help_2933
entry.text: Whether to support preemption in the standby configuration for the initially active interface. Depending on the preemption setting, the follow activity occurs when the initially active member returns to service after a failure. When preemption is enabled, the interface resumes its active role. The standby interface becomes a passive member. When preemption is disabled, the interface is a passive member. #b#Attention:#/b# Do not enable preemption.

entry.name: standby_preempt_standalonestandbycontrol_descr_2933
entry.text: Indicates whether to support preemption in the standby group.

entry.name: standby_priority_standalonestandbycontrol_help_2934
entry.text: The priority of the interface in the standby group. Enter a value in the range 0 - 255. The default value is 100. Use the default value unless one system or interface is in some way better than another one. For each standby group, there is one active member and one or more passive members. The interface with the highest priority seeks to be the active member. If multiple interfaces have the same priority, one becomes the active member.

entry.name: standby_priority_standalonestandbycontrol_descr_2934
entry.text: Set the priority of the interface in the standby group.

entry.name: standby_self_balance_standalonestandbycontrol_help_2935
entry.text: Whether to use self-balancing in the standby group. When enabled, the active member distributes connections to available members. When disabled, all connections go to the active member. The active member receives all TCP connections and processes all requests and responses. If the active member becomes unavailable, the standby member becomes the active members. The active member manages all TCP connections to virtual IP addresses. When a client initiates a new TCP connection, the active member selects a member to act as the connection endpoint. The active member tracks member capabilities to distribute traffic appropriately. The selected member completes the establishment of the connection. The active member forwards all segments of the TCP connection to the member that is acting as the connection endpoint. In a non-graceful transition, if the active member becomes unavailable, the passive member with the next highest priority becomes the active member. The active member might become unavailable because of network issues, an appliance crash, power outage, or similar cause. In a graceful transition, such as for scheduled maintenance, most connections can be preserved if the appliance that terminates the connection remains available. In practice, quiesce the active appliance to ensure that established connections complete before you start maintenance; for example, apply firmware. In some environments, the time for the takeover exceeds the client timeout value. Similarly, if the appliance timeout value is aggressive, connections can be lost because the appliance terminated the connection because of a timeout.

entry.name: standby_self_balance_standalonestandbycontrol_descr_2935
entry.text: Indicates whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.

entry.name: standby_authentication_standalonestandbycontrol_help_2936
entry.text: The authentication string, or security token in hex. The default value is 0x5841333500000000. Every member in the standby group must use the same security token.

entry.name: standby_authentication_standalonestandbycontrol_descr_2936
entry.text: Set the authentication string for the interface in the standby group.

entry.name: standby_hello_timer_standalonestandbycontrol_help_2937
entry.text: The frequency to broadcast hello messages. Set this value to at least one third the duration of the hold timer. Enter a value in the range 2 - 40. The default value is 3.

entry.name: standby_hello_timer_standalonestandbycontrol_descr_2937
entry.text: Set the frequency to broadcast hello messages.

entry.name: standby_hold_timer_standalonestandbycontrol_help_2938
entry.text: The duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover. Set this value to at least three times the interval of hello messages. Enter a value in the range 6 - 120. The default value is 10.

entry.name: standby_hold_timer_standalonestandbycontrol_descr_2938
entry.text: Set the duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover.

entry.name: standby_distribution_algorithm_standalonestandbycontrol_help_2939
entry.text: The algorithm to distribute incoming connections to available members when self-balancing is enabled.

entry.name: standby_distribution_algorithm_standalonestandbycontrol_descr_2939
entry.text: Set the distribution algorithm for incoming connections when self-balancing is enabled.

entry.name: correlation_path_apiclientidentification_help_2949
entry.text: The correlation path specifies the part of the API definition that correlates with the API action. This path is exposed in the debug data by the API Gateway for use by debugging tools. For example, for an API configuration that is retrieved from API Connect and specified in an OpenAPI (Swagger 2.0) document with IBM extensions, this path is the JSON path to the assembly policy in the IBM extensions section of the document. The path can be expressed in any form that the debugging tool can correlate to the API definition.

entry.name: correlation_path_apiclientidentification_descr_2949
entry.text: The path which correlates the API action to a specific part of the API specification.

entry.name: correlation_path_apiexecute_help_2959
entry.text: The correlation path specifies the part of the API definition that correlates with the API action. This path is exposed in the debug data by the API Gateway for use by debugging tools. For example, for an API configuration that is retrieved from API Connect and specified in an OpenAPI (Swagger 2.0) document with IBM extensions, this path is the JSON path to the assembly policy in the IBM extensions section of the document. The path can be expressed in any form that the debugging tool can correlate to the API definition.

entry.name: correlation_path_apiexecute_descr_2959
entry.text: The path which correlates the API action to a specific part of the API specification.

entry.name: output_apifinal_help_2966
entry.text: Identifies the destination context that receives variables from the API context. The API final action uses the variables in the destination context to prepare the final response to the client. The default value OUTPUT indicates to transmit the context variables to the destination context. When the value is changed or removed, the context variables are not transmitted to the destination context, and therefore, no response is returned to the client.

entry.name: output_apifinal_descr_2966
entry.text: The destination context

entry.name: debug_assemblyactionclientsecurity_help_2993
entry.text: Controls whether to enable the GatewayScript debugger to troubleshoot the following GatewayScript file or script. Troubleshoot the GatewayScript file that is called from the assembly GatewayScript action. Troubleshoot the GatewayScript file that is invoked by the GatewayScript associated XSLT extension functions or elements, such as the gatewayscript() extension function, from the assembly XSLT action. Troubleshoot the GatewayScript script that is invoked through the value or the default property in the JSON file from the assembly map action. To debug a file or script, the following conditions must be met: The file contains one or more debugger; statements at the points in your script where you want to start debugging. The GatewayScript debugger is enabled. Then you can run the debug-action command to debug.

entry.name: debug_assemblyactionclientsecurity_descr_2993
entry.text: Whether to enable GatewayScript debugger in assembly actions

entry.name: enforce_api_security_assemblyactionclientsecurity_help_2994
entry.text: The API security definitions and requirements are configured on the API definition or operation. The routed definition and operation dictate the security that the transaction must fulfill.

entry.name: enforce_api_security_assemblyactionclientsecurity_descr_2994
entry.text: Indicates whether the API security configuration from the routed API definition or operation is enforced.

entry.name: stop_on_error_assemblyactionclientsecurity_help_2995
entry.text: Whether to stop processing if client security fails. If failed, stops the assembly and return an error.

entry.name: stop_on_error_assemblyactionclientsecurity_descr_2995
entry.text: Controls whether to stop processing if client security fails.

entry.name: secret_required_assemblyactionclientsecurity_help_2996
entry.text: Whether to require the client secret. When required, the secret is compared to the registered secret on the application that is identified by the client ID.

entry.name: secret_required_assemblyactionclientsecurity_descr_2996
entry.text: Controls whether to require the client secret.

entry.name: extract_credential_method_assemblyactionclientsecurity_help_2997
entry.text: The method to extract client credentials from the request. For all methods except HTTP, use the ID name and the Secret name to specify the locations that contains the ID and the location that contain the secret. When cookie, specify which cookie. When context variable, specify which runtime context variable. When form data, specify the form data. When header, specify which header. When query parameter, specify which query parameter. For the HTTP method, use the HTTP type to specify the format of the Authorization header, which expects the basic form in the Basic base64_id:secret format.

entry.name: extract_credential_method_assemblyactionclientsecurity_descr_2997
entry.text: Specifies the method to extract client credentials from the request

entry.name: id_name_assemblyactionclientsecurity_help_2998
entry.text: The location where to find the client ID to extract. When cookie, specify which cookie. When context variable, specify which runtime context variable. When form data, specify the form data. When header, specify which header. When query parameter, specify which query parameter.

entry.name: id_name_assemblyactionclientsecurity_descr_2998
entry.text: Specifies the location where to find the client ID to extract.

entry.name: secret_name_assemblyactionclientsecurity_help_2999
entry.text: The location where to find the secret to extract. When cookie, specify which cookie. When context variable, specify which runtime context variable. When form data, specify the form data. When header, specify which header. When query parameter, specify which query parameter.

entry.name: secret_name_assemblyactionclientsecurity_descr_2999
entry.text: Specifies the location where to find the secret to extract.

entry.name: http_type_assemblyactionclientsecurity_help_3000
entry.text: The format of the Authorization header.

entry.name: http_type_assemblyactionclientsecurity_descr_3000
entry.text: Specifies the format of the Authorization header.

entry.name: client_auth_method_assemblyactionclientsecurity_help_3001
entry.text: The method to authenticate the extracted client credentials. When third-party, specify the user-registry to authenticate the extracted client credentials.

entry.name: client_auth_method_assemblyactionclientsecurity_descr_3001
entry.text: Specifies the method to authenticate the extracted client credentials

entry.name: user_registry_assemblyactionclientsecurity_help_3002
entry.text: The API registry to authenticate the extracted client credentials. The supported registries are API authentication URL and API LDAP.

entry.name: user_registry_assemblyactionclientsecurity_descr_3002
entry.text: Specifies the API registry to authenticate the extracted client credentials.

entry.name: gatewayscript_location_assemblyactiongatewayscript_help_3017
entry.text: Specifies the name and location of the GatewayScript file to process. You can specify the location with a URL or by referencing the variable in the API context with the $(variable) format, such as $(request.headers.URL) . The URL must start with local: , store: , or temporary: . For example, local:///test.js .

entry.name: gatewayscript_location_assemblyactiongatewayscript_descr_3017
entry.text: The name and location of the GatewayScript file

entry.name: input_assemblyactiongraphqlexecute_help_3025
entry.text: Specifies the name of a variable in the API context. The content of the body field of the variable is the input and is the GraphQL query to execute. The default variable name is message .

entry.name: input_assemblyactiongraphqlexecute_descr_3025
entry.text: Variable in the API context that contains the input to execute

entry.name: output_assemblyactiongraphqlexecute_help_3026
entry.text: Specifies the name of a variable in the API context. The content of the body field of the variable contains the results of the action. By default, the variable name is the same as the variable specified in the input message. Therefore, by default, the input message is overwritten by the output message.

entry.name: output_assemblyactiongraphqlexecute_descr_3026

entry.name: input_assemblyactiongraphqlintrospect_help_3035
entry.text: Specifies the name of a variable in the API context. The content of the body field of the variable is the input and is a GraphQL query for the GraphQL introspect action. The default variable name is message .

entry.name: input_assemblyactiongraphqlintrospect_descr_3035
entry.text: The name of a variable in the API context. Data represented by the variable is a GraphQL query. The GraphQL query can be used to introspect a GraphQL schema.

entry.name: output_assemblyactiongraphqlintrospect_help_3036
entry.text: Specifies the name of a variable in the API context. The content of the body field of the variable represents the GraphQL introspection result. The default variable name is the same as that of the variable specified in the Input message property. Therefore, by default, the input message for parsing is overwritten by the output message.

entry.name: output_assemblyactiongraphqlintrospect_descr_3036
entry.text: The name of a variable in the API context where the result of GraphQL introspection is stored.
