entry.name: debug_assemblyactionhtmlpage_help_3042
entry.text: Controls whether to enable the GatewayScript debugger to troubleshoot the following GatewayScript file or script. Troubleshoot the GatewayScript file that is called from the assembly GatewayScript action. Troubleshoot the GatewayScript file that is invoked by the GatewayScript associated XSLT extension functions or elements, such as the gatewayscript() extension function, from the assembly XSLT action. Troubleshoot the GatewayScript script that is invoked through the value or the default property in the JSON file from the assembly map action. To debug a file or script, the following conditions must be met: The file contains one or more debugger; statements at the points in your script where you want to start debugging. The GatewayScript debugger is enabled. Then you can run the debug-action command to debug.

entry.name: debug_assemblyactionhtmlpage_descr_3042

entry.name: correlation_path_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3049
entry.text: The correlation path specifies the part of the API definition that correlates with the assembly action. This path is exposed in the debug data by the API Gateway for use by debugging tools. For example, for an API configuration that is retrieved from API Connect and specified in an OpenAPI (Swagger 2.0) document with IBM extensions, this path is the JSON path to the assembly policy in the IBM extensions section of the document. The path can be expressed in any form that the debugging tool can correlate to the API definition.

To debug a file or script, the following conditions must be met: The file contains one or more debugger; statements at the points in your script where you want to start debugging. The GatewayScript debugger is enabled. Then you can run the debug-action command to debug.

entry.name: url_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3051
entry.text: Specifies the URL to be invoked. You can also reference a custom API property that resolves as the value. To reference an API property, use the $(api.properties.property_name) format, where property_name is the name of the property to reference. You can also use the short $(property_name) format when the assembly action does not have a property with the same name.

entry.name: websocket_upgrade_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3057
entry.text: Whether to allow WebSocket upgrade requests to the server. When allowed, the existing connection uses the WebSocket protocol. WebSocket upgrade requests require that the HTTP method is GET. When the WebSocket protocol is used, further actions are skipped. By default, WebSocket upgrade requests are not allowed.

entry.name: websocket_upgrade_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3057
entry.text: Indicate whether to allow WebSocket upgrade requests to the server.

entry.text: The message type of backend payload

entry.name: graphql_send_type_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3059
entry.text: GraphQL send type

entry.name: compression_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3060
entry.text: Controls whether to enable HTTP compression.

entry.name: compression_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3060
entry.text: Whether to enable HTTP compression.

entry.name: cache_type_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3061
entry.text: Controls how to cache documents. This property takes effect only when a response is received from the target. When it is set, the invoke action always returns the non-expired response that is previously saved in cache.

entry.name: cache_type_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3061
entry.text: How to cache documents

entry.name: ttl_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3062
entry.text: Sets the validity period in seconds for documents in the cache. The default value is 900.

entry.name: ttl_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3062
entry.text: The validity period for documents in the cache.

entry.name: cache_unsafe_response_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3063
entry.text: Caches responses to POST and PUT requests when the cache policy type is set to time to live. The response to these requests is the result of an action on the server that might change its resource state. You might want to cache responses to these requests when you know that the action (for example: HTTP POST) will not change the server state.

entry.name: cache_unsafe_response_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3063
entry.text: Cache response to POST and PUT requests

entry.name: cache_key_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3064
entry.text: The string to use as a key for the cache. If omitted, the entire URL string is used as the key.

entry.name: cache_key_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3064
entry.text: The string to use as a key for the cache.

entry.name: follow_redirects_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3065
entry.text: Some protocols generate redirects as part of the protocol; for example, an HTTP 304 response code. When enabled, the invoke action attempts to transparently resolve redirects.

entry.name: follow_redirects_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3065
entry.text: Whether to follow the redirects.

entry.name: use_http_10_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3066
entry.text: Controls whether to restrict transactions to HTTP/1.0. Use HTTP Version instead.

entry.name: use_http_10_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3066
entry.text: Restrict to HTTP/1.0

entry.name: http_version_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3067
entry.text: Select the HTTP version to use on the server-side connection. The default value is HTTP/1.1.

entry.name: http_version_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3067
entry.text: Server-side HTTP version

entry.name: http2_required_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3068
entry.text: Select whether an HTTP/2 connection is required when connecting to the server. Only applicable when the HTTP version to the server is set to HTTP/2 and the connection uses TLS. The default value is off.

entry.name: http2_required_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3068
entry.text: Require HTTP/2 connection

entry.name: chunked_uploads_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3069
entry.text: Controls the ability to send chunked-encoded documents to the target server. When the device employs the HTTP/1.1 protocol, the body of the document can be delimited by either Content-Length or chunked encoding. While all servers understand how to interpret Content-Length , many applications fail to understand chunked encoding. For this reason, Content-Length is the standard method used. However, the use of Content-Length interferes with the ability of the device to fully stream. To stream full documents to the target server, set this property to on. However, the target server must be RFC 2616 compatible. Unlike all other HTTP/1.1 features that can be negotiated down at run time, you must know beforehand that the target server is RFC 2616 compatible. The default value is on.

entry.name: chunked_uploads_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3069
entry.text: Whether to enable uploading of HTTP/1.1 chunked-encoded documents

entry.name: persistent_connection_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3070
entry.text: Specifies whether to enable HTTP persistent connections.

entry.name: persistent_connection_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3070
entry.text: Whether to enable HTTP persistent connections to the invoke target

entry.name: stop_on_error_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3071

entry.name: stop_on_error_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3071
entry.text: Whether the flow stops when a particular type of error occurs

entry.name: error_types_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3072
entry.text: Specifies the type of error on which the flow stops. Use this property when the stop on error is enabled.

entry.name: error_types_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3072
entry.text: The type of error on which the flow stops

entry.name: output_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3073
entry.text: The name of a variable to store the invoke action output

entry.name: decode_request_params_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3074

entry.name: decode_request_params_assemblyactioninvoke_descr_3074

entry.name: encode_plus_char_assemblyactioninvoke_help_3075

entry.name: input_assemblyactionjson2xml_help_3088
entry.text: Specifies the name of a variable in the API context that contains the input message to convert. The content of the body field is the input. The default variable is message , so the input to convert is message.body .

entry.name: input_assemblyactionjson2xml_descr_3088
entry.text: The name of a variable where the JSON input is stored.

entry.name: output_assemblyactionjson2xml_help_3089
entry.text: Specifies the name of a variable in the API context to store the conversion results. The conversion results are written to the body field of the specified variable. The output variable cannot be a read-only variable. When you want the converted output to be returned to the client, you must use message as the output variable. When you do not specify an output variable, the variable name matches the input variable name. For example, if the input variable is message , the output variable is also message . Therefore, if the input variable is foo , the output variable is also foo . When you use an output variable other than message , the content is converted but not returned to the client.

entry.name: output_assemblyactionjson2xml_descr_3089
entry.text: The name of a variable where the result of the conversion is stored.

entry.name: output_root_assemblyactionjson2xml_help_3091
entry.text: Controls whether the action allows always to output the root element in the resulting XML. When this property is enabled, the conversion action always outputs the root element in the resulting XML.

entry.name: output_root_assemblyactionjson2xml_descr_3091
entry.text: Whether always to output the root element in the resulting XML document

entry.name: unnamed_element_assemblyactionjson2xml_descr_3092
entry.text: The name of an XML element

entry.name: jws_jwk_assemblyactionjwtgenerate_help_3106

entry.text: The context variable that contains the JWK to sign the JWT

entry.name: jws_alg_assemblyactionjwtgenerate_help_3107
entry.text: The cryptographic algorithm to use. Use one of the following values. HS256 - HMAC using SHA-256 HS384 - HMAC using SHA-384 HS512 - HMAC using SHA-512 RS256 - RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-256 RS384 - RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA 384 RS512 - RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-512 ES256 - ECDSA using P-256 and SHA-256 ES384 - ECDSA using P-384 and SHA-384 ES512 - ECDSA using P-521 and SHA-512 none - Do not sign the JWT, which is unsecured and provides no integrity protection but can be used for a nest JWT An inline parameter to read at runtime

entry.name: jws_alg_assemblyactionjwtgenerate_descr_3107
entry.text: The cryptographic algorithm to use

entry.name: jws_crypto_assemblyactionjwtgenerate_help_3108
entry.text: Specifies the cryptographic object (a shared secret key or certificate) to use to sign the JWT.

entry.name: jws_crypto_assemblyactionjwtgenerate_descr_3108
entry.text: The cryptographic object to sign the JWT

entry.name: jwe_enc_assemblyactionjwtgenerate_help_3109
entry.text: The encryption algorithm to use. Use one of the following values. A128CBC-HS256 - AES_128_CBC_HMAC_SHA_256 authenticated encryption algorithm A192CBC-HS384 - AES_192_CBC_HMAC_SHA_384 authenticated encryption algorithm A256CBC-HS512 - AES_256_CBC_HMAC_SHA_512 authenticated encryption algorithm A128GCM - AES GCM using 128-bit key A192GCM - AES GCM using 192-bit key A256GCM - AES GCM using 256-bit key An inline parameter to read at runtime

entry.name: jwe_enc_assemblyactionjwtgenerate_descr_3109
entry.text: The encryption algorithm to use

entry.name: jwe_jwk_assemblyactionjwtgenerate_help_3110
entry.text: Specifies the context variable that contains the JWK to use to encrypt the JWT.

entry.name: jwe_jwk_assemblyactionjwtgenerate_descr_3110
entry.text: The context variable that contains the JWK to encrypt the JWT

entry.name: jwe_alg_assemblyactionjwtgenerate_help_3111
entry.text: The key encryption algorithm to use. Use one of the following values. RSA1_5 - RSAES-PKCS1-V1_5 RSA-OAEP - RSAES OAEP using default parameters RSA-OAEP-256 - RSAES OAEP using SHA-256 and MGF1 with SHA-256 A128KW - AES Key Wrap with default initial value using 128 bit key A192KW - AES Key Wrap with default initial value using 192 bit key A256KW - AES Key Wrap with default initial value using 256 bit key dir - Direct use of a shared symmetric key as the CEK An inline parameter to read at runtime

entry.name: jwe_alg_assemblyactionjwtgenerate_descr_3111
entry.text: The key encryption algorithm to use

entry.name: jwe_crypto_assemblyactionjwtgenerate_help_3112
entry.text: Specifies the cryptographic object (a shared secret key or certificate) to use to encrypt the JWT.

entry.name: jwe_crypto_assemblyactionjwtgenerate_descr_3112
entry.text: The cryptographic object to encrypt the JWT

entry.name: assembly_jwt_validate_kglobalconfig_help_3113
entry.text: The validate JSON Web Token (JWT) action specifies credentials and methods to validate a JWT in the request. The following guidelines apply. All claims that are specified in the validate JWT action are validated. If any specified claim fails, the JWT validation fails. You can use a cryptographic object or a JWK to decrypt or verify the JWT. When both are specified, the cryptographic object is used. If the original message is signed with a shared secret key, the cryptographic object that is specified must also be a shared secret key. If the original message is signed with a private key, the cryptographic object that is specified must be a crypto certificate (public certificate). If a JWK header parameter is included in the header of the JWT, the parameter must match the cryptographic object or JWK that is specified in the action. Otherwise, the JWT validation fails.

entry.name: assembly_jwt_validate_kglobalconfig_descr_3113
entry.text: Assembly Validate JWT Action

entry.text: Whether to enable GatewayScript debugger in assembly actions

entry.name: jwt_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_help_3119
entry.text: Specifies the context variable that contains the JWT to be validated. The default value is request.headers.authorization . The format of the authorization header must be Authorization: Bearer jwt-token where jwt-token indicates the encoded JWT.

entry.name: jwt_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_descr_3119
entry.text: The context variable that contains the JSON Web Token (JWT) to be validated

entry.name: output_claims_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_help_3120
entry.text: Specifies a context variable to store all the claims that the JWT contains when the validation of the JWT succeeds. The default value is decoded.claims .

entry.name: output_claims_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_descr_3120
entry.text: The context variable to store all the claims that the JWT contains

entry.name: iss_claim_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_help_3121
entry.text: Specifies the optional PCRE to use to validate the issuer "iss" claim. When specified, the issuer claim in the JWT is validated. If the issuer claim fails, the JWT validation fails. The maximum length of the value is 256 characters.

entry.name: iss_claim_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_descr_3121
entry.text: PCRE to use to validate the issuer claim

entry.name: aud_claim_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_help_3122
entry.text: Specifies the optional PCRE to use to validate the audience "aud" claim. When specified, the audience claim in the JWT is validated. If the audience claim fails, the JWT validation fails. The maximum length of the value is 256 characters.

entry.name: aud_claim_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_descr_3122
entry.text: PCRE to use to validate the audience claim

entry.name: jwe_crypto_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_help_3123
entry.text: Specifies the cryptographic object (a shared secret key or certificate) to use to decrypt the JWT.

entry.name: jwe_crypto_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_descr_3123
entry.text: The cryptographic object to decrypt the JWT

entry.name: jwe_jwk_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_help_3124
entry.text: Specifies the context variable that contains the JWK to use to decrypt the JWT.

entry.name: jwe_jwk_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_descr_3124
entry.text: The context variable that contains the JWK to decrypt the JWT

entry.name: jws_crypto_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_help_3125
entry.text: Specifies the cryptographic object (a shared secret key or certificate) to use to verify the JWT.

entry.name: jws_crypto_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_descr_3125
entry.text: The cryptographic object to verify the JWT

entry.name: jws_jwk_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_help_3126
entry.text: Specifies the context variable that contains the JWK to use to verify the JWT.

entry.name: jws_jwk_assemblyactionjwtvalidate_descr_3126
entry.text: The context variable that contains the JWK to verify the JWT

entry.name: assembly_log_kglobalconfig_help_3127
entry.text: An assembly log action writes transaction data to the API context to send to the analytics server. The API activity logging settings specified in the API definition determine the type of transaction data that is gathered. This action is not supported in IBM Cloud. Any assembly that includes it will fail.

entry.name: assembly_log_kglobalconfig_descr_3127
entry.text: Assembly Log Action

entry.name: admin_state_assemblyactionlog_help_3128
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_assemblyactionlog_descr_3128
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_assemblyactionlog_descr_3129
entry.text: Brief summary for Assembly action.

entry.name: title_assemblyactionlog_descr_3130
entry.text: The title for Assembly action.

entry.name: correlation_path_assemblyactionlog_help_3131
entry.text: The correlation path specifies the part of the API definition that correlates with the assembly action. This path is exposed in the debug data by the API Gateway for use by debugging tools. For example, for an API configuration that is retrieved from API Connect and specified in an OpenAPI (Swagger 2.0) document with IBM extensions, this path is the JSON path to the assembly policy in the IBM extensions section of the document. The path can be expressed in any form that the debugging tool can correlate to the API definition.

entry.name: correlation_path_assemblyactionlog_descr_3131
entry.text: The path which correlates the assembly action to a specific part of the API specification.

entry.name: debug_assemblyactionlog_help_3132
entry.text: Controls whether to enable the GatewayScript debugger to troubleshoot the following GatewayScript file or script. Troubleshoot the GatewayScript file that is called from the assembly GatewayScript action. Troubleshoot the GatewayScript file that is invoked by the GatewayScript associated XSLT extension functions or elements, such as the gatewayscript() extension function, from the assembly XSLT action. Troubleshoot the GatewayScript script that is invoked through the value or the default property in the JSON file from the assembly map action. To debug a file or script, the following conditions must be met: The file contains one or more debugger; statements at the points in your script where you want to start debugging. The GatewayScript debugger is enabled. Then you can run the debug-action command to debug.

entry.name: debug_assemblyactionlog_descr_3132
entry.text: Whether to enable GatewayScript debugger in assembly actions

entry.name: mode_assemblyactionlog_help_3133
entry.text: Specifies the mode to use for the assembly log action. Analytics data must strictly conform to the format required by your analytics server. If you modify the format, you must use gather only mode. When you use the IBM API Connect analytics server without offloading data to a third-party log server, the format is correct. If you redact the input and output payloads, ensure that you do not modify the format. When you offload data to a third-party analytics server, you can redact any aspect of the event data. When you use API Connect analytics, you can redact only the input and output payloads.

entry.name: mode_assemblyactionlog_descr_3133
entry.text: Mode to use for the assembly log action

entry.name: log_level_assemblyactionlog_help_3134
entry.text: Specifies the type of content to log. The value can be one of none, activity, header, payload, default, or an inline parameter in the format $(value) to retrieve a value from the API context.

entry.name: log_level_assemblyactionlog_descr_3134
entry.text: Type of content to log

entry.name: assembly_map_kglobalconfig_help_3135
entry.text: A map action applies data transformations to the assembly flow according to a specified map file. The map file is a JSON file that defines all mapping operations. Prepare a valid map file as follows: If you do not get the map file automatically, you need to create the map file manually. See the reference information about map file examples on IBM API Connect Knowledge center. Make sure that the map file is JSON formatted. If the map file is YAML formatted, convert it to JSON format. Import the JSON file to the DataPower Gateway. The file must be in the local:/// directory, the temporary:/// directory, or one of their subdirectories.

entry.name: assembly_map_kglobalconfig_descr_3135
entry.text: Assembly Map Action

entry.name: parse_settings_reference_assemblyactionparse_help_3156
entry.text: A parse settings configuration defines the constraints on the documents to parse. You can configure the constraints by specifying a URL reference from which to retrieve the constraints definition. You can also specify a literal configuration string in XML management interface or REST management interface format that contains the constraints definition. You can also select a parse settings configuration from the list in Object reference to retrieve constraints definition. Precedence rules apply when the constraint for the same aspect of an input document is configured with more than one method.

entry.name: parse_settings_reference_assemblyactionparse_descr_3156
entry.text: Specifies the parse settings configuration for the parse action

entry.name: input_assemblyactionparse_help_3157
entry.text: Specifies the name of a variable in the API context. The content of the body field of the variable is the input to the parse action. The default variable name is message .

entry.name: input_assemblyactionparse_descr_3157
entry.text: The name of a variable in the API context. Data represented by the variable can be parsed.

entry.name: warn_on_empty_input_assemblyactionparse_help_3158
entry.text: Specifies whether to generate a warning-level log message instead of an error when the payload of the input message is empty.

entry.name: warn_on_empty_input_assemblyactionparse_descr_3158
entry.text: Whether to generate a warning-level log message instead of an error when the payload of the input message is empty.

entry.name: use_content_type_assemblyactionparse_help_3159
entry.text: Specifies whether to attempt a parse with the specified content-type. This is only applicable if the expected content-type is either json or xml. With this option enabled, a parse action will result in failure if content-type does not match the parse-settings (i.e Content-type:application/json and parse-settings is configured for xml). If the parse-setting is configured to detect input content, it will be forced to the specified content-type.

entry.name: use_content_type_assemblyactionparse_descr_3159
entry.text: Whether to attempt a parse with the specified content-type

entry.name: output_assemblyactionparse_help_3160
entry.text: Specifies the name of a variable in the API context. The content of the body field of the variable represents the parse result. The parse metrics of the parsed document can be stored in different parts of the message. The default variable name is the same as that of the variable specified in the Input message property. Therefore, by default, the input message for parsing is overwritten by the output message.

entry.name: output_assemblyactionparse_descr_3160
entry.text: The name of a variable in the API context where the result of parsed data is stored.

entry.text: The title for Assembly action.

entry.name: correlation_path_assemblyactionvalidate_help_3226
entry.text: The correlation path specifies the part of the API definition that correlates with the assembly action. This path is exposed in the debug data by the API Gateway for use by debugging tools. For example, for an API configuration that is retrieved from API Connect and specified in an OpenAPI (Swagger 2.0) document with IBM extensions, this path is the JSON path to the assembly policy in the IBM extensions section of the document. The path can be expressed in any form that the debugging tool can correlate to the API definition.

entry.name: correlation_path_assemblyactionvalidate_descr_3226
entry.text: The path which correlates the assembly action to a specific part of the API specification.

entry.name: debug_assemblyactionvalidate_help_3227
entry.text: Controls whether to enable the GatewayScript debugger to troubleshoot the following GatewayScript file or script. Troubleshoot the GatewayScript file that is called from the assembly GatewayScript action. Troubleshoot the GatewayScript file that is invoked by the GatewayScript associated XSLT extension functions or elements, such as the gatewayscript() extension function, from the assembly XSLT action. Troubleshoot the GatewayScript script that is invoked through the value or the default property in the JSON file from the assembly map action. To debug a file or script, the following conditions must be met: The file contains one or more debugger; statements at the points in your script where you want to start debugging. The GatewayScript debugger is enabled. Then you can run the debug-action command to debug.

entry.name: debug_assemblyactionvalidate_descr_3227
entry.text: Whether to enable GatewayScript debugger in assembly actions

entry.text: The type of schema to validate against.

entry.name: validate_against_assemblyactionvalidate_descr_3228
entry.text: How the schema is specified.

entry.name: error_policy_assemblyactionvalidate_help_3229
entry.text: The behavior of the assembly validate action when the GraphQL backend server returns an error.

entry.name: error_policy_assemblyactionvalidate_descr_3229
entry.text: GraphQL error policy

entry.name: schema_assemblyactionvalidate_help_3230
entry.text: The schema object to validate the message.

entry.name: schema_assemblyactionvalidate_descr_3230
entry.text: The schema object to validate the message.

entry.name: input_assemblyactionvalidate_help_3231
entry.text: The name of a variable in the API context. The content of the body field of the variable is the input to validate. The default variable name is message .

entry.name: input_assemblyactionvalidate_descr_3231
entry.text: The name of a variable in the API context. Data represented by the variable can be validated.

entry.name: output_assemblyactionvalidate_help_3232
entry.text: The name of a variable in the API context. If the validation passes, the body field of the output variable stores the output of the assembly validate action. If the schema to validate is a JSON schema, the validation also adds any default values that are missing from the payload. If an output variable is not specified, the results of the validation are not stored. By default, no output variable is specified. If the validation fails, no output is stored.

entry.name: output_assemblyactionvalidate_descr_3232
entry.text: The name of a variable in the API context where the result of validation data, with defaults added, is stored.

entry.name: definition_assemblyactionvalidate_help_3233
entry.text: The path to a schema in the API definition. Use the format #/definitions/mySchema or mySchema to specify a previously defined schema to be used for validation.

entry.name: definition_assemblyactionvalidate_descr_3233
entry.text: The path to a schema in the API definition.

entry.text: Specifies the compile settings reference that defines the compile options for the assembly validate action.

entry.name: compile_settings_validate_assemblyactionvalidate_descr_3234
entry.text: The compiler option for the assembly validate action.

You can also use the short $(property_name) format when the assembly action does not have a property with the same name.

entry.name: conversion_format_assemblyactionxml2json_help_3269
entry.text: Indicates the supported conversion type that determines the target format of the JSON output. The default setting is badgerfish .

entry.name: conversion_format_assemblyactionxml2json_descr_3269
entry.text: The conversion type for converting XML input to JSON output

entry.name: input_assemblyactionxml2json_help_3270
entry.text: Specifies the name of a variable in the API context that contains the input message to convert. The content of the body field is the input. The default variable is message , so the input to convert is message.body .

entry.name: input_assemblyactionxml2json_descr_3270
entry.text: The name of a variable where the XML input is stored.

entry.name: output_assemblyactionxml2json_help_3271
entry.text: Specifies the name of a variable in the API context to store the conversion results. The conversion results are written to the body field of the specified variable. The output variable cannot be a read-only variable. When you want the converted output to be returned to the client, you must use message as the output variable. When you do not specify an output variable, the variable name matches the input variable name. For example, if the input variable is message , the output variable is also message . Therefore, if the input variable is foo , the output variable is also foo . When you use an output variable other than message , the content is converted but not returned to the client.

entry.name: output_assemblyactionxml2json_descr_3271
entry.text: The name of a variable where the result of the conversion is stored.

entry.name: payload_assemblyactionxslt_help_3278
entry.text: Indicates whether to use the current payload as the XSLT input. When enabled, the XSLT input document uses the current payload. When not enabled, there is no input.

entry.name: serialize_output_assemblyactionxslt_help_3280
entry.text: Specifies whether to serialize the XSLT output tree into binary data after the transformation. The serialized output is not accessible as XML unless it is re-parsed. To access the output as XML after serialization, the API rule must contain an assembly parse action after the XSLT action.

entry.name: assembly_throw_kglobalconfig_help_3282
entry.text: You can customize an error in the throw action. When the throw action is triggered, the custom error is thrown. After the throw action is triggered, the API Gateway does not run subsequent assembly actions and the current assembly rule is ended. The thrown error, including the error identifier and text for the error message, is saved in the API context.

entry.name: assembly_throw_kglobalconfig_descr_3282
entry.text: Assembly Throw Action

entry.name: admin_state_assemblyactionthrow_help_3283
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_assemblyactionthrow_descr_3284
entry.text: Brief summary for Assembly action.

entry.name: title_assemblyactionthrow_descr_3285
entry.text: The title for Assembly action.

entry.name: correlation_path_assemblyactionthrow_help_3286
entry.text: The correlation path specifies the part of the API definition that correlates with the assembly action. This path is exposed in the debug data by the API Gateway for use by debugging tools. For example, for an API configuration that is retrieved from API Connect and specified in an OpenAPI (Swagger 2.0) document with IBM extensions, this path is the JSON path to the assembly policy in the IBM extensions section of the document. The path can be expressed in any form that the debugging tool can correlate to the API definition.

entry.name: correlation_path_assemblyactionthrow_descr_3286
entry.text: The path which correlates the assembly action to a specific part of the API specification.

entry.name: debug_assemblyactionthrow_help_3287
entry.text: Controls whether to enable the GatewayScript debugger to troubleshoot the following GatewayScript file or script. Troubleshoot the GatewayScript file that is called from the assembly GatewayScript action. Troubleshoot the GatewayScript file that is invoked by the GatewayScript associated XSLT extension functions or elements, such as the gatewayscript() extension function, from the assembly XSLT action. Troubleshoot the GatewayScript script that is invoked through the value or the default property in the JSON file from the assembly map action. To debug a file or script, the following conditions must be met: The file contains one or more debugger; statements at the points in your script where you want to start debugging. The GatewayScript debugger is enabled. Then you can run the debug-action command to debug.

entry.name: debug_assemblyactionthrow_descr_3287
entry.text: Whether to enable GatewayScript debugger in assembly actions

entry.name: error_id_assemblyactionthrow_help_3288
entry.text: Specifies the identifier of the thrown error. The identifier contains a maximum of 64 characters. The following characters are valid: a - z A - Z 0 - 9 Underscore(_) Dash(-) You can also reference a custom API property that resolves as the value. To reference an API property, use the $(api.properties.property_name) format, where property_name is the name of the property to reference. You can also use the short form $(property_name) when the assembly action does not have a property with the same name.

entry.name: error_id_assemblyactionthrow_descr_3288
entry.text: The identifier of the error

entry.name: error_text_assemblyactionthrow_help_3289
entry.text: Specifies the text for the error message. You can also reference a custom API property that resolves as the value. To reference an API property, use the $(api.properties.property_name) format, where property_name is the name of the property to reference. You can also use the short form $(property_name) when the assembly action does not have a property with the same name.

entry.name: error_text_assemblyactionthrow_descr_3289
entry.text: The text for the error message

entry.name: error_status_code_assemblyactionthrow_help_3290
entry.text: Specifies the HTTP status for the error. You can also reference a variable in the API context with the $(variable) format, such as $(message.status.code) .

entry.name: error_status_code_assemblyactionthrow_descr_3290
entry.text: The HTTP status code to return to the client for the error

entry.name: error_status_reason_assemblyactionthrow_help_3291
entry.text: Specifies the HTTP reason phrase for the error. You can also reference a variable in the API context with the $(variable) format, such as $(message.status.reason) .

entry.name: error_status_reason_assemblyactionthrow_descr_3291
entry.text: The HTTP reason phrase to return to the client for the error

entry.name: charset_transparency_stylepolicyaction_help_3312
entry.text: Control whether the output from the convert action retains the input encoding or is converted to ISO 8859-1. An encoding is also known as a character set. For illustrative purposes, assume UTF-8 is the input encoding. When enabled and the input encoding is UTF-8, the output is UTF-8. When disabled and the input encoding is UTF-8, the output is ISO 8859-1. This behavior is the default behavior.

entry.name: tenant_kglobalconfig_help_3327
entry.text: Modify the connection details for a tenant. Each tenant and the landlord have different management interfaces and a different quota enforcement server. When you define the addresses for tenant management interfaces, use an explicit IP address to isolate tenant management traffic from landlord management traffic. Tenant services that use the IP address values of 0.0.0.0 or :: can cause port contention on the landlord. When you define listening ports for tenant management interfaces and for the quota enforcement server, ensure that they are unique across the tenants and the landlord.

entry.text: Tenant

entry.name: trv_route_kglobalconfig_help_3347
entry.text: The Route object configures the transmission characteristics for outbound TIBCO RV messages. Each route object creates a logical outbound stream. A TIBCO RV policy can define multiple routes on which to send outbound messages. The routes also use Message Selection rules to filter outbound messages. Once a message is selected for routing, you configure a Subject Name that describes where to route the message.

entry.name: trv_route_kglobalconfig_descr_3347
entry.text: TIBCO RV Route

entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: protocol_trvroute_help_3350
entry.text: To configure the transmit protocol for this route, choose one of the following:

entry.name: protocol_trvroute_descr_3350
entry.text: Transmit protocol for route

entry.name: instance_trvroute_help_3351
entry.text: Hidden instance property.

entry.name: instance_trvroute_descr_3351
entry.text: LLM Instance

entry.name: selection_trvroute_help_3352
entry.text: A SQL-92 expression. Use this field to filter outbound messages. If the SQL-92 expression evaluates to TRUE, the message is selected and routed. If it evaluates to FALSE or UNKNOWN, it is not routed. The default is TRUE. For example, use the following syntax to select all outbound messages whose prop1 property begins with the letter a: prop1 like 'a%%' You can build expressions using message properties or parsed fields that are part of the message content. For example, specifying: xml:Symbol@name will give you the name attribute on the first Symbol element in the message. If this element does not exist, the result is UNKNOWN and the message is not selected.

entry.name: selection_trvroute_descr_3352
entry.text: Message Selection

entry.name: subject_trvroute_help_3353
entry.text: A string that defines a logical channel of communication between transmitters and receivers. You configure what subject a route transmit on by specifying a Subject Name. Transmitters publish messages on a subject. The structure of a subject name is a string of characters which are divided into elements by the dot character. A valid subject name may not be more than 196 characters minus the number of elements. A single element can not be longer than 127 characters. Wildcard characters are acceptable character. The asterisk is a wildcard character that matches any one element. The greater-than character is a wild card character that matches all the elements remaining to the right. Examples of valid subject names: finance.stock.yield finance.stock.* finance.>

entry.name: subject_trvroute_descr_3353
entry.text: Subject

entry.name: search_subject_trvroute_help_3354
entry.text: Specifies a prearranged subject name that this route will use to establishing and communicate with a point-to-point receiver.

entry.name: search_subject_trvroute_descr_3354
entry.text: Search Subject

entry.name: search_timeout_trvroute_help_3355
entry.text: Specifies the number of milliseconds that the system will wait for a subject search reply from a point-to-point receiver before a new subject search request is sent. Default value is 3000 milliseconds. The minimum value of 0 indicates that requests should not be resent. The maximum value is 300000 milliseconds.

entry.name: search_timeout_trvroute_descr_3355
entry.text: Search Timeout

entry.name: propagate_searches_trvroute_help_3356
entry.text: Specifies whether to propagate point-to-point subject searches across the multiprotocol gateway. If at least one policy referencing this route is configured for the TIBCO RV Point-to-point (TPP) protocol and the back-end protocol is TIBCO RV Local Messaging (TLM) with at least one TPP route, then this property must be set to "on". If at least one policy referencing this route is configured for the TIBCO RV Point-to-point (TPP) protocol and the back-end protocol is not TLM, then this property must be set to "off". Otherwise, this property has no effect.

entry.name: propagate_searches_trvroute_descr_3356
entry.text: Propagate Subject Searches

entry.name: properties_trvroute_help_3357

entry.name: properties_trvroute_descr_3357
entry.text: Use Properties

entry.name: copy_properties_trvroute_help_3358
entry.text: Use this toggle to copy input properties to output properties for transmitted messages. When disabled, input properties are removed before transmitting.

entry.name: copy_properties_trvroute_descr_3358
entry.text: Copy Message Properties

entry.name: transport_trvroute_help_3359
entry.text: The TIBCO RV transport configuration properties.

entry.name: transport_trvroute_descr_3359
entry.text: Transport

entry.name: map_properties_trvroute_help_3360
entry.text: Specifies a set of rules to add properties to outbound messages that are transmitted through this route. Before creating mapping rules, enable the Use Properties toggle. Enable the Copy Message Properties toggle to ensure that properties are copied from the input message and are available for use with a map. Copying properties is not required if only using the map to create new properties. Mapping rules provide a set of actions for modifying certain properties. Each rule consists of a property name or field that you can specify, such as llm:Length, followed by a new value, which can be a SQL92 expression to be evaluated. If the SQL92 expression is blank or resolves to unknown, no assignment is done, and the specified property is removed from the output. Otherwise, expressions used in mapping rules resolve to integers, strings, or floating points. Mapping rules for a message execute in sequential order. Output properties can reside in the unspecified or llm namespaces. Variables defined in the var namespace are never part of the output message. Properties in the fix and xml namespaces cannot be mapped, although fields in these namespaces can be used in creating a property value. You can modify or suppress TurboFlow values using a map properties rule. After configuring a field, such as llm:Length, all future references to that field will use its modified value. Create property mappings using the following fields or properties: llm:Label Sets the TurboFlow numeric label. llm:Length Sets the length of the message in bytes. llm:Text Replaces the text of the message with the expression value. llm:Bitmap Sets the TurboFlow bitmap. llm:Byte[#] Modifies the specified byte, where # is a number from 0 to the length of the message. The expression value is interpreted as an integer. var:integer Sets a local variable, a number between 0 and 9. Use to save a result in a temporary location. The saved value can be accessed in subsequent mappings within the same map. Local variables are never part of the message. var:name Sets a string used to create a variable that is global to the domain. Use to save a result in a temporary location. The saved value can be accessed in subsequent mappings across all maps in the domain. Global variables are never part of the message. property The name of a property in the unspecified property namespace (not llm or var) of an input message. Examples (if fred=3): fred fred+3 result: 6 fred fred#3 result: 33 fred 'fred'#3 result: fred3 fred fred+4.0 result: 7 fred "'fred' # fred" result: fred3

entry.name: map_properties_trvroute_descr_3360
entry.text: Map Properties

entry.name: certified_message_delivery_trvroute_help_3361
entry.text: Specifies whether to expect confirmation from the message recipient that its messages have been received from the sender and that the messages are received in the order in which they were sent.

entry.name: certified_message_delivery_trvroute_descr_3361
entry.text: Certified Message Delivery

entry.name: request_reply_trvroute_help_3362
entry.text: Use this toggle to allow a route to receive a reply after it has sent the request. Default value is off. When the reply is received, it will be forwarded back to the original sender. This applies if the message received contains a reply subject. One reply is sent per request. A policy configured to send to multiple routes may only have one route that is configured with request/reply enabled.

entry.name: request_reply_trvroute_descr_3362
entry.text: Enable request/reply flows

entry.name: reply_timeout_trvroute_help_3364
entry.text: Specifies an interval of time the route will wait for a reply. Minimum value is 1000. Maximum value is 800000.

entry.name: reply_timeout_trvroute_descr_3364
entry.text: Reply Timout

entry.name: reply_map_properties_trvroute_help_3365
entry.text: Specifies a set of rules to manipulate fields of a reply message that is received by this route.

entry.name: reply_map_properties_trvroute_descr_3365
entry.text: Map Properties for Reply Messages

entry.name: service_parameter_trvroute_help_3366
entry.text: The port number used to send messges on the transport.

entry.name: service_parameter_trvroute_descr_3366
entry.text: Service Parameter

entry.name: network_interface_trvroute_help_3367
entry.text: The IP address or host-alias name used to send messages for this route.

entry.name: network_interface_trvroute_descr_3367
entry.text: Network Interface

entry.name: multicast_group_trvroute_help_3368
entry.text: abc

entry.name: multicast_group_trvroute_descr_3368
entry.text: Network Multicast Groups

entry.name: network_send_address_trvroute_help_3369
entry.text: The multicast address used to send multicast data. You can not use a host name or network name. If a multicast address is not specified, then the default is the first value specified for the multicast group.

entry.name: network_send_address_trvroute_descr_3369
entry.text: Network Send Address

entry.name: daemon_parameter_trvroute_help_3370
entry.text: A daemon can be specified to reside on either the local or a remote host. For a local daemon, only the port is specified (default 7500). For a remote daemon, both a host name and port number are specified.

entry.name: daemon_parameter_trvroute_descr_3370
entry.text: Daemon Parameter

entry.name: use_ledger_file_trvroute_help_3371
entry.text: Enables use of ledger file. The default is off, which means the ledger is stored in memory.

entry.name: use_ledger_file_trvroute_descr_3371
entry.text: Use Ledger File

entry.name: sync_ledger_trvroute_help_3373
entry.text: Specifies whether ledger file updates are synchronized to the disk before an operation can continue. Default is off.

entry.name: sync_ledger_trvroute_descr_3373
entry.text: Sync ledger file to disk

entry.name: cm_name_trvroute_help_3374
entry.text: The name for the certified message delivery transport. This name is reusable. If the transport also uses a file based ledger, then Certified Message Delivery can be resumed in the case where the transport is destroyed and reestablished. If Certified Message Delivery Name is not specified, then Certified Message Delivery transports cannot be reused once they are destroyed. Reusable names must not contain the following: Reserved elements such as _INBOX, _RV, _LOCAL More than four elements More than fifty characters in length Leading character of an underscore ('_') Wildcard characters Null element The same name as an existing cm-name or relay agent on the network

entry.name: cm_name_trvroute_descr_3374
entry.text: Certified Message Delivery Name

entry.name: pre_register_listener_trvroute_help_3375
entry.text: Specifies the reusable name in anticipation of a Certified Message Deliver request. The sending Certified Message transport will store outbound messages in its ledger prior to a Certified Message Delivery request. This property allows Certified Message transports which have a request-old specified to receive all messages transmitted prior to a Certified Message agreement. Reusable names must not contain the following: Reserved elements such as _INBOX, _RV, _LOCAL More than four elements More than fifty characters in length Leading character of an underscore ('_') Wildcard characters Null element The same name as an existing cm-name on the network

entry.name: pre_register_listener_trvroute_descr_3375
entry.text: Pre-register Listener

entry.name: disallow_listener_trvroute_help_3376
entry.text: Disallows the specified reusable name to register a Certified Message Delivery agreement between a listener and the TIBCO RV Route. Reusable names must not contain the following: Reserved elements such as _INBOX, _RV, _LOCAL More than four elements More than fifty characters in length Leading character of an underscore ('_') Wildcard characters Null element

entry.name: disallow_listener_trvroute_descr_3376
entry.text: Disallow Listener

entry.name: message_time_limit_trvroute_help_3377
entry.text: Specifies in seconds the interval of time allowed to certify message delivery. After the time specified expires, certified delivery for the message is not performed. When setting the message time limit consider network latencies, retransmission of messages, and the restarting of correspondent application and systems.

entry.name: message_time_limit_trvroute_descr_3377
entry.text: Message Time Limit

entry.name: ledger_file_volume_type_trvroute_help_3378
entry.text: The type of storage volume the ledger file will be stored on. The default is RAID.

entry.name: ledger_file_volume_type_trvroute_descr_3378
entry.text: Ledger File Volume Type

entry.name: ledger_file_volume_trvroute_help_3379
entry.text: Specifies the name of the volume where the ledger file is stored. The default volume name is the default RAID volume.

entry.name: ledger_file_volume_trvroute_descr_3379
entry.text: Ledger File Volume

entry.name: trv_transport_kglobalconfig_help_3380
entry.text: A TIBCO RV Transport object is a container for TIBCO RV transport configuration properties.

entry.name: trv_transport_kglobalconfig_descr_3380
entry.text: TIBCO RV Transport

entry.name: admin_state_trvtransport_help_3381
entry.text: The administrative state of the configuration. To make active, set to enabled. To make inactive, set to disabled.

entry.name: admin_state_trvtransport_descr_3381
entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: summary_trvtransport_descr_3382
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: service_parameter_trvtransport_help_3383
entry.text: Specifies the port number used for the transport. If the transport is associated with a TIBCO RV Policy the port is the local port for receiving messages. If the transport is associated with a TIBCO RV Route the port is the destination port to transmit messages.

entry.name: service_parameter_trvtransport_descr_3383
entry.text: Service Parameter

entry.name: network_interface_trvtransport_help_3384
entry.text: The IP address or host-alias for the interface used to receive for a TIBCO RV Policy or transmit for a TIBCO RV Route. The Network Interface refers to the network from the perspective of the remote system that hosts the daemon process.

entry.name: network_interface_trvtransport_descr_3384
entry.text: Network Interface

entry.name: multicast_group_trvtransport_help_3385
entry.text: A list of multicast groups. A TIBCO RV Policy joins and listens to each multicast group specified in the list. The Network Multicast Groups refers to the network from the perspective of the remote system that hosts the daemon process.

entry.name: multicast_group_trvtransport_descr_3385
entry.text: Network Multicast Groups

entry.name: network_send_address_trvtransport_help_3386
entry.text: The multicast address used to send multicast data. You cannot use a host name or network name. If a multicast address is not specified, the Network Send Address will default to the first value specified in the Network Multicast Groups. The Network Send Address refers to the network from the perspective of the remote system that hosts the daemon process.

entry.name: network_send_address_trvtransport_descr_3386
entry.text: Network Send Address

entry.name: daemon_parameter_trvtransport_help_3387
entry.text: The IP address or host name and port number, separated by a colon, of the RV daemon located on a remote host. For example 192.168.200.62:7500.

entry.name: daemon_parameter_trvtransport_descr_3387
entry.text: Daemon Parameter

entry.name: suppress_password_change_user_help_3402

entry.name: waxhn_proxy_kglobalconfig_help_3411
entry.text: WebSphere Application Acceleration for Hybrid Networks (WAXHN). Configure the WAXHN application proxy before you activate the WAXHN feature. The DNS settings must be configured before you activate the WAXHN feature. The WAXHN application proxy must be in a down operational state until you activate the feature.

entry.text: WebSphere Application Accelerator for Hybrid Networks Proxy

entry.name: cache_raid_volume_waxhnproxy_descr_3414
entry.text: Cache storage volume.

entry.name: reserved_host_address_waxhnproxy_help_3415
entry.text: Specify the IP address of the host interface. This address is used for internal communication. Ensure that this address is part of a private network. Specify the same subnet but different IP address as used for the guest address. Use the default value if it does not conflict with an IP address elsewhere in the appliance or in the same network segment.

entry.name: reserved_host_address_waxhnproxy_descr_3415
entry.text: Reserved host IPv4 address.

entry.name: reserved_guest_address_waxhnproxy_help_3416
entry.text: Specify the IP address of the guest interface. This address is used for internal communication. Ensure that this address is part of a private network. Specify the same subnet but different IP address as used for the host address. Use the default value if it does not conflict with an IP address elsewhere in the appliance or in the same network segment.

entry.name: reserved_guest_address_waxhnproxy_descr_3416
entry.text: Reserved guest IPv4 address.

entry.name: wcc_service_kglobalconfig_help_3417
entry.text: Use the WebSphere Cell configuration to retrieve configuration information and runtime information from a Network Deployment or Virtual Enterprise product. Load balancer groups use this information to automate configuration and updates.

entry.name: wcc_service_kglobalconfig_descr_3417
entry.text: WebSphere Cell

entry.name: odc_info_hostname_wccservice_help_3420
entry.text: Host name or IP address of the Deployment Manager. It is used to communicate with the ODCInfo servlet. The ODCInfo servlet must be installed in a WebSphere Application Server environment.

entry.name: odc_info_hostname_wccservice_descr_3420
entry.text: Host name or IP address

entry.name: odc_info_port_wccservice_help_3421
entry.text: Specifies the listening port of the ODCInfo servlet on the deployment manager. To determine the listening port number, log in to the WebSphere Application Server administrative console and click System Administration > Deployment Manager > ports. From the list, use the port associated with WC_adminhost for HTTP or the port associated with WC_adminhost_secure for HTTPS.

entry.name: odc_info_port_wccservice_descr_3421
entry.text: Destination port of ODCInfo servlet

entry.name: ssl_wccservice_help_3422
entry.text: You must select a TLS proxy profile if you are using TLS (HTTPS) to connect to the ODCInfo servlet. If you do not specify a profile, an HTTP connection is used.

entry.name: ssl_wccservice_descr_3422
entry.text: The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile.

entry.name: update_method_wccservice_help_3423
entry.text: Specifies the method for retrieving WebSphere information. The method defines the responsiveness of the updates received by the DataPower Gateway. The method also affects the amount of system resource used for providing those updates. The default is poll.

entry.name: update_method_wccservice_descr_3423
entry.text: Method for retrieving WebSphere information

entry.name: time_interval_wccservice_help_3424
entry.text: If the update method is poll, the time interval specifies the amount of time in seconds between poll requests. If the update method is subscribe, the time interval specifies the maximum duration of the request in seconds. Use any value of 1 - 86400. The default is 10.

entry.name: time_interval_wccservice_descr_3424
entry.text: Interval for updates

entry.text: Set the administrative state of this configuration.

entry.name: rewrite_errors_webappfw_help_3430
entry.text: Error messages after a decryption action can provide an attacker who is using the padding oracle attack method with enough information to determine the contents of the plain-text data. When enabled, the default, the client receives error messages without the internal information that could lead to a discovery. When disabled, the client receives the original message with this information.

entry.name: rewrite_errors_webappfw_descr_3430
entry.text: Whether to rewrite error messages to avoid providing a padding oracle.

entry.name: delay_errors_webappfw_help_3431
entry.text: The timing difference of the error messages returned after a decryption action can provide an attacker with enough information to determine the contents of the plain-text data. When enabled, the default, the DataPower Gateway delays error messages for the defined duration. When disabled, the DataPower Gateway does not delay error messages.

entry.name: delay_errors_webappfw_descr_3431
entry.text: Whether to delay error messages to avoid providing a padding oracle.

entry.name: delay_errors_duration_webappfw_help_3432
entry.text: When enabling the delay of error messages, specify the delay duration in milliseconds. If delaying messages for 3000ms, the DataPower Gateway will not send error messages to the client until 3 seconds have elapsed since the DataPower Gateway performed decryption on the requests. Use any value of 250 - 300000. The default value is 1000.

entry.name: delay_errors_duration_webappfw_descr_3432
entry.text: How long to delay error messages from the start of the transaction.

entry.name: debugger_type_webappfw_help_3433
entry.text: Select the probe mode.

entry.name: debugger_type_webappfw_descr_3433
entry.text: Probe Mode

entry.name: debugger_url_webappfw_help_3434
entry.text: Configures the URL for external probe mode

entry.name: debugger_url_webappfw_descr_3434
entry.text: External Server URL

entry.name: host_rewriting_webappfw_help_3435
entry.text: Some protocols have distinct name based elements, separate from the URL, to de multiplex. HTTP uses the Host header for this purposes. If this feature is enabled the backside server will receive a request reflecting the final route, otherwise it will receive a request reflecting the information as it arrived at the DataPower device. Web servers issuing redirects may want to disable this feature, as they often depend on the host header for the value of their redirect.

entry.name: host_rewriting_webappfw_descr_3435
entry.text: Enable/Disable rewriting of host names when accessing back side server

entry.name: max_payload_size_webservicesagent_help_3446
entry.text: Specifies the maximum total payload size of a buffered transaction record. The total payload size is the sum of the payloads that are collected at the following points in time during a transaction. When the DataPower service accepts the request When the DataPower service sends the processed request to its target When the DataPower service accepts the response When the DataPower service sends the processed response to the client A record is dropped when its total payload size exceeds the maximum value. The default value of 0 indicates no limit.

entry.name: max_payload_size_webservicesagent_descr_3446
entry.text: Maximum payload size for a transaction record

entry.name: listen_on_webtokenservice_help_3464
entry.text: Define the addresses and ports that the service listens on. You can define listening sources for HTTP and HTTPS requests. For HTTPS request, set the listening source to use TLS parameter and assign the TLS profile.

entry.name: listen_on_webtokenservice_descr_3464
entry.text: Define addresses and ports that the service listens on

entry.name: stylepolicy_webtokenservice_help_3465
entry.text: Assign the processing policy to the service. The processing policy defines the actions to perform on security token requests.

entry.name: stylepolicy_webtokenservice_descr_3465
entry.text: Assign the processing policy

entry.name: rewrite_errors_webtokenservice_help_3466
entry.text: Error messages after a decryption action can provide an attacker who is using the padding oracle attack method with enough information to determine the contents of the plain-text data. When enabled, the default, the client receives error messages without the internal information that could lead to a discovery. When disabled, the client receives the original message with this information.

entry.name: rewrite_errors_webtokenservice_descr_3466
entry.text: Whether to rewrite error messages to avoid providing a padding oracle.

entry.name: delay_errors_webtokenservice_help_3467
entry.text: The timing difference of the error messages returned after a decryption action can provide an attacker with enough information to determine the contents of the plain-text data. When enabled, the default, the appliance delays error messages for the defined duration. When disabled, the appliance does not delay error messages.

entry.name: delay_errors_webtokenservice_descr_3467
entry.text: Whether to delay error messages to avoid providing a padding oracle.

entry.name: delay_errors_duration_webtokenservice_help_3468
entry.text: When enabling the delay of error messages, specify the delay duration in milliseconds. If delaying messages for 3000 ms, the appliance will not send error messages to the client until 3 seconds have elapsed since the appliance performed decryption on the requests. Enter any value in the range 250 - 300000. The default value is 1000.

entry.name: delay_errors_duration_webtokenservice_descr_3468
entry.text: How long to delay error messages from the start of the transaction.

entry.name: front_timeout_webtokenservice_help_3469
entry.text: Set the intra-transaction timeout for Web Token Service to client connections. This value is the maximum idle time to allow in a transaction on the Web Token Service to client connection. This timer monitors idle time in the data transfer process. If the specified idle time is exceeded, the connection is torn down. Enter a value in the range 1 - 86400. The default value is 120.

entry.name: front_timeout_webtokenservice_descr_3469
entry.text: Maximum intra-transaction timeout for Web Token Service to client connections

entry.name: front_persistent_timeout_webtokenservice_help_3470
entry.text: Set the inter-transaction timeout for Web Token Service to client connections. This value is the maximum idle time to allow between the completion of a TCP transaction and the initiation of a new TCP transaction on the Web Token Service to client connection. If the specified idle time is exceeded, the connection is torn down. Enter a value in the range 0 - 86400. The default value is 180. A value of 0 disables persistent connections.

entry.name: front_persistent_timeout_webtokenservice_descr_3470
entry.text: Maximum inter-transaction timeout for Web Token Service to client connections

entry.name: http_front_version_webtokenservice_help_3471
entry.text: Set the HTTP version for client-to-service connections. If the client submits an HTTP/1.0 request, the service on the DataPower appliance always replies with HTTP/1.0 compatible responses regardless of this setting. The default version is HTTP 1.1.

entry.name: http_front_version_webtokenservice_descr_3471
entry.text: Set the HTTP version for client-to-service connections

entry.name: http_client_ip_label_webtokenservice_help_3472
entry.text: Set the HTTP header that contains the client IP address. When defined, the client IP address is read from this HTTP header. This IP address will then be used for monitoring and logging. Retain the default value X-Client-IP or specify another value; for example, X-Forwarded-For .

entry.name: http_client_ip_label_webtokenservice_descr_3472
entry.text: Set the HTTP header that contains the client IP address

entry.name: http_global_tranid_label_webtokenservice_help_3473
entry.text: Enter the name of an HTTP Header to read to determine the global transaction ID for chained services. This value defaults to X-Global-Transaction-ID.

entry.name: http_global_tranid_label_webtokenservice_descr_3473
entry.text: HTTP header label containing global transaction ID

entry.name: debug_mode_webtokenservice_help_3474
entry.text: Select the diagnostic mode for processing policies. When enabled, you can view details about the state of variables and contexts for a captured transaction in the probe. The default value is off . Transaction diagnostic mode is not intended for use in a production environment. Transaction diagnostic mode consumes significant resources that can slow down transaction processing.

entry.name: debug_mode_webtokenservice_descr_3474
entry.text: Controls transaction diagnostic mode

entry.name: xslrefresh_xmlmanager_help_3490
entry.text: Optionally, assigns a Stylesheet Refresh Policy to the XML manager. Stylesheets cached by this manager are refreshed in accordance with policy rules.

entry.name: xslrefresh_xmlmanager_descr_3490
entry.text: A Stylesheet refresh policy

entry.name: xslconfig_xmlmanager_help_3491
entry.text: Optionally, assigns a Compilation Options Policy to the XML Manager. Stylesheets cached by this manager are compiled in accordance with policy rules. Compile Options allow the administrator to manage profiling and debug modes, which are helpful during development and troubleshooting sessions. Profiling and debug modes should not be left on for production purposes. Compile Options Policy also enables streaming mode, which might be a valid choice for production environments that regularly encounter very large documents.

entry.name: xslconfig_xmlmanager_descr_3491
entry.text: The Compile Options Policy assigned to this XML Manager

entry.name: xsl_cache_memorysize_xmlmanager_help_3492
entry.text: Enter the maximum size of the stylesheet cache. The default value is 2147483647. A value of 0 disables caching. Stylesheets are purged when either the cache size or the cache count is reached.

entry.name: xsl_cache_memorysize_xmlmanager_descr_3492
entry.text: Maximum size of stylesheet cache

entry.name: xsl_cache_size_xmlmanager_help_3493
entry.text: Enter the maximum number of stylesheets to cache. Enter a value in the range 5 - 250000. The default value is 256. Stylesheets are purged when either the cache size or the cache count is reached.

entry.name: xsl_cache_size_xmlmanager_descr_3493
entry.text: Maximum number of stylesheets cached

entry.name: xsl_checksummed_cache_xmlmanager_help_3494
entry.text: Enables/disables SHA1-assisted stylesheet caching. With SHA1 caching enabled, stylesheets are cached by both URL and SHA1 message digest value. With SHA1 caching disabled, stylesheets are cached only by URL.

entry.name: xsl_checksummed_cache_xmlmanager_descr_3494
entry.text: Enable/disable SHA1-assisted caching

entry.name: static_document_calls_xmlmanager_help_3495
entry.text: The latest XSLT specifications require that multiple document calls in the same transformation return the same result. Disable to allow all document calls to operate independently.

entry.name: static_document_calls_xmlmanager_descr_3495

entry.name: tx_warn_xmlmanager_help_3496
entry.text: Enables the XML manager to support IBM Transformation Extender warning conditions. The DataPower Gateway sets the warning message to the var:///service/multistep/tx-warn variable and continues the map-processing when it encounters a warning condition.

entry.name: tx_warn_xmlmanager_descr_3496

entry.name: bytes_scanned_xmlmanager_descr_3498
entry.text: XML parser maximum bytes scanned

entry.name: element_depth_xmlmanager_descr_3499
entry.text: XML parser maximum element depth

entry.name: attribute_count_xmlmanager_help_3500
entry.text: Enter the maximum number of attributes of a given element. The default value is 128.

entry.name: attribute_count_xmlmanager_descr_3500
entry.text: XML parser maximum attribute count

entry.name: max_node_size_xmlmanager_help_3501
entry.text: Enter the maximum size that any one node can consume. Enter a value in the range 1024 - 4294967295. The default value is 33554432. Sizes which are powers of two result in the best performance. Although you define a value, the DataPower Gateway uses a value that is the rounded-down to the largest power of two that is smaller than the defined value.

entry.name: max_node_size_xmlmanager_descr_3501
entry.text: XML parser maximum node size

entry.name: forbid_external_references_xmlmanager_help_3502
entry.text: Defines whether the XML parser stops when an input document specifies to resolve an external reference such as an external entity or external DTD definition.

entry.name: forbid_external_references_xmlmanager_descr_3502
entry.text: XML parser forbid external references toggle

entry.name: external_references_xmlmanager_help_3503
entry.text: Select the special handling for input documents that contain external references, such as an external entity or external DTD definition.

entry.name: external_references_xmlmanager_descr_3503
entry.text: Special handling for external references in XML

entry.name: max_prefixes_xmlmanager_help_3504
entry.text: Enter the maximum number of distinct XML namespace prefixes in a document. This limit counts multiple prefixes defined for the same namespace, but does not count multiple namespaces defined in different parts of the input document under a single prefix. Enter a value in the range 0 - 262143. The default value is 1024. A value of 0 indicates that the limit is 1024.

entry.name: max_prefixes_xmlmanager_descr_3504
entry.text: XML parser maximum distinct prefixes

entry.name: max_namespaces_xmlmanager_help_3505
entry.text: Enter the maximum number of distinct XML namespace URIs in a document. This limit counts all XML namespaces, regardless of how many prefixes are used to declare them. Enter a value in the range 0 - 65535. The default value is 1024. A value of 0 indicates that the limit is 1024.

entry.name: max_namespaces_xmlmanager_descr_3505
entry.text: XML parser maximum distinct namespaces

entry.name: max_local_names_xmlmanager_help_3506
entry.text: Enter the maximum number of distinct XML local names in a document. This limit counts all local names, independent of the namespaces they are associated with. Enter a value in the range 0 - 1048575. The default value is 60000. A value of 0 indicates that the limit is 60000.

entry.name: max_local_names_xmlmanager_descr_3506
entry.text: XML parser maximum distinct local names

entry.name: maxdocs_xmlmanager_help_3507
entry.text: Enter the maximum number of documents to cache. Enter a value in the range 1 - 250000. The default value is 5000.

entry.name: maxdocs_xmlmanager_descr_3507
entry.text: Maximum number of documents cached

entry.name: size_xmlmanager_help_3508
entry.text: Enter the maximum size of the document cache. Regardless of the specified size, no document that is greater than 1073741824 bytes is cached. This restriction applies even if the cache has available space.

entry.name: size_xmlmanager_descr_3508
entry.text: Maximum size of document cache

entry.name: max_writes_xmlmanager_help_3509
entry.text: Enter the maximum number of concurrent write requests to create documents or refresh expired documents in the document cache. Enter a value in the range 1 - 32768. The default value is 32768. After the maximum number is reached, requests are forwarded to the target server and the response is not written to the cache.

entry.name: max_writes_xmlmanager_descr_3509
entry.text: Maximum number of concurrent writes to create documents in the cache

entry.name: policy_xmlmanager_help_3510
entry.text: A document cache policy allows the administrator to determine how documents are cached by the XML manager. The policy offers time-to-live, priority, and type configuration values. This document cache is distinct from the stylesheet cache for the XML manager. Documents and stylesheets that the XML manager retrieves can be cached.

entry.name: policy_xmlmanager_descr_3510
entry.text: Document Cache Policy

entry.name: sysplex_distributor_tcs_kglobalconfig_help_3514
entry.text: The Sysplex Distributor Target Control Service on the DataPower Gateway establishes control connections with the z/OS Sysplex Distributor that allow the z/OS Sysplex Distributor to intelligently distribute traffic across multiple DataPower Gateway instances. The use of the Sysplex Distributor Target Control Service is deprecated. Multiple z/OS Sysplex Distributors can establish control connections to the single Sysplex Distributor Target Control Service on the DataPower Gateway. When the Sysplex Distributor Target Control Service is disabled, existing z/OS Sysplex Distributor control connections are closed. Ensure that the reverse path filtering property for Network Settings is not selected. If you allow reverse path filtering, the interface cannot correctly route requests from the Sysplex Distributor to use the Target Control Server.

entry.name: sysplex_distributor_tcs_kglobalconfig_descr_3514
entry.text: Sysplex Distributor Target Control Service (deprecated)

entry.name: ssl_zosnssclient_descr_3528
entry.text: The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use an TLS client profile.

entry.name: client_id_zosnssclient_help_3529
entry.text: Specifies the client ID to be used for registration with the NSS server. Minimum length is 1. Maximum length is 24. Valid characters are: a through z A through Z 0 through 9 _ (underscore) - (dash) Embedded spaces are invalid. The Client ID identifies the client ID to register the appliance with the NSS server. The NSS client ID is a unique string used by the NSS Server to track clients. The Client ID does not have to correspond to any preexisting object. It is provided to the server at the time of registration. If another client attempts to register with the same client ID to the same NSS Server, the NSS server will send a heartbeat to the first client. If the first client responds to the heartbeat, the second client's registration will be rejected. If the first client does not respond, the connect to the first client will be severed and the second client will be registered.

entry.name: client_id_zosnssclient_descr_3529
entry.text: Specifies the Client ID for registration with the NSS server.

entry.name: system_name_zosnssclient_help_3530
entry.text: Specifies a name for the NSS client. Minimum length is 1. Maximum length is 8. Valid characters are: a through z A through Z 0 through 9 _ (underscore) - (dash) Embedded spaces are invalid. The System Name identifies the NSS client to the NSS server. NSS server commands identify NSS clients by system name in the output when displaying information for connected NSS clients.

entry.name: system_name_zosnssclient_descr_3530
entry.text: Specifies a name that identifies the NSS client to the NSS server.

entry.name: user_name_zosnssclient_help_3531
entry.text: Specifies a user name to use to authenticate to the NSS server. Minimum length is 1. Maximum length is 8. Valid characters are: a through z A through Z 0 through 9 _ (underscore) - (dash) Embedded spaces are invalid. The user name must match an existing user ID on the NSS Server.

entry.name: user_name_zosnssclient_descr_3531
entry.text: Specifies a user name to authenticate as in SAF on the NSS server

entry.name: password_zosnssclient_help_3532
entry.text: Specifies the password to use to authenticate to the NSS server. Minimum length is 1. Maximum length is 8. Valid characters are: a through z A through Z 0 through 9 _ (underscore) - (dash) Embedded spaces are invalid. The Password specifies the password to use in conjunction with the value provided by the User Name.

entry.name: password_zosnssclient_descr_3532
entry.text: Password to use to authenticate to NSS

entry.name: password_alias_zosnssclient_help_3533
entry.text: Specifies the password alias of the password to use to authenticate to the NSS server. The associated password is used in conjunction with the value provided by the User Name.

entry.name: password_alias_zosnssclient_descr_3533
entry.text: Password Alias of the password to use to authenticate to NSS

entry.name: gateway_peering_cluster_remove_stale_node_kglobalconfig_help_3569
entry.text: Use this action to remove the stale node in the cluster by its node ID. Ensure that this node is not a valid primary or secondary node.

entry.name: gateway_peering_cluster_remove_stale_node_kglobalconfig_descr_3569
entry.text: Remove the stale node in the cluster by its node ID.

entry.name: gateway_peering_cluster_replicate_kglobalconfig_help_3570
entry.text: Use this action to transfer the secondary node to a different primary node in the gateway peering cluster. Ensure that this gateway peering is not primary and that its operational state is up.

entry.name: gateway_peering_cluster_replicate_kglobalconfig_descr_3570
entry.text: Transfers the secondary node to a different primary node in the gateway peering cluster.

entry.name: gateway_peering_remove_stale_peers_kglobalconfig_help_3571
entry.text: Removes all known information about peers from the current member.

entry.text: Use the action to remove stale peers from the Gateway Peering.

entry.name: gateway_peering_switch_primary_kglobalconfig_help_3572
entry.text: Use this action to designates this gateway peering as primary. Ensure that this gateway peering is not primary and that its operational state is up.

entry.name: gateway_peering_switch_primary_kglobalconfig_descr_3572
entry.text: Switches this gateway peering to primary.

entry.name: no_waxhn_cache_search_kglobalconfig_help_3573
entry.text: Cancels the current WAXHN cache search.

entry.name: no_waxhn_cache_search_kglobalconfig_descr_3573
entry.text: Cancels the WAXHN cache search.

entry.name: waxhn_cache_purge_kglobalconfig_help_3574
entry.text: Purges the WAXHN cache items matching the specified parameters by making them inaccessible. In order to completely remove the items from the cache, the WAXHN Cache Erase check box must be selected. The search string can be any regular expression. Multiple cache purge requests are queued and processed sequentially. Provide a search string or URL but not both.

entry.name: waxhn_cache_purge_kglobalconfig_descr_3574
entry.text: Searches the WAXHN cache and purges matching cache items.

entry.name: no_waxhn_cache_purge_kglobalconfig_help_3575
entry.text: Cancels the running WAXHN cache purge and all queued cache purge requests. Cache items purged before the cancellation request remain purged.

entry.name: no_waxhn_cache_purge_kglobalconfig_descr_3575
entry.text: Cancels all WAXHN cache purge operations.

entry.name: waxhn_reset_cache_kglobalconfig_help_3576
entry.text: Clears the entire WAXHN cache and restarts the WAXHN service. This interrupts the service and removes all cache items from the WAXHN cache.

entry.name: waxhn_reset_cache_kglobalconfig_descr_3576
entry.text: Clear cache and restart the WAXHN service.

entry.name: waxhn_cache_search_kglobalconfig_help_3577
entry.text: Searches the WAXHN cache for items matching the specified parameters and returns their status. Simultaneous cache searches are not supported. Provide a search string or URL but not both. An active search must complete or be cancelled before a new search can be successfully requested. Results of previous searches are overwritten by new searches.

entry.name: waxhn_cache_search_kglobalconfig_descr_3577
entry.text: Searches WAXHN cache to obtain the status of cache items.

entry.name: waxhn_activate_kglobalconfig_help_3661
entry.text: Activate WebSphere Application Accelerator for Hybrid Networks (WAXHN). Before activating you must configure the WAXHN proxy to use a RAID array and the operational state of the WAXHN proxy must be down. You only need to activate one time. However, you will need to activate again if you reinitialize your firmware, your RAID array, or to modify the maximum cache size.

entry.name: waxhn_activate_kglobalconfig_descr_3661
entry.text: Activate WebSphere Application Accelerator for Hybrid Networks.
